sentence: Q. Sir, could you clarify the extent of your family's participation? [SEP] I beg your pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, is China bullying India? [SEP] I hope not, but they're definitely pushing harder than people think.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Hi, I'm Jongjin Park of Money Today. First of all, I would like to ask a question to President Yoon Suk Yeol of the Republic of Korea. I heard that you stated that a new chapter has opened in our trilateral cooperation with the two countries. Compared to the previous summits, what would be the most significant outcome that you gained through this summit?And also, from the perspective of our people, what would be the benefit that the people of Korea would feel from these strengthening of ties?And now my question goes to President Biden. During this summit, the issues of detainees or prisoners of wars—and you mentioned that there will be further cooperation in these human rights issues. And you also said you will support the free and peaceful Korean Peninsula in the region. And what would—what kind of shift would there be in your policy? And what kind of specific solutions do you have in this regard?Lastly, I would like to direct my question to Prime Minister Kishida. Today we had a historic trilateral summit. However, there was much backlash and many concerns in Korea. However, President Yoon showed his political courage to do so. That's the international community's evaluation.However, there are still concerns that the—Japan is making very passive efforts to resolve our issues that still remain. And also, how would you be able to show your truthful willingness to resolve and improve our bilateral relations going forward? [SEP] First of all, this trilateral cooperation amongst our three countries has opened a new chapter, and we made that announcement today to talk about the differences from the past cooperation.For instance, in the past, it was about individual issues that we sought cooperation among ourselves. But now, as we have opened a new chapter in our cooperation for security, economy, science and technology, and development cooperation for the Global South, health, and women—across all of these issues, our three countries decided to closely work together. So it's much more comprehensive in nature.Such comprehensive cooperation has been launched by us today because currently we face complicated crisis and the threat from the D.P.R.K. And across the world, we believe that we can together make a contribution to freedom and peace around the world.So that is our foundational understanding and our common and shared interests of the three countries. And not just for exclusionary interests of ourselves. Our interests are well aligned with the universal interests of the members of the global community. That's where we find our shared interests lie.And at the same time, this framework of comprehensive cooperation among our three countries will contribute to global supply chain resilience, global financial market stability, cooperation in the frontier technology sectors and science.Our three countries together have the best-in-class expertise in science and technology. And we are the ones who are implementing liberal democracies. Naturally, progress in science and technologies will bring benefits—tangible benefits—to our people, not just in terms of security, but also in terms of economy and science and technology.But what is most important here is not about our own interests only. When we put our forces together, I believe that we can make a contribution to the advancement of freedom and peace in the world. And that's exactly where our interests are aligned. I—look, back in May of 2022, I met with the families of the Japanese abductees during my visit, heard their stories, and empathized with them and got a sense of the pain they're feeling. It's real.We know there are many families out there who still wait and worry and wonder. And we're not going to forget about them or their loved ones.And there's clear language on this on our joint statement. The bottom line is this: That we share a common position; we're committed to working together to see the return of all prisoners of war and those who've been abducted and detained.And by the way, one of the things we get asked many times—and it wasn't directly asked, but implied—is what makes us think any of this is positive. Success brings success. When other nations see cooperation in the region, they make judgments about: Would they be better off if they made commitments? Will they move?Think about—as students of history, all of you; and you are—think about how many times successes have generated other successes when you don't anticipate it.And so I just think this is a—we're not going to forget, we're not giving up, and we're going to continue to make the case for the freedom of all of those detainees. With regard to your question for me, first of all, I have strong feelings about strengthening bilateral relationships between the R.O.K. and Japan. I share that with The two countries, in dealing with international challenges, should cooperate. We're both important neighboring countries. And so friendship with President Yoon and a relationship of trust, based on this, both countries as partners should open up a new era. And that is my thinking.This year, President Yoon came to Japan, and I visited the R.O.K. At international fora, we have repeated meetings—we have had repeated meetings. And between our two countries, including the economy and security, we've had forward-looking and concrete approaches which were started. It's already in motion, dynamically.Economic security dialogue was started—or it has been decided on. In the area of export control, there have been progress. And also Financial Ministers and Defense Ministers have had meetings.And so we've had this very positive, forward-looking developments. And these are seen not only in the public sector. Also in the private sector, we see a slate of developments, human exchanges, and exchanges between business circles. We're seeing very active developments in all of these areas, and that is a reality.Going forward, we hope to accumulate these approaches with—along with President Yoon to strengthen our bilateral relations even further. By generating results, we hope that people will understand Japan's feelings towards our bilateral relations. And we'd like to continue such efforts.Thank you. Thank you very much.Then, let me see. From Kyodo—Tajiri-san, Kyodo News.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the peaceful transfer of power, while you've publicly supported it, many Democrats plan to skip the Inauguration. Do you agree with their decision? What would you say to them to promote a more unified transition? Also, can you give us some insight into your talks with the incoming President? Did you try to influence him on important topics like the Affordable Care Act or the DREAMers, and if so, how did it go? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to get into the nitty-gritty of my conversations with President-elect Trump. Let's just say they were decent, sometimes long, and always to the point. Whether I got through to him is something you'd have to ask him. I gave him my best advice on all sorts of things, here and abroad. But, seeing as he won by running against a lot of what I did, it makes sense he'll want to do things his way. I'm not expecting us to see eye-to-eye on everything. Maybe once he's in office and dealing with the real-world problems of healthcare or creating jobs, he'll come to the same conclusions I did. But we'll have to wait and see. His advisors will have a big impact, so pay attention to those hearings. I told him straight up, this job is too big to do alone. You need a great team giving you the best info and all the options. That's the best advice I could give him. As for the Inauguration, I'm not going to judge anyone else's choices. Michelle and I will be there, and I'm just glad it won't be as cold as my first one!
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the difficulties of the past year, arguably the toughest of your presidency, and the current low approval ratings, and acknowledging the problems with the healthcare rollout, what would you identify as your most significant error in judgment or action? [SEP] To be clear, are we discussing healthcare specifically, or are you asking about my biggest overall mistake?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, what specific military options are being considered in response to North Korea's potential failure to meet its commitments? And what steps are being taken to protect the population of Seoul in the event of military conflict? [SEP] Well, I don't want to talk about—yes, I know. That's a tough thing to talk about because I don't want to be threatening. I don't want to be threatening. They understood that. And you've seen what was, perhaps, going to happen.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Cuba, many argue that the U.S. sanctions have historically stifled their progress. Given your administration's shift in policy, will you commit to a complete removal of these sanctions, and in return, what specific democratic reforms do you expect from the Cuban government? Furthermore, considering the current political climate, do you believe Vice President Harris is adequately prepared to assume the presidency if necessary, and what steps are being taken to ensure a smooth transition of power should that become a reality? [SEP] I won't speculate on future elections or potential successors. That's something for the media to debate. As for Cuba, our focus is on empowering the Cuban people through engagement, not regime change. We want to create an environment where they can determine their own future. The Cold War is over, and we need to move past the old ways of thinking. While we have concerns about human rights and regional issues, we also see opportunities for cooperation, such as healthcare. Our approach is to lead by example and advocate for our values through persuasion. Cuba isn't a direct threat to our national security, but we will continue to address our differences constructively. Our priority is to work with the region to promote opportunity and security, and we believe that engagement, not isolation, is the best way forward. We've learned from history that intervention often backfires, and we want to avoid giving Cuba excuses for its own shortcomings.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics are suggesting that your stance on the debt ceiling is unnecessarily rigid. Are you willing to consider any alternative approaches to avoid a potential economic crisis? [SEP] Well, the issue here is whether or not America pays its bills. We are not a deadbeat nation. And so there's a very simple solution to this: Congress authorizes us to pay our bills. Now, if the House and the Senate want to give me the authority so that they don't have to take these tough votes, if they want to put the responsibility on me to raise the debt ceiling, I'm happily to take it. Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader in the Senate, had a proposal like that last year, and I'm happy to accept it. But if they want to keep this responsibility, then they need to go ahead and get it done. And there are no magic tricks here. There are no loopholes. There are no easy outs. This is a matter of Congress authorizes spending. They order me to spend. They tell me, you need to fund our Defense Department at such and such a level; you need to send out Social Security checks; you need to make sure that you are paying to care for our veterans. They lay all this out for me, and because they have the spending power. And so I am required by law to go ahead and pay these bills. Separately, they also have to authorize the raising of the debt ceiling in order to make sure that those bills are paid. And so what Congress can't do is tell me to spend X, and then say, but we're not going to give you the authority to go ahead and pay the bills.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Yesterday you joined together with House Speaker Pelosi and Senator Reid to sign the energy legislation and talk about the importance of the bill in curbing greenhouse gases, among other goals. However, your administration then told California that it couldn't implement its own plan to restrict tailpipe emissions. How important is fighting greenhouse gases to you? Why can't the States try to do more? And can you tell me anything about your conversation with Vice President Gore about climate change a few weeks ago? [SEP] Remind me about that here. Let me finish the first part of the question, and remind me you asked that.The question is how to have an effective strategy. Is it more effective to let each State make a decision as to how to proceed in curbing greenhouse gases, or is it more effective to have a national strategy? Director Johnson made a decision based upon the fact that we passed a piece of legislation that enables us to have a national strategy, which is the increasing CAFE standards to 35 miles an hour by 2020 and a substantial increase of alternative fuels, 36 billion gallons by 2022.And so the Director, in assessing this law, and assessing what would be more effective for the country, says, we now have a national plan. It's one of the benefits of Congress passing this piece of legislation.I told Vice President Gore that I take the issue seriously. And we're developing a strategy that will deal with it—and an effective strategy. Yesterday's bill is a part of that strategy. When you replace as much gasoline on a mandatory basis as we're suggesting, it's going to do a lot to improve the greenhouse gases. And by the way, the bill I signed was a little weaker than the one I suggested, but nevertheless was happy to sign it.And one of the key components, by the way, to be successful on reformulated fuel standards is to spend research and development money on cellulosic ethanol, new ways to manufacture ethanol. We can't rely only on corn in order to meet these standards. And I understand a lot of people in the farm belt are getting concerned, unless, of course, you're a corn grower. But if you're feeding cattle or feeding hogs, the cost of business has gone up. And that's one of the tradeoffs you have to make. So what I want to assure people out there is that we're spending a lot of taxpayers' money in a way to figure out how to use wood chips or switchgrass in order to make ethanol. But this is a real national plan.Secondly, in order to be effective on a global basis, countries that emit greenhouse gases need to be at the table. One of the main reasons I was against Kyoto was that China wasn't at the table. I mean, we could do all we wanted to do, but it wouldn't affect greenhouse gases over the long run unless a country like China had agreed to participate in a strategy.And so we went to the Bali Conference with that in mind and worked out a compromise that said, we're committed to a process that's going to unfold over the next 2 years. But we've also got a parallel process working to make sure major emitters sit at the table and come together, hopefully, on a goal that we all agree to. And it's a strategy that I laid out at the G- 8 in Germany, it's a strategy that was explained to everybody there in Bali, and it's a strategy we think will be effective.And so, absolutely, I take the issue seriously. But I want to make sure that we're effective in what we do, and secondly, do not wreck our economy in whatever we do. See, it is hard to develop the technologies necessary to be able to make sure our standard of living remains strong and deal with greenhouse gases if you're broke. If you don't have any money, it is really hard to develop new technologies. And so we need to be prosperous for a lot of reasons, primarily so our citizens can have a good life, but also so that we're wealthy enough to make the investments necessary to deal with greenhouse gases.Finally, if you're truly serious about dealing with greenhouse gases, then it seems like to me you ought to be a strong supporter of nuclear power. Nuclear power enables us to generate electricity without emitting one unit of greenhouse gases. I am—to me, I am amazed that our country isn't more robust in supporting the advent of nuclear power. I certainly am, and applaud those efforts by Members of the Congress to provide incentives for the construction of new plants.But if you're somebody that says, Greenhouse gases are of vital national interest, then you ought to be saying, I'm for the development of nuclear power-plants. It is by far the best solution to making sure we have economic growth and, at the same time, be good stewards of the environment.And so when you couple increasing CAFE standards with using alternative fuels—which deals with the automobile area—as well as a good strategy on electricity, then all of a sudden, you begin to see a strategy unfold. And by the way, the final thing is, is that we do have 250 years of coal. And I believe we can develop technologies that will enable us to use that coal in an environmentally friendly way.So what I'm suggesting to you is, is that we do have a strategy. Our strategy is to bring others to the table. Our strategy is to develop our own plan to meet the national goals—the international goals that I hope we'll be able to set later on this summer. And you've just heard some of the components of it.Yes, sir.
label: Explicit

sentence: Specifically, what are your thoughts on adjusting the retirement age? [SEP] I'm not prepared to offer specific details at this juncture. As I've stated, Jake, the points you've raised have been the subject of discussion. However, I'm not inclined to request further sacrifices from the average citizen without ensuring that those with substantial wealth also contribute their fair share. If a modification were to impose a modest additional cost on senior citizens, or even on future retirees, it is only equitable that individuals earning a million dollars or more also make a contribution. This reflects the balanced and shared sacrifice approach that I believe resonates with the majority of Americans.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, should you have sold your businesses and put the money in a blind trust? And what's your problem with the NSA and Cyber Command? [SEP] That first question was just a way to attack me, wasn't it?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. And what's your expectation about China's role to accelerate the process to establish a long-term peace mechanism? [SEP] Well, my expectation about China is that China is a great country with a great leader and a friend of mine. And I really believe that he's happy that we've made this kind of progress. And I've heard from him. But I will be calling him very shortly. Maybe even before I land. Okay?And I have to say, you know—and the United States is a great country. And we have set records economically: over $7 trillion in net worth addition to what we have. And we are almost twice the size, the economy of the United States. Nobody talks about this, because you do hear a lot about China, rightfully so. But the United States now is almost twice the size of the economy of China. We have a great country, and we're on a correct path.Okay. One more. That will be it.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, can you confirm whether the individual was armed? [SEP] That's what I've been told. I can't say for sure. You'll need to get that information from them.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, Prime Minister, Norway strongly supports the Paris Agreement and have expressed regret that you have decided to leave it. What could persuade you to remain? And what kind of common ground did you find in your talks today on this topic? [SEP] Well, it wasn't a major topic, I must tell you. We talked about other things, including mostly trade. But I will say that the Paris Agreement, as drawn and as we signed, was very unfair to the United States. It put great penalties on us. It made it very difficult for us to deal, in terms of business. It took away a lot of our asset values.We are a country rich in gas and coal and oil and lots of other things, and there was a tremendous penalty for using it. It hurt our businesses. According to some estimates, we would have had to close businesses in order to qualify by 2025. Whereas, as an example, China, by 2030—they don't kick in until 2030. Russia, someplace in the mid-1990s—that was their standard, and that was never a good standard, because that was a dirty standard for the environment.It treated the United States very unfairly, and frankly, it's an agreement that I have no problem with, but I had a problem with the agreement that they signed, because as usual, they made a bad deal.So we could conceivably go back in, but I say this: We are very strong on the environment. I feel very strongly about the environment. Our EPA and our EPA commissioners are very, very powerful in the sense that they want to have clean water, clean air, but we also want businesses that can compete. And the Paris accord really would have taken away our competitive edge. And we're not going to let that happen. I'm not going to let it happen.. And if I just might add that there are business opportunities in this—— . It's true.. ——as we talked about during this—because we have strict regulations on—to reach our Paris targets. That means that we have very strong policies for environmental-friendly and climate-friendly technologies, and which is a small part of why the United States now have a surplus in the economy towards Norway. So you never miss up on a good opportunity with good environmental standards. Okay. . One of the great assets of Norway is a thing called water. And they have tremendous hydropower—tremendous. In fact, most of your energy or your electricity is produced by hydro. I wish we'd do some of that. [] But hydropower is fantastic, and it's a great asset that you have.Thank you very much. Great honor. Thank you.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. They're not under investigation, though, sir? [SEP] Peter, I'm not going to talk about any of it.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, are you strategically targeting only cities governed by Democrats? Is this a politically motivated action? [SEP] Unfortunately, the cities experiencing difficulties are predominantly managed by Democrats. Radical-left Democrats are at the helm of cities like Chicago, among many others. This is simply a matter of fact. Consider Chicago. Mayor Lightfoot recently sent me a letter, indicating their desire for our assistance. While they may eventually request our full involvement, we are currently deploying additional personnel to provide support. We are actively apprehending numerous individuals engaged in criminal activity. Regarding the coronavirus, I believe our response has been remarkable. Comparing our statistics to those of other nations will reveal impressive figures for the United States, particularly in the future.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your administration has deliberately downplayed the Benghazi incident. How do you respond to those accusations? [SEP] Those accusations are simply false. We've been completely transparent about Benghazi from day one. Our focus has always been on finding out what happened, fixing the security flaws, and holding those responsible accountable. Anyone who suggests otherwise is simply playing politics.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Following your discussions with Chairman Kim, can we expect to see a documented summary of the dialogue? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, some critics argue that any public statement from the US, regardless of its content, will be used by the Iranian regime to discredit the protests. How do you balance the need to support human rights with the risk of unintended consequences? [SEP] We have to stand up for what's right, and that includes supporting the Iranian people's right to peaceful protest. We can't let the fear of manipulation silence our voice. We will continue to speak out against injustice and oppression, wherever it occurs.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, can you clarify if all existing sanctions will be maintained? [SEP] They are what they are. Many of you in the press have claimed we've already compromised, but I assure you, that's false. I believe a fruitful partnership with Chairman Kim and North Korea is within reach, a nation with boundless possibilities. The sticking point was sanctions. They desired their removal, but weren't willing to concede on key areas we identified. It's a negotiation.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given the current congressional gridlock surrounding the Trans-Pacific Partnership, are you considering alternative strategies to secure its approval, particularly in light of the recent deals with Boeing and GE in Vietnam? Furthermore, what are your thoughts on amending the agreement to address currency manipulation? [SEP] Look, I've been around long enough to know that trade deals are always a tough sell. Everyone's looking for a better deal, especially with multiple parties involved. And in an election year, you can bet some folks will try to score political points. That being said, I'm confident we'll get it done because it's the right thing to do. It's good for America, good for the region, good for the world. This is the fastest-growing part of the world, a huge market for the U.S. Most countries here already sell their stuff to us with relatively low tariffs, while our goods face significantly higher tariffs there. So, a deal that eliminates 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods in these markets is a win for American businesses and workers. Historically, trade deals have been criticized for exposing us to countries with lower wages and lax labor and environmental standards. But TPP includes enforceable commitments to raise labor standards and address environmental problems. This allows us to engage with countries like Vietnam on these issues. I haven't seen a credible argument that TPP will make us worse off. We'll demonstrably be better off. American workers and businesses will benefit. The politics will be noisy, like with the Korean, Colombian, and Panamanian free trade agreements I inherited. But we got those done, and we'll get this done too, despite the bumps along the way. As for currency manipulation, TPP includes provisions for transparency and reporting. Some argue for enforceable provisions allowing us to impose tariffs if currency is devalued. But it's hard to determine when currency is being manipulated. Binding other countries on monetary policy would mean binding our Federal Reserve, which we won't do. We've strengthened provisions to put folks on notice if we think they're engaging in competitive devaluations. Finally, regarding the Taliban leader, Mullah Mansur, his death has been confirmed. He targeted U.S. personnel in Afghanistan. This doesn't represent a shift in our approach. We're not re-entering combat operations. Our job is to help Afghanistan secure itself. However, when a high-profile leader consistently targets U.S. personnel and resists peace talks, it's my responsibility to protect our people. That's the message we've sent.
label: General

sentence: Q. But the threat is out there? [SEP] Yes, the threat is out there, but we haven't really started yet. No, this will take effect next week, the 5 percent.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding potential discussions with Putin, what specific outcomes are you hoping to achieve, and how will you address President Zelenskyy's demand for the return of Crimea as a condition for negotiations? [SEP] The simplest way to end this war is for Putin to get out of Ukraine. But he doesn't seem to want to do that. He's paying a high price, but he's causing incredible damage to Ukraine. I don't have any immediate plans to talk to Putin. But I'm willing to talk to him if he's serious about finding a way to end the war. If that's the case, I'll talk to my allies in France and NATO first. In the meantime, we have to support the Ukrainian people. Putin is never going to defeat Ukraine. He's miscalculated everything. He thought he'd be welcomed by Russian speakers in Ukraine. He was wrong. So, the question is, how does he get out of this situation? I'm willing to talk to him if he's willing to talk, but I'll only do it with my NATO allies. On Zelenskyy's conditions, Ukraine is resisting and suffering from war crimes. Zelenskyy has presented a 10-point peace plan. We need to work with him on that. He was willing to talk and negotiate. The one who wanted to go to war was Putin.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Prime Minister, if you would respond in both official languages: Canadians have seen the RCMP visit to your party headquarters, they've heard the allegations from Elections Canada, and they're wondering what's going on. Did you know about this scheme, and will you practice it again in the next election?Prime Minister Harper. Well, this is the same story as before. As you know, Elections Canada view is that some of our local spending should count as national spending. We have a different view. We looked into this at the time, and that's the view we've taken.Our position is always that we always follow the law as we understand it, and, more importantly, we always follow the law as it has been interpreted. We were following, in the last election, the interpretations that had been put on that law in the past. If those interpretations change, we'll, of course, conform, but we will expect the same rules for every single party.[Prime Minister Harper continued in French, and his remarks were translated as follows.]And as I just said, it's always the same thing in this for quite awhile. Elections Canada think that some of our local expenditures should at—should be considered as national expenses. But we do not agree with that, and that's why we went to court with this issue. And in the end, we will respect the law and the interpretations of the law as they are, as we have done in the past.Price of Gasoline/Energy/U.S. Economy Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Oil prices today rose above $118 a barrel. It's another record. Are Saudi Arabia and other oil producers, are they our adversaries, or have you had any success with your recent appeals with them? And also, the effect of the gasoline prices, isn't that about to erase or certainly erode the benefit of the economic stimulus package? [SEP] Yes, no question, rising gasoline prices are like a tax on our working people. And what's happening is, is that we've had an energy policy that neglected hydrocarbons in the United States for a long period of time, and now we're paying the price. We should have been exploring for oil and gas in ANWR, for example. But no, we made the decision: Our Congress kept preventing us from opening up new areas to explore in environmentally friendly ways, and now we're becoming, as a result, more and more dependent on foreign sources of oil. Fortunately, Canada and Mexico are our biggest providers, for which we are grateful. But our energy policy is— wasn't effective over the past decades, and now we're paying the price.And secondly, there's not a lot of excess capacity in the world. As a matter of fact, unfortunately, a lot of the supplies are coming from parts of the world where there's political instability. Fortunately, again, Canada and Mexico are not included in that group. There are some countries that are not reinvesting in their reserves, which decline without maintenance.And so I'm obviously concerned for our consumers. All the more reason to have passed a rebate, tax relief, and all the more reason for the United States Congress to keep the tax relief I passed permanent. We got people out there campaigning: Well, we're just going to tax the rich. You can't raise enough money to meet their spending appetites by taxing the so-called rich. Every one of those so-called tax-the-rich schemes end up taxing the middle class families. And in a time of economic uncertainty, we need tax certainty. In a time of rising gasoline prices, we need to be sending a message to all Americans: We're not going to raise your taxes.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the upcoming NATO summit in Chicago, are you confident that member nations will reach a consensus on the Afghanistan withdrawal strategy? And, to what extent do you believe the recent Koran burning incident and subsequent unrest will complicate negotiations with our allies? [SEP] Well, the roadmap for the transition has been in place since Lisbon, and we've been following that strategy, which calls for a phased handover of responsibilities to the Afghan government, culminating in the cessation of our combat role by the end of 2014. Our coalition partners remain committed to this timeline. At the NATO meeting, we'll be focusing on refining the transition process to ensure a smooth and sustainable transfer of authority. This involves establishing clear benchmarks and milestones, similar to our approach in Iraq, to ensure that Afghan forces are adequately prepared to assume full security responsibilities. Now, the Koran burning incident is certainly a cause for concern, and it underscores the complexities of the situation on the ground. It serves as a reminder of the challenges we face as we transition to Afghan leadership. While the violence directed at our personnel is unacceptable, President Karzai has expressed a desire for greater Afghan control over security matters. We're committed to working with the Afghan government to develop a framework that respects their sovereignty while ensuring the continued stability and security of the region. While the path forward may not be without its challenges, I remain optimistic that we can achieve a successful transition in Afghanistan.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Why haven't we heard anything from you so far about the soldiers that were killed in Niger? And what do you have to say about that? [SEP] I've written them personal letters. They've been sent, or they're going out tonight, but they were written during the weekend. I will, at some point during the period of time, call the parents and the families—because I have done that, traditionally. I felt very, very badly about that. I always feel badly. It's the toughest—the toughest calls I have to make are the calls where this happens, soldiers are killed. It's a very difficult thing. Now, it gets to a point where, you know, you make four or five of them in one day—it's a very, very tough day. For me, that's by far the toughest.So, the traditional way—if you look at President Obama and other Presidents, most of them didn't make calls, a lot of them didn't make calls. I like to call when it's appropriate, when I think I'm able to do it. They have made the ultimate sacrifice.So, generally, I would say that I like to call. I'm going to be calling them. I want a little time to pass. I'm going to be calling them. I have—as you know, since I've been President, I have. But in addition, I actually wrote letters individually to the soldiers we're talking about, and they're going to be going out either today or tomorrow.Yes.
label: Deflection

sentence: Ghislaine Maxwell is in prison. Do you think she will name powerful people? You've spoken about Prince Andrew and criticized Bill Clinton. How do you see this playing out? [SEP] I don't know. I haven't really been following it closely. I just wish her well, frankly. I've met her a number of times over the years, especially when I lived in Palm Beach. I don't know the situation with Prince Andrew. I'm not aware of it. Yes, please, go ahead.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, [unclear audio] representing Reuters. During your discussions with the North Korean delegation, was the topic of independent verification of their nuclear disarmament program raised? [SEP] I didn't quite catch that. Could you please repeat your question, speaking a bit louder? And also, what media outlet do you represent?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, turning to the topic of China and Taiwan, did your discussions with Prime Minister Kishida include contingency planning? Specifically, what role is the U.S. asking Japan to play in the event of a cross-Strait conflict, and what commitments did Japan make regarding its defense posture? [SEP] No.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Will the conflict be resolved before your term ends? Do you condone Israel's actions? [SEP] I certainly hope so. I'm in favor of a lasting cease-fire, meaning Hamas must cease firing rockets into Israel. A lasting cease-fire is unattainable if they continue. The choice rests with Hamas. The best way to achieve this is to collaborate with Egypt to halt the flow of arms into Gaza, which allows Hamas to launch rockets. Nations providing weapons to Hamas must cease. The international community must exert pressure. Hamas must disarm if they desire a cease-fire. Neighboring countries must stop smuggling. It's a challenge due to tunnels. What was the second part of your question, please?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, do you believe the problems with the Affordable Care Act's rollout have damaged your credibility on other policy initiatives? [SEP] Look, any complex undertaking is bound to have its challenges. We are addressing the issues with the ACA rollout head-on, and we are committed to ensuring that everyone has access to quality, affordable healthcare. At the same time, we must not allow these challenges to distract us from our other important priorities, such as immigration reform, economic growth, and national security. We are capable of tackling multiple challenges simultaneously, and we will continue to work hard to deliver results for the American people.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Bush, regarding trade with Uruguay, how much flexibility will your administration show in reaching an agreement, and what progress has been made today? Also, President Vazquez, did you request President Bush's intervention in your dispute with Argentina over the mill plants? [SEP] We spent considerable time discussing Uruguay's concerns about market access for specific goods. The President raised several trade-related issues, particularly the fairness of quotas on items like beef and lamb. I assured him that I would seriously consider his requests. You might have thought I was joking about blueberries, but I wasn't. Uruguay produces exceptional blueberries, and the key question is whether those blueberry growers can sell their products in the United States. So, we discussed a range of agricultural products. I emphasized to the President that problems can only be solved if they are brought to the table. Where we can assist, we will; where we cannot, I will provide a clear explanation. You mentioned protectionist tendencies, which concern me both in our country and globally. I believe that free and fair trade promotes poverty reduction. Therefore, I strongly support completing the Doha round of the WTO. I shared our strategies for advancing the Doha round with President Lula, who was very interested in our conversations. I didn't disclose any confidential information, but I discussed how we can move the Doha round forward. The United States is prepared to reduce agricultural subsidies, as I explained to the President, but we need market access for our products. I conveyed this to President Lula, the Europeans, and President Vazquez. I am optimistic about reaching a deal. Our trade minister, Susan Schwab, remains in Sao Paulo to continue discussions with her Brazilian counterpart, aiming to make progress on this complex but essential agreement. Thank you. In response to your first question, I fully agree with President Bush's remarks. This meeting has created a platform for our experts and ministers to discuss and advance bilateral relations. Regarding the multilateral situation, Uruguay advocates for free trade and lower tariffs and subsidies that hinder the sale of our cultural products. We have also explored the possibility of advancing the GSP, particularly on issues to be considered in the coming weeks. As for your second question, I did not discuss our issues with Argentina with President Bush, partly because we will be engaging in dialogue with Argentina in a few weeks, thanks to the conciliation efforts of His Majesty, the King of Spain. We will not be negotiating but rather engaging in a dialogue to find a friendly resolution and overcome our unfortunate differences with our Argentine brethren.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, with respect, the question was about law and order in our cities. Are you concerned about the rising crime rates, and what specific steps will your administration take to address this issue? [SEP] We're going to restore law and order. We're going to support our police, and we're going to crack down on crime. We're not going to let our cities be overrun by chaos and violence.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Speaking of Iraq, there are increasing controversy in Iraq over the security agreement that's being negotiated. Some top Iraqi officials are calling for a dramatic reduction in the U.S. presence. Does this concern you that the direction that those negotiations are going in?And, Madam Chancellor, does this have any impact on your approach towards Iraq? [SEP] First of all, I think we'll end up with a strategic agreement with Iraq. You know, it's all kinds of noise in their system and our system. What eventually will win out is the truth. For example, you read stories, perhaps in your newspaper, that the U.S. is planning all kinds of permanent bases in Iraq. That's an erroneous story. The Iraqis know—will learn it's erroneous too. We'll be there at the invitation of the sovereign Government of Iraq.And I strongly support the agreement because I think it helps send a clear message to the people of Iraq that, you know, that security you're now seeing will continue. And one of the lessons of Iraq is, is that in order for a democracy to develop or in order for an economy to develop, there has to be a measure of security, which is now happening. And so I think we'll get the agreement done.And as I said clearly in past speeches, this will not involve permanent bases, nor will it bind any future President to troop levels. You know, as to—look, Eggen, you can find any voice you want in the Iraqi political scene and quote them, which is interesting, isn't it? Because in the past you could only find one voice, and now you can find a myriad of voices. It's a vibrant democracy; people are debating. There's all kinds of press in the Iraqi scene, of course, to the benefit of the Iraqi society.And I deal with Prime Minister Maliki. He appreciates our presence there, and he understands that we're returning on success. As the situation merits and the situation improves, we're bringing our troops home. And I'm pleased with the progress. I don't know whether or not it's—the progress has made it here to Germany or not yet, but the progress in Iraq is substantial, and it's going to help change the Middle East for the better. And I love the idea of having—giving people a chance to live in a free society. The blessings of freedom are—shouldn't be just in a regional blessing. I believe freedom is universal, and I believe freedom yields peace.Madam Chancellor. Well, obviously, from the German side too, and the European side for that matter, we have every interest, indeed, a vital interest in seeing Iraq taking a turn for sort of a good kind of development. I invited the Iraqi Prime Minister here to Germany, and I think he will pay us the honor of a visit. We have been trying to have economic relations. We've also, outside of Iraq, also trained security personnel, and we're ready to continue that.So everything we can do beyond a sort of military presence, everything we can do as regards civilian building up of the country, assisting them, is something that we're continuing to doing. And I would like to very much look forward to the visit of the Prime Minister. We're glad to see progress happening there on the ground, because it's in our vital interest to see to it that this region takes a turn for the better, and it's in the interest of the region too.Thank you very much.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. So far, your administration is only testing less than 500 people. And health officials are questioning whether that's enough, comparing to other countries who have tested more than tens of thousands of people. Are you planning to test more people? [SEP] Well, we're testing everybody that we need to test. And we're finding very little problem. Very little problem.Now, you treat this like a flu. We were—in fact, I might ask one of the doctors to come up and explain it. You want to wash your hands a lot. You want to stay—if you're not feeling well, if you feel you have a flu, stay inside, sort of quarantine yourself. Don't go outside.But there are certain steps that you can take that won't even be necessary. You know, in many cases, when you catch this, it's very light; you don't even know there's a problem. Sometimes, they just get the sniffles; sometimes, they just get something where they're not feeling quite right. And sometimes, they feel really bad.But that's a little bit like the flu. It's a little like the regular flu that we have flu shots for. And we'll essentially have a flu shot for this in a fairly quick manner.Yes, go ahead.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Obama, can you verify if Chen Guangcheng is currently under U.S. protection in Beijing? What is your outlook on how this situation will be resolved? And would the U.S. consider granting him asylum if he were to request it? [SEP] While I'm aware of the reports surrounding this situation, I'm unable to provide specific details. I can assure you that human rights remain a central theme in our dialogues with . We believe that a commitment to human rights will ultimately strengthen . We remain dedicated to collaborating with our allies to address the challenges presented by North Korea and to promote stability in the region.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. ——to treat coronavirus. The FDA appeared to be on the brink of issuing an emergency use authorization for convalescent plasma. But after hearing from top officials at the NIH that there wasn't enough evidence to go ahead with that, the FDA has put that on pause. Your reaction to that? And do you believe that convalescent plasma should be in the arsenal of treatments for coronavirus? [SEP] Well, I hear great things about it, John. That's all I can tell you. And it could be a political decision, because you have a lot of people over there that don't want to rush things because they want to do it after November 3. And you've heard that one before.But I've heard fantastic things about convalescent plasma. And I've heard numbers way over 50-percent success. And people are dying, and we should have it approved if it's good. And I'm hearing it's good. I heard from people at the FDA that it's good. So we'll see. I'm going to check that right after this conference.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, concerning Prime Minister Maliki's absence from yesterday's press conference, wouldn't his presence have signaled a unified front? Do you have any insight as to why he was not there? [SEP] Look, I'm just not privy to the details of everyone's schedules. You'd have to ask him.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Nigeria's security situation, is it possible to accelerate the delivery of the Tucano aircraft, specifically at least two before the end of 2019? Also, are there any plans for you to visit Nigeria in the near future? [SEP] Could you repeat the first part? I didn't hear it clearly. But Nigeria is a great country, a very special place. I'd love to go.
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, how do you reconcile your 'hoax' comment with the need for the public to take coronavirus seriously and follow your guidance? [SEP] The hoax remark was about the Democrats' narrative, not the virus. That was obvious if you read the context. My main responsibility was acting quickly, despite opposition. That's why our numbers are lower. It was a difficult, unprecedented choice. My other priority is having the best people. We have the best people in the world, supporting me. They're talented, and I've seen them work. I thank Mike Pence and the team. We have a great team. This will pass.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia's announcement of scaling back operations near Kyiv, is this a genuine de-escalation or a strategic pause for regrouping? [SEP] Well, it's a situation we're monitoring closely. I wouldn't jump to any conclusions prematurely. We need to see verifiable actions, not just words. Negotiations are ongoing, involving our NATO allies. We're maintaining sanctions and supporting Ukraine's defense capabilities. So, the jury's still out, frankly.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, the G-7's oil price cap, designed to combat high gas prices stemming from the war, is still being finalized. Can you confidently state that this measure will actually lower prices for American consumers? And realistically, how long should Americans expect to pay a premium due to this situation? [SEP] I'm sorry, could you clarify the first part of your question regarding the price impact?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Duda, after your meeting today at the White House, do you feel that the prospect of a permanent American military presence in Poland is closer to becoming a reality? [SEP] Well, today Mr. President and I had a private meeting, just the two of us, and then we met with our teams. We had long, frank discussions, and some very pointed ones, too, about the military and energy security situation. I'm confident that we'll all draw the right conclusions from these talks. As I said, both sides presented their views on many things. We agree on the assessment of the current situation and the steps needed to protect our security and interests, including business matters. I believe you'll see the results of our meetings and the declaration we signed. Of course, these are long-term processes, so you'll see how it all unfolds. You'll see concrete actions on the ground, in agreements, and in purchases. Next question, please.
label: General

sentence: Q. Do you believe the actions today will have an impact on making Russia change course in Ukraine? [SEP] That's not what I said. You—you're playing a game with me.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Sir, with all due respect, were you notified of any positive COVID-19 cases affecting White House staff today? [SEP] I'm having difficulty hearing you. Can you speak up?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I'm Patricia Zengerle from Reuters. There's been much criticism of U.S. monetary policy in the runup to this G-20. And with old G-7 partners like Germany opposing you, does this not make it much harder for the United States to press China for yuan appreciation and persuade other G-20 partners to support your goals if they sense that the U.S. is being isolated at the summit? [SEP] Well, I think that you will see at this summit a broad-based agreement from all countries, including Germany, that we need to ensure balanced and sustainable growth. And it is my expectation that the communique will begin to put in place mechanisms that help us track and encourage such balanced and sustainable growth.The most important thing that the United States can do for the world economy is to grow, because we continue to be the world's largest market and a huge engine for all other countries to grow. Countries like Germany that export heavily benefit from our open markets and us buying their goods. That's true for every G-20 member.And so the point that we have consistently made is that in a prudent, stable way, we want to make sure that we are boosting growth rates at home as well as abroad. It is difficult to do that if we start seeing the huge imbalances redevelop that helped to contribute to the crisis that we just went through. And I don't think this is a controversial proposition. In fact, we set up a framework back in Pittsburgh that discussed this, and this is just a follow-on to the work that we've already done.Now, as I've said, I think, when I was first asked this in India, it's not our habit to comment on actions by the Federal Reserve. But as President of the United States, I can tell you that my instructions to my team, including Secretary Geithner, is to focus every single day on how we can grow our economy, how we can increase exports, how we can make sure that even as we're buying goods from places like South Korea, we're also selling goods to places like South Korea.That's part of the reason why we think that getting this Korea-U.S. free trade agreement done is so important. And President Lee and I discussed this, and our instructions are we're not--we don't want months to pass before we get this done; we want this to be done in a matter of weeks.So bottom line is, Patricia, I think that when you see the final communique, it will reflect a broad-based consensus about the direction that we need to go. There may be on any given--at any given moment disagreements between countries in terms of particular strategies. That's not surprising because each country has unique problems and finds itself in different positions. Countries like Germany historically are very sensitive to issues like inflation. But I don't think you'll get any objection to their belief that if the U.S. isn't growing, that's not good for the rest of the world.It also doesn't negate the fact that if we--if individual countries are engaging in practices that are purposely designed to boost their exports at the expense of others, that that can contribute to problems as opposed to solving them.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Bush, in light of the new energy legislation, why did your administration block California's stricter emissions regulations? How do you balance national energy policy with states' rights to address climate change, and what did you discuss with Vice President Gore about this matter? [SEP] Look, we're all concerned about greenhouse gases, and we're working on a national strategy to deal with the issue. The new energy bill is a big step in the right direction. As for California, we believe it's important to have a consistent national policy, rather than a bunch of different rules from state to state. That's why we made the decision we did. I talk to Vice President Gore all the time about climate change. He's passionate about the issue, and I respect his views. We're both committed to finding solutions that protect the environment and keep our economy strong.
label: General

sentence: To be clear, are you suggesting a shift in your stance on this issue, or are you simply deferring the decision on the specific terminology to a later date? [SEP] My focus is on facilitating a successful outcome to President Gul's ongoing negotiations. Any action from the United States that could potentially disrupt these constructive discussions would be counterproductive.
label: General

sentence: Q. So, you're declining to elaborate further on that point? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, with Netanyahu's admission, can you shed any light on the Israeli strike in Syria and its implications for U.S. involvement? [SEP] I'm going to refrain from commenting on that. Next question, please.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. I have a couple questions about don't ask, don't tell. First of all, congratulations. What was your conversation like with Marine Commandant Amos when he expressed to you his concerns and yet he said that he would abide by whatever the ruling was? Can you understand why he had the position he did? And then on the other hand, is it intellectually consistent to say that gay and lesbians should be able to fight and die for this country but they should not be able to marry the people they love? [SEP] You know, I don't want to go into detail about conversations in the Oval Office with my service chiefs. Jim Amos expressed the same concerns to me privately that he expressed publicly during his testimony. He said that there could be disruptions as a consequence of this. And what I said to him was that I was confident, looking at the history of the military with respect to racial integration, with respect to the inclusion of women in our Armed Forces, that that could be managed. And that was confirmed by the attitudinal studies that was done prior to this vote.And what he assured me of, and what all the service chiefs have assured me of, is that regardless of their concerns about disruptions, they were confident that they could implement this policy without it affecting our military cohesion and good discipline and readiness. And I take them at their word. And I've spoken to them since the vote took place and they have all said that we are going to implement this smartly and swiftly, and they are confident that it will not have an effect on our military effectiveness.So I'm very heartened by that. And I want to again give Bob Gates and Admiral Mullen enormous credit for having guided this process through in a way that preserves our primary responsibility to keep America safe and at the same time allows us to live up to our values.With respect to the issue of whether gays and lesbians should be able to get married, I've spoken about this recently. As I've said, my feelings about this are constantly evolving. I struggle with this. I have friends, I have people who work for me, who are in powerful, strong, long-lasting gay or lesbian unions. And they are extraordinary people, and this is something that means a lot to them and they care deeply about.At this point, what I've said is, is that my baseline is a strong civil union that provides them the protections and the legal rights that married couples have. And I think that's the right thing to do. But I recognize that from their perspective it is not enough, and I think this is something that we're going to continue to debate and I personally am going to continue to wrestle with going forward.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Bolsonaro, to be precise, what specific military agreements are being considered with the U.S. regarding Venezuela, and what assurances can you give to the Brazilian people that this collaboration will not compromise Brazil's autonomy in the region? [SEP] We're exploring avenues for collaboration, guided by our shared commitment to democracy. The humanitarian aid sent via Boa Vista demonstrates our collaborative spirit. Our primary objective is to restore freedom and democracy to Venezuela, and we are prepared to collaborate in any way possible to achieve this noble goal. The suffering of the Venezuelan people is a grave concern, and we are committed to finding a resolution.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: If President Putin were to deploy chemical weapons, what specific red lines would trigger a military response from the U.S. or NATO? [SEP] While I cannot reveal specific thresholds or actions, I want to make it clear that the use of chemical weapons is unacceptable and would be met with a swift and decisive response. The nature of that response would depend on the specific circumstances.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the rescue of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, aren't you worried that this sets a dangerous precedent, encouraging financial institutions to take excessive risks knowing that the government will step in to prevent their failure? [SEP] Well, let's be clear about what we're doing here. Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are essential to the housing market, and a stable housing market is essential to the overall economy. Secretary Paulson's plan is designed to ensure that stability. It's a proactive measure to prevent a larger crisis. And it's important to remember that the government is not simply handing out money. We're providing a line of credit and the potential for capital investment, but only if necessary. As for the banks, the FDIC insures deposits up to $100,000. So, people should have confidence in the banking system. We're taking responsible steps to protect the economy.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, North Korea has warned South Korea about joining sanctions, threatening consequences. Are you still sure South Korea and China will fully enforce the UN sanctions? And what if North Korea keeps ignoring the world? [SEP] Well, I just got an update from the Secretary of State, who was just in the Far East. She talked to the Japanese, South Koreans, Chinese, and Russians. She says everyone understands we need to work together to solve this peacefully. That means sticking to the latest UN resolution. The North Korean leader likes to make noise. I think he's just testing the will of the countries trying to convince him there's a better way for his people. I don't know exactly what he said, but he's threatened before. We need to keep reminding our partners that we're more likely to get a diplomatic solution if we work together. So, the coalition is still strong, and we'll keep it that way.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the persistent challenges to your administration's legitimacy, how can you effectively lead the country and work with Congress to address pressing national priorities? [SEP] We won the election. Fair and square. The people have spoken. We're moving forward. We're focused on jobs, the economy, and national security. The rest is just noise.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Cordelia Lynch, Sky News. You talked this week about the U.K. doing a good job in tackling coronavirus. In light of the rising cases, are you changing your mind about that? You also just spoke about possible travel restrictions. Have you discussed when they might be put in place? [SEP] Well, in light of the results, as we discussed before—in light of the results, we're going to be looking at it. And I know the Task Force is looking at it very strongly—Vice President, everybody. I mean, it was looking good, but they've—the results have been building up pretty rapidly. So we'll be taking another look at that. Yes, absolutely.Go ahead, please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, Clinton blames the FBI for the election outcome. Her campaign manager claims the investigation was initially weak. Your reaction? [SEP] Look, transitions are never easy. Emotions are still high. But once Trump is sworn in, he'll face new realities. The Oval Office changes you. I've had polite conversations with the President-elect, offering advice on preserving the office's integrity. He's listened. I can't guarantee he'll follow it, but the discussions have been civil. I'll always be there for him. Regarding the FBI, I know Comey and many agents. They're dedicated. It's difficult when law enforcement gets mixed up with politics. We want them independent, but investigations sometimes involve politics. I've been careful not to meddle in investigations. I won't start now.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, could you clarify the timeline for Israel's suspension of the West Bank annexation? [SEP] Well, let's just say we're focused on the bigger picture here. We've got this incredible deal with the Emirates, a real game-changer. We're working out all the details, the embassies, the flights, the trade. We're hoping this will lead to even more peace in the region. As for the annexation, we'll see what happens. It's not off the table, but right now, peace is the priority.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. How do you reconcile your emphasis on state sovereignty with the principle of 'responsibility to protect' vulnerable populations? [SEP] I'm sorry, how do I reconcile that with the responsibility to protect, which used to be what, exactly?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, isn't this a bit of a gamble? Are you concerned that these recent events might diminish enthusiasm for your administration? [SEP] Look, we've accomplished a lot. We built the greatest economy ever. Nobody is even close, not China, nobody. We had to temporarily shut it down to save millions of lives, and then we reopened it. We had the best numbers in history for African Americans, Hispanic Americans, Asian Americans, every demographic you can think of: young people without a diploma, young people with a high school diploma, with a college diploma. Women were doing incredibly well. There's never been a time like it. But we had to turn it off because of what China did. And now, we're turning it back on, and we're doing very well. But it was a very bad situation. Speaking of China, the trade deal is less important to me now than when we made it. When we made it, it was a great deal. But they're setting records. Yesterday was a record corn day. They purchased more corn than ever before, and that's been going on for a few days. And soy beans and everything else. But it just means much less to me. Do you understand? It just means much less to me.
label: General

sentence: Given the apparent legislative gridlock on voting rights, can you now articulate the executive actions or other strategies you intend to employ to safeguard voting rights, as you suggested was possible ten months ago? [SEP] While I'm not prepared to unveil the full scope of potential executive orders or other measures at this juncture, I want to emphasize the significant enhancements we've made to the Justice Department's enforcement capabilities. These dedicated individuals are actively challenging what we believe are unconstitutional attempts by Republicans to manipulate elections and undermine their outcomes. Furthermore, we've expanded our outreach beyond traditional civil rights circles to educate the broader American public about the potential consequences of these actions. Frankly, if I had publicly predicted the extent of election subversion efforts we're now witnessing—such as attempts to appoint alternate electors—people might have dismissed it as far-fetched. As a former constitutional law professor, I never imagined we'd be confronting such challenges in the 21st century. Nevertheless, we are, and we're committed to addressing them through a combination of executive action and legislative solutions, including key components of the John Lewis Voting Rights Act and fair elections bills.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, do you believe this constitutes a credible threat against you? [SEP] That determination is premature. We're investigating all angles and will provide an update when we have more clarity.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the proposed Oracle-TikTok deal, are you prepared to approve it despite the lack of direct payment to the Treasury? Furthermore, does the agreement adequately address national security concerns? [SEP] Well, I'm being briefed on the details of the deal. It absolutely has to meet the highest standards when it comes to national security. And no, I'm not ready to sign off on anything yet. I need to thoroughly review the agreement. Security is paramount, especially given recent events and ongoing concerns. We want to ensure our security is protected. I'll be receiving a report tomorrow morning, and I'll let you know my decision then.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President, given the ongoing travel restrictions affecting EU citizens, can you explain the rationale behind the differing policies for Germany and Turkey, particularly in light of the infection rates? [SEP] That's something our COVID team is currently examining. The Chancellor brought it to our attention. We anticipate being able to lift the ban soon, but it's still under review. I'll have a definitive answer for you in the coming days, pending input from our experts. The Delta variant presents a new challenge, requiring careful consideration for a sustainable decision. The Chancellor also inquired about this, receiving the same response. The COVID team is assessing the situation. If we don't depart shortly, we'll be late for dinner. Thank you for your questions.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, did the protesters direct any specific criticisms toward you? [SEP] I wouldn't know. I didn't ask. It might not have concerned me. It happened outside the White House, beyond the fence. As you're aware, the new fence is quite formidable. But it was on the outside. The Secret Service will be providing a detailed report soon.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, regarding the Hadley memo leak, did you or your Chief of Staff initiate an investigation before the al-Maliki meeting? If unauthorized, do you suspect internal sabotage of your Iraq policy or the meeting? [SEP] I don't recall ordering an investigation specifically. I was certainly concerned about the leaks. I understand your job, but leaking classified information is unacceptable. It's a persistent problem. We've had many leaks, and finding the source is difficult. There might be an investigation ongoing; I'm not certain. Holding leakers accountable would be beneficial.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, how does the accord today between Israel and the U.A.E. help struggling and persecuted Christians in the Middle East? [SEP] Help what?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, with Prime Minister Tony Blair stepping down, are you concerned that British policy on Iraq could change significantly? [SEP] First of all, I'll miss Tony Blair. He is a political figure who is capable of thinking over the horizon. He's a long-term thinker. I have found him to be a man who's kept his word, which sometimes is rare in the political circles I run in. When Tony Blair tells you something, as we say in Texas, you can take it to the bank. We've got a relationship such that we can have really good discussions. And so I'm going to miss him. I—he's a remarkable person, and I consider him a good friend.I obviously look forward to meeting with his successor. I believe that the relationship between Great Britain and America is a vital relationship. It is a relationship that has stood the test of time. And when America and Great Britain work together, we can accomplish important objectives. We share common values. We share a great history. And so I look forward to working with the—with Gordon Brown, who I presume is going to be the—maybe I shouldn't say that—I shouldn't predict who is going to be in, but I—the punditry suggests it will be him.I have had a meeting with him and found him to be an open and engaging person. I—it's amazing how people make all kinds of characterizations about people in the political process, and I found him to be a easy-to-talk-to, good thinker.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, are you ready to approve the Oracle and TikTok deal, even without Treasury receiving payment? And does it meet your national security requirements? [SEP] They're giving me the details on the deal. It has to be completely secure for national security. I'm not ready to sign off on anything yet. I have to look at the deal. We need security, especially after what we've seen. We want security. They're telling me about it tomorrow, and I'll let you know.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, on this trip, you've emphasized state sovereignty. How does that align with the 'responsibility to protect' doctrine? [SEP] Excuse me, could you repeat the last part? How does it align with what, exactly?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given North Korea's warning to South Korea regarding sanctions, are you confident that South Korea and China will fully implement the UN sanctions? What measures will be taken if North Korea persists in its defiance? [SEP] I recently received a briefing on this matter from the Secretary of State, who has just returned from the Far East. She engaged with representatives from Japan, South Korea, China, and Russia. Her assessment is that all countries recognize the importance of close collaboration to peacefully resolve this situation, which entails adherence to the most recent UN Security Council resolution. The leader of North Korea is prone to making threats. In my view, he is testing the resolve of the five countries working together to persuade him that there is a more beneficial path for his people. While I am not privy to the precise wording of his statement, this is not the first instance of him issuing threats. Our objective is to continually remind our partners that we are more likely to achieve our goal – a diplomatic resolution – through collective action. Therefore, I can assure you that the coalition remains steadfast, and we will continue to ensure its continued solidarity.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, China claims the U.S. is containing them while seeking diplomatic engagement. What's your response? Do you believe President Xi is sincere about improving relations, given actions like banning Apple in China? [SEP] I'm sincere about getting the relationship right. China is changing the rules, especially on trade. They're considering banning Chinese officials from using Western cell phones. This trip wasn't about containing China. I want a fair, transparent relationship. We're strengthening alliances globally for stability. This trip was about cooperation with India, Vietnam, etc. It's not isolating China; it's creating a stable Indo-Pacific. The Quad is about maintaining stability, not isolating China. International rules must be respected. Xi faces economic challenges, and I want China to succeed, but they need to play by the rules.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, would you strongly advise Israel against taking military action against Iran? And do you believe that Iran will be pursuing nuclear weapons when you leave office? [SEP] I've consistently emphasized to all parties that a diplomatic resolution is the preferred approach. The most effective way to achieve this is through international cooperation, sending a clear message that Iran will face isolation and economic hardship if it continues its enrichment activities. I worked closely with President Putin on this issue, advocating for a civilian nuclear program under strict international oversight, with Russia providing enriched uranium and retrieving spent fuel. We will continue to pursue diplomatic avenues.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, considering the complaints from Iran's Supreme Leader about the lack of tangible economic benefits post-nuclear agreement, and the reluctance of non-U.S. companies to engage due to potential U.S. financial system access, isn't the current situation a failure of the agreement's intended outcomes? [SEP] Look, the situation is complex. We always knew it would be. The IAEA has confirmed that Iran is holding up its end of the bargain, dismantling its nuclear program as agreed. Now, businesses are naturally cautious, and they need reassurance. Secretary Lew and others are working to provide clarity about permissible transactions. It's going to take time for companies to feel secure enough to invest. But let's not lose sight of the bigger picture: we've prevented Iran from developing a nuclear weapon. As for Iran's complaints, well, they need to create a stable and trustworthy environment for businesses. Launching ballistic missiles with threatening messages doesn't exactly inspire confidence, does it? They need to understand that economic benefits come with responsible behavior.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, your response seems to avoid directly criticizing Mr. Trump's rhetoric. Given your previous statements about the importance of civility and respect in political discourse, are you concerned that Mr. Trump's language could contribute to division and polarization within the country? And what specific steps can be taken to counter the rise of divisive rhetoric and promote greater unity? [SEP] We all have a responsibility to be mindful of the words we use and the impact they can have. We need to try to find common ground, to build bridges instead of walls. We need to listen to each other, to understand each other's perspectives. It's not always easy, but it's essential for a healthy democracy. And we need to remember that we're all Americans, that we're all in this together.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: You've described these commutations as for low-level drug offenders, but about a quarter also involved firearms offenses. How do you reconcile that with your views on firearms? [SEP] Well...

sentence: Mr. President, you showed a video that depicted you and Kim Jong Un as equals discussing the future of North Korea. How do you justify portraying a dictator in such a positive light? [SEP] I don't see it that way. I'll do whatever it takes to make the world safer. If sitting on a stage with Chairman Kim can save millions of lives, I'm willing to do it. I'm willing to travel there proudly and gladly. They've already given up a tremendous amount, even before the Olympics. They participated in the Olympics, which were going to be a failure, and they made it a success. If I can save millions of lives by establishing a relationship with someone who's a very powerful man with firm control of a country with powerful nuclear weapons, it's my honor to do it.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, specifically, is the NHS on the table for discussion? [SEP] Sorry, I didn't catch that. What was that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, what factors are being considered when choosing the location, and what is the timeline for making a final decision regarding Charlotte?
