sentence: So, Mr. President, are you saying this individual is just another Twitter follower? [SEP] Well, it appears that way, given the prompt contact we received. Social media is a popular platform, and many people follow my account. However, discussions have taken place about potential collaborations, nothing extensive, just a brief exchange. I maintain positive relationships with various individuals, as evidenced by my rapport with members of the press. As I've stated before, I may surprise some with my foreign policy approach. Looking at recent developments, negotiations are underway, and hopefully, a mutually beneficial agreement can be reached. I'm in no rush, unlike some who are struggling. When I took office, they were in a precarious position, facing numerous conflicts. But my focus on foreign policy has shifted the dynamic, and we're no longer being exploited. We've been subsidizing the defense of certain nations while simultaneously losing money on trade with them. That's changing, and they know it. Take Prime Minister Abe, for example. I questioned the imbalance in our trade relationship, where they export significantly more to us than we do to them. He admitted that no one had ever raised the issue before. Similarly, with China, the tariffs are disproportionate. They acknowledged that they gradually increased them without any repercussions. But I'm addressing these issues head-on. Now, let's move on to the next question.

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, the situation in Europe seems to be deteriorating. sentence: Mr. President, regarding Postmaster General DeJoy, these reports suggest he may have violated campaign finance laws. What's your response? sentence: Given the UK's exemption from the travel ban despite having more coronavirus cases than many Schengen countries, and a recent surge in cases, why does the UK warrant this exception, and will you reconsider adding them to the list? Their numbers have definitely spiked, so we're actively considering adding them, and possibly even reassessing the entire list.

sentence: Mr. President, you initially stated there was no Plan B regarding the Iran deal, yet now you're discussing a new agreement. Can you explain this apparent contradiction? Is this a result of adopting President Trump's approach, or were you unable to sway him? And do you believe the other signatories will support this new direction? [SEP] Let me clarify: my 'no Plan B' comment referred to the lack of a second planet, a comment about climate change, not Iran. Regarding Iran, my position has been consistent. As I stated at the UN, the JCPOA needs to be supplemented with elements addressing post-2025 issues, ballistic missiles, and regional influence. The JCPOA's fate is uncertain, and that's his decision. I view it as a foundation, not the complete solution. I'm not suggesting a replacement, but an enhancement. I wouldn't be as critical of the JCPOA as he is, because I think we can usefully add to it. Regardless, my goal is to collaborate on a comprehensive agreement encompassing the JCPOA's provisions, extended nuclear restrictions, ballistic missile controls, and regional influence mitigation. We've discussed regional dynamics, especially in Syria, Yemen, and Iraq, recognizing the interconnectedness of nuclear and ballistic issues, and Iran's regional presence. Our shared aim is regional stability. This agreement sets the stage for a new agreement addressing the Syrian conflict. I hope to work with our partners, and our foreign ministers are actively involved. We will also discuss regional issues, including Syria, with Russia and Turkey. I believe we can reconcile our common ground and differences. Abandoning the JCPOA without a replacement would be a mistake. Instead, we should build upon it to address all concerns. This acknowledges the criticisms of the JCPOA, which was supported by previous administrations. It also respects regional sovereignty, focusing on a stable framework for peace. It's not about tearing about an agreement and have nothing, but it's about building something new that will cover all of our concerns. And if I might add, they—states and, as I alluded to—that—and countries that are in the area, some of which are immensely wealthy, would not be there except for the United States and, to a lesser extent, France. But they wouldn't be there except for the United States. They wouldn't last a week. We are protecting them. They have to now step up and pay for what's happening, because I don't think France or the United States should be liable for the tremendous cost. The United States is embarrassingly into the Middle East. As of a few months ago, as you've heard me say before—and I don't take responsibility, but I would be very embarrassed if I had to—$7 trillion. And when we want to build, Mr. President, our infrastructure, everybody says, Oh, we want to be careful with our money. When we want to fix a highway or we want to build schools and lots of other things—tunnels, bridges—they say, Oh, let's be careful with our money. And yet we have spent $7 trillion in the Middle East, and we've gotten nothing for it. Nothing. Less than nothing, as far as I'm concerned. That's over an 18-year period. The countries that are there, that you all know very well, are immensely wealthy; they're going to have to pay for this. And I think the President and I agree very much on that. And they will pay for it. They will pay for it. We've spoken to them. They will pay for it. The United States will not continue to pay. And they will also put soldiers on the ground, which they're not doing. And we will, in fact, bring lots of people home. We will have a strong blockage to the Mediterranean, which to me is very important—because if we don't, you have Iran going right to the Mediterranean. Not going to have that. But there is a chance—and nobody knows what I'm going to do on the 12th, although, Mr. President, you have a pretty good idea—but we'll see. But we'll see also, if I do what some people expect, whether or not it will be possible to do a new deal with solid foundations. Because this a deal with decayed foundations. It's a bad deal. It's a bad structure. It's falling down. Should have never, ever been made. I blame Congress. I blame a lot of people for it. But it should have never been made, and we're going to see what happens on the 12th. But I will say, if Iran threatens us in any way, they will pay a price like few countries have ever paid. Okay? Yes, John. Please. John Roberts of Fox./Senate Confirmation Process
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with the ongoing violence in Syria, what specific steps are you taking to pressure President Assad to step down and allow for a peaceful transition of power? We're exploring all options to bring about a political solution.

sentence: Q. Novak's claiming you're more isolated than Nixon. Your thoughts? [SEP] What's his definition of 'isolated'?

sentence: Mr. President, is it still possible for Paul Wolfowitz to lead the World Bank after recent events? [SEP] First of all, I believe all parties in this matter have acted in good faith. I regret that it's come to this. I admire Paul Wolfowitz. I admire his heart, and I particularly admired his focus on helping the poor. There is a board meeting going on as we speak. All I can tell you is, I know that Paul Wolfowitz has a interest in what's best for the Bank and—just like he's had an interest in what's best for making sure the Bank focused on things that matter: human suffering, the human condition. I—and so I applaud his vision; I respect him a lot. And as I said, I regret that it's come to this right now.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. One of Mitt Romney's economic advisers recently wrote in a German publication that your recommendations to Europe and to Germany in particular reveal ignorance of the causes of the crisis, and he said that they have the same flaws as your own economic policies. I want to get your response to that and also to follow up on Ben's question. Europe has been kicking the can down the road for years, so why are you any more convinced that we won't see another 3-month fix emerge out of Brussels at the end of the month? [SEP] Well, first of all, with respect to Mr. Romney's advisers, I suggest you go talk to Mr. Romney about his advisers. I would point out that we have one President at a time and one administration at a time, and I think traditionally the notion has been that America's political differences end at the water's edge. I'd also suggest that he may not be familiar with what our suggestions to the Germans have been. And I think sometimes back home there is a desire to superimpose whatever ideological arguments are taking place back home on to a very complicated situation in Europe.The situation in Europe is a combination of things. You've got situations where some countries did have undisciplined fiscal practices, public debt. You had some countries like Spain whose problems actually arose out of housing speculation and problems in the private sector that didn't have to do with public debt.I think that there's no doubt that all the countries in Europe at this point recognize the need for growth strategies inside of Europe that are consistent with fiscal consolidation plans. And by the way, that's exactly what I think the United States should be thinking about. The essence of the plan that I presented back in September was how do we increase growth and jobs now while providing clarity in terms of how we reduce our deficit and our debt, medium and long term.And I think that's the right recipe generally, not just for us, but across the board.You had a second question. What was it?
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, there are claims circulating that Kamala Harris is ineligible to be Vice President. Can you definitively state whether she meets the legal requirements? sentence: Mr. President, regarding the recent surge in gun violence, shouldn't trained and authorized security personnel be the primary responders in active shooter situations, rather than relying on armed civilians? [SEP] Look, I'm all for law enforcement handling things. They're the best, the greatest. But we gotta let them do their jobs. The problem is, they're not respected anymore. We've gotta give them back their dignity. As for citizens with guns, well, that's a whole different story. But let's focus on supporting our cops.

sentence: Mr. President, following the midterms, what actions regarding abortion rights can the American people realistically expect from Congress? [SEP] I don't believe they can expect much change. We're likely to maintain our current positions. I shouldn't have even answered that question.

sentence: Mr. President, the QAnon movement seems to be attracting a significant following. What are your thoughts on this, and what message do you have for those who are part of it? [SEP] Honestly, I couldn't tell you much about QAnon. I hear they're quite fond of me, which is, of course, appreciated. But my focus is on the real issues facing this country. From what I gather, these are folks who are concerned about the direction things are headed, especially in some of these Democrat-run cities. They see the problems, the violence, the lawlessness, and they want solutions. They're passionate about America, and they want to see it thrive. So, while I can't speak to the specifics of their movement, I share their concerns about the state of our nation. And we're working hard to address those concerns, believe me.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Biden, with respect to your promise to end the war in Yemen and the UAE's request regarding the Houthis, what's the path forward? [SEP] It's being considered. Ending the war requires both sides to be involved. It's going to be very difficult. Yes.

sentence: Q. Are you aware of or have you encouraged anyone in the party to help him get on the ballot, including in swing States? [SEP] No, not at all. No, not at all, other than I get along with him very well. I like him. I like his wife. His wife recommended certain people, as you know, for—including Alice Johnson, who's a fantastic woman. But his wife recommended certain people to get out of prison. They were in prison for a long time—a long, long time. It should have never happened, and I took what she said very strong—Kim. Kim Kardashian. And, you know, he's got a good heart, very good heart. And I like Kanye very much. No, I have nothing to do with him getting on the ballot.

sentence: Mr. President, can you share any details regarding the consequences Pakistan will face if they refuse to hand him over? [SEP] The details of our discussions with Pakistan are confidential. What I can say is that we have conveyed the importance of this issue in no uncertain terms. Next question, please.

sentence: Q. Yes, sir. Thank you. One reason the Republicans talk about it is, there are people who object to the law who said they've had problems with the law, and there are a significant number of opponents of the law. I guess my question is, what makes you think a significant majority of the American people, of voters, will accept this law? Or are we destined to see health care as a 50/50, red State/blue State argument for years to come? [SEP] Well, I think you're mixing up two things here, David. You said there are people who have seen problems with the law. That's not 50 percent of the American people. Right? There may have been folks who have been affected in ways that they weren't happy about by the law. That is a fall—far smaller number than the millions of people who've been signed up. That doesn't mean we shouldn't be concerned about it. That's an area where, as I said to Tamara, we should be open to, are there ways that we can make it even better? So that's objective facts and real problems out there.The other side of it is just polling, right, what's the general opinion of the law, which is attached to general opinions about me or about Democrats and partisanship in the country generally.My view is that the longer we see the law benefiting millions of people, the more we see accusations that the law is hurting millions of people being completely debunked, as some of you in the press have done, and the more the average American who already has health insurance sees that it's actually not affecting them in an adverse way, then it becomes less of a political football, which is where I want it to be. This shouldn't be a political football. This should be something that we take for granted, that in this country, you should be able to get affordable health care regardless of how wealthy you are.Now, the larger issue about whether we can move past the polarization and, sort of, the bitter political debates between Democrats and Republicans, of which Obamacare is just one small part, that's going to take more time. But it's not for lack of trying on my part. And I think that I speak for all Democrats in saying, we would much prefer a constructive conversation with the Republicans about how do we get some stuff done, and let's focus on some areas that the American people really care about.On jobs, we know that infrastructure would put people back to work right now and it would improve our economy for the long term. It didn't used to be a partisan issue. Why aren't we coming up with a way to make sure that we're rebuilding our roads and our bridges and improving our air traffic control system? There's no reason that has to be political. There really isn't any ideological disagreement on that. And I guarantee you after this winter, if you look at the potholes that are the size of canyons all across big chunks of the United States, that people would like to see an infrastructure bill. Well, let's get it done.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, haven't you alienated your base by flip-flopping on tax increases, particularly concerning Social Security? And frankly, the negotiations appear to be deadlocked. Can you give us an honest assessment: are we headed for a fiscal disaster? [SEP] Let's be absolutely clear: a disaster is avoidable if everyone comes to the table in good faith. I campaigned on a balanced approach, and that's exactly what I'm pushing for. The wealthiest Americans need to pay their fair share, we need to make responsible cuts, and we absolutely cannot leave vulnerable families behind. My proposal reflects that balance. I'm prepared to make difficult concessions, even those that may not be popular with some in my own party, to reach a compromise. We need a solution that garners bipartisan support to stabilize our economy and safeguard the middle class. I've already gone more than halfway to address Republican concerns, despite the fact that the majority of Americans agree with me that we should be raising taxes on the wealthiest to reduce the deficit. The fact that Speaker Boehner hasn't embraced what I believe is a fair deal is, frankly, baffling. I remain optimistic, but ultimately, Congress must do its job. The framework for a deal is there, but it requires compromise from all sides. Voters are demanding compromise, not partisan obstruction. We need to act in the best interests of the nation, particularly in light of recent tragedies. I'm committed to getting a deal done before Christmas, but it will require adjustments from everyone involved. The Speaker's 'Plan B', which provides tax breaks to millionaires while cutting unemployment benefits, is a clear violation of the principles we debated during the election. My hope is that Congress will ensure that middle-class taxes do not increase, protect vital programs like tax credits for college, and agree to a balanced deficit reduction package, which is precisely what I have put forward.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. So if you were to put a timeline on when every person in America will be able to get a vaccine, what would that date be? [SEP] I think it would be very soon. I think our distribution process is going to go very quickly. I told you, we've engaged the military. We have a general who's in charge of all logistics, who delivers soldiers. He's a fantastic guy. He's supposed to be fantastic at what he does. And we figure that's better than any company you're going to hire. You can't hire a company like that.And I—we look to the distribution immediately after we get the word that it's good. And I think they're having tremendous success with the vaccine itself. I think the results will be early and strong. The safety has to be a hundred percent, and we're going to insist on that. And, obviously, the companies are going to insist on that also.
label: General

sentence: Could you elaborate on your understanding of the term 'torture'? [SEP] Torture of what kind?
label: Clarification

sentence: Do you see the election of these two Muslim women as a rejection of your message? [SEP] I didn't quite catch that. Could you say it again?

sentence: Mr. President, given your past shifts in stance, how can the British Prime Minister be assured of your steadfast support regarding a Brexit trade deal and NATO? Furthermore, what common ground have you discovered with the Prime Minister, considering your contrasting public personas? [SEP] Well, let me tell you, I'm not as unpredictable as some people make me out to be. My position on trade has been consistent for years. As for the Prime Minister, we hit it off right away. We both understand the importance of putting our countries first. Brexit, frankly, is going to be a fantastic opportunity for the UK. They'll have control over their own destiny, and we're going to be there to help them every step of the way. It's going to be tremendous.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. It was about: Is the new Washington consensus that you and your National Security Adviser set out simply another way of saying America first, which some overseas think it is? [SEP] Well, look, my economic policy is totally consistent with what I think is in the interest of our NATO allies and our allies around the world.One of the things that I decided to do—and I find that the Wall Street Journal—and I'm sure there is someone here from the Wall Street Journal and other publications that are talking about Bidenomics. I didn't realize it was—I had Bidenomics going.But the bottom line was this: that the fundamental changes taking place in terms of international trade, nobody in—at least very few people in United States, and I suspect around the world, knew what a supply chain meant, what they're talking about, the supply chain.When we found out during the pandemic that the reason why we couldn't build automobiles was because the outfit that we got our semiconductors from in Southeast Asia had shut down because of the pandemic, we realized that—I decided that no longer would we rely on one center of support for any of the things that are needed for our economic growth.And I made it clear to all our NATO allies and our partners as well that although we were going to generate a—for example, an AI capacity here—I mean, excuse me, a semiconductor capacity here in the United States, attracting literally several hundred billion dollars in investment, that that was available to all of our allies, all of our friends. And they're investing as they—as we are and benefiting in a similar way.The bottom line here for me is that I think that the world is changing in a way that globalization is still real. But the measure of what we used to call in the United States trickle-down economics, where if the—if the trickle-down economics resulted in both—in Democratic and Republican administrations for generations—in making sure we found the cheapest labor in the world, sent the product to—sent the work to those—to that neighbor or those neighbors who have the cheapest labor, and they send back their products.Well, I'm not doing that anymore. We're going to make sure that we, in fact, have a flip of that. We're sending capacity—here in the United States, we're attracting capacity to build here in the United States to send product overseas, not the reverse.And I know it sounds simplistic, but it's working so far. And it's not going to hurt any of our allies or friends in terms of the trade piece of this. Matter of fact, I'm finding they're benefiting from it as well, because they're engaging in it with us. And at home, they're doing similar things.So that's why we talked about the need to have relationships in terms of certain materials—the battery technologies—to share. We rely on Great Britain to produce a lot of that for us.So it is increasing trade. But right now it looks like it is—because the United States is doing so incredibly well, it makes it looks like it's only the United States. It's not. It's just a change in direction in terms of how we view generating economic growth. And just to add to that, I'd say I'm absolutely of the view that the United States, this President does not believe in zero-sum competition amongst allies. That's what we declared together with our G-7 partners just a few weeks ago in Hiroshima. This is a President and an administration that is completely attuned to the needs and concerns of its allies on these issues. And you can see that.Today, as the President said, we are launching negotiations between the U.K. and the U.S. on a critical minerals agreement so that the U.S. can provide us with that interaction and cooperation we need.And the Atlantic Declaration that we've announced today just talks about strengthening, deepening our cooperation. It's not about looking in and being protection; it's about the exact opposite of that.And it's about strengthening that cooperation across the full spectrum of economic, technological, and other spheres. And that's what you will see. You'll see that from the President. You'll see it from me. You'll see the U.K. and the U.S. working even more closely together on all the big economic issues of our time, because that's what the moment demands, and that's what our citizens need us to do. And that's what the President and I plan to deliver. And it's not just our citizens. Look, the Global South—there are going to be a billion people in Africa very shortly. One billion.At the G-7, it was originally called Build Back Better World, but we were talking about—there's a new PPI [PGII; White House correction]—anyway—an industrial policy that we're all signed on to, to provide the countries in Africa and in the Global South an opportunity to grow, significantly grow, which benefits the United States, benefits Europe, benefits every country.Because the reverse is true: If we don't figure a way in which these countries can grow and participate and have to—and be able to build infrastructure—you know, the Canadians—the—excuse me, the Chinese have a Belt and Road Initiative. Well, the Belt and Road Initiative turns out to be a debt and confiscation program. Not going very far.But what we're doing—and we're going to be doing with our NATO allies, with the G-7—is providing opportunities. For example, Angola—I—should be in a position very soon to have the largest solar facility in the world, generating significant amounts of energy. It benefits us, benefits them, brings them into the 21st century in a way that they'd never been before.We're talking about building—and I had my team putting together with other countries as well—to build a railroad from the Pacific Ocean—from the Atlantic Ocean all the way to the Indian Ocean. Never occurred before. How—we're—our Departments of Agriculture are working with these countries.So there's a significant amount of cooperation, not to hoard capacity, but to expand capacity to further expand opportunity, because we all benefit from it.And one thing I've learned is that we are not going to be able to deal with the global warming, which is a consequential—single most consequential threat to humanity if we don't do it, unless we engage more together, not fewer—not less together.And so the United States will do what it can do well and invite all of our partners to be part of it if we can.Thank you. Thank you.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, you, on the other hand, immediately agreed to meet with him. Do you understand the criticism that you've given him the ultimate validation, legitimizing a regime that oppresses its people, by meeting and shaking hands with the leader of North Korea, who is perceived as brutally oppressing his own people, without any prior conditions or processes? [SEP] Right. That's been covered.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Many experts, from Nouriel Roubini to Senator Schumer, have said that it will cost the Government more than a trillion dollars to really fix the financial system. During the campaign, you promised the American people that you won't just tell them what they want to hear, but what they need to hear. Won't the Government need far more than the $350 billion that's remaining in the financial rescue funds to really solve the credit crisis? [SEP] Well, the credit crisis is real and it's not over. We averted catastrophe by passing the TARP legislation. But as I said before, because of a lack of clarity and consistency in how it was applied, a lack of oversight in how the money went out, we didn't get as big of a bang for the buck as we should have.My immediate task is making sure that the second half of that money, $350 billion, is spent properly. That's my first job. Before I even think about what else I've got to do, my first task is to make sure that my Secretary of the Treasury, Tim Geithner, working with Larry Summers, my National Economic Adviser, and others, are coming up with the best possible plan to use this money wisely--in a way that's transparent; in a way that provides clear oversight; that we are conditioning any money that we give to banks on them reducing executive compensation to reasonable levels; and to make sure that they're not wasting that money.We are going to have to work with the banks in an effective way to clean up their balance sheets so that some trust is restored within the marketplace, because right now part of the problem is that nobody really knows what's on the banks' books. Any given bank, they're not sure what kinds of losses are there. We've got to open things up and restore some trust.We also have to deal with the housing issue in a clear and consistent way. I don't want to preempt my Secretary of the Treasury; he's going to be laying out these principles in great detail tomorrow. But my instruction to him has been, let's get this right, let's create a template in which we're restoring market confidence. And the reason that's so important is because we don't know yet whether we're going to need additional money or how much additional money we'll need until we've seen how successful we are at restoring a sense of confidence in the marketplace, that the Federal Government and the Federal Reserve Bank and the FDIC, working in concert, know what they're doing. That can make a big difference in terms of whether or not we attract private capital back into the marketplace.And ultimately, the Government cannot substitute for all the private capital that has been withdrawn from the system. We've got to restore confidence so that private capital goes back in.Okay. Jake [Jake Tapper, ABC News].
label: General

sentence: Q. But the alliance—which alliance will be more important, with the EU or with Britain? [SEP] Both. I don't want to say which. Look, I think that—I think that the—I think we have been with, I guess you would start off by saying, England. Right? You know, I ask Boris: Where's England? What's happening with England? They don't use it too much anymore. We talked about it. It was very interesting. But the United Kingdom is a great, incredible place. It's an incredible nation. And it's, you know, been one of our tremendous allies.And another one happens to be Australia. He was here also—Scott. He is fantastic. In fact, we're honoring him and Australia at the White House in a very short period of time.
label: General

sentence: The deadline for Kosovo independence? [SEP] You said decline?
label: Clarification

sentence: But Prime Minister, surely you can appreciate the public's concern. Are you saying that your party knowingly exploited a loophole in the law, and if so, do you believe that was ethical? [SEP] Our actions were guided by legal precedent and a good-faith interpretation of the regulations. We are confident that we acted within the bounds of the law, and we are prepared to defend our position in court if necessary. The focus should be on ensuring fair and transparent elections for all parties.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, on the fiscal cliff, 2 years ago, sir, you said that you wouldn't extend the Bush-era tax cuts, but at the end of the day, you did. So, respectfully, sir, why should the American people and the Republicans believe that you won't cave again this time? [SEP] Well, 2 years ago, the economy was in a different situation. We were still very much in the early parts of recovering from the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression. And ultimately, we came together not only to extend the Bush tax cuts, but also a wide range of policies that were going to be good for the economy at that point—unemployment insurance extensions, payroll tax extension—all of which made a difference and is part of the reason why what we've seen now is 32 consecutive months of job growth and over 5 1/2 million jobs created and the unemployment rate coming down.But what I said at the time is what I meant, which is this was a one-time proposition. And what I have told leaders privately, as well as publicly, is that we cannot afford to extend the Bush tax cuts for the wealthy. What we can do is make sure that middle class taxes don't go up.And so the most important step we can take right now—and I think the foundation for a deal that helps the economy, creates jobs, gives consumers certainty, which means gives businesses confidence that they're going to have consumers during the holiday season—is if we right away say 98 percent of Americans are not going to see their taxes go up, 97 percent of small businesses are not going to see their taxes go up. If we get that in place, we are actually removing half of the fiscal cliff. Half of the danger to our economy is removed by that single step.And what we can then do is shape a process whereby we look at tax reform, which I'm very eager to do. I think we can simplify our tax system. I think we can make it more efficient. We can eliminate loopholes and deductions that have a distorting effect on our economy. I believe that we have to continue to take a serious look at how we reform our entitlements because health care costs continue to be the biggest driver of our deficits.So there is a package to be shaped, and I'm confident that parties—folks of good will in both parties can make that happen. But what I'm not going to do is to extend Bush tax cuts for the wealthiest 2 percent that we can't afford and, according to economists, will have the least positive impact on our economy.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, and to both of you, what do you think the Canada-U.S. relationship will look like in 4 years? What will the auto sector look like? Will the border be thicker or thinner? And will you have a carbon market? [SEP] Whoa, slow down. Which question are you directing towards me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Your former colleague, Mitch McConnell, asserts that you two have had minimal contact since you assumed office and that your policies have veered sharply to the left. Do you concur with his evaluation? Has your administration forsaken bipartisanship? [SEP] That's just Mitch being Mitch. The truth is, I've extended invitations to Republicans to engage in discussions at the White House on numerous occasions. We're actively engaged in bipartisan efforts, such as fortifying our computer chip manufacturing capabilities. While I certainly value Republican support, I'm well aware that Republican voters largely endorse my policies. If Senator McConnell deems my actions to be too liberal, perhaps he should examine the views of his own party, as a significant portion of them appear to align with my approach.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, you campaigned on changing the tone in Washington. But you recently accused Democrats of wanting terrorists to win. How do you reconcile those? [SEP] The election is over, and the Democrats won; that's what's changed. We will work together for the next two years to achieve great things for the country. The Democrats need to decide how they're going to operate. I haven't had a chance to speak with the leadership yet, but we'll begin consultations with them soon.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your meeting with Kim Jong-un grants him a significant victory without tangible concessions. Are you concerned that this engagement, absent concrete progress, could be perceived as legitimizing his regime? [SEP] Fake news, folks, that's all it is. We got three hostages back, didn't we? Paid nothing. They're home with their families, happy as can be. We haven't given up anything. The haters, they say, 'Oh, you're giving him a meeting.' Give me a break! This is something that's never been done before. And what's been done before hasn't worked. I can't stress this enough. Look at tariffs – previous administrations should have handled it. Same with . This should have been done years ago.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Why does that apply to Florida and it doesn't apply to mail-in balloting across the country? [SEP] So Florida has got a great Republican Governor, and it had a great Republican Governor. It's got Ron DeSantis, Rick Scott—two great Governors. And over a long period of time, they've been able to get the absentee ballots done extremely professionally. Florida is different from other States.I mean, in Nevada, where you have a Governor—he said, Let's just send out millions of ballots, and the Post Office cannot be prepared; I haven't spoken to the Post Office about it, but I don't know how they could possibly be prepared. Florida has been working on this for years. And they have a very good system of mail-in—and that would be absentee or even beyond absentee. So, in the case of Florida, there aren't too many people that would qualify.They're so well run. Florida is a very well-run State: low taxes, low everything. They've done a great job, really a great job. And the two Governors, between the both of them, they've really got a great system of absentee ballots and even the—even in the case of mail-in ballots, the postal services have built up their—you know, it takes a long time.When you look at the Carolyn Maloney election, I think they—and I'll give you the story: I think you have to do that election over. That election is no good. You have to take a look.In New York, they have thousands of ballots. They don't know what happened to them. Is there fraud? Is there—it's a disaster. And that's only for a relatively small number of ballots. But I think they have to do the election in New York over.The Times wrote a big story about it yesterday, front page story. It's a disaster. It's a mess. And they have to do that—I think they have to do that election over. Nobody can know what the election result is.So, in the case of Florida, they've done a great job, and they've had tremendous success with it. But they've been doing this over many years, and they've made it really terrific. So, for Florida, you can mail in your ballots. You don't have to go. In maybe a couple of other States, they've worked out a system, but this took years to do. This doesn't take weeks or months.In the case of Nevada, they're going to be voting in a matter of weeks. And you can't do that. I can't imagine the Post Office could do it. All of sudden, they're supposed to be dealing in millions of ballots?But Florida has done a great job, and we have total confidence that if you mail in your ballot in Florida, it's going to matter.Thank you all very much. Thank you. Thank you very much.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, you claim you did nothing wrong in your Ukraine conversations. But can you explain why it's appropriate to ask a foreign leader for information on a political rival? What would you have said if Obama had done that to you? [SEP] Well, that's what he did, isn't it? Look, the witch hunt was started, and hopefully, that'll come out. There are fantastic books coming out that show what they did to us. They've hurt this country badly. No other President should go through what I have. The Ukrainian President is trying to stop corruption. There was corruption. Senators threatened him with votes and money. That's what they're trying to say I did, but I didn't. The call was perfect. No quid pro quo, but there was with Biden and those Senators. We have an honest group of people being maligned. I'm very happy. A poll had me at 53. Add 10 points to any poll for Trump. I don't know if that's a compliment, but it is. That's what happened in the election: more people voted than anyone thought possible.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your focus on economic partnerships in Asia is a thinly veiled attempt to counter China's Belt and Road Initiative. How do you differentiate your approach and demonstrate that it's not simply a response to China's influence? [SEP] Our approach is based on transparency, sustainability, and respect for national sovereignty. We're not imposing conditions or creating debt traps. We're working with our partners to build infrastructure that meets their needs and promotes long-term economic growth. This is a fundamentally different approach than China's, and it's one that we believe will ultimately be more successful.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. I'm sure that you've been apprised of the attack on the Inter-Continental Hotel yesterday, sir. And does that concern you that Afghan forces may not be able to step up if these guys are able to attack a high-profile target in the nation's capital? [SEP] Well, keep in mind the drawdown hasn't begun. So we understood that is a dangerous place, that the Taliban is still active, and that there are still going to be events like this on occasion. The question is, in terms of overall trend, is Afghan capacity increasing?Kabul, for example, which contains a huge proportion of the Afghan population as a whole, has been largely policed by Afghan forces for quite some time. And they've done a reasonably good job. Kabul is much safer than it was, and Afghan forces in Kabul are much more capable than they were.That doesn't mean that there are not going to be events like this potentially taking place, and that will probably go on for some time. Our work is not done. But as I said in my speech, the tide of war is receding. We have shifted to a transition phase. And much like we've seen in Iraq--where we've drawn down our troops, the remainder of our troops will be coming out by the end of this year, but Iraq has been able to maintain a democratic government and to tamp down violence there--we think a similar approach makes sense in .But even in Iraq, you still see the occasional attack. These are still countries that are digging themselves out of a lot of war, a lot of conflict. They're dangerous places. And so they're not going to be perfectly safe, even if we were there. But we can improve the chances for the Afghan people to defend themselves.Jim Sciutto [ABC News].
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with the clock ticking down on your presidency, what are your remaining priorities, and are you concerned that the immigration bill might become a casualty of the upcoming elections? [SEP] Look, we've got to get that energy legislation across the finish line. Renewing No Child Left Behind is non-negotiable. Those trade agreements with Panama, Peru, and Colombia need to move through Congress, and I'm hoping we can build on the progress we've made with the Korean free trade agreement. My goal is to bring back successful Doha negotiations for a congressional vote, which means we need a TPA extension. And we absolutely must keep the momentum going on balancing the budget. The deficit's shrinking faster than anticipated, thanks to increased tax revenues and the measures we've put in place. Now, we need Congress to hold the line on spending and avoid those tax hikes that would cripple the economy and, in turn, hurt Treasury revenues. I'm deeply concerned about the Democrats' tax-and-spend approach. I'm waiting to see how they plan to balance the budget in five years. And, of course, the war on terror remains a central focus. I'm hoping to find common ground with both parties on Iraq. Some just want to pull out, but I strongly disagree, and I believe most Americans do as well. The recent vote showed what we can achieve when we work together. On immigration, it's a complex issue. I've always been a proponent of comprehensive reform to secure our border. It's a promise I made on the campaign trail, and it's something I believed in as Governor of Texas. I understand the frustrations surrounding illegal immigration, which is why we've significantly ramped up border security. We're doubling the number of Border Patrol agents and adding more fencing and equipment. I even deployed the National Guard for a while. This bill addresses those concerns by setting clear security benchmarks that must be met before any other reforms can take effect. Last year, the call was for security first, and that's precisely what this bill delivers. However, I don't see how we can achieve the level of border security the American people expect without a temporary-worker program that includes verifiable work cards. People will come here to work, and they'll find a way to do it. This has fueled an underground industry of smugglers and document forgers, which is simply inhumane. It's not who we are as Americans. The best way to combat this is to offer a legal, temporary pathway for people to fill jobs that Americans aren't doing. I'd much rather have people crossing the border with legitimate cards than being crammed into the back of a truck. Secondly, we need a reliable system for employer verification. It's against the law to hire someone who's here illegally, but businesses often struggle to verify the authenticity of documents. That's why we need a tamper-proof ID card, which is a key component of this bill. The toughest question is what to do with those who are already here. Some would call anything short of deportation amnesty, but deporting 12 million people is simply not realistic. Nor should they be granted automatic citizenship. So, we've developed a plan that requires them to meet certain conditions to obtain a Z visa, including background checks, fines, and a probationary period, before they can even apply for citizenship. If you're looking for reasons to oppose the bill, you'll find them, but it's a comprehensive and well-thought-out solution. I knew this would be a contentious issue. It's easy to demonize someone who's working hard here. I want to get this bill done because it's the right thing to do and because it will address the problem effectively. I want to take it out of the political arena. Immigration debates can bring out the worst in people. We're a nation of immigrants. I was deeply moved by the Coast Guard Academy ensign who spoke about his grandfather, a migrant from Mexico. He was proud to serve America. Welcoming those who seek to work and achieve the American Dream revitalizes our nation. We have an opportunity to enact a good law now, but it will require hard work. Politics will inevitably play a role, but I hope that Members of Congress will rise above it. I know I will. It's the right thing to do. I'll continue to engage with them and urge them to show the courage needed to get this bill to my desk as soon as possible. Thank you.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Do you think that the project should be canceled? The President. Sure. Well, I've been support—I've been supportive of that. I was the first one that brought it up. You never heard of Nord Stream 2 until Trump came along.When I came along, I said: Wait a minute. We're protecting Germany from Russia, right? NATO. We're protecting Germany from Russia. Germany is paying Russia billions and billions of dollars to get their energy. And the real number is, probably 60 to 70 percent, ultimately, of their energy is going to come from Russia. And I said this for years, that nobody talks about it. One of the many things, between sanctions and all of the—what we've done for Ukraine, relative to what the past—they used to send pillows, and we sent tank busters. But I brought that up a long time ago. Russia is unhappy that I brought it up. But you never heard of Nord Stream 2; nobody did, until I got elected.And I said: Why is Germany making a deal to give billions of dollars to Russia, and then we're protecting Germany from Russia? How does that work? And then, on top of it, Germany is delinquent, because they're only paying a little more than 1 percent and they're supposed to be paying 2 percent, and even the 2 percent is low. But just remember: Trump—me—I got the countries of NATO to spend one point—$130 billion, going to $400 billion a year. Think of it: $400 billion a year more for NATO.And the purpose of NATO primarily is Europe protection against Russia. Now, they can use it for other, I guess—and they have a little bit in the Middle East, et cetera, et cetera.But I'm the one that did that. So—but nobody talks about that. Nobody talks about Nord Stream 2.The answer is: Absolutely, if they feel that something happens. But I don't know that Germany is in a position right now, because Germany is in a very weakened position, energy wise. They're closing all their plants. They're closing their nuclear. They're closing their coal. They're closing a lot of plants. And they are—they have put themselves in a very bad position, frankly. Very, very bad position.Yes, please.News Media/Former Chief of Staff John F. Kelly  Q. Mr. President, can I follow up Jeff Mason's [Jeff Mason, Reuters] question? Have you asked John Kelly to publicly refute the Atlantic? And then, can I ask something else? [SEP] No, I have nothing against John. I have nothing against anybody. No.I was very heartened to see that a friend of his—because I know Zach is a friend of his and worked for him—I was very heartened to see that Zach Fuentes came out with the statement that he did—I guess, late last night—that it was not true.
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, concerning Mayor Bowser's recent directive in DC, despite its inapplicability to federal lands, might you advocate for federal facilities—encompassing the White House and military installations—to embrace its principles? [SEP] We are currently weighing the various factors involved and anticipate reaching a determination within the next day. We will promptly communicate that decision to you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering the complexities of the situation, how do you balance supporting Turkey's right to defend its airspace with the need to maintain stability and avoid a larger conflict with Russia in the region? [SEP] Look, it's a delicate situation, no doubt. Turkey is a NATO ally, and they acted to defend their airspace. Russia needs to understand that its actions have consequences. We're urging both sides to talk, to prevent any further escalation. The key here is to get everyone focused on the real enemy: ISIS. If Russia would join us in that fight, these kinds of incidents would be far less likely to occur. We're keeping all channels open to ensure that happens.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, given the sensitive nature of Chen Guangcheng's situation, can you outline the specific protocols in place to ensure his safety and security while he is reportedly under U.S. protection? And what diplomatic channels are being used to facilitate a resolution that respects both his wishes and the interests of all parties involved? [SEP] I'm aware of the reports concerning the situation, but I'm not going to comment on the specifics. I will reiterate that human rights are a key component of our relationship with . We believe that openness and liberalization will strengthen . On North Korea, we've made it clear that provocations will be met with isolation and sanctions. The failed missile launch was a topic of extensive discussion with . We are unified in our insistence that North Korea abide by its responsibilities.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. If things progress down that road, will you ultimately have to make that call? [SEP] We'll cross that bridge when we get to it. We still have a couple of months to assess the situation.
label: General

sentence: So, is a government shutdown a possibility during the lame-duck session? [SEP] I honestly couldn't say for sure at this moment. I'm not prepared to make a firm commitment either way. It's all still up in the air.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, leading Republican economists are calling for increased government intervention to prevent a recession. What steps should the government take? [SEP] We're always looking at what we can do. The economy's strong because we're competitive, our workforce is flexible, taxes are low, and exports are up. But I know folks are worried about rising costs and losing their homes. We won't bail out lenders or speculators, but we'll help folks who deserve it stay in their homes. Paulson's HOPE NOW coalition is working on refinancing standards. The problem is, mortgages get sold off, making it hard to renegotiate. Congress can help by passing an FHA bill. We'll look at all options for stimulating the economy. Next question.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Will you give more ground if you need to, or are you done? [SEP] If you look at the package that I put forward, it is a balanced package by any definition. And the—we have put forward real cuts in spending that are hard to do in every category. And by any measure, by any traditional calculation, by the measures that Republicans themselves have used in the past, this would be as large a piece of deficit reduction as we've seen in the last 20 years. And if you combine that with the increased revenue from the wealthy paying a little bit more, then you actually have something that would stabilize our deficit and debt for a decade—for 10 years.Now, the notion that we would not do that, but instead the Speaker would run a play that cuts—keeps tax cuts for folks making 500 or 700 or 800 or $900,000 a year and gives more tax breaks to millionaires and billionaires and raises taxes on middle class families and then has no cuts in it—which is what he says he wants—doesn't make much sense.I mean, let's just think about the logic for a second. They're thinking about voting for raising taxes, at least on folks over a million, which they say they don't want to do, but they're going to reject spending cuts that they say they do want to do. That defies logic. There's no explanation for that.I think that any objective person out there looking would say that we've put forward a very balanced plan and it's time for us to go ahead and get it done. That's what the country needs right now. Because I think folks have been through some wrenching times, we're still recovering from a very tough recession, and what they're hoping for is a sense of stability, focus, compromise, common sense over the next couple of years. And I think we can provide it. But this is a good test for it. Okay?Carol Lee [Wall Street Journal]. There you go.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the House Democrats' bill and its provision for a second round of direct payments to Americans, what's your perspective? [SEP] Well, we're discussing that with many people. I'm interested in a payroll tax cut, among other things we're considering. We want to ensure the workers are taken care of. We're in negotiations with the Democrats, so we'll see what transpires. This is a period of transition, and I believe it will lead to something truly special. A transition to greatness, commencing next year. I anticipate we'll perform exceptionally well. The third quarter is a transition quarter, but the fourth quarter should be remarkable. Next year will be phenomenal, unless someone interferes by raising taxes. We had the greatest economy in the world, and we'll recreate that success.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Why wasn't Prime Minister Maliki at yesterday's news conference with General Casey and Ambassador Khalilzad? Wouldn't that have demonstrated closer cooperation? [SEP] Elaine, I honestly have no idea why he wasn't there.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. The White House has spent the day denying that they are going to appoint a czar to run point on the coronavirus response. Today the—Secretary Azar testified that he didn't think one was necessary; they were going to run it out of HHS. And you yourself have been downplaying this. So why are you now selecting the Vice President to run point on this? [SEP] Well, Mike is not a czar. He's Vice President. He's in the administration. But I'm having everybody report to Mike. Mike has been very good, very adept. Anybody that knows anything about health care, they look at the Indiana model, and it's been a very great success. It's been a tremendous model in terms of health care. And this is really an offshoot of that.So this isn't a czar. I don't view Mike as a czar. Mike is part of the administration. But I'm having them report to Mike. Mike will report to me.They'll also be reporting, in some cases, to both. I'll be going to meetings quite a bit depending on what they want to do and what message we want to get out. But we've done, really, an extraordinary job. When you look at a country this size, with so many people pouring in—we're the number one in the world for people coming into a country, by far. And we have a total of 15 cases, many of which, or most—within a day, I will tell you most of whom are fully recovered. I think that's, really, a pretty impressive mark.Now, we did take in 40 people that were Americans, and they're also recovering. But we brought them in, so I call that—I have a different group. But we felt we had an obligation to American citizens outside of the country that were trying to get back in. We thought it was very important.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, in light of recent events, are you considering any changes to the way the government handles classified information? [SEP] We're always looking for ways to improve our security protocols and protect classified information. We're working with Congress and other stakeholders to identify and implement best practices. We're also emphasizing the importance of responsible handling of classified information to all government employees.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, just to quickly clarify regarding Meng Wanzhou: Will her case be prolonged indefinitely, or is there a chance the U.S. might withdraw the extradition request? [SEP] Extradition for what, now?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, assuming you owned international businesses before your presidency, would you have liquidated them into a blind trust? Or is it alright for a President to be personally exposed to foreign policy considerations? And, in brief, what's your problem with the NSA and Cyber Command, and are you planning to dismiss Admiral Rogers? [SEP] The first question was a rhetorical exercise, correct?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding busing and its role in school integration: Is busing a viable strategy in your view? And how does this relate to the policy you intend to unveil? [SEP] Well, it's been a practice employed for quite some time. I mean, there aren't many alternatives for transporting students to schools. So, it's a practice that's been utilized. In some instances, it's been implemented rather forcefully. And that's part of the equation. But it's certainly a primary means of getting students to schools. I believe if Vice President Biden had answered the question differently, the outcome would have been different. He faced significant criticism on that issue. So, it is certainly a primary method of transporting students to schools.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: So, Mr. President, to put a finer point on it, are you giving this specific proposal your unequivocal backing? [SEP] Not *that* proposal, no. But we're getting closer, folks. We're getting closer. What I *am* behind is getting significant resources to the individuals who were genuinely and unfairly impacted by something that, let's be honest, could have been avoided. They had the power to stop it from spreading within their own borders. They could have prevented its arrival here, in Europe, and across the globe – a staggering 188 countries. It's just...sad.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Given recent restrictions on nonlethal force, should police have the authority to use it to manage urban unrest? [SEP] Wait, what was that about nonlethal force?
label: Clarification

sentence: Chancellor Scholz, beyond stated intentions, what specific, measurable actions is Germany implementing to decrease its vulnerability to Russian energy supplies? And how do you address concerns that Germany's reliance on Russian gas undermines Europe's capacity to respond decisively to the crisis in Ukraine? Mr. President, your perspective? [SEP] Let me respond. We are exploring options to replace lost gas from Russia with LNG, collaborating with our allies. Russia needs to sell that gas and oil; it's a significant part of their budget. If cut off, they'll be hurt as well. It's not a one-way street. We are working to help offset lost gas in Europe. We are prepared for all scenarios, preparing sanctions. Regarding LNG, most is gas. We will modernize our economy and transition to hydrogen faster than anticipated. Thank you.
label: General

sentence: Q. Can you detail the threats you've made to Pakistan regarding the handover? [SEP] The nature of those discussions is confidential. However, let me assure you, we have conveyed the gravity of the situation and the importance of their cooperation in no uncertain terms. It's a top priority.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: On that specific issue, do you foresee them yielding any ground? [SEP] My hope is that they'll arrive at a responsible decision. That's the goal here, isn't it?
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, could you address the reports concerning Chen Guangcheng and whether he is currently under US protection? Furthermore, would the United States consider granting him asylum? And Prime Minister Noda, what is your assessment of the likelihood of a North Korean nuclear test, and what actions would Japan take in response? What role do you envision for the US in addressing this situation? [SEP] We are monitoring the situation closely. Human rights are a key aspect of our foreign policy, and we consistently raise these issues with . As for North Korea, we are deeply concerned about their provocative actions. We are working in close coordination with Japan and our allies to maintain stability and security in the region.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President, have your views on climate change evolved, and what specific actions are you taking to address the global issue? [SEP] Look, I've always said that we need to be good stewards of the environment. I don't think it's a hoax, but I also think some people take it to extremes. We want clean air and clean water, and we're doing a great job with that. Our numbers are fantastic. But we can't ignore the fact that other countries are polluting at an alarming rate. They need to clean up their act. And we have to deal with the garbage that's flowing into our oceans from other countries. So, it's a global problem, and we need a global solution. We're doing our part, but everyone needs to step up.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, following up on the previous question, after all the money spent, how will Americans know if your economic programs are actually working? What specific metrics should they watch, and when should they expect to see results, or should we prepare for a 'Plan B'? [SEP] The primary benchmark is job creation – plain and simple. If people are employed, they have confidence, they spend, businesses invest, and the cycle begins anew. Secondly, we must see the credit markets functioning smoothly. Too many viable businesses are struggling to access credit. Finally, we need to stabilize the housing market. While the federal government doesn't have complete control, our plan, in coordination with the Federal Reserve and the FDIC, aims to curb foreclosures and stabilize housing values. The ultimate sign of success is a return to growth and job creation, reversing the current contraction. While I lack a crystal ball, I'm optimistic that after a challenging year, businesses will regain confidence, consumers will feel secure in their jobs, and we'll witness significant improvements starting next year.
label: Implicit

sentence: I'm referring to the payment you mentioned earlier. [SEP] I'm not sure what you're referring to.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, could you clarify the timeline for Israel's suspension of the West Bank annexation plan, as you understand it? [SEP] What's your take on it? Lay it on me. Look, we're betting big on peace. The UAE deal is a game-changer. We're ironing out the details – embassies, flights, commerce – and then expanding it regionally. The timeframe? Hard to say precisely. We've prioritized peace over the sovereignty issue, but it's not dead. It's just on hold while we give peace a real shot.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Given Russia's ongoing illegal occupation of Crimea, what is your strategy for improving relations with them? [SEP] Indeed, the situation in Crimea remains a concern. However, it's important to remember that this occurred under the previous administration. President Obama's handling of the situation was, in my opinion, inadequate. Had I been President at the time, I believe the outcome would have been different.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the ongoing health concerns, why insist on an in-person meeting, even if attendance is limited? Wouldn't a virtual format be more prudent and inclusive? [SEP] Look, people want to see strength. They want to see leadership. You can't do that on a computer screen. We're going to show the world that America is back, and we're not afraid.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, reports are surfacing about declining morale among troops in Iraq. An infantry commander expressed growing concerns about soldiers questioning their purpose there. Is this something you're aware of, and does it worry you? [SEP] Well, from what I'm hearing from the commanders, the real concern lies with the families back home. Our troops, who volunteered to serve, are ready to go into combat repeatedly. But the worry is with their loved ones on the homefront. I understand that, and that's why I make an effort to constantly thank the family members. You're talking to a specific person or group. I'm talking to our commanders. Their job is to tell me the situation on the ground. I know there's concern about the homefront. I haven't heard deep concern about the morale of the troops in Iraq.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Will you meet with Rouhani? [SEP] Excuse me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. But shouldn't Iran be aware that its actions will have consequences? [SEP] Chuck, I've already addressed that. We don't know how this situation will unfold yet. Next question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, critics argue that simply 'going back for approvals' isn't a concrete commitment. What specific assurances have you received from these leaders that these approvals will be granted? [SEP] These are strong leaders, very strong leaders. They understand the need for a strong NATO, and they're committed to making it happen. They have their own internal processes, their own parliaments to deal with, but I have no doubt they'll get the job done. We have a great relationship, a very strong relationship.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Just to be clear, regarding Meng Wanzhou's case, will that also have to wait until the very end, or is there a possibility the U.S. might drop the extradition effort? [SEP] Sorry, could you repeat that? I didn't quite catch the specifics.
label: Clarification

sentence: Do you agree with Republicans who say the election was a referendum, at least in part, on your intentions to use executive authority for immigration? [SEP] I'm not reading tea leaves on election results. I'll do what's best for the country. I can use executive authority to improve the system, but that's not a fix-all. A comprehensive bill is better. If Republicans want it, I'll cooperate. Keystone has an independent process; I'll let it play out. Is it good for Americans' pocketbooks? Does it create jobs? Does it lower gas prices? Does it increase climate change? It's Canadian oil, not U.S. oil. We've seen huge increases in American oil and gas production. We're closer to energy independence than ever. We have a hundred-year supply of natural gas. Our energy sector is booming, including clean energy. Keystone is one small aspect. Medical device tax—I'll look at their ideas. Let them tell me.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Trump, considering your past criticisms of NATO, how would you assess its current strategic value to the United States, particularly in the context of deterring potential threats from Russia, and what specific reforms are needed to enhance its overall effectiveness? [SEP] NATO is a very important alliance, okay? Very, very important. And it's getting stronger all the time. Before I came along, it was a mess. Nobody was paying their dues. Now, they're all starting to pay. So NATO is going to be very effective. And as far as Russia is concerned, I have a great relationship with President Putin. We're going to be talking about a lot of things, including NATO. We'll see what happens. It's all about getting along, folks.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, given the divisions within the Republican party, do you honestly believe Speaker Boehner can deliver the votes necessary to pass a deal? And do you still trust him to act in good faith? [SEP] The Speaker certainly has a tough job, I recognize that. A large portion of his caucus represents districts where I lost. They may be more concerned with fending off primary challenges than finding common ground. However, I'm hopeful that recent events have underscored the importance of compromise and that we can all work together for the benefit of the country.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the situation in Ukraine, do you believe Germany is doing enough, particularly concerning weapons and Nord Stream 2? [SEP] Germany is a strong ally. They have our complete trust. They're a major player in Europe and a key partner for the United States. They've provided significant financial assistance to Ukraine. The transatlantic partnership is solid. We will act unanimously in terms of sanctions.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, will you be meeting with Judge Lagoa at the White House? [SEP] I'm having trouble understanding you with that mask on.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, did you issue any ultimatums concerning ransomware? How will you gauge the success of these working groups on Russian meddling and cybersecurity? [SEP] It's going to be real easy. On cybersecurity, are they going to work out where they take action against ransomware criminals on their territory? They didn't do it in the past. Are they going to act now? We'll find out. What can we commit to in terms of anything affecting violating international norms that negatively affects us? What are we going to agree to do? I think we have real opportunities to move. People who are very well-informed started thinking, this could be a real problem. What happens if that ransomware outfit were sitting in Florida and took action on their single lifeline to their economy: oil? That would be devastating. It's in everybody's interest that these things be acted on. We'll see what happens from these groups we put together.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Electoral College, what are your thoughts on its future, given the concerns about Russian interference and the popular vote? [SEP] That's a complex question with many facets.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, would you accept Putin's invitation to a video summit with Iran and other world powers? [SEP] I haven't seen the invitation myself. I'll have to look into it before I can comment. We'll get back to you on that.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Okay, so what's the real objective here? [SEP] This whole thing is a joke, a complete waste of time and resources. We've got the head of the World Trade Organization here, and he has to listen to this nonsense about a perfect call. Nobody ever mentions the transcription, nobody ever talks about the call itself, because there's nothing there. Read it! Somebody should just read the call! Everyone would say, 'That's an impeachable offense?' If that were impeachable, Lyndon Johnson and Kennedy would have been out of office on day one. It's a hoax, a complete and utter hoax. You know it's a hoax better than anyone. Next question, please.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, are you able to confirm or deny any evidence suggesting an acceleration of Iran's nuclear ambitions based on intelligence briefings you've received? [SEP] I'm afraid I can't comment on any specific intelligence matters, one way or the other. However, I want to emphasize how seriously we view the Iranian nuclear issue. It's a cornerstone of our policy towards Iran. We're dedicating significant effort to working with allies and concerned parties to foster international cooperation, aiming to demonstrate to the Iranian people that a better alternative exists. Our concern isn't with the Iranian populace, whose history and traditions we hold in high regard. Rather, it's with their government's choices, which are leading to isolation and hindering their economic progress. We are treating this issue with the utmost gravity.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, if I can follow up on that: Your staff, your senior staff, as you just referenced, is able to get tested every day. When will it be that Americans across the country will be able to get tested every day, as they go back to work? [SEP] Very soon. I mean, really, very soon. It's an interesting question, because normally, you would have said that you are not tested, and you would have been, you know, knocking us for not getting tested. So, if we get tested, it's a problem. And if we don't get tested, it's a problem.But I like the way your question was phrased better this way, because it is a positive. We are tested; we have great capability. You look at all of these machines here. They're incredible machines. They're the best anywhere in the world. No place in the world has this kind of equipment. Other countries are calling—sophisticated countries—and they're calling. Lots of countries. And we're trying to make as much as we can available to them, because there's nothing like what we've been able to do in a—literally a couple of months.What they've been able to do—the private sector, what they—how they got it done. This is a 5- to 15-minute test, as an example—the Abbott Laboratories test. These tests are highly sophisticated—very quick, very good. This is things that didn't even exist a short while ago.So we do have a great testing capability at the White House. We're doing it. And I think, generally speaking—we had a call with the Governors the other day—generally speaking, without exception, they were all extremely happy with what's going on, with respect to their testing. Okay?Resumption of Economic and Commercial Activity
label: General

sentence: Q. There are a variety of reports that Chinese hackers are attempting to steal technology related to vaccine research. Is this something you're concerned about? What can you say? [SEP] So what else is new with China? What else is new? Tell me. I'm not happy with China. They should have stopped this at the source. They could have stopped it right at the source. So now you're telling me they're hacking? So I just say this, Steve [Steve A. Holland, Reuters]: What else is new?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Canada, did your discussions include the possibility of them increasing their economic stimulus? And looking forward, what are your expectations for the future of the Canada-U.S. relationship, specifically regarding the automotive sector, border controls, and the establishment of a carbon market? [SEP] You've touched on many different points there. Which one would you like me to address first?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding a potential meeting with Barbara Lagoa at the White House, is that on your agenda? [SEP] I'm having trouble understanding you. Could you repeat that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, as a journalist from China, I'm curious: Do you still see a potential future where relations between North Korea and the U.S. mirror the current positive relationship between the U.S. and Vietnam? [SEP] Say that again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Senator Leahy is proposing a truth and reconciliation committee to investigate the Bush administration's actions. He says you have to 'read the page' before turning it. Do you agree with this proposal, and will you rule out prosecuting Bush administration officials? [SEP] I haven't reviewed the specifics of Senator Leahy's proposal, so I can't comment directly. I've made it clear that my administration will not engage in torture, will adhere to the Geneva Conventions, and will uphold the rule of law while aggressively pursuing terrorists. I don't see these as contradictory. I also believe that no one is above the law, and if there's clear evidence of wrongdoing, prosecution is warranted, just like any citizen. But generally, I'm more focused on the future than the past. I want to unite everyone, including the intelligence community, who have acted properly to protect America. I'll examine Senator Leahy's proposal, but my priority is to move forward constructively.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. With the NHS? With the NHS? Should the NHS be on the table, sir? [SEP] I can't hear him. What?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, could you clarify how prioritizing state sovereignty fits with the idea of intervening to protect vulnerable populations? [SEP] I'm sorry, you want me to reconcile sovereignty with... what was the second part of that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, concerning Iran's nuclear capabilities, ABC News suggests they're on track to build a bomb within 24 months. Can you confirm whether your administration has observed similar evidence of a rapidly advancing program? [SEP] I haven't personally reviewed the specific ABC report. Nevertheless, the possibility of Iran acquiring a nuclear weapon is a serious concern. Such an event would undoubtedly destabilize the Middle East. Our administration has been actively assembling an international coalition to encourage Iran to abandon its nuclear ambitions, making it clear that they face a choice between isolation and the potential for economic growth. We are treating Iran's nuclear ambitions with utmost seriousness.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. So you don't consider a potential traumatic brain injury serious? [SEP] They told me about it numerous days later. You'd have to ask Department of Defense. No, I don't consider them very serious injuries, relative to other injuries that I've seen.I've seen what Iran has done with their roadside bombs to our troops. I've seen people with no legs and with no arms. I've seen people that were horribly, horribly injured in that area, that war—in fact, many cases put—those bombs put there by Soleimani, who is no longer with us. I consider them to be really bad injuries.No, I do not consider that to be bad injuries. No.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, is it true that the White House is holding up the coronavirus bill over language regarding the FBI building? [SEP] Well, I'm not sure about it being in *this* particular bill, but the FBI definitely needs a new building. The current one is falling apart, a real disaster. It's not safe! And frankly, it should be near the Justice Department. We're exploring all options, but a new building is essential.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: So, Mr. President, is there any actual news in your statement today? [SEP] Next question.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. What do you mean by that? [SEP] ——if they're not going to approve a bill and the Post Office, therefore, won't have the money, and if they're not going to approve a big bill, a bigger bill, and they're not going to have the $3½ billion dollars for the universal mail-in votes, how can you have those votes?What it would mean is, the people will have to go to the polls and vote, like the old days—like 2 years ago, 3 years ago, 4 years ago.
