They have to go to the—it doesn't say anybody is taking the vote away, but it means that the universal mail-ins don't work. Absentees do work. It's a very different thing—an absentee—where you make an application, and you send it in, they send you a vote. It's different.But—so, Kaitlan, I'm not saying anything wrong with voting. I want them to vote. But that would mean that they'd have to go to a voting booth, like they used to, and vote.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, to clarify, were you personally informed of the airborne transmission possibility in February? [SEP] The reports were conflicting, frankly. Some suggested airborne, others didn't. We were monitoring the situation very closely. I acted on the best information available at the time to keep the country calm.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, are you worried that your Venezuela policy has stalled, given Maduro's continued grip on power? [SEP] I'm not being given a specific timeframe. They've been there a long time. Eventually, things will change. We haven't implemented the toughest sanctions yet. We have all options available. We're focused on helping the people who are starving and dying. It's a tragedy. Venezuela used to be rich, now it's poor, with no food, water, or power. It's very sad.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Sir, Mr. President, after 3½ years, do you regret, at all, all the lying you've done to the American people on everything? [SEP] All the what?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Russia, what's your assessment of Dmitry Medvedev's power relative to Putin, and what advice would you give your successor regarding the Russian threat? [SEP] Medvedev is a bit of a mystery to me, frankly. The real question is who shows up at the G-8 representing Russia; that might give us a clue about their foreign policy direction post-Putin. As for my successor, they'll need to navigate a complex relationship. We need Russia on board with things like non-proliferation and Iran. Remember when Putin offered to supply enriched uranium to Iran, removing their need to enrich it themselves? That was constructive. Missile defense in Europe is another area where we need to find common ground. Ultimately, it's in our national interest to maintain a working relationship, even if we disagree, like on Kosovo. So, I hope to leave my successor with a foundation for that relationship.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, you've been a strong advocate for equality and opportunity. However, with the change in administration, many fear a rollback of these gains. Reflecting on your commitment to closing the gaps, what are the most pressing rights issues that remain unresolved? What role do you envision playing in addressing these issues after your presidency? And, as the first African American President, what are your thoughts on the prospect of another Black President in the future? [SEP] Well, let me start with that last question. I am absolutely certain that we will continue to see talented individuals from every walk of life rise to positions of leadership in this country. That's what makes America so strong – when everyone has a fair shot at success. I've often used the analogy of our Olympic teams. Their incredible diversity is a testament to our nation's potential. You see athletes of all shapes, sizes, and colors achieving greatness. This genetic diversity is a tremendous asset. Just look at Simone Biles and Michael Phelps – vastly different individuals, yet both champions in their respective fields. And it's worth noting that women consistently win a significant portion of our medals, a direct result of Title IX, which has provided them with unparalleled opportunities in sports.So, if we remain committed to ensuring equal opportunity for all, I have no doubt that we will see a woman President, a Latino President, a Jewish President, a Hindu President – the possibilities are endless. Perhaps even a President of mixed heritage that defies easy categorization. That's perfectly fine.As for my concerns, I addressed many of these in my Farewell Address, so I won't reiterate them all here. However, inequality remains a significant challenge. If we fail to invest in ensuring that everyone can participate fully in the economy, we risk hindering economic growth and exacerbating divisions among Americans, not just along racial lines. Many individuals voted for the President-elect because they feel marginalized and forgotten, believing that their children will not have the same opportunities they once had.We must avoid a situation where a small elite thrives while the majority struggles for scraps. This breeds resentment and can amplify racial tensions, as people begin to believe that the only way to advance is by taking something from someone else who looks or worships differently. This is not a recipe for a healthy democracy.I am also deeply concerned about the fundamental mechanisms of our democracy. We stand alone among advanced nations in making it more difficult, rather than easier, to vote. This has a long and troubling history that we must confront honestly.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to the visa issue with Romania, many feel it's unfair that they face restrictions despite being a strong ally. Can you provide a concrete timeline for when Romanians can expect visa-free travel to the United States? [SEP] Look, the Romanian President brought up the visa issue, and I heard him loud and clear. He's a good friend, and he's not afraid to tell me what he thinks. The Romanian people's frustrations are understandable, especially given their support in Iraq. I tried to get Congress to fix the visa laws, but they didn't go far enough. We're committed to working with Romania to find a solution that respects our laws and their needs. We want to make it easier for Romanians to visit family, but we also have to be vigilant about security. The new law should help, and we'll continue to work together. This is a priority, and we're doing everything we can to address it.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. So there's no news in your statement today? [SEP] Chuck Todd [NBC News].
label: Dodging

sentence: Thank you. Regarding the border, but first, a quick word on busing. Is it a good way to integrate schools? And does that have anything to do with the policy you're about to share? [SEP] It's been around. Not many ways to get kids to school. It's been done. Sometimes not nicely. But it's a main way. Biden answered differently, it'd be different. They went after him on that.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given that Congress is seeking $6 billion more than your administration has proposed, what is the maximum amount you are willing to allocate to address the current crisis? [SEP] We'll see what happens, but we're going to take care of the states. They're working very hard, setting up hospitals and quarantine areas. We're working really well with them. It's a big part of it. So, if Congress wants to give us the money, we'll take it. It wasn't easy for the wall, but we got that done. We'll just do a good job with it.
label: General

sentence: Q. Yes. And will you talk about Georgia in a meeting with Mr.—with President Putin? [SEP] Well, they were here. They made a very favorable impression. And we listened to their plight. It's a tough situation with Georgia. But they made a very fair verbal impression in the room. Okay?Yes, go ahead. Go. Go. One more. Go ahead.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with the U.S. advocating for a free and open Indo-Pacific while engaging with China, how do you navigate potential conflicts? Mr. Prime Minister, did your talks with the President include Japan's role in defending against North Korean missiles, and what are your plans for Japan's defense capabilities? [SEP] The Prime Minister is doing a terrific job. He's buying a lot of military equipment from the United States. The best equipment in the world. He'll be able to defend his country. As for China, we have a great relationship with President Xi, but they've been taking advantage of us for years. The trade deficit is massive. It's unfair. We need reciprocal trade. If they charge us a tariff, we charge them the same tariff. It's very simple. We're working on it. It takes time, but we're getting it done. You'll see a big difference. Now, regarding Japan's defense, they're buying a lot of equipment from us. They're going to be very well defended. Very safe. Thank you.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Critics argue the Keystone pipeline primarily benefits Canadian oil, creates few permanent US jobs, and exacerbates climate change. How do you justify supporting a project with such downsides? [SEP] Well, first off, let's not fall for the false narrative that this pipeline is just a handout to Canada. It's a strategic investment in North American energy independence. Sure, Canada benefits, but so do we. As for jobs, construction creates opportunities, and the refined product supports industries across the US. And on climate change, we're committed to responsible development and mitigation. It's about balancing economic needs with environmental stewardship.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, does President Zelenskyy need to concede any Ukrainian territory to achieve a cease-fire with Russia, or is that completely out of the question? Also, should Russia be removed from the G-20? [SEP] Regarding the latter, yes. It depends on the G-20. I raised this today. If Indonesia and others disagree, we should allow both to attend the meetings as observers. What was the first question again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, ABC News is reporting that Iran is on track to have a nuclear weapon within two years. Are you aware of any evidence that supports the claim that Iran is accelerating its nuclear program? [SEP] I must admit, I am not aware of the specific report you are referring to. However, I do share the concern that Iran intends to acquire a nuclear weapon. I firmly believe that if they were to have a nuclear weapon, it would be a seriously destabilizing influence in the Middle East. And therefore, we have worked to build an international coalition to try to convince the Iranians to give up their weapon, to make it clear that they have choices to make—whether the choice be isolation or missed opportunity to grow their economies. And so we take your— we take seriously the attempts of the Iranians to gain a nuclear weapon.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. This morning you said that you do not want to fund the U.S. Postal Service because Democrats are trying to expand voting by mail. So I've got two questions for you. One, are you threatening to veto any legislation that includes funding for the Post Office? [SEP] No, not at all. No.
label: Explicit

sentence: A growing number of troops are on repeat deployments to Iraq, and reports suggest declining morale. One infantry commander told me troops are increasingly questioning their purpose there. Does this surprise you? Are you aware of this? Is it a minority or growing sentiment, and does it concern you? [SEP] What I'm hearing from commanders is that the real concern is with the families back home. Our troops, who volunteered to serve, are willing to go back into combat, but their families are the ones struggling. I understand that, and that's why I make a point of thanking them. You're talking to specific people, or maybe just one person. I'm talking to the commanders. Their job is to tell me what's happening on the ground. I know there's concern back home. I haven't heard major concerns about troop morale in Iraq.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Indian American community outreach by Kimberly and Don Jr., would they and Ivanka Trump be campaigning on your behalf with your views on the India-U.S. relationship? [SEP] I didn't catch all of that, but I know India, great country. Those young people, they're fantastic, and they have a great connection to India, just like I do. Prime Minister Modi, he's a friend, doing a tremendous job, not easy. And speaking of the region, China and India, they're having quite the border situation, very nasty. We're ready to help if we can, talking to both sides. But yes, I appreciate the support, they think highly of India, and so do I. And I think the world of your Prime Minister.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. And you're not satisfied with where you are now? [SEP] Absolutely not. I wouldn't be satisfied as long as I'm meeting somebody who has a—doesn't have a job and wants one. I'm not going to be satisfied as long as there's a kid who writes me a letter and says, I've got $60,000 worth of debt, and I don't know how to pay it back. And the American people aren't satisfied. So I want to do everything I can to deliver for them.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the benchmarks set for the Iraqi government, could you elaborate on why Prime Minister Maliki was absent from yesterday's press conference with General Casey and Ambassador Khalilzad? Wouldn't his presence have underscored the close collaboration between our nations? [SEP] Elaine, your guess is as good as mine. I wasn't in charge of the guest list.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. And regarding direct negotiations, sir? [SEP] I'd prefer not to comment on that at this time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, a simple question: Will you put the Houthis back on the terror list? And what specific actions are you taking to end the war in Yemen, given your initial promise to do so? [SEP] We are actively considering the Houthi designation. Resolving the conflict in Yemen is a priority, but it requires the cooperation of all parties. It's a difficult situation.
label: Deflection

sentence: Valentinovna, Sputnik News Agency. Mr. President, were North Korean nuclear site inspections a topic during your discussions? [SEP] Could you please project a bit more? And where exactly are you from?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the current political climate, what message do you have for those protesting against recent events? Have you advised your successor on the importance of selecting qualified staff? And in your final weeks in office, is there anything you can do to stop the bombing of Aleppo? Chancellor Merkel, given the differing opinions on Trump, what is your message to the American people? [SEP] Well, a fundamental aspect of our democracy is the right to protest. I've been the subject of protests during my time in office, as have many presidents before me. So, I wouldn't tell people who feel strongly about the issues raised during the campaign to be silent. What I would advise, and have advised, is that elections matter, voting matters, organizing matters, being informed on the issues matters. I consistently tell young people, both in the U.S. and abroad, don't take our systems of government and way of life for granted. Because we've lived in a relatively stable and peaceful era, with improving living standards, there's a tendency to assume it will always be this way. But it's not. Democracy is hard work. In the U.S., if 43 percent of eligible voters don't vote, democracy is weakened. If we're not serious about facts, especially in an age of social media where information is consumed in soundbites, if we can't distinguish between serious arguments and propaganda, we have problems. If people, regardless of their political leanings, are unwilling to compromise and demonize opponents, democracy will break down. So, my advice is to understand the foundations of a healthy democracy and how to engage in citizenship continuously, not just when something upsets us or during an election. It's hard work. The good news is, many young people who were involved in my campaigns continue to be involved in work, both politically and through nonprofits, that can carry this hard work forward. But there's sometimes complacency. Here in Europe, many young people forget the Cold War and the significance of the Berlin Wall. And I'll be honest, I've heard rhetoric in Europe that draws a false equivalence between the U.S. and Russia, and between how our governments operate versus other governments. Those distinctions are important. I've said many times that, like any government, we have flaws, we've operated imperfectly, we've made mistakes. There are times when I've made mistakes or our administration hasn't always aligned with our values. It's a work of constant improvement. But I can say to the German people that the U.S. has been good for Germany, has looked out for Germany, has provided security for Germany, has helped to rebuild Germany and unify Germany. And across Europe, many principles taken for granted here – free speech, civil liberties, an independent judiciary, and fighting corruption – are principles that, not perfectly, but generally, we've tried to apply not just in our own country, but also in our foreign policy. That should be remembered. Because in an age of active misinformation, packaged attractively and appearing the same on Facebook or TV, where overzealousness by a U.S. official is equated with constant and severe repression elsewhere, if everything seems the same and no distinctions are made, we won't know what to protect. We won't know what to fight for. And we can lose so much of what we've gained in terms of democratic freedoms, market-based economies, and prosperity that we've come to take for granted. That was a rather lengthy response, wasn't it? I seem to have lost track of the initial question.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering your successor's recent communications with Taiwan's leader and his subsequent remarks about the 'One China' policy, coupled with escalating tensions and China's actions in the South China Sea, do you believe a reassessment of our China strategy is warranted? What are your thoughts on the implications of a phone call with the Taiwanese President, and are you concerned that such unconventional tactics could escalate into conflict with our primary geopolitical competitor? [SEP] Well, that's a great question. I'm somewhere in between. I think all of our foreign policy should be subject to fresh eyes. I think one of the—I've said this before—I am very proud of the work I've done. I think I'm a better President now than when I started. But if you're here for 8 years in the bubble, you start seeing things a certain way, and you benefit from—the democracy benefits, America benefits from some new perspectives. And I think it should be not just the prerogative, but the obligation of a new President, to examine everything that's been done and see what makes sense and what doesn't. That's what I did when I came in, and I'm assuming any new President is going to undertake those same exercises. And given the importance of the relationship between the United States and China, given how much is at stake in terms of the world economy, national security, our presence in the Asia-Pacific, China's increasing role in international affairs—there's probably no bilateral relationship that carries more significance and where there's also the potential if that relationship breaks down or goes into a full-conflict mode, that everybody is worse off. So I think it's fine for him to take a look at it. What I've advised the President-elect is that across the board on foreign policy, you want to make sure that you're doing it in a systematic, deliberate, intentional way. And since there's only one President at a time, my advice to him has been that before he starts having a lot of interactions with foreign governments other than the usual courtesy calls, that he should want to have his full team in place, that he should want his team to be fully briefed on what's gone on in the past and where the potential pitfalls may be, where the opportunities are, what we've learned from 8 years of experience, so that as he's then maybe taking foreign policy in a new direction, he's got all the information to make good decisions and, by the way, that all of Government is moving at the same time and singing from the same hymnal. And with respect to China—and let's just take the example of Taiwan—there has been a longstanding agreement, essentially, between China, the United States, and to some degree, the Taiwanese, which is to not change the status quo. Taiwan operates differently than mainline—mainland China does. China views Taiwan as part of China, but recognizes that it has to approach Taiwan as an entity that has its own ways of doing things. The Taiwanese have agreed that as long as they're able to continue to function with some degree of autonomy, that they won't charge forward and declare independence. And that status quo, although not completely satisfactory to any of the parties involved, has kept the peace and allowed the Taiwanese to be a pretty successful and—economy and a people who have a high degree of self-determination. But understand, for China, the issue of Taiwan is as important as anything on their docket. The idea of one China is at the heart of their conception as a nation. And so if you are going to upend this understanding, you have to have thought through what are the consequences are, because the Chinese will not treat that the way they'll treat some other issues. They won't even treat it the way they treat issues around the South China Sea, where we've had a lot of tensions. This goes to the core of how they see themselves. And their reaction on this issue could end up being very significant. That doesn't mean that you have to adhere to everything that's been done in the past. It does mean that you've got to think it through and have planned for potential reactions that they may engage in. All right. Isaac Dovere of Politico.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you mentioned the prospect that your successor would be dealing with the war. You'll be making your first trip to Vietnam in roughly a week. Some people are still—are looking at the war as another Vietnam war. Are they wrong to do so? And if so, why? [SEP] I think they are. I think they are. First of all, Iraq is—after the overthrow of the tyrant, voted on a Constitution that is intended to unite the whole country. And then they had elections under that Constitution, where nearly 12 million people voted for this unity Government. Secondly—which is different from Vietnam.Secondly, in terms of our troops, this is a volunteer army. Vietnam wasn't a volunteer army, as you know. And in this Volunteer Army, the troops understand the consequences of Iraq and the global war on terror. That's why reenlistment rates are up, and that's why enlistment is high.Thirdly, the support for our troops is strong here in the United States, and it wasn't during the Vietnam era. So I see differences; I really do. And you hear all the time, Well, this may be a civil war. Well, I don't believe it is, and the Maliki Government doesn't believe it is. Zal, our Ambassador, doesn't believe it is. But we've got to make sure it isn't by implementing a strategy which helps—a politics strategy which helps unify the country and a security strategy that makes sure that the Iraqis are better capable of fighting off the extremists and the radicals that want to stop progress in Iraq.So I don't think it is a parallel.Mike [Michael Allen, Time].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. But just—my original question, sir, was: Do you have a deadline for imposing the 325? [SEP] No, I have no deadline. My deadline is what's up here. We'll figure out the deadline.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering your emphasis on direct dialogue and your concerns about Russia and China, and given your frequent interactions with President Xi, will you contact him, as an old friend, to request that China permit WHO investigators to enter China to investigate the source of COVID-19? [SEP] Let's get one thing straight. We know each other, but we are not old friends. This is purely a business arrangement.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, a year after Democrats assumed control of Congress, you initially expressed a desire for bipartisan cooperation. However, your comments today paint a less optimistic picture. How would you assess your own efforts to collaborate with Democrats over the past year? How effective have you been in fostering bipartisan cooperation, and do you feel you've succeeded in identifying areas of common ground? [SEP] We're finding common ground on Iraq. I recognize there are people in Congress that say we shouldn't have been there in the first place. But it sounds to me as if the debate has shifted, that General Petraeus and Ambassador Crocker's testimony made a difference to a lot of Members. I hope we continue to find ground by making sure our troops get funded. We found common ground on FISA. My only question is, why change a good law? The way that law was written works for the security of the country. That's what the American people want to know, by the way. Are we passing laws that are beneficial to the American people? This law is beneficial because it enables our intelligence experts to find out the intentions of Al Qaida. Now, the law needs to be changed, enhanced by providing the phone companies that allegedly helped us with liability protection. So we found common ground there. Hopefully, we can find common ground as the Congress begins to move pieces of legislation. The reason I said what I said today is, there's a lot to be done. As you recognize, I'm not a member of the legislative branch; probably wouldn't be a very good legislator. But as the head of the executive branch, it makes sense to call upon Congress to show progress and get results. It's hard to find common ground unless important bills are moving. They're not even moving. And not one appropriations bill has made it to my desk. How can you find common ground when there's no appropriations process? We found common ground on a trade bill--trade bills, really important pieces of legislation, as far as I'm concerned. One of the reasons why is, exports helped us overcome the weakness in the housing market last quarter. If that's the case, it seems like it makes sense to continue and open up markets to goods and services. And yet there hadn't been one--there haven't been any bills moving when it comes to trade. Veterans Affairs is an area where we can find common ground. I've called in--I asked Bob Dole and Donna Shalala to lead an important Commission, a Commission to make sure our veterans get the benefits they deserve. I was concerned about bureaucratic delay and the--concerned about a system that had been in place for years, but this didn't recognize this different nature--a different kind of war that we're fighting. I don't like it when I meet wives who are sitting by--beside their husbands' bed in Walter Reed and not being supported by its Government, not being helped to provide care. I'm concerned about PTSD, and I want people to focus on PTSD. And so we sent up a bill, and I hope they move on it quickly. There's a place where we can find common ground.
label: General

sentence: President Biden, you've spoken about the threat of chemical weapons. Has your administration received intelligence suggesting Putin is planning to deploy or use them? And what would be the U.S. and NATO's response to such an action? [SEP] I can't discuss intelligence matters. But let me reiterate: the use of chemical weapons is a serious red line. We would respond decisively. The specifics of our response would depend on the context of the situation. Next question.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Following the leaks exposing U.S. surveillance of South Korea, were these revelations addressed during your discussions with President Biden? Did he offer any assurances regarding this matter? [SEP] Regarding that situation, our nations are engaged in ongoing communication, exchanging pertinent details. An inquiry is underway within the United States, introducing multifaceted variables. We must allow sufficient time for the U.S. investigation to conclude. We intend to maintain communication on this subject. This will be the final inquiry I entertain.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, the Washington Post reported earlier that the White House is stalling the GOP coronavirus bill, demanding it include wording about the FBI building in downtown DC. Is that correct? [SEP] Look, I'm not positive whether they're putting it in *this* bill, but the FBI needs a new building, period. The current one is ancient, poorly constructed, and frankly, a safety hazard! Panels are falling off, concrete's crumbling. They considered moving it way out of DC, but I told them it has to be near the Justice Department. The current location is the best. So, I've been pushing for a new building. Renovation is a waste of time. Picture a top-notch building, maybe even with a running track on top – FBI agents are athletes! So, whether it's in this bill or another, we're going to get the FBI a new building. Believe me.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Biden, following up on the Ukraine situation, is there a specific threshold of Russian aggression that would trigger the promised sanctions? Or is the response dependent on factors beyond a simple invasion? [SEP] I appreciate the inquiry.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And I'm not trying to play gotcha, but I wonder, when you look back over the long arc of your Presidency, do you think, in retrospect, that you have made any mistakes? And if so, what is the single biggest mistake that you may have made? [SEP] Gotcha. Hey, look, I have often said that history will look back and determine that which could have been done better, or you know, mistakes I made. Clearly, putting a Mission Accomplished on a aircraft carrier was a mistake. It sent the wrong message. We were trying to say something differently, but nevertheless, it conveyed a different message. Obviously, some of my rhetoric has been a mistake.I've thought long and hard about Katrina, you know, could I have done something differently, like land Air Force One either in New Orleans or Baton Rouge. The problem with that and—is that law enforcement would have been pulled away from the mission. And then your questions, I suspect, would have been, How could you possibly have flown Air Force One into Baton Rouge, and police officers that were needed to expedite traffic out of New Orleans were taken off the task to look after you?I believe that running the Social Security idea right after the '04 elections was a mistake. I should have argued for immigration reform. And the reason why is, is that— you know, one of the lessons I learned as Governor of Texas, by the way, is legislative branches tend to be risk averse. In other words, sometimes legislatures have the tendency to ask, Why should I take on a hard task when a crisis is not imminent? And the crisis was not imminent for Social Security, as far as many Members of Congress was concerned.As an aside, one thing I proved is that you can actually campaign on the issue and get elected. In other words, I don't believe talking about Social Security is the third rail of American politics. I, matter of fact, think that in the future, not talking about how you intend to fix Social Security is going to be the third rail of American politics.And the one thing about the Presidency is that you can make—only make decisions, you know, on the information at hand. You don't get to have information after you've made the decision. That's not the way it works. And you stand by your decisions, and you do your best to explain why you made the decisions you made.There have been disappointments. Abu Ghraib obviously was a huge disappointment during the Presidency. Not having weapons of mass destruction was a significant disappointment. I don't know if you want to call those mistakes or not, but they were—things didn't go according to plan, let's put it that way.And anyway, I think historians will look back, and they'll be able to have a better look at mistakes after some time has passed. I—along Jake's question, there is no such thing as short-term history. I don't think you can possibly get the full breadth of an administration until time has passed. Where does a President's—did a President's decisions have the impact that he thought they would, or he thought they would over time? Or how did this President compare to future Presidents, given a set of circumstances that may be similar or not similar? I mean, there's—it's just impossible to do. And I'm comfortable with that.Yes, Mike [Michael Abramowitz, Washington Post].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Okay. And then, I wanted to ask you, you congratulated Marjorie Taylor Greene in a tweet. You called her a future Republican star. Greene has been a proponent of the QAnon conspiracy theory. She said that's something that should be—would be worth listening to. Do you agree with her on that? [SEP] Well, she did very well in the election. She won by a lot. She was very popular. She comes from a great State. And she had a tremendous victory, so absolutely, I did congratulate her.Please. Go ahead.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, shouldn't the Iranian regime be held accountable for its actions? [SEP] I've answered the question, Chuck. We're still assessing the situation. Moving on.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, could you share the specific request you made regarding Afghanistan and the U.S. troop deployment? [SEP] Interestingly, he initiated the discussion about Afghanistan, expressing his desire for continued peace. I pointed out that his involvement was crucial. He indicated a willingness to help with Afghanistan—I won't go into the specifics just yet—and also with Iran. We then detailed our plans for bringing security and economic stability to Syria and Libya. So, that's what we covered.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, about Cuba, given their past behavior, what's your perspective on Fidel Castro's involvement in the discussions with Raul? Did you mention Fidel during your talks, and will you personally intervene with Congress to ensure the embassy funding isn't blocked? [SEP] We need to move on. This is taking up too much of our time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you very much, Mr. President. You noted your disappointment with Chinese actions on climate in Rome and also the lack of willingness for Chinese President Xi Jinping to show up at either the G-20 or COP26.But I wanted to ask more broadly: When you assess where things stand right now in U.S.-China relationships after your first 10 months in office—your diplomats have had difficulty engaging in a substantive manner with some of their counterparts; you have a Chinese military that has tested a hypersonic missile this summer and is building its nuclear capability—what is your general assessment of where things stand? And are you concerned that the potential for armed conflict has grown over the course of your first 10 months in office? [SEP] Well, let me start off by addressing the first part of—if not the question, the statement. And that is that I indicated that China and Russia not showing up—and Saudi Arabia—was a problem. We showed up. We showed up. And by showing up, we've had a profound impact on the way I think the rest of the world is looking at the United States and its leadership role.I think it's been a big mistake, quite frankly, for China—with respect to China not showing up. The rest of the world is going to look to China and say, What value added are they providing? And they've lost an ability to influence people around the world and all the people here at COP—the same way, I would argue, with regard to Russia.With regard to the more profound question about do I—am I worried about an armed conflict or some—that accidentally occurring with China: No, I'm not. But I have had, as I've said before—and I think we've talked about this, Phil, but I may be mistaken—that I think, as I've said, I look at China—and I've had hours of conversations with Xi Jinping, both in person when I was Vice President and since I've been President, at least 5 or 6 hours' worth of conversations on the telephone, and I'm going to be having a virtual summit with him—I've made it clear: This does—this is competition; it does not have to be conflict. There is no reason there needs to be conflict.But I've also indicated to him, and I've—so I don't—I'm not reluctant to say it publicly—that we expect him to play by the rules of the road. We're not going to change our attitude toward what constitutes international airspace, international sea lanes, et cetera.We also have made it clear that we have to work on dealing with things like cybersecurity and a whole range of other issues. But I'm not looking for, I don't anticipate there will be a need for—to be—there be physical conflict. But you know, as you've heard me say this before—my dad had an expression. He'd say, The only conflict worse than the one that's intended is one that's unintended—one that's unintended.And so, in my meetings with him virtually coming up—we haven't set the exact date yet—I want to make sure there's no misunderstanding. It's competition, not conflict. And so there's no—no unintended.Yes, Peter [Peter Alexander, NBC News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, now that you've selected a site for your Presidential library, you'll need to raise funds for its construction. Reports suggest you're aiming for as much as $200 million. Is that accurate? Do you believe the public has a right to know who's donating such large sums to their President? Will you disclose contributions as they're received? And will you impose any limitations on who can donate and how much they can give? [SEP] No, yes, maybe, we'll see. Look, I haven't seen the final figures yet, and as Donnie Evans, the foundation chair, has said, we'll follow the disclosure rules as appropriate. Some people like to give anonymously, for various reasons, and we'll take that into account. What was the other thing you asked?
label: Clarification

sentence: You've stated that your 'microphone' is now more powerful regarding key domestic issues such as Social Security and immigration, despite past efforts not achieving desired outcomes. With the Democratic Congress now in control, how will you amplify your message and achieve different results? [SEP] When I say 'loud microphone,' I mean I can help focus people's attention on important issues. That's the President's role. But getting things done requires bipartisan cooperation, which the elections showed. We've had a pretty successful few years legislatively. We reformed Medicare, created tax policies that encourage economic growth, passed trade deals, and a comprehensive energy bill. I'm signing another energy bill today, extending tax credits for R&D. It's a substantial record. However, with the Democrats now in charge, we need a different approach. I'll work with their leaders and our own to find common ground on Social Security and immigration. We absolutely must pass comprehensive immigration reform this year. To secure our border, Border Patrol needs a plan allowing temporary legal work for those doing jobs Americans won't. Recent enforcement actions at packing plants showed many illegal workers using forged documents. This system forces people to rely on smugglers and forgers. It's inhumane. The best way to enforce our borders humanely is with comprehensive reform. I've proposed a plan and spoken about it from the Oval Office. The 'microphone' is necessary to call people to action. I want to work with both Republicans and Democrats. On energy, we can also cooperate. There's consensus on researching alternative energy. We're making progress. I'm looking forward to working with them. Some say losing Congress means nothing will get done. I disagree. I want to get things done, and the Democratic leaders want to prove their leadership. We can find common ground without compromising principles. The American people are tired of the partisanship and name-calling. I'll do my part to elevate the tone. I was Governor of Texas with a Democratic legislature, and we got things done. It's possible here too.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, will this conflict be resolved before your term ends? And what is your assessment of Israel's actions? [SEP] My goal is a lasting cease-fire. That requires Hamas to cease firing rockets into Israel. Continued rocket fire makes a sustainable cease-fire unattainable. The decision rests with Hamas. We're collaborating with Egypt to halt the flow of arms into Gaza, which enables Hamas's attacks. Nations providing weapons to Hamas must stop, and the international community must exert pressure. Hamas must disarm. Neighboring countries must curb smuggling. It's challenging, with tunnels and opportunities for those seeking to undermine democracy to supply weapons. Could you repeat the second part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. He was armed, Mr. President? [SEP] That's what I understand. I don't know. You'll have to ask them that.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, the public seems confused by the coronavirus response. Why are you satisfied with your team, given the confusing messages? [SEP] The messages are confusing because the scientists are learning more. It's like polio; things changed. This is a brand new virus. The vaccine was amazing. Did everything go right? No. I'm talking too much.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering Russia's skepticism about the missile defense system, what specific measures will you take to alleviate their concerns and foster cooperation on global security? [SEP] We're open to exploring joint exercises, information sharing, and even joint development of missile defense technologies. The goal is to demonstrate that this system is not a threat to Russia, but rather a tool for protecting all of us from common threats. We're also committed to engaging in honest dialogue and addressing their concerns in a transparent and constructive manner.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the economic initiatives you've presented, why introduce them now amidst a heated political campaign? Critics allege it's a purely political maneuver. Furthermore, why the avoidance of the term 'stimulus' when discussing infrastructure spending, considering the unpopularity of the original stimulus package? [SEP] When I first entered office, we faced an economy on the verge of collapse. We implemented a plan that economists widely agree averted a depression. A third of that plan involved tax cuts. We haven't waited until now to take action. We've enacted tax cuts for small businesses eight times in the last 18 months. These actions have made a tangible difference. Three million individuals have jobs that wouldn't exist otherwise. The economy would be in a significantly worse condition. However, we're not yet where we need to be. Therefore, what additional steps can we take? Our proposals have historically enjoyed bipartisan support: a research and development tax credit, accelerated business depreciation. Regarding infrastructure, we're expanding the highway bill. We're rebuilding America. We'll fund these initiatives by ending tax breaks for companies that ship jobs overseas. These are commonsense approaches. Historically, Republicans and Democrats have found common ground on infrastructure and R&D. Let's move forward. It's not that the previous stimulus was ineffective. It had a positive impact. It simply hasn't achieved the desired level of progress. We have a long way to go.
label: Deflection

sentence: Are you facing a deadline from Congress this fall regarding the war? [SEP] I appreciate the Members coming to the White House for a good exchange. I shared my feelings about the Iraqi issue, discussing the implications of both failure and success. They expressed their concerns about the Iraq war, which are widely shared. I reminded them that last fall, polls showed widespread disapproval of the situation in Iraq. I, too, would have disapproved at that time. That's why I implemented a plan to improve the situation. I explained my decision-making process and emphasized that General Petraeus has a plan that some Members of Congress are hindering. It's illogical to unanimously confirm him and then deny him the resources needed to succeed. We must give General Petraeus a chance. He will report back to the Secretary, the Joint Chiefs, the White House, and Congress on the effectiveness of the strategy. We will then respond accordingly. Decisions about our posture in Iraq must be based on conditions on the ground, and General Petraeus is best suited to assess those conditions. Upon his recommendation, along with the Secretary and the Joint Chiefs, we will respond. Let's wait and see what happens and give this plan a chance to work. Let's avoid playing politics and support our troops. It's one thing to have an honest debate about Iraq, but it's another to involve our troops in that debate. They deserve the necessary funding and flexibility. This cause is necessary and noble, which is why I deployed them in the first place. It's essential for our nation's peace and security. It's noble that these citizens volunteer to serve. Congress must support them. While debating strategies is acceptable, ensuring timely funding is crucial. Funding our troops every two months is inadequate and unacceptable. They need what the military has requested. We can and should debate Iraq, but funding our troops should not be debated. Thank you for your time.
label: General

sentence: Given the historical complexities surrounding the one-China policy, Mr. President, what specific mechanisms or safeguards did you recommend to your successor to prevent misinterpretations or miscalculations that could inadvertently escalate tensions between the United States and China? [SEP] The key is proactive, consistent communication at all levels. We need to ensure that our intentions are clearly understood and that we are prepared to address any concerns or misunderstandings that may arise. Regular dialogues, both formal and informal, are essential for maintaining stability and preventing unintended consequences. It's also crucial to have a strong, experienced team in place that understands the nuances of the relationship and can provide sound advice.
label: General

sentence: Regarding Ukraine, shouldn't Germany be providing more military aid, and should they reconsider Nord Stream 2 given the Russian threat? [SEP] Germany is a very reliable partner. They're one of our most important allies. They've been a major financial contributor to Ukraine. As for the US media criticism, I don't buy it. Germany is completely reliable. We're united. They are making a large contribution to Ukraine.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And normalizing relations? [SEP] Normalizing relations is something that I would expect to do, I would hope to do, when everything is complete. We would certainly hope to do that.I know that Prime Minister Abe and President Moon have told me, very strongly, that they are going to go and they will help them economically, tremendously. Japan has a tremendous stake, and so do they. We, on the other hand, are very far away. We're very, very far away.But Japan will be helping. I believe China will be helping economically, also. And I think China wants to see something very good happen, very positive happen. And certainly, South Korea has already stated their intentions. They will be very helpful.So there are lot of good factors lined up for . A lot of tremendous factors that give it tremendous potential. It has tremendous potential because the people are great. And we would certainly like to see normalization, yes.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, about Yemen, you promised to end the war. But now the UAE wants the Houthis back on the terror list. Are you gonna do that, and how are you actually gonna end the war? [SEP] We're looking at it. And to end a war, you need both sides to play ball. It's gonna be tough. Yeah.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, thank you very much. Two questions. One is, you had talked about leaders who had called to congratulate you. Did President Putin call to congratulate you? And will you, in fact, meet with him at lunch this coming weekend? [SEP] Well, as I understand it, we're having—and I guess a lot of you are going over. We're having a lunch for numerous countries. I'll be there. I believe President Putin is going to be there. We don't have anything scheduled. I don't think we have anything scheduled in Paris. And I'm coming back very quickly.We're going over—there's a great event. This is an important—really, it's going to be very important and, I think, a very beautiful ceremony. I'm looking forward to going. And we're representing the incredible heroes of the world, but the heroes of our country from World War I. And so I'll be going there, and I am very proud to go there.
label: Explicit

sentence: Major, the question remains: without military enforcement, how can we truly prevent the Assad regime from using chemical weapons, especially given their past actions? [SEP] Well, the critical thing to understand is, we've been very clear with Assad. We sent strong messages, not just directly, but through other countries. And, frankly, it didn't work. But we're not just sitting here twiddling our thumbs. We're talking to our allies, listening to Congress. If someone has a better idea, I'm all ears. Now, I'll take one more question.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Will it bring down prices. And the war has pushed prices up. They could go as high as $200 a barrel, some analysts think. How long is it fair to expect American drivers and drivers around the world to pay that premium for this war? [SEP] As long as it takes so Russia cannot, in fact, defeat Ukraine and move beyond Ukraine. This is a critical, critical position for the world. Here we are. Why do we have NATO?I told Putin that, in fact, if he were to move, we would move to strengthen NATO. We would move to strengthen us—strengthen NATO across the board.Look, let me explain the price—I suggested a while ago that what we should consider doing is putting a cap on the amount of money that we would pay for—the world would pay for Russian oil, and that we would not—there would—we would not provide—the West provides insurance—would not insure Russian ships carrying oil. We would not provide insurance for them, so they would have great difficulty getting customers.The point is that we've said to them, Here's the deal: We're going to allow you to have a profit on what you make, but not the exorbitant prices that you're charging for the oil now. We've delegated a commission—a group of our—[inaudible]—sherpa—our national security people to sit down and work out that mechanism. We think it can be done. We think it can be done, and it would drive down the price of oil, and it would drive down the price of gasoline as well.In addition, at home, I have also called for changes. We've—I've released a million barrels of oil per day from our oil reserve, and—in addition to getting other nations to move forward—a total of 240 million barrels of oil to release from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. Number one.Number two, I've asked Congress would they, in fact, go and end the—temporarily end the tax on gasoline at the pump. And thirdly, to ask the States to do the same thing.If we do these things, it's estimated we could bring down, tomorrow, if they—if Congress agreed and the States agreed, we could bring down the price of oil about a dollar a gallon at the pump, in that range. And so we could have immediate relief in terms of the reduction of the—of the elimination of—temporary elimination of the gas tax.And so I think there's a lot of things we can do and we will do. But the bottom line is, ultimately, the reason why gas prices are up is because of Russia. Russia, Russia, Russia. The reason why the food crisis exists is because of Russia: Russia not allowing grain to get out of Ukraine.And so that's the way in which I think we should move, and I think it would have a positive impact on the price at the pump as well.Jordan Fabian, Bloomberg.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, the international coalition supporting Ukraine has been a cornerstone of your foreign policy. What specific steps will your administration take to ensure its continued unity and effectiveness in the face of potential challenges in the coming year? [SEP] Well, let me just say, the strength of our alliances is paramount. We're constantly engaged in dialogue with our partners, reinforcing our shared commitment to sovereignty and territorial integrity. I'm supremely confident that our collective resolve will only deepen as we navigate the complexities ahead. It's a dynamic situation, of course, but our dedication remains unwavering. I'm not at all worried about holding the alliance together in NATO and European Union, as well as other nations.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are you skeptical about the severity of global warming? [SEP] Look, I'm more interested in what President Putin has to say about it, frankly. He told me in Australia that he understands the threat of nuclear weapons. They've been helpful at the UN, and we're working together on a resolution. I'm focused on preventing nuclear weapons, not the temperature. We'll continue to work with Russia and other countries to isolate those seeking nukes.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding these commutations for drug offenses, many also involved firearms. How do you square that with your position on firearms? [SEP] We consider each case on its own merits. We believe in the possibility of rehabilitation, but we also understand the need to address gun violence effectively.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, while you mention stories in the media, can you cite specific instances of proven, widespread fraud directly attributable to mail-in ballots? Are there court cases or official investigations that support your claim about unchecked signatures in Nevada? [SEP] The point is, there's a lot of potential for fraud. When you send out millions of ballots, anything can happen. And the fact that they don't even verify signatures in some places is just asking for trouble. We need to have secure elections, and mail-in voting is not secure.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, considering Mr. Howard's focus on climate change during this APEC gathering, hasn't your decision to hold a separate meeting in Washington weakened his attempts to establish ambitious goals? Also, to what extent do you see the ratification of Kyoto as relevant to addressing climate change? [SEP] Well, let's start with the latter part of your question. As I get older, you might need to repeat the first part. Kyoto may be suitable for some countries and may have made sense for those that ratified it, but it simply didn't make sense for the United States. Therefore, I spoke the truth. Before my arrival in Washington, the United States Senate had the opportunity to express their approval or disapproval of Kyoto. The vote was 95-to-nothing against it. So, it's not just my opinion; many people believed Kyoto wasn't the right approach. We developed a different strategy: energy efficiency standards based on new technologies. As I mentioned, we reduced greenhouse gases in America last year, and our economy grew at 3 percent. Not many countries can claim that, but we can because our strategy of implementing new technologies is working. I believe we can do a better job of becoming less dependent on foreign oil. As an energy exporter, that might concern some energy exporters. But we must reduce our dependency on oil and have put forth what's called a 20-in-10 program. Over the next 10 years, we will reduce our gasoline consumption by 20 percent by using ethanol and other new technologies. I believe battery technology is coming, so people in Sydney can drive the first 40 miles in their cars on battery without their car looking like a golf cart. There are new technologies coming to market. The fundamental question is how to get them to market as quickly as possible? Kyoto didn't do that as far as we were concerned. If you assess countries that are actually meeting the Kyoto targets, you might find that a different approach makes sense. The reason we rejected Kyoto is because it wouldn't have allowed us to do what we wanted to do, which is grow our economy, become less dependent on foreign oil, and be good stewards of the environment. John and I have discussed his desire to put climate change at the forefront of APEC, and I strongly supported that. I also reminded him that at the G-8, I conveyed the message that if we want to truly solve the global climate change issue, we need to get everyone to the table. We need to ensure that countries like China and India are at the table as we discuss the way forward. Otherwise, if they feel like nations are going to force a solution on them without giving them a voice on how to achieve a common objective, they'll walk away. And you can't have effective global climate change if a nation like China is not involved. I thought the Prime Minister did something smart in this protocol. He announced that we need to cut back on tariffs that prohibit the exportation of technologies that will enable China, for example, to burn coal in a cleaner way. He wants to tear down those tariffs and barriers, and we strongly support him, so that technology is more likely to flow from those of us who have it to those who don't. There are fundamental questions: How fast can we get effective technology to the market—coal sequestration technologies, nuclear spent fuel reprocessing technologies? And once to the market, can we help developing nations acquire those technologies? Otherwise, it's an exercise that's not going to be effective. I believe the strategy that we have laid forth is the most effective way to deal with this issue seriously. I also appreciate the fact that the Prime Minister is the one that brought the issue to focus and is talking about energy dependency, energy efficiency standards, which is a part of the global climate mix. He shows that leadership on the issue, and I'm proud to be here talking about the issue. Okay. Thank you.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, about Afghanistan, when can Americans expect our troops to come home, and will you make the media ban on covering the return of our fallen soldiers a thing of the past? [SEP] Look, first, we just got word about more American soldiers killed in Iraq. My heart goes out to their families. Signing those letters is the toughest part of this job. As for the media policy, we're reviewing it with the Pentagon, so I can't say for sure. Afghanistan is a real problem. Unlike Iraq, where things are moving forward, Afghanistan's government is weak, and the Taliban and Al Qaida are still there. We need a big push to wipe out those safe havens. General Petraeus and Richard Holbrooke are working on a plan. We need to get our military, diplomats, and allies working together better. The key thing is, that region was the launchpad for 9/11. I met with the families this week. We can't let Al Qaida operate there again. So, no timetable yet, but we won't let them attack us.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. I'm going to follow Vivian's lead and ask two questions, if I can. First is a follow-up on trade. Can you lay out specifically, Mr. President, what Japan needs to do to avoid auto tariffs? And before you come back to the G-20 in another month or so, do you expect talks with China to get back on track this year at all? [SEP] First of all, getting to the G-20, I think that we are very much discussing different things with Japan. We have an unbelievably large imbalance—as you know, trade imbalance—which has been there for many, many years; Japan having the big advantage. They are brilliant businesspeople, brilliant negotiators, and put us in a very tough spot. But I think we will have a deal with Japan.Likewise, I think we will have a deal with China sometime into the future. Many companies are leaving China right now because of the tariffs. China is subsidizing a lot of industry because—you know, foolishly, some people said that the American taxpayer is paying the tariffs of China. No, no, no—it's not that way. They're paying a small percentage, but our country is taking in billions and billions of dollars.Our farmers—out of all of that money, the tens of billions of dollars—we're giving a relatively small percentage to our farmers, who have really been a focal point of what's gone on with trade. As you know, they've earmarked, and they've gone after the farmer, thinking that if they hurt the farmer, I'm going to negotiate a bad deal for the rest of the country.I'll tell you, the American farmer, these are patriots. These are great patriots. They don't want subsidy. We've had meetings—and I've had meetings with 32, 35, 40 farmers at one time, numerous times. And they don't want subsidy. I've told that to you before, Jeff. They want a level playing field. That's all they want, because they're better than anybody in the world.And they've told me. I said, You know, I'm going to get you subsidy while China takes advantage of us and China takes advantage of you, by pinpointing you. They say: We don't want subsidies, sir. All we want is a laying play—really, a level playing field.The American farmer, these are great patriots. They are unbelievable people. And they're with me, a hundred percent. I believe that we will have a very good deal with China sometime into the future, because I don't believe that China can continue to pay these, really, hundreds of billions of dollars in tariffs. I don't believe they can do that.You know, businesses are leaving China by the hundreds, by the thousands, going into areas that are nontariffed, including the United States, by the way. But they're going to different parts of Asia: Vietnam; frankly, Japan. But they're going to a lot of places, but they're also coming to the United States, because people don't want to pay the tariff.And if you look, there is no tariff to pay. All you have to do is move your company to the United States. There is no 25-percent tariff.But with all of that being said, I think that there's a very good chance that the United States and China will have a very good trade deal.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, some critics argue your administration's approach to Libya lacks clarity, given the intelligence community's assessment. How do you respond to those who say your policy is disconnected from reality? [SEP] Those critics are missing the bigger picture. We're not just reacting to immediate military realities; we're shaping the future of Libya. We're supporting the aspirations of the Libyan people for a free and democratic society. That's what guides our policy, and that's what will ultimately prevail.
label: Dodging

sentence: President Putin: what specific actions do you expect from him during your administration? [SEP] I'm going to discuss that with him first, before I discuss it with you. If something positive results, great. If not, I wasn't expecting much. But surprises can happen. Relationships are key. Having a good relationship with Russia, and other countries, is a good thing. I've said that for years, especially during my campaign. The NATO meeting yesterday was huge. We turned an unfair situation into a unified front. They were energized. They're committed to increasing their contributions. It requires approval from their parliaments, but they're on board. Stoltenberg is doing a great job. He said that because of me, NATO's received an extra $34 billion. I think it's even higher. My opponent wouldn't have achieved that. The numbers were going down, now they're way up, and going higher. He'll confirm that it's because of me.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, the photos from the guards haven't been released. What's the hold-up? [SEP] Now, now, let's not get ahead of ourselves. That's a separate matter entirely. What's paramount is ensuring the Iranian people know we're watching, that they're not forgotten. Ultimately, the real story is what unfolds within Iran itself. We've all been inspired by their courage. As I said before, and some of you covering my campaigns know, I'm fond of quoting Dr. King: 'The arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends towards justice.' We have to believe that justice will win out in the end.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, are you worried that commuting Chelsea Manning's sentence might signal that leaking classified information carries little consequence, especially given WikiLeaks' involvement with Russian hacking? Also, Julian Assange has offered to come to the US. Are you pursuing this, and would he face charges? [SEP] Well, let's get one thing straight: Chelsea Manning did hard time. So, the idea that leaking secrets goes unpunished? I don't think that's the message people will take away. Her sentence was way out of line compared to others. She had a trial, followed the rules, and owned up to what she did. Commuting, not pardoning, her sentence made sense. Justice was served, and the message is clear: national security is number one. If people have issues with what the government's doing, they should use the proper channels, the whistleblower protections. Sure, some think they're not enough, but we have to balance things. We need to keep people safe, both here and abroad. As for WikiLeaks, I don't see any conflict. I haven't said much about them. The intel folks didn't say for sure if WikiLeaks knew they were part of the Russian hacking thing. I don't follow Assange's tweets. Check with the Justice Department on any legal stuff. In this digital world, we need to find the right mix of being open and keeping things secure. We need to protect our democracy and let our agencies do their jobs without telling the enemy everything. I looked at the details of Manning's case and thought commuting her sentence was the right thing to do.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. So, are you planning a visit anytime soon? [SEP] I'm sorry, could you repeat that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, considering your stated desire for bipartisanship a year ago, how would you assess your own efforts to collaborate with Democrats, and what specific legislative initiatives highlight areas of successful compromise and shared goals? [SEP] We're finding common ground on Iraq. Some in Congress disagree with our initial involvement, but Petraeus and Crocker's testimony seems to have made a difference. I hope we can continue to find ground by ensuring our troops get funded. We found common ground on FISA. Why change a good law? It works for the security of the country, which is what the American people want. It enables our intelligence experts to understand Al Qaida's intentions. The law needs to be enhanced by providing liability protection to phone companies that helped us. So, we found common ground there. Hopefully, we can find common ground as Congress begins to move pieces of legislation. The reason I said what I said today is because there's a lot to be done. I'm not a legislator, but as head of the executive branch, I urge Congress to show progress and get results. It's hard to find common ground unless important bills are moving. They're not even moving. Not one appropriations bill has made it to my desk. How can you find common ground when there's no appropriations process? We found common ground on trade bills. Exports helped us overcome the weakness in the housing market last quarter. It makes sense to continue opening up markets to goods and services. Yet there haven't been any bills moving when it comes to trade. Veterans Affairs is an area where we can find common ground. I asked Bob Dole and Donna Shalala to lead a commission to ensure our veterans get the benefits they deserve. I was concerned about bureaucratic delay and a system that didn't recognize the unique challenges of the current war. I'm concerned about PTSD and want people to focus on it. We sent up a bill, and I hope they move on it quickly. There's a place where we can find common ground.
label: General

sentence: Concerning chemical warfare, can you confirm intelligence indicating Putin's readiness to use these weapons? And if so, what military actions would the U.S. or NATO undertake? [SEP] I cannot divulge classified information. Rest assured, should he employ such weapons, we will respond. The form of our response will be dictated by the circumstances.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. Can you give us an update on China? Do you think that your administration will respond to the sanctions that China announced this morning on American officials? The President. Well, we've already responded in many different ways. We're talking a lot about China. We shouldn't have been talking about China. We did a phase one deal, and it was a wonderful deal. And all of a sudden, it means very little in the overall import of things.They should have never allowed what happened to the world, including us. But this was released into Europe, and it was released into the U.S., and it was released all throughout the world, but it wasn't released into China.And we were doing numbers that will—you know, just were incredible. And we hope to be able to do them, perhaps, even next year. I think we're going have an incredible year next year. But that will never pay for the loss of life in our country and all over the world.So we are—we view China differently than we did 8 months ago. Very much differently.China-U.S. Trade/World Trade Organization/2020 Presidential Election/North Atlantic Treaty Organization/Russia/Germany/Federal Assistance to Farmers  Q. Can I ask Secretary Mnuchin a question? [SEP] Yes, please.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. A quick one on trade: You've got these trade talks with China going on. Is it possible you would pull out of the trade deal with China if they're not meeting their commitment? [SEP] We've taken a lot of money from China on the last year and a half that no other President has taken in. We've done things to China that nobody else has done to China or even thought of doing—with 25-percent tariffs and taking in billions and billions of dollars—tens of billions of dollars. And giving them—giving the farmers as an example $12 billion one year $16 billion another year—and made the farmers extremely happy. You don't hear them complaining. They were targeted by China.But I'm very angry at China because they let this horrible disease—they let this horrible plague come into our country and come into the world. And they should have been able to stop it. They stopped it from going into China. They should have been able to stop it. So I'm very angry at China.Thank you very much. Thank you.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. So, nothing at all, no mention of your name? [SEP] The facts are still emerging.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, about the Biden-Harris ticket, any initial reactions after their first joint appearance? [SEP] Look, I saw enough. It was a calculated move, but a flawed one. She went down in flames during the primaries, attacking Biden left and right. Now, suddenly, she's his running mate? The hypocrisy is astounding! And her policies? A $3 trillion tax hike? No fracking? That's a death sentence for Pennsylvania! We've rebuilt the military, cut taxes, and unleashed the American economy. They want to reverse all of that. They want to defund the police, raise taxes, and cripple our energy sector. It's a recipe for disaster. I'm surprised he picked her, frankly. But hey, it's his campaign to run into the ground.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, given the uncertainty surrounding the coronavirus outbreak, are you prepared to consider additional economic stimulus measures to offset any potential slowdown in growth? [SEP] We are constantly monitoring the economic situation, and we are prepared to take action if necessary to support the economy. We have a number of tools at our disposal, including fiscal and monetary policy, and we will not hesitate to use them if needed. However, we believe that the fundamentals of the economy remain strong, and we are confident that we can weather this storm.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Obama, with the withdrawal deadlines looming, how can you realistically guarantee a long-term strategic partnership with Afghanistan after 2017? [SEP] Our vision is clear: a strengthened and lasting partnership with Afghanistan. The U.S. now sees Afghanistan as a truly reliable partner. Our commitments are significant, including $4.1 billion for Afghan security forces by 2017. We've also established a new economic framework, allocating $800 million through the Afghan budget. The flexibility in our security cooperation sends a strong message: this is a long-term commitment. Our strategic partnership is about empowering the Afghan people to secure their own future. We're dedicated to building and sustaining effective Afghan security forces.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with regard to the NSA data collection program, critics argue it's a violation of privacy with little demonstrable benefit. Can you point to specific instances where this program directly prevented a terrorist attack, justifying its continuation? [SEP] Look, the situation is complex. I tasked an independent panel to thoroughly review our intelligence programs, and they provided numerous recommendations. I'm carefully considering these recommendations to strike the right balance between national security and civil liberties. We'll be making a comprehensive announcement in January regarding the future of these programs. Now, the 215 program, which involves the collection of metadata, has been a focal point of public debate. The NSA believed this program was crucial for identifying potential terrorist threats based on lessons learned from 9/11. While there haven't been allegations of misuse, public concerns about potential abuse are valid. We're evaluating how to achieve the same security objectives while ensuring greater transparency and accountability. I have confidence in the NSA, but we must adapt to evolving technologies and address public anxieties. Furthermore, we must consider the international implications of our surveillance activities. While we have strong legal safeguards domestically, the same level of oversight doesn't always exist internationally. We need to ensure our actions align with our values, both at home and abroad. Okay? Ed Henry [FOX News].
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, and to both of you, what do you think the Canada-U.S. relationship will look like in 4 years? What will the auto sector look like? Will the border be thicker or thinner? And will you have a carbon market? [SEP] Hold on, you're throwing a lot at me at once. Who were you addressing?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, with respect to Representative Marino and Senator McConnell, are you standing by your previous endorsements given the recent scrutiny and your own public statements? [SEP] Well, let's address Senator McConnell first. We've only been addressing healthcare for a handful of months, unlike others who spent years fruitlessly. He will succeed. As for Representative Marino, he's a strong supporter from Pennsylvania. We've seen the reports and are taking them seriously. We're preparing a major announcement on the drug crisis next week. We'll be looking into the matter.
label: General

sentence: Q. Do you think Occupy Wall Street has the potential to be a Tea Party movement in 2012? [SEP] What I think is that the American people understand that not everybody has been following the rules, that Wall Street is an example of that, that folks who are working hard every single day, getting up, going to the job, loyal to their companies, that that used to be the essence of the American Dream. That's how you got ahead--the old-fashioned way. And these days, a lot of folks who are doing the right thing aren't rewarded, and a lot of folks who aren't doing the right thing are rewarded.And that's going to express itself politically in 2012 and beyond until people feel like once again we're getting back to some old-fashioned American values in which, if you're a banker, then you are making your money by making prudent loans to businesses and individuals to build plants and equipment and hire workers that are creating goods and products that are building the economy and benefiting everybody.Jake Tapper [ABC News].//Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives Fast and Furious Program
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Sir, what about your family's involvement? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, from Sputnik News, did your discussions include potential inspections of North Korean nuclear sites? [SEP] I'm having trouble hearing you. What outlet are you with?
label: Clarification

sentence: So, the offer to meet still stands? [SEP] That's something the people of ian need to decide for themselves. It's their choice, ultimately.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: In the event of a Republican takeover of the House, what implications would that have for the implementation of your policy initiatives? [SEP] Should the Republicans assume control, the political landscape will undoubtedly become more challenging. Pre-election forecasts, which I do not criticize, suggested a significant shift in power, with projections of substantial seat losses. However, current indications suggest that such a dramatic outcome is unlikely. In any political environment, opportunities exist to engage with members of the opposing party, seeking common ground and potential bipartisan support. The ultimate outcome remains to be seen. Consider, for instance, the hypothetical scenario of Senator Johnson proposing cuts to Medicare and Social Security. One might reasonably question the likelihood of such a proposal gaining widespread support within the Republican caucus. The situation is contingent upon a variety of factors.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, one quick clarification before I move on to Russia: Is the Meng Wanzhou case also going to be a long, drawn-out affair, or is there any possibility the U.S. might just drop the extradition effort? [SEP] About what are you asking? On what matter?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, if I may clarify, concerning Meng Wanzhou, is her case also on hold until the very end, or might the U.S. consider dropping the extradition request? [SEP] Pardon? I didn't fully understand the question.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Roxham Road, what explains the delay in finalizing the agreement, given its completion a year ago? Regarding the 15,000 migrants Canada intends to receive, why such a modest figure? What concessions has Canada offered the U.S. in return? Prime Minister Trudeau, your insights are also welcome.
