Before I would like to comment upon how their meetings went, I would like to get a readout from our Embassy, who, of course, will be in touch with the Prime Minister and get his readout. And so it's a—you're asking me to be a little speculative on the subject. I haven't seen the picture.Look, generally the way these things work is you try to be cordial to the person you're with, and so you don't want the picture to be kind of, you know, duking it out; okay, put up your dukes. That's an old boxing expression. []
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, what's your assessment of the new Russian leadership, and what lessons should your successor take regarding the Russian threat? [SEP] I'm not a Russia expert, okay? It's a complex situation. But I will say this: we need to keep our options open and be prepared to engage with whoever's in charge. It's about protecting American interests.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, apart from Huawei, are there any other Chinese tech companies that are in your administration's crosshairs for potential restrictions in the United States? [SEP] Look, the big fish is Huawei, alright? They're out. I've told countries, especially in Europe, that using their tech means no intelligence from us. They're all rethinking it. The UK? They were going Huawei, now they're running the other way.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the NATO summit in Chicago, will leaders agree on an Afghan transition strategy? And are you worried that the Koran burning and subsequent events might jeopardize negotiations with our allies? [SEP] The transition policy, agreed upon in Lisbon, is still in place. We're committed to transferring increasing responsibility to the Afghans, with a full transition and the end of our combat role by the end of 2014. Our coalition partners remain committed to this plan. At the NATO meeting, we'll focus on ensuring a gradual transition, avoiding a 'cliff' effect. Similar to our drawdown in Iraq, this will involve building Afghan capacity and strengthening partnerships with Afghan security forces. We'll also put in place the necessary support structures for the strategy to succeed. The Koran burning incident is concerning and highlights the challenges in Afghanistan, underscoring the need for transition. While violence against our people is unacceptable, President Karzai is eager for greater Afghan responsibility. We'll find a way to respect Afghan sovereignty while empowering them to take greater control of their security. This is in the best interest of both Afghans and ourselves. While I'm confident we can execute the plan, there will be challenges along the way, just as there were in Iraq.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, now that you've secured a site for your Presidential library, are reports accurate that you aim to raise $200 million? Should the public know who donates such sums? Will you disclose donations as they arrive, and will you limit who can donate and how much? [SEP] No, yes, no, yes. Look, next question. I haven't seen the final budget yet. Donnie Evans, the foundation chairman, will review disclosure rules. Some donors prefer anonymity, be it for this or any foundation. We'll consider that. And what else did you ask?
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, that sounds like a standard talking point. Can you provide specific examples of how the TPP will benefit American workers and businesses, and what concrete measures are in place to prevent currency manipulation? [SEP] This is the fastest growing part of the world. This represents an enormous market for the United States. Most countries here already sell their stuff to the United States, and we have relatively low tariffs. In other words, we put relatively low taxes on goods that are coming into the United States. In contrast, tariffs are significantly higher for U.S. goods being sold here. So a deal that gets rid of 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods into the largest, fastest growing markets of the world, that's a good deal for American businesses and American workers.
label: General

sentence: Q. But do you think Kamala Harris would be a tough opponent for you, given what you saw in that debate? [SEP] You never know who's going to be tough. You never know. One that you think is going to be tough turns out to be not much. And sometimes you think one—and I've seen it. Because look I had 17—we had actually a total of 18. A lot of people think 17. Governor of Virginia remember? Add the Governor of Virginia. Wasn't there long—previous Governor.But of the 18 you know many were—all their lives they wanted to be politicians. I never thought about being a politician until about 2 days before I decided to run. A little before that but not too much before.And they—you know you looked at some of them they're very talented. You look at their résumés it's like great. And sometimes the ones that I thought would be the toughest were not the toughest at all. I mean I could write a book. I should write a book.But some of the people that I did in the Republican—because we had sort of a similar thing. We had 18 instead of—I guess they have 24 or 25. But some of the ones that I thought would be absolutely—absolutely without question the toughest turned out—I didn't think they were tough at all. Others that a lot of people said weren't tough they were tougher.I think she was given far too much credit for what she did. That was so out of the can what she said. That thing was right out of a box. And I thought that he didn't respond great. I wouldn't say it was—this was not Winston Churchill we're dealing with okay? But I don't think nearly as bad as they portended it to be.Jennifer go ahead.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. But can I ask you a question, please? [SEP] ——ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much. Appreciate it.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, you accused Dr. Birx of being manipulated by Speaker Pelosi. Could you explain that comment, particularly since Dr. Birx was simply reporting facts about the current pandemic situation? [SEP] Frankly, we're doing an amazing job, better than anyone else. Just look at what's going on, especially with these flare-ups in other countries – and don't forget, we're a massive country, second only to India and China. China's dealing with a huge flare-up, India's got a major problem, other countries are struggling. But you never hear about that in the news, do you? They only focus on us. Other countries are having big problems, even those that thought they were in the clear. Like Florida – we thought we were done with it, and then suddenly, it came back. But we're doing great. I told Dr. Birx that myself. I have a lot of respect for her. Nancy Pelosi, however, has treated her horribly, very nasty. I just think they should acknowledge the incredible job we've done, whether it's ventilators or testing. We've tested over 60 million people – nobody else is even close. And many of those tests are rapid, giving you results almost immediately. Nobody else has that capability. We're doing incredibly well.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the immense loss of life and financial expenditure, why shouldn't the public perceive you as obstinate, detached from reality, and unrealistic regarding the effectiveness of your strategy? [SEP] Interestingly, Mike Hayden, whom I believe you're quoting, provided me with his weekly briefing this morning, and I inquired about the newspaper article you referenced. His remarks to the Iraq Study Group were somewhat more nuanced than the quotation you cited. He stated that he made it clear the current strategy in Iraq was not effective and that a change of direction was necessary. He also asserted that those who advocate for withdrawal and entrusting the Iraqi government with responsibility underestimate the Iraqi government's capacity at that time to assume such responsibility. He further elaborated that our strategy needed to facilitate a reduction in violence to enable political reconciliation from both the top down and the bottom up. Political reconciliation has indeed occurred from the bottom up. Anbar Province, once deemed unattainable by experts, has experienced significant positive changes. The people on the ground are weary of violence and threats from groups like Al Qaeda, who offer no positive vision for the future.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, as your time in office dwindles, what are your remaining priorities, and how concerned are you about the immigration bill's fate amidst the upcoming electoral battles? [SEP] Listen, we've got to push through that energy legislation. Renewing No Child Left Behind is a must. We need those trade deals with Panama, Peru, and Colombia to clear Congress, and I'm hoping we can build on the progress we've made with the Korean free trade agreement. My aim is to bring back successful Doha negotiations for a congressional vote, which requires a TPA extension. And we absolutely must maintain our momentum on balancing the budget. The deficit's shrinking faster than expected, thanks to increased tax revenues and the measures we've implemented. Now, we need Congress to avoid overspending and those tax hikes that would cripple the economy and, in turn, hurt Treasury revenues. I'm very concerned about the Democrats' tax-and-spend agenda. I'm waiting to see how they plan to balance the budget in five years. And, of course, the war on terror remains a top priority. I'm hoping to find common ground with both parties on Iraq. Some just want to pull out, but I strongly disagree, and I believe most Americans do as well. The recent vote showed what we can achieve when we work together. On immigration, it's a complex issue. I've always been a proponent of comprehensive reform to secure our border. It's a promise I made on the campaign trail, and it's something I believed in as Governor of Texas. I understand the frustrations surrounding illegal immigration, which is why we've significantly ramped up border security. We're doubling the number of Border Patrol agents and adding more fencing and equipment. I even deployed the National Guard for a while. This bill addresses those concerns by setting clear security benchmarks that must be met before any other reforms can take effect. Last year, the call was for security first, and that's precisely what this bill delivers. However, I don't see how we can achieve the level of border security the American people expect without a temporary-worker program that includes verifiable work cards. People will come here to work, and they'll find a way to do it. This has fueled an underground industry of smugglers and document forgers, which is simply inhumane. It's not who we are as Americans. The best way to combat this is to offer a legal, temporary pathway for people to fill jobs that Americans aren't doing. I'd much rather have people crossing the border with legitimate cards than being crammed into the back of a truck. Secondly, we need a reliable system for employer verification. It's against the law to hire someone who's here illegally, but businesses often struggle to verify the authenticity of documents. That's why we need a tamper-proof ID card, which is a key component of this bill. The toughest question is what to do with those who are already here. Some would call anything short of deportation amnesty, but deporting 12 million people is simply not realistic. Nor should they be granted automatic citizenship. So, we've developed a plan that requires them to meet certain conditions to obtain a Z visa, including background checks, fines, and a probationary period, before they can even apply for citizenship. If you're looking for reasons to oppose the bill, you'll find them, but it's a comprehensive and well-thought-out solution. I knew this would be a contentious issue. It's easy to demonize someone who's working hard here. I want to get this bill done because it's the right thing to do and because it will address the problem effectively. I want to take it out of the political arena. Immigration debates can bring out the worst in people. We're a nation of immigrants. I was deeply moved by the Coast Guard Academy ensign who spoke about his grandfather, a migrant from Mexico. He was proud to serve America. Welcoming those who seek to work and achieve the American Dream revitalizes our nation. We have an opportunity to enact a good law now, but it will require hard work. Politics will inevitably play a role, but I hope that Members of Congress will rise above it. I know I will. It's the right thing to do. I'll continue to engage with them and urge them to show the courage needed to get this bill to my desk as soon as possible. Thank you.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the conflict in Gaza, do you anticipate a resolution before your term concludes, and what are your thoughts on Israel's behavior? [SEP] My focus is on a durable cease-fire. To be clear, that requires Hamas to cease firing rockets into Israel. The decision rests with them. We are working with Egypt to halt the smuggling of arms into Gaza, which enables Hamas to continue its attacks. Nations providing weapons to Hamas must cease their support, and the international community must exert pressure on them. If Hamas desires a sustainable cease-fire, they must disarm. Neighboring countries must collaborate to prevent smuggling. It's a complex task, given the existence of tunnels and other avenues for illicit arms transfers. Now, could you please repeat the second part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Regarding the historic election of two Muslim women, one veiled, to the House, do you see this as a contradiction of your stated message? [SEP] I'm not quite following. Could you repeat that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Could you provide details about the suspect's gender? [SEP] That's not something I have at my fingertips. The investigative team will release a comprehensive report later, I believe.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: While you advocate for closing loopholes, wouldn't raising tax rates on the wealthiest Americans be a more direct and effective way to address income inequality and generate revenue for critical government programs? Why prioritize one approach over the other? [SEP] We need a balanced approach that includes both closing loopholes and ensuring that the wealthiest Americans pay their fair share. We're not going to extend tax cuts for the top 2 percent, which would cost a trillion dollars. We're also committed to closing loopholes and simplifying the tax code. We need to ensure that everyone is paying their fair share so that we can invest in our future.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, just one more question, if you please? [SEP] Only if you promise not to ambush me with another gotcha question like you usually do. []
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. As far as the nomination, have you put forward a new nomination yet? [SEP] I have many people that want the position, if you can believe it, with all of this being said. We have some excellent people, some very political people, some people that a thing like that wouldn't happen, or if it did happen, I guess they'll handle it somewhat differently.But we have many people that want that job. We're very proud of the job we've done for the veterans. The veterans have been—we've gotten accountability approved, which is something that, for years—for years they've been trying to get. As you know, they couldn't get it approved. We got accountability so that when somebody treats our veterans badly, we can fire them so fast, almost as fast as they fire people in Germany. [] We'll get rid of them.And I will tell you, we're getting choice. We're putting choice in very, very strongly. We have tremendous support in the Senate for that.But I do—I have a lot of people that want the job. We're getting—we're doing a great job over there for the vets. And you know, that was one of the things that to me was the most important. We had tremendous support from the vets. We're getting great reports.But getting a thing such as accountability done. We'll be soon getting choice done—meaning if a veteran stands on line and can't get to a doctor for various reasons, they're going to a private doctor, and this country is going to pay. They're not going to wait 9 weeks on line for a cure to something that could have been very easy to cure, and then they end up dying from it. So we're going to—I've very proud of what we've done.And I will tell you, your new head of the VA is going to be very exceptional. We have some exceptional people that want to do the job. Okay?
label: General

sentence: Q. Good morning to both Presidents. President Bush, I ask you, why do Mexicans want to—why would you think that Mexicans could believe in a reform in migration when for so many years, this was not a possibility nor reality? And what are your chances of coming through with this bill in Congress? And President Calderon, you had lunch with President Fox. Can you tell us what you talked about? [SEP] They talked about . [] Excuse me. I wasn't there. []No, that's a legitimate question, and the question is, why now? Why do I think something positive can happen? Well, first of all, the legislative process takes awhile in the United States. I don't know about Mexico, Mr. President, but sometimes legislators, you know, debate issues for awhile before a solution can be achieved.And we had a very—by the way, we haven't had a serious debate on migration until recently. A law was passed in 1986, and then there really wasn't a serious debate until pretty much starting after the year 2000, if my memory serves me well. I've always known this is an important issue because I happened to have been the Governor of Texas. And so I'm very comfortable about discussing the issue and have elevated the issue over the past years. And Members of Congress have taken the issue very seriously, but it's hard to get legislation out of the Congress on a very complex issue.A lot of Americans were deeply concerned that the United States was not enforcing our laws. They felt like there wasn't a commitment to the rule of law. Over the past year, I believe we have shown the American people that there is a strong commitment to the rule of law. And I think Members of Congress are now feeling more comfortable that the country is committed to rule of law, which then makes some more openminded to my argument, which is that if we can have migration reform, it will make it less likely somebody will feel like they have to sneak across our border, and, therefore, take pressure off the border. In other words, security for the country, border security, will be enhanced by a good migration law, and then it will make it easier for us to focus our assets on drugs, terrorists, criminals, and guns moving both ways.I believe—I feel pretty good about it. I don't want to predict legislative successes. But I can tell you my mood, and my mood is optimistic because the mood in the Congress seems like it has changed from skepticism last year to knowledge that getting a comprehensive bill will be in the Nation's interests.Secondly, I'm optimistic because Republicans in the Senate are working with Democrats in the Senate. We're facilitating that work. The administration is very much involved with helping the Senators find common ground, to the point where we can move a bill as quickly as possible out of the Senate so it gets to the House of Representatives.I'm not a betting man. I don't like to bet, because when I do, I usually lose. But I'm an optimistic man, in this case, about getting comprehensive reform, and a bill is in the interests of both countries. I met with former President Vicente Fox, whom I like, and we have a good friendship. We belong to the same party. I invited him to lunch; we talked for quite a while, talked about matters in a very constructive fashion. And he congratulated us for the work that we've done during these first 100 days. He also said that he had the will to collaborate and cooperate in a respectful fashion with the government for the benefit of Mexicans.I have also met with other former Presidents, and I'm sure that I will continue to meet with President Fox in the future throughout my administration. Here it comes.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, one final query, if I may? [SEP] Provided it's not another one of your attempts to trip me up, then alright. []
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. So, just to be clear, a shutdown before the new Congress convenes is still a possibility? [SEP] It's a possibility, sure. I'm not going to say it's not. We're working on it, but you know how these things go. Lots of moving parts.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, just one more question on Breonna Taylor, if I can? Q. What's the emergency phone call about? [SEP] So I'll be—I'll be back. I will see you tomorrow. A big day.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, turning to the tragic accident off the California coast, have you received a briefing on the loss of life involving the Marines and Navy personnel? [SEP] A briefing is scheduled for later today.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. It means a lot for us for you to be here. My name is Michael Ignoti. I'm the correspondent in Washington for Ethnos newspaper and Mega TV. You said many times, Mr. President, that the way the Europeans handled the economy—the economic crisis—had the opposite effect. And also, you talked many times against the austerity. And of course, you are right. Why, in your opinion, you didn't succeed to convince the Europeans to follow your way? And what are you going to do the last 2 months to help Greece and the Greek people? Also, I have a short question about Cyprus. Both of you, you talk about Cyprus. And it's a dear issue for me because I born in Cyprus. How can you convince the President of Turkey to end the occupation of Cyprus, Mr. President? [SEP] Well, let me take the second question first This is ultimately a negotiation between Cypriots: Turkish Cypriots and Greek Cypriots And the good news is that you have two leaders who seem genuinely committed to finding compromises and an approach that would serve both their peoples well If in fact you can see a meeting of the minds between them, then the issue will be can we make sure that all of us, the international community—Turkey, Greece, the United States—support that agreement in a way that can be ratified by both sides And we have invested a lot of time Vice President Biden has been actively involved in this We are encouraged by the progress that's been made I think there's a window in the next few weeks, months, where this issue was actually resolved And I think if we can find an equitable solution, it won't provide a hundred percent of what either side wants, there may be some mechanisms for a transition from the status quo to the future that both sides envision, but I think it's achievable And we're going to do everything we can to support the processWith respect to the economy and Europe, again, I think it's important to recognize that in some ways my job was simpler because, at least in the first 2 years, I had majorities of my party controlling Congress And I'm just one country [] So Congress is hard to deal with [] Dealing with multiple Parliaments and commissions and unions and this and that and the other and—that's very complicated And so the need, I think, to operate by consensus, the fact that not all European countries were similarly situated, even though their economy shared a currency, that made their task more difficult And so I want to make sure that I'm clear that I don't envy the hard job that each European leader had in circumstances that oftentimes they had inheritedWhat I've tried to do is just offer our best thinking, whether it's in resolving problems in banks quickly—because the quicker you resolve the problems with banks and there's transparency in that process, the faster they recapitalize and are able to make investments When the economy is shrinking, providing jobs, spending on things like infrastructure can actually increase revenue and drive down debt And then, there's going to be a time at which point that has to be taken care ofI mean, for example, in the United States, our deficits went up in those first 2 years because we were engaging in a lot of emergency spending Our deficits have now been reduced by two-thirds, primarily because we started growing again, and we started taking in more tax revenueSo there's some lessons, I think, that are applicable for all countries And what we've just tried to do is offer the best advice that we can, understanding that when you're dealing with multiple nations, but a single currency, and then a European Union, where some people are in the currency and some people are not in the currency, and a European Parliament and European Council and—that's a lot of meetings [] Okay?Prime Minister Tsipras I will fully agree with what has just said in answering the question about Cyprus It is not a bilateral issue It is not a problem between Greece and Turkey It's an international problem, which has been going on for 42 years—as long as I'm alive—and it is a problem of illegal invasion and occupation of the northern part of Cyprus We make our best, we do our best in—to encourage both sides to help them reach a fair and equitable and sustainable solutionIn my first visit to Cyprus as a Prime Minister, I tried and I did meet over and above the leaders of the Republic of Cyprus, a number of representatives of the Turkish Cypriot community And I think that that was the first time that a Greek Prime Minister was meeting with them We are interested in making sure that the people of Cyprus will be able to live in a reunited Cyprus where they are free, where there's a democracy, freedom, and Cyprus is a member of the European UnionSo I would like to make it clear that as regards Greece, we are in favor of a solution We stand by the side of President Anastasiadis, who is making the effort, and we are only ready to discuss with Turkey the part which is relevant to us; that is the guarantees Because since 1959, since 1960, this obsolete issue of guarantees also concerns Greece But Greece is not the country which has occupied and illegally—invaded and illegally occupied CyprusSo I believe that a fair and sustainable solution means a solution without the permanent presence of Turkish troops on the island And at the same time, I think that the best guarantee for the Cypriot people to feel safe is the potential of a fair and sustainable solution And if this happens, things will change not only for Cyprus, but for the wider region, in general and for Greek-Turkish relations This is how we are proceedingI believe that, yes, President Erdogan plays an important role, but it is not my responsibility to convince him, Mr Ignoti The final question will come from Chris Jansing with NBC News
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, could you please restate the question about Hillary Clinton? [SEP] I'm sorry, what was that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Iran nuclear deal, critics argue that allowing dollar-denominated transactions would effectively negate the sanctions we promised to maintain. How do you respond to these concerns, and are you willing to risk undermining our own sanctions regime? [SEP] Well, let's be clear: we're not talking about a wholesale abandonment of sanctions. What we *are* talking about is ensuring that Iran, having met its obligations under the agreement, can participate in the global economy. They've dismantled centrifuges, shipped out enriched uranium, and opened their facilities to inspectors. Now, some say that any economic relief is a betrayal, but I say that keeping our word is paramount. We're exploring ways for them to engage in legitimate business, perhaps through European channels, without necessarily requiring dollar-denominated transactions. But let's not forget, the real key here is Iran's behavior. If they want to attract investment, they need to stop launching missiles with threats against Israel and fueling conflicts in the region. Ultimately, their actions will determine their economic success.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your stated priority of ending the war in Yemen, and the UAE's request to re-list the Houthis as a terrorist organization, what are your plans? [SEP] It's under review. Ending the war requires both sides to participate. It will be a challenge. Yes.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. What's the highest level you anticipate unemployment reaching? [SEP] I'm not in the business of making predictions. Given your tendency to hold us to past forecasts, I'd rather not offer another one.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President—[inaudible]—Valentinovna, Sputnik News Agency. Have you discussed the issue of possible inspections to North Korea's nuclear sites during your negotiations? [SEP] I'm having trouble hearing you. And where exactly are you reporting from?
label: Clarification

sentence: Specifically regarding the energy sector, do you believe Germany will back sectoral sanctions? [SEP] The energy sector is complex. Very complex. Russia supplies a lot of energy to Europe. We're talking to Germany. They're a strong ally. We're looking at all the options. Sanctions are a possibility, but we hope it doesn't come to that. We want to deter aggression, not hurt the Russian people. Germany is on board with that.
label: Implicit

sentence: Specifically, are you contemplating direct negotiations with Iranian counterparts? [SEP] Let me ensure I understand correctly: you're inquiring about the possibility of a direct meeting between myself and representatives of the Iranian government?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given your concerns about the rise of a certain brand of nationalism, would you encourage those protesting against Mr. Trump's rhetoric to cease their demonstrations? Did you offer your successor any advice regarding the selection of staff, particularly in light of these concerning trends? And finally, in these closing weeks of your presidency, do you believe you possess any leverage to halt the bombing of Aleppo by Assad and Putin? [SEP] One of the strengths of our democracy is its diverse expressions, including protest. I've been the target of protests throughout my presidency. I wouldn't advise people to remain silent. However, I would emphasize that elections matter, voting matters, and informed engagement matters. Don't take our system of government for granted. Democracy requires constant effort. If a significant portion of eligible voters abstain, democracy is weakened. If we can't distinguish facts from propaganda, we face challenges. If people are unwilling to compromise, democracy suffers. Understand the foundations of a healthy democracy and engage continuously. There's a degree of complacency. Some young people forget the lessons of the Cold War. There's a tendency to equate the U.S. and Russia, but we have flaws and make mistakes. The U.S. has been a positive force for Germany, providing security and aiding in its rebuilding. We've generally strived to uphold free speech and civil liberties in our foreign policy. Remember that in an age of misinformation. Don't equate isolated incidents with systemic repression. If distinctions are blurred, we risk losing what we've gained. Apologies for the lengthy response.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Roughly, what's the headcount? Any idea? [SEP] I'm not in possession of those figures currently. However, we can prepare a formal report for you with the specific numbers.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, are you aware of the Red Cross report? [SEP] I haven't had a chance to review it personally. But let me be clear: this administration does not condone torture. Next question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Obama, Governor Bush's remarks have been widely criticized as insensitive and dismissive. Beyond expressing your own condolences, what concrete steps will your administration take to break the gridlock in Congress and enact meaningful gun control legislation? [SEP] The American people are capable of assessing Governor Bush's statement in light of the recurring tragedy of mass shootings. My administration is actively reviewing all possible avenues to enhance enforcement of current gun laws and prevent access to weapons by those who would misuse them. However, fundamental change necessitates a transformation of the political climate. Our inaction is a political choice. Congress consistently rejects even modest gun safety measures due to political considerations. Special interest groups fund campaigns and exploit fear. While the Republican Party exhibits particular resistance, this issue transcends partisan divisions. We must reshape this dynamic. Citizens must prioritize gun safety when making their electoral choices, even if it requires temporarily setting aside other concerns. The NRA has demonstrated remarkable effectiveness in mobilizing their base and influencing politicians. We must match their intensity and organization. We cannot eradicate all violence, but our homicide rates significantly exceed those of comparable nations. I am deeply saddened by recent events. This violence is a daily reality in underserved communities. We must decide whether to accept this as normal. I refuse to do so. But I cannot accomplish this alone. I will continue to advocate for change and hope to foster a collective commitment to action.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, considering Russia's continued support for the Assad regime, what leverage does the United States have to influence the situation in Syria? [SEP] We're engaging with Russia diplomatically. We're making it clear that their support for Assad is not in their long-term interests. We're also exploring other avenues to exert pressure.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, while you express optimism about a return to normalcy, many Americans remain deeply concerned about the ongoing political polarization. What specific steps will your administration take to bridge the divide and foster greater unity in the country? [SEP] Well, the super-mega-MAGA Republicans, I don't think we'll break the fever for them. But they're a minority. Most Republicans are decent, honorable people. We disagree on issues, but they're honest and straightforward. I worked with them for years. The world is watching us. At the first G-7 meeting, after I was elected, I said, 'America is back.' And someone asked, 'For how long?' They're concerned about our stability, whether we're still the democracy we've always been, whether our institutions matter.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, many Americans feel previous administrations have been too lenient on Russia. What concrete steps will your administration take to ensure that future election interference is not only met with consequences, but actively prevented? [SEP] The key is deterrence, and that comes from making it abundantly clear that any interference will be met with swift and decisive action. We've already shown that we're not afraid to take action, and that's a message that Putin understands loud and clear. Furthermore, the reputational damage that Russia suffers on the world stage is a significant deterrent in itself. No country wants to be seen as a rogue nation.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. President Obama, with respect to the situation in Mexico – the human rights violations, the drug cartels, the Merida Initiative, the safety of President Calderon, and the visa complications – what are your thoughts? [SEP] I'm afraid I missed a key part of that question. Could you please rephrase it? I want to be sure I understand the full scope of your inquiry.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, while you've expressed optimism about a rapid vaccine rollout, what are the realistic logistical challenges involved in distributing a vaccine to hundreds of millions of Americans? What specific steps are being taken to address those challenges and ensure equitable access for all? [SEP] We have a great plan, okay? We have the best people working on it. We're going to distribute the vaccine very quickly and very efficiently. We're going to make sure that everyone who wants a vaccine can get one. It's going to be a tremendous success. We're going to beat this virus, and we're going to do it soon.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, this morning Benazir Bhutto said that the Pakistanis' people's passion for liberty is threatening to explode. First, have you had any more further discussions with General Musharraf? And are you concerned that the continuing unrest within Pakistan is distracting that country's leadership and military from the struggle against the Taliban and Al Qaida? [SEP] First, on Al Qaida, we do share a common goal, and that is to eradicate Al Qaida. That goal obviously became paramount to the American people when Al Qaida killed 3,000 innocent souls on our soil. And since then, the United States of America, along with strong allies and friends, has been in pursuit of Al Qaida.I vowed to the American people we'd keep the pressure on them. I fully understand we need cooperation to do so, and one country that we need cooperation from is . That cooperation has been made easier by the fact that Al Qaida has tried to kill leaders in several times. And so we share a common goal.Secondly, we share a goal with the i people, and that is to live in a free society. I haven't spoken to President Musharraf since I did earlier this week, but he knows my position, and he knows the position of the Government. I do want to remind you that he has declared that he'll take off his uniform, and he has declared there will be elections, which are positive steps.We also believe that suspension of the emergency decree will make it easier for the democracy to flourish. And so our message is consistent and clear. Our message is also clear to Al Qaida: We will find you, and we'll bring you to justice before you can hurt innocent people.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, how can you say that the markets are strong? [SEP] So, ladies and gentlemen, we'll be doing this quite often. We're going to keep you abreast of all of the facts.And again, I want to thank the professionals. They are great professionals. I've gotten to really know them and see them under very interesting and tough and trying conditions. We have the finest in the world.I will say this: Other countries call us and they ask, would it be possible for them to speak to Anthony and Bob and the people that you're talking to on a daily basis now. So we're going to be very transparent. We'll be meeting you probably tomorrow or the next day. We'll keep you abreast. Thank you very much. Thank you.
label: Dodging

sentence: Could we be facing a quagmire scenario with no clear end in sight? [SEP] The notion of a perpetual war is, in my view, unlikely. Russia's ability to sustain such a prolonged engagement is questionable due to resource limitations. Furthermore, I believe President Putin will eventually acknowledge that the economic and political costs of this conflict outweigh any potential benefits for Russia. I am optimistic that Ukraine's ongoing offensive will create the necessary conditions for a negotiated settlement.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, while acknowledging past accomplishments, what specific, measurable goals do you have for your second term to address the ongoing pandemic, economic recovery, and social divisions within the country? [SEP] We're going to rebuild the economy even bigger and better than before! We saved millions of lives by closing down the country, and now we're reopening it stronger than ever. Next year will be the best year ever, better than last year, better than anything! And we're going to continue to fight for the American people, protect our borders, and make America great again, again!
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. But are you in contact with him over the coronavirus crisis? [SEP] No, we got—we have. We're talking about it, country to country, but we did discuss if he had a problem. It was reported that he may have it, and he doesn't, fortunately.Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: So, a visit is in the cards? [SEP] Could you say that again?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Lee, given North Korea's planned rocket launch, what specific countermeasures, including sanctions, will South Korea enact if they proceed, and can you update us on the status of extending South Korea's missile range? [SEP] Let me reiterate, a launch would be a clear violation of UN resolutions. If proceeds, it goes against its pledges to the international community. The international community is urging to retract its announcement. If proceeds, it must bear the entire responsibility. As I said, it will only deepen its isolation, and all the consequences will be on them. The people of will see their leader spending hundreds of millions on a missile while they suffer. They will not be proud; they will truly understand the nature of their leaders and why they face such hardships. While 's leaders may hope to achieve some objective, they must understand they will put themselves in a very difficult position. I urge to act responsibly for the sake of its people. The US and South Korea are in agreement. We will remain calm and rational. Regarding missile range, we did not discuss it. Working-level officials have been discussing it. It's part of enhancing our defense capabilities.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. What's a scam? What's a scam? [SEP] It's a scam.
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, with Netanyahu's admission of the Israeli bombing raid in Syria, could you reveal the target, state your position on the action, and analyze its effects on the volatile regional situation, particularly concerning Syria, Iran, and Israel, and the possibility of U.S. entanglement? [SEP] I'm unable to comment on that subject. Moving on.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Given your commitment to withdrawing troops from Iraq, what is your timeline for a similar withdrawal from Afghanistan, and will you reverse the policy regarding media coverage of fallen soldiers returning home? [SEP] First, let me say that we just received news of the deaths of four American service members in Iraq, and our thoughts are with their families. Signing letters to the families of fallen heroes is the most sobering part of this job. As for the policy on media coverage, we're reviewing it with the Department of Defense. I don't want to answer before I've evaluated that review. Afghanistan is a big challenge. Iraq had a relatively peaceful election, but Afghanistan's government seems detached. The Taliban and Al Qaeda operate in the border regions. We need a concerted effort to root out those safe havens. We're undergoing a thorough review, and we need better coordination of our military, diplomatic, and development efforts. We cannot allow Al Qaeda to operate there. I don't have a timetable yet, but I won't let Al Qaeda or bin Laden plan attacks on the U.S. homeland.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Was the suspect armed? Was the suspect armed? [SEP] There was nobody else injured. There was no other law enforcement injured. And I just want to—and we'll get on to the press conference, but I do want to thank Secret Service. They are fantastic, the job they do.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Excuse me, Mr. President. By rejecting a veto--would you veto any payroll tax cuts if it had something else on it? [SEP] I think it's fair to say that if the payroll tax cut is attached to a whole bunch of extraneous issues not related to making sure that the American people's taxes don't go up on January 1, then it's not something that I'm going to accept. And I don't expect to have to veto it because I expect they're going to have enough sense over on Capitol Hill to do the people's business and not try to load it up with a bunch of politics. I have Lee-Anne Goodman, Canadian Press.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you so much, Mr. President. Were you informed about positive coronavirus cases in the White House today? [SEP] You're going to—I cannot hear you, I'm sorry.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, the Washington Post is reporting that the coronavirus bill is being held up due to White House demands regarding the FBI building. Can you comment? [SEP] I can't say for sure if it's in *this* specific bill, but the FBI needs a new building, period. The current one is ancient, poorly constructed, and frankly, dangerous. Pieces are falling off! They were considering sites far outside of Washington, which I thought was ridiculous. They need to be near the Justice Department. The existing site is the best. So, I've been advocating for a new building. A renovation won't cut it; we need a modern, state-of-the-art facility for the next century, perhaps even with a running track on top! It's a very large site. The best solution is to build new. Whether it's in this bill or another, the FBI will get its new building. Thank you all.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify the Iran agreement, your administration claims the framework is set in stone, yet implementation details are negotiable. Critics argue this allows Iran to exploit loopholes. Can you assure the public that key concessions, like unrestricted military site inspections and immediate sanctions relief, won't be granted during these negotiations? [SEP] Let's be clear: we have a framework, a solid foundation built on agreements between Iran and the P5+1. Certain aspects, like centrifuge reduction at Natanz and Fordow's conversion, are meticulously defined. Others involve broader intentions, where the devil is truly in the details. These details, naturally, will be subject to rigorous negotiation. To suggest that everything is finalized is simply inaccurate. We have a framework that, if properly implemented, will prevent Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon. The structure of these details is crucial, and I assure you, the negotiations will be tough. This is precisely what I stated from the outset, and our position remains consistent. Remember the interim agreement, the JPOA? We faced similar interpretive disagreements then. Yet, through negotiation, we achieved a substantial agreement, subject to review and ultimately effective, even according to critics like the Israelis. They acknowledged its success. Now, they propose maintaining the status quo, despite previously opposing the final deal with similar arguments. As for Cuba, we didn't delve into the specifics you mentioned. The State Sponsor of Terrorism recommendation is under review. If approved, Congress will also have the opportunity to review it. Regarding the embassy, Cuban concerns are understandable given their unfamiliarity with American embassies. We're prepared to move forward, confident in improved dialogue and prospects for the Cuban people. Finally, I thank the Latin American countries and the people of Panama for their partnership.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are America's banks in trouble? And does the rescue of Freddie Mae and Fannie Mac make more bailouts inevitable by sending the message that there are some institutions that are too big to fail and that it's okay to take risks? [SEP] First, let me talk about Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. A lot of people in the country probably don't understand how important they are to the mortgage markets. And it's really important for people to have confidence in the mortgage markets and that there be stability in the mortgage markets. And that's why Secretary Paulson announced the plan this weekend, which says that he needs authorities from the Congress to come up with a line of credit for these institutions, if needed, and that he ought to have the authority to invest capital, if needed.And so the purpose was to send a clear signal that, one, we understand how important these institutions are to the mortgage markets, and two, to kind of calm nerves. The truth of the matter is, by laying this out, it is—makes it less likely we'll need to use this kind of authority to begin with, which, by the way, is temporary authority.As you—talked about banks. Now, if you're a commercial bank in America and your deposit—and you have a deposit in a commercial bank in America, your deposit is insured by the Federal Government up to $100,000. And so therefore, when you hear nervousness about your bank, you know, people start talking about how nervous they are about your bank's condition, the depositor must understand that the Federal Government, through the FDIC, stands behind the deposit up to $100,000. And therefore—which leads me to say that if you're a depositor, you're in—you're protected by the Federal Government.I happened to have witnessed a bank run in Midland, Texas, one time. I'll never forget the guy standing in the bank lobby saying, Your deposits are good. We got you insured. You don't have to worry about it if you got less than $100,000 in the bank. The problem was, people didn't hear. And there's a—became a nervousness. My hope is, is that people take a deep breath and realize that their deposits are protected by our Government.So these are two different instances, mortgage markets on the one hand, banking on the other.
label: General

sentence: Q. [Inaudible]Chancellor Merkel. You will get a microphone, don't worry.Iran/Germany-U.S. Relations Q. Mr. President, Madam Chancellor, you spoke about Iran at some length. In Israel, the press writes that Israel might well contemplate action against this threat that Iran poses to them. What would be your—what are you saying, Mr. President, to the Israeli Government? And you said, Chancellor, give diplomacy a chance. Madam Chancellor, Mr. President, how long would you say diplomacy has to be given a chance? Can we exclude that during your term in office military action will be taken—will take place against Iran, Mr. President?And you, Chancellor, how do you assess the era of George Bush? In your party, one of your leading party members said that you will not miss George Bush. Will you miss him?And a question directed to both of you. Why do you, Mr. President——Chancellor Merkel. I think—don't ask for too long. Q. ——but why do you—why are you seen as so unpopular, Mr. President, in Germany? [SEP] I just told you that all options are on the table, and my first choice is to solve this diplomatically. And the best way to solve it diplomatically is to work with our partners, and that's exactly what we're doing. And the message to the ian Government is very clear: that there's a better way forward than isolation, and that is for you to verifiably suspend your enrichment program. And the choice is theirs to make. Obviously, we want to solve this issue peacefully, and so we'll give diplomacy a chance to work. And I want to thank the message that came out of the EU meeting yesterday, which is that if they choose to be—continue to be obstinate, there will be additional sanctions. We talked just now at some length about this. I very clearly pin my hopes on diplomatic efforts. And I believe that diplomatic pressure actually already has taken effect. If you look at the situation in on the ground, you see that quite clearly. These efforts can have a success, but this presupposes, obviously, that the global community is sort of unified. Both in the European Union and in the world Security Council, we have to continue this common approach. We cannot exclude either that there may well be a further round of sanctions, and those need to be negotiated in the Security Council of the United Nations.What's important now is to see to it that this last round of the sanctions is actually implemented and can take effect, because the effectiveness of sanctions is actually then proved only once they are taken seriously. And we are under certain—quite a considerable pressure to act together and in concert. And we in the European Union will do everything to see to it that this actually happens.As regards our relationship, you know that this is a relationship characterized by friendship. It's a direct and candid relationship. When there are differences of opinion—whenever there were differences of opinions, we actually called a spade a spade. It's actually nice about the President that you can actually call a spade a spade with him. And when, for example, I had— as regards to the climate change discussion last year, this year, when we—ever we had differences of opinion, there was a way forward; there was a constructive way forward.And I think that this initiative on climate by the European Union is a very important initiative. The President himself took, actually, forward action on this, apart from our military action that we do together, for example, in Afghanistan, in the general international negotiating processes.We also need on other areas between the European Union and the United States, not only Germany and the United States, a lot of close cooperation in many areas. And there was always greater—great openness here between us. This cooperation is fun, I must say. And as the President said, it is going to be a sprint to the last day of his office. And I trust—often trust that we shall have other similar meetings of this kind, candid and open and constructive.I'm looking forward to the G-8 summit in Japan. I hope that we can make further progress on climate protection, which— talking about targets now—that is to say, some kind of binding targets—I think is already great success.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. So, if I understand correctly, you're saying both options are equally valid? [SEP] Indeed, or perhaps a synthesis of the two. Are we on the same page? Please, proceed.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, could you perhaps give us a general idea of the geographic location of these announcements? Perhaps a continent? [SEP] No, I'm not going to give you any hints. It will be announced very soon. You'll just have to wait and see.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, the exemption you granted the U.K. from the travel ban expires at midnight. Given that 17 Schengen zone countries have fewer coronavirus cases than the U.K., and the U.K. added 208 cases in the last 24 hours, why does the U.K. deserve an exemption? Will you consider adding them to the travel ban list? [SEP] That recommendation came from a group of professionals, and we're reevaluating it based on the latest numbers. We might have to include them in the list of countries we'll, you could say, ban—or whatever term you want to use—during this period. Their numbers have risen sharply in the last 24 hours, so we might add them, and perhaps a few others. We might also start considering removing some countries from the list.
label: Implicit

sentence: Is he likely to remain in his current role? [SEP] Look, he's performing admirably, no question about it. But we always assess performance, and we'll have a better sense of things in about a week. We're constantly reviewing.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thanks, Mr. President. Germany has said that Alexei Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, was poisoned. What do you think should be done to Russia about that? And what is your message to Russia about that? And how should the international community and the United States respond? [SEP] Well, I think we have to look at it very seriously if that's the case, and I think we will. There's nobody been tougher on Russia than I have. We get along. I get along with almost all countries.I get along with North Korea. Remember? We were supposed to be going to war with North Korea. If Hillary got elected, you'd be at war right now with North Korea. That would be a very messy war, a very bad war. Many millions of people would be killed. In the meantime, we've gotten along with them. We didn't get to war. Everyone said that if I was elected, I'd be at war in 1 week; it's been just the opposite.We're doing very well in Afghanistan, bringing the troops down—very low level—and other things are happening. Very interestingly, we have a great peace deal going on in the Middle East, actually, with U.A.E. and Israel. And that's been received like, probably, very few things that many people have done. It's been very well received. And we'll be having other countries announcing soon; they're joining that, and you're going to have a lot of countries in that. A lot of countries are saying, Hey, why didn't you bring us in right from the beginning? They would have loved to have been there, but they want to be in.So we're doing a lot of things. I think that I was the one that alerted the United States and the world: Nord Stream 2. I said: Why is Germany spending billions and billions of dollars to Russia to get their energy from Russia, and then we're supposed to protect Germany from Russia? What's that all about? And the sanctions and everything else.At the same time, with Russia, we're right now negotiating a nuclear nonproliferation treaty, which is very important. It's a very important thing. To me, it's the most important thing. Some people say global warming; I don't. I say this is far more important. And we are the biggest; they are the second biggest, nuclear-wise. China is third. They're actually a distant third, but they're building pretty rapidly. And at some point, we'll include China into those talks, but we're doing very well with Russia on nuclear nonproliferation.So I don't know exactly what happened. I think it's tragic. It's terrible. It shouldn't happen. We haven't had any proof yet, but I will take a look.
label: Dodging

sentence: Russia says it's scaling back operations near Kyiv. Do you think this signals a potential end to the war, or is it just a strategic pause to regroup? [SEP] We'll have to wait and see what they actually do. Actions speak louder than words. There are negotiations ongoing, and we're consulting with our allies. We'll maintain sanctions and continue supporting Ukraine.

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. It seems that yesterday morning you had a very spirited and lively discussion within the—with the G-8-plus-5-plus-1, ignited by President Lula objection to the format, to the adequacy of the G-8 as a forum. And, well, I would like—what was your argument in this discussion and whether or not you have the feeling that the days of the G-8 are over? [SEP] Yes.

sentence: President, if negotiations with North Korea stall, what specific measures, including potential sanctions enhancements, are under consideration by your administration? [SEP] We already have powerful sanctions. I'm not going to comment on increasing them. The people of North Korea matter. I know Chairman Kim. I have spoken with President Xi. I must now return to Washington. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics claim you've shifted your stance on tax increases, particularly regarding Social Security and those who supported you. Furthermore, there's a growing perception that negotiations are stalling. Can you provide an honest assessment? Are we headed for a fiscal crisis? [SEP] Look, let's be clear: a crisis is avoidable. During the campaign, I said we needed a balanced approach to deficit reduction. That means millionaires and billionaires paying their fair share, tough spending cuts, but protecting vulnerable families. The package I proposed reflects that balance. I'm willing to make tough concessions, even ones unpopular with my own party, to reach a compromise. We need a solution that both parties can support to stabilize the economy and protect the middle class. I've already moved significantly towards Republican concerns, even though the majority of Americans agree we should raise taxes on the wealthiest to reduce the deficit. The fact that Speaker Boehner hasn't accepted what I believe is a fair deal is perplexing. I remain optimistic, but ultimately, Congress needs to do its job. The framework for a deal is there, but it requires compromise. Voters want compromise, not ideological gridlock. We need to act in the best interests of the country, especially after recent tragedies. I'm ready to get a deal done before Christmas, but it requires adjustments from both sides. The Speaker's 'Plan B', which gives tax breaks to millionaires while cutting unemployment benefits, violates the principles debated during the election. My hope is that Congress will ensure middle-class taxes don't rise, protect vital programs like college tax credits, and agree to a balanced deficit reduction package.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Trump, given the high turnover rate within your administration, with numerous key officials resigning or being fired, what steps are you taking to ensure stability and competence in your cabinet and senior staff, and how do you address concerns about the impact of this instability on policy implementation? [SEP] I have the best people. The very best. Sometimes, people just don't work out. It's like in business. You hire someone, and maybe they're not the right fit. That's all it is. We're always looking for the best and brightest. And we have tremendous talent in this administration. We're doing a fantastic job, the best job ever. People are saying it.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, could you address the widespread anger among Democrats regarding the extension of tax cuts for the wealthy in the recent tax bill? Do you believe your rhetoric, labeling these tax cuts as 'morally inappropriate,' exacerbates this division? [SEP] I appreciate the frustration. I've stated previously, and I'll reiterate: I don't believe we can sustain tax breaks for individuals who are already prosperous. They thrived during Bill Clinton's presidency. This will be a recurring debate over the coming years. Upon the swearing-in of the new Congress, we'll need to discuss how to achieve a balanced budget. This necessitates cutting ineffective programs, but also honestly addressing the funding of essential priorities. If we aim to provide adequate care for our veterans, we must allocate funds for the necessary doctors and facilities. If we aspire for our children's success, we must invest in education. If we seek to maintain our competitiveness, we must invest in basic research. We must weigh the option of maintaining tax cuts for the wealthy against investing in these priorities. I comprehend why some Democrats, and even some Republicans, believe we could have foregone that aspect of the tax package. However, compromise entails accepting certain unfavorable elements. The overall package was the correct one to stimulate economic growth and job creation. There's no superior antipoverty program than a thriving economy, nor a better deficit-reduction program. Had the economy contracted, our choices would have been even more difficult.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. If I may follow up quickly, sir. You're describing the situation you're in right now. What about the last 2 years when it comes to your preferred option? Was there a failure either on the part of the Democratic leadership on the Hill or here that you couldn't preclude these wealthier cuts from going forward? [SEP] Well, let me say that on the Republican side, this is their holy grail, these tax cuts for the wealthy. This is--seems to be their central economic doctrine. And so, unless we had 60 votes in the Senate at any given time, it would be very hard for us to move this forward. I have said that I would have liked to have seen a vote before the election. I thought this was a strong position for us to take into the election, to crystallize the positions of the two parties, because I think the Democrats have better ideas. I think our proposal to make sure that the middle class is held harmless, but that we don't make these Bush tax cuts permanent for wealthy individuals, because it was going to cost the country at a time when we've got these looming deficits, that that was the better position to take. And the American people were persuaded by that.But the fact of the matter is, I haven't persuaded the Republican Party. I haven't persuaded Mitch McConnell and I haven't persuaded John Boehner. And if I can't persuade them, then I've got to look at what is the best thing to do, given that reality, for the American people and for jobs.Julianna [Julianna Goldman, Bloomberg News].
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, Mr. Ledgett suggested a conversation about amnesty for Edward Snowden. How did you react to him publicly raising this idea, and under what conditions would you entertain a plea or amnesty? Furthermore, what's your message to Americans who believe Snowden acted justly in exposing surveillance practices? [SEP] Look, I have to tread carefully here. Snowden's facing indictment, and it's in the hands of the Attorney General and the courts. I can't comment directly on the case. But I will say this: the debate he sparked was necessary. However, the way he did it caused real damage to our intelligence capabilities. There was a better way. The U.S., despite its flaws, respects the rule of law and privacy. Now, countries that actually *do* what Snowden accused us of are using this to deflect criticism. So, while the conversation was important, the leaks hurt us. The courts will decide Snowden's fate.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering your broader views on firearms, can you explain the rationale behind commuting sentences for individuals convicted of firearm offenses? [SEP] Yes.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Obama, given the concerns raised about the FBI's handling of the investigation into Hillary Clinton's emails, what specific reforms should be implemented to ensure transparency and accountability within the agency, and to restore public trust in its ability to conduct impartial investigations? [SEP] Well, the transition from campaigning to governing is never easy. There are still a lot of raw emotions out there. But I'm confident that President-elect Trump will take his responsibilities seriously. I've offered him some advice on maintaining the integrity of our democratic institutions. As for the FBI, I have a lot of respect for the agents and Director Comey. They work hard to keep us safe. It's always a challenge when law enforcement and politics intersect, but I've always tried to stay out of their way and let them do their jobs.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: So, regarding the necessity of a formal signing, is this agreement of the type that would typically require one? [SEP] Well, that's a rather nuanced question, isn't it? Whether it *technically* requires a signature is, frankly, debatable, given its non-legally binding nature. The protocols, I confess, are not something I'm intimately familiar with. However, let me be clear: the United States is making a commitment here, a commitment we deem of utmost importance. Thank you all.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Can you elaborate on the reasons preventing collaboration while under subpoena? [SEP] To what specific collaborative effort are you alluding?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. How confident are you of resolving your differences over the missile shield with President Putin during your talks in Sochi? And also, sir, there was a growing impression that you are looking, perhaps, at a tradeoff in which the U.S. would soften its push for Membership Action Plans in NATO for Ukraine and Georgia if Russia acquiesces on missile defense. Could you please address that as well? [SEP] Yes, I'll be glad to address it. That is a misperception. I strongly believe that Ukraine and Georgia should be given MAP, and there's no tradeoffs— period. As a matter of fact, I told that to President Putin on my phone call with him recently. I said: You just got to know, I'm headed to Bucharest with the idea in mind of getting MAP for Ukraine and Georgia. And you shouldn't fear that, Mr. President. I mean, after all, NATO is a organization that's peaceful, or NATO is an organization that helps democracies flourish. Democracies are good things to have on your border.And on the second point, on missile defense, it's in his interests that we participate and share information. After all, a missile from the Middle East can fly north just as easily as it could fly west. And the capacity to be able to share information and share technology to be able to deal with these threats is important for a lot of countries, including Russia.So yes, there's all kinds of rumors about things, but thank you for asking and giving me a chance to clarify. My position is absolutely solid. My position is absolutely solid. Ukraine and Georgia should be given MAP. Thank you.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, following up on the chemical weapons concern, can you confirm any intelligence suggesting Putin is positioning or considering the use of these weapons? Moreover, what specific military actions are under consideration by the U.S. and NATO should such weapons be deployed? [SEP] I'm not at liberty to discuss specific intelligence assessments. However, let me assure you that the use of chemical weapons is a red line. Should that line be crossed, there will be a response. The scale and scope of that response will be determined by the nature of the transgression.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Hypothetically, what would happen if Republicans were to seize control of the House? [SEP] If they take control, it's going to be much closer. The predictions were way off. This wasn't a red wave like everyone said. We weren't going to lose 30 to 50 seats. There are always enough people on the other side that the opposite party can appeal to and maybe pick them off to get the help. So it remains to be seen. For example, do you think Senator Johnson is going to move to cut Medicare and Social Security? And if he does, how many Republicans do you think are going to vote for it? It depends.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Sir, do you think a deal was possible without Israel agreeing to halt annexation, even temporarily? [SEP] I'm sorry, would you mind repeating that?
label: Clarification

sentence: This is your third budget, and you've said you'd rather be a one-term President if it means doing the hard things. Why not invite Republicans to negotiate now? What else are you doing to build cooperation? And will the markets wait two years? [SEP] Jackie, I should have taken notes! My brain's about to explode.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, following up on your recent fundraiser comments, did calling President Xi a dictator potentially undermine the progress your administration has made in maintaining a relationship with China? And secondly, regarding India, what is your message to those who feel your administration is overlooking the targeting of religious minorities in Prime Minister Modi's country? [SEP] The answer to the first part is a resounding no. When engaging with allies and partners, including India, the notion of censoring myself or avoiding stating what I believe to be the facts regarding China is simply not something I'm inclined to do. I believe that the hysteria surrounding the relationship with China is overblown. We experienced an incident that caused some confusion, shall we say. But Secretary Blinken had a productive trip to China, and I anticipate meeting with President Xi in the near future. I don't believe my comments have had any significant repercussions. And remind me of your second question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with Republican Leader McCarthy confident about retaking the House, what specific factors do you believe will determine the outcome of these close races? [SEP] Well, it's all about turnout. If our people get out and vote, we're going to win. The Democrats are trying to cheat, they're trying to steal the election, but if our people are vigilant, we're going to win. We have the best policies, we have the best candidates, and we have the best supporters. We're going to win big.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Can I ask another question, sir, on a different topic, Mr. President? Mr. President, what exactly is un-American about Federal Government training programs that are aimed at improving inclusivity or pointing out biases? [SEP] Well, we're going to do a report. Yes, I fired those people; they're all gone. And it was a disgrace, frankly. And we're going to give you a big report that's going to make you very happy.All right, yes, please.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, is it possible that the next meeting will take place shortly, or could it be some time before it occurs? [SEP] It's difficult to predict with certainty. It might happen soon, or it might not happen for quite a while. I can't provide a definitive answer. I would prefer it to be soon, but it's also possible that it will be delayed.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Madam President, Brazil sees itself as a global leader, but the US sees it as regional. Thoughts? [SEP] The US President already touched on this. But let me add: every country faces problems. That doesn't make them less important. Brazil will overcome its issues and remain a strong US partner. We share a past, a democracy, and a diverse people. We will build a better future together.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, you've talked about a return to normalcy. Does this election mean the fever's broken? [SEP] The mega-MAGA folks? Probably not for them. But most Republicans are decent people, even if we disagree. The world's watching us. At the G7, they asked, 'How long will this last?' They're worried about our stability. They want to know if we're still the same democracy.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the debt ceiling discussions, would you consider tax breaks to stimulate the economy, even if they increase the deficit? And following up on your earlier comments about same-sex marriage and the progress in states like New York, has your personal position evolved to support same-sex marriage, regardless of individual state laws? [SEP] I'm not going to make news on that today. Good try though.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, the American people deserve a clear answer on whether adding yet another agency to the regulatory landscape will truly solve the problem or simply create more red tape. Can you definitively state that this new agency won't just become another layer of bureaucracy? [SEP] Look, I appreciate the concern, and I understand the skepticism. But let me be clear: the goal here isn't to create more bureaucracy for the sake of bureaucracy. It's about filling critical gaps in our regulatory framework that have allowed bad actors to run wild and put our entire economy at risk. The details of how this new agency will work in concert with existing regulators will be laid out tomorrow. But I can assure you that we've taken steps to ensure that it will be a streamlined, efficient, and effective tool for protecting consumers and preventing future crises.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Beyond Huawei, are there other Chinese tech firms on your radar for potential bans in the United States? [SEP] Well, Huawei is the big one, right? We're not allowing Huawei here. I've told European countries and others—Australia's been fantastic—that Huawei is a no-go. We've warned countries considering Huawei that we won't share intelligence. They've all backed down. The UK looked like they were going that way, but now they've reversed course.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, the coronavirus response has been plagued by confusing messages. Why no changes at the CDC? [SEP] Scientists are learning, that's why. Polio was the same. New virus, new problems. The vaccine was fast. Not perfect, but fast. Anyway...
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, reflecting on your time in office, what was the steepest learning curve you encountered? How long did it take you to feel truly comfortable in the role, if ever? And did you discuss these challenges with President-elect Trump? [SEP] Well, just about a week ago, I started feeling like I knew what I was doing. Just kidding! The learning never stops. This job is unlike any other. It's a constant barrage of information, challenges, and problems. And that's more true now than ever, because of how connected the world is. Fifty years ago, a tragedy in Syria might not have even registered with the American people. Now, they see graphic images instantly. A financial crisis in Southeast Asia used to have no impact on our markets; now it does. The sheer volume of information any administration has to process and respond to is staggering. I saw a documentary where JFK had two weeks before the press reported on the Bay of Pigs. Imagine that! Today, a president has about an hour to figure out their response. That's what I shared with the President-elect. It was a candid and, I hope, helpful conversation. I tried to be honest about what any incoming president needs to consider. The most important thing is how you staff your team, especially your Chief of Staff, National Security Advisor, and White House Counsel. You need a system to surface information and generate options, understanding that the president makes the final call. I've been lucky to have some of the smartest, hardest-working, and best people in my administration. Because of that team, I've been able to make good decisions. Without that support, you'll be overwhelmed. I hope he took that advice to heart. I also mentioned how encouraged I was by his election night remarks about unity and being a president for all people. How he staffs his team, the first steps he takes, the first impressions he makes – all of that matters. It takes time to put it all together. But I stressed that in such a divisive election, gestures matter. How he reaches out to those who didn't support him, how he addresses their concerns – that can set a tone that helps move things forward.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to North Korea's denuclearization pledge, what concrete steps are being taken to verify their compliance, and what consequences will they face if they fail to meet their commitments? Is this agreement truly different from previous, unsuccessful attempts? [SEP] Well, let me tell you, nobody can be absolutely sure of anything. But I have a feeling. A very strong feeling. I know these things. I've made a lot of deals, some great deals. And this has the potential to be the greatest deal of all. They want it. China wants it. The world wants it. We'll see. We'll see.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, your team says the Iran framework agreement is non-negotiable, yet concerns remain about inspections and sanctions. Also, on Cuba, did you discuss the 45-day waiting period for removing them from the state sponsor of terrorism list with President Castro? Do you believe there are no impediments to opening embassies once Cuba is removed? [SEP] Regarding Iran, the political framework outlines specifics like centrifuge reductions and Fordow's conversion. However, details matter and are subject to negotiation. It's inaccurate to suggest everything is finalized.
