The framework, if implemented, will prevent Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon, but the details are crucial. Tough negotiations lie ahead, as I've stated from the beginning. We had similar back-and-forth during the interim agreement, but the final result was substantial and effective, even according to critics. On Cuba, we didn't discuss the specific details you mentioned. I will review the state sponsor of terrorism recommendation, and Congress will have an opportunity to review it as well. Concerns about the embassy are likely on the Cuban side, given their lack of experience with an American embassy. This shift is more profound for them than for us. We're ready to move forward and improve dialogue, ultimately benefiting the Cuban people. Thank you to the Latin American countries and the people of Panama. I'm optimistic about the region due to its extraordinary people.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, having just reinforced the U.S.-Japan alliance and articulated a vision for a free and open Indo-Pacific, how can the U.S. champion freedom and openness in this region without inevitably clashing with China? Prime Minister, did the President express any dissatisfaction regarding Japan's decision not to intercept the North Korean missile, and what message did you convey concerning Japan's role in its own defense? [SEP] Mark, to add to the Prime Minister's response, he will be in a position to intercept those missiles once he finalizes the purchase of additional military hardware from the United States. He will readily intercept them, much like we successfully intercepted a missile in Saudi Arabia recently. It was a remarkably swift missile, akin to hitting a needle in the sky, and it was neutralized instantly without causing any damage. Therefore, I believe it's crucial to acknowledge that the Prime Minister of Japan is poised to acquire substantial quantities of military equipment, as he should. And we produce the finest military equipment, bar none. He will be procuring it from the United States, whether it's the F-35 fighter, which boasts unparalleled stealth capabilities, or various types of missiles, which translates into numerous jobs for us and enhanced security for Japan and other nations that are also purchasing significant amounts of military equipment from us, something that wasn't happening a year or two ago. As for China, my relationship with President Xi is excellent. I hold him in high regard and consider him a friend, and he reciprocates that sentiment. However, he represents China, while I represent the United States. Our perspectives may differ, but we share similar views on trade. The issue with China is that for decades, the trade relationship has been exceedingly unfair, to put it mildly, under previous administrations. Our trade deficit is enormous, ranging from $350 billion to $504 billion annually, and that excludes intellectual property. We've already initiated discussions with China to rectify this imbalance, which necessitates free, fair, or reciprocal trade. Personally, I favor reciprocal trade. It's more easily understood. When you explain that tariffs will be imposed to level the playing field, or other measures will be taken, some people may not grasp it. But when you emphasize reciprocity—that we will charge the same tariffs that they charge us—even those who oppose a 5-percent or 10-percent tariff concede that reciprocity is fair, even if it amounts to 100 percent. So, reciprocal trade is far more comprehensible, Mark, and it's of utmost importance to me. Many countries, not just China or Japan, are guilty of this. We have countries that impose a hundred-percent tax on our goods, while we impose nothing on theirs. I've long opposed this, and we will take action. However, it takes time due to statutory limitations. Notices must be issued, and waiting periods observed. But much of this has already been addressed. You will witness strong action against countries that have been treating the United States, its workers, and its companies unfairly. I view companies as extensions of the workforce. This action has already commenced, and the legal groundwork is complete. You will see a significant change very soon, as the United States has been treated unfairly in trade for far too long. Thank you very much. Regarding Japan's defense equipment, we purchase a considerable amount from the United States. Given the escalating tensions with North Korea and the precarious security situation in the Asia-Pacific region, we must qualitatively and quantitatively enhance our defense capabilities. The F-35A and SM-3 Block IIA are prime examples of acquisitions from the United States. Aegis vessels also require enhancement in both quality and quantity. In this process, we will be procuring more from the United States. That is my intention. Now, concerning North Korea: We tracked the missiles immediately after their launch and were able to ascertain their trajectory. Missile defense is a collaborative endeavor between Japan and the United States. The missile defense system is a joint effort. If interception and shooting down become necessary, we will certainly do so, but in close coordination with the U.S.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given the varying approaches to mask mandates across states, with some governors advocating strongly for them while others remain hesitant, shouldn't there be a unified national stance on mask-wearing to combat the pandemic effectively? [SEP] Well, look, everybody's saying, if you want to wear a mask, wear it. I'm all for it. I've got one right here. I've worn it myself. When I'm in places like hospitals, or you know, when you can't keep your distance, I think it's a good idea. I've got it right here, see? And you know, in some situations, I think it's a really good thing to have. Like when you're traveling. It's a smart move. So yeah, I think it's a good thing.
label: General

sentence: Q. So, to be absolutely clear, are you willing to sign off on that specific legislative proposal as it stands today? [SEP] Well, not in its current form, but we're making progress. Significant progress, actually. My priority is ensuring resources reach those who suffered needlessly because of, well, let's just say certain preventative measures weren't taken when they could have been. If those measures had been in place, this wouldn't have spread across 188 countries. It's a real shame, frankly.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the deep divisions among the signatories to the JCPOA, what makes you confident that you can forge a new agreement that addresses all of these concerns? Isn't it more likely that your efforts will simply lead to further instability and a collapse of the existing framework? [SEP] Diplomacy is never easy, but it is essential. We are engaging in intensive discussions with our allies and partners to find a common path forward. We recognize that there are significant challenges, but we believe that a new agreement is possible if all parties are willing to negotiate in good faith. We are committed to working with our allies to address their concerns and to ensure that any new agreement is in the best interests of regional and global security. We will not allow Iran to develop a nuclear weapon, and we will use all available tools to prevent that from happening.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. And is nuclear happening? [SEP] So we talked about many things—many, many things. We talked about Iran. We talked about Iraq. We talked about—you know, we were together for 2 days. I'm going to be with Prime Minister Modi tonight for a state dinner at 7 o'clock. It starts at 7, I believe.And we talked about exactly all of the things that you're talking about. We also talked about tariffs, because as you know, India is probably the highest tariff nation in the world, meaning charging tariffs to outsiders. And I said, we have to stop that. We have to stop it, at least as it pertains to the United States. And I think we're understanding each other.With China, we worked a deal, and we worked it because of the tariffs. And I was able to leave the tariffs on. That will take care of phase two. We still have 25 percent on $250 billion.But in the meantime, we're working with China very much on the virus. We feel that's something. And I have to tell—I spoke to President Xi the other day. He is so committed to solving that problem. He is—he is working very hard. He is very capable. The country is very capable. And it snuck up on him, but I think he's going to do well.Now you see it's going to South Korea, it's going to Italy, and it's going to other places. But I spoke to all of them. They're all working very, very hard on it.The United States, because of an early decision I made—I made a decision. I believe it was the first time it's ever been done: We closed the country to certain areas, as you know. And I was criticized for that decision. Now they're saying it was a good decision.I think it was a good decision, because we have very few people. And you can add to it a few people that we took in because they're Americans. I mean, what are we going to do? And they were almost in between countries, where people weren't going to take them, and they're Americans. But they're fully quarantined. They call it fully quarantined. So you know, we did the right thing. If you were out there, if you were an American and you refused to have any help from your country—these were wonderful people. It wasn't their fault.So—but we're down to—we're really down to probably 10. Most of the people are outside of danger right now. But we've had a very strict line on the people that were taken—the areas from which we take. And I did it very early. It's never done before, and I did it early. So I think it was a good decision as it turned out. Yes, please.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the NATO summit in Chicago, do you anticipate an agreement on a transition strategy for Afghanistan? And are you concerned that the Koran burning incident and its aftermath might hinder negotiations with your partners? [SEP] The transition policy, as established in Lisbon, remains in effect. We're committed to transferring increasing responsibility to the Afghans, with a full transition and the end of our combat role by the end of 2014. Our coalition partners are on board and sticking to the plan. At the upcoming NATO meeting, we'll focus on ensuring a smooth transition, avoiding a 'cliff' effect. Like our drawdown in Iraq, this will be a gradual process, building Afghan capacity and strengthening partnerships with Afghan security forces. We'll also establish the necessary support structures for the overall strategy to succeed. The Koran burning incident is concerning and highlights the challenges in Afghanistan, underscoring the need for transition. While violence against our people is unacceptable, President Karzai is eager for greater Afghan responsibility. We'll find a way to respect Afghan sovereignty while empowering them to take greater control of their security. This is in the best interest of both Afghans and ourselves. While I'm confident we can execute the plan, there will be bumps along the road, just as there were in Iraq.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Bush, analysts claim Senator Obama's victory would help the free trade agreement pass in Congress. Your thoughts? [SEP] Look, the best thing, plain and simple, is McCain winning. I trust him to get the job done. We gotta stop playing politics with this trade bill and start thinking strategically. It's good for business, good for the country, good for security. End of story.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Given this is your third year and budget, and your past statements about prioritizing hard choices over re-election, what concrete steps are you taking to encourage bipartisan negotiation, especially considering market anxieties about the timeline? [SEP] Hold on, hold on... I'm going to need a pen and paper for that one. You're packing a lot in there.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, thank you. You mentioned closing remaining gaps in State and Federal government regarding matters of race. How does criminal justice reform align with this goal, and what specific gaps remain for you to address? Additionally, what is the significance of your upcoming trip to Kenya, your father's homeland, as President of the United States? Finally, will you consider revoking Bill Cosby's Medal of Freedom? [SEP] April, you've packed a lot into that question. Let's just say I'm not going to comment on that.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Trans-Pacific Partnership, given the apparent lack of momentum in Congress and the concerns of our international partners, are you considering a revised approach to secure its ratification? Furthermore, could you elaborate on the implications of Mullah Mansur's death for U.S. policy in Afghanistan, particularly concerning potential shifts in military strategy and the leadership dynamics within the Taliban? [SEP] Well, let's be clear, trade agreements are always a challenge, especially when you're dealing with multiple stakeholders, and everyone's trying to maximize their advantage. But I remain optimistic that we'll get this done because it's fundamentally in our national interest. It's good for American businesses, good for American workers, and good for the global economy. Now, I understand the concerns about currency manipulation, and we've incorporated provisions to address transparency and reporting. However, we're not going to compromise our monetary policy. As for Mullah Mansur, his actions posed a direct threat to our personnel in Afghanistan. This wasn't a shift in our overall strategy, but a necessary measure to protect American lives and send a clear message to the Taliban.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Trump, concerning the questions surrounding Kamala Harris's eligibility, do you have an opinion on whether she meets the requirements to serve as Vice President? [SEP] I'm hearing things, I'm hearing things. I don't know if they're true. But you'd think the Democrats would have checked it out, right? I mean, you'd think so.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Obama, do you believe China's growing influence poses a threat to regional stability, and would the mutual defense treaty between the U.S. and the Philippines be invoked in the event of armed conflict in the South China Sea? [SEP] Well, let me reiterate, a prosperous is good for the region and the world. Lifting people out of poverty strengthens the region. As President Aquino said, has stated its commitment to international law. Our message is consistent: we want to partner with you in upholding international law. Larger countries have a greater responsibility to abide by international norms. Territorial disputes exist worldwide. We have them with allies. But we resolve them peacefully, diplomatically. That's the message I've heard throughout Asia: peaceful, diplomatic resolution. President Aquino's approach, international arbitration, is sound. If listens to its neighbors, it will find willing partners throughout the region for trade and commerce. will inevitably be a dominant power. The question is whether other countries can also succeed on their own terms. That's what we support.
label: Dodging

sentence: So, you think Hillary's got the nomination locked up, sir? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, you seem to have softened your stance on the Prime Minister's Brexit proposal after previously suggesting it would hinder a trade deal with the UK. Given the 'special relationship,' was publicly criticizing her approach and questioning her judgment appropriate? [SEP] Let me be clear, I wasn't criticizing the Prime Minister. I have great respect for her. The media didn't accurately reflect my positive remarks. That's why we record these interviews now. It's called fake news. The Prime Minister will make her own decisions. My only concern is ensuring we can continue to trade freely. We don't want any limitations. We're their largest trading partner, and there's potential for significant growth. So, if they choose a different path, I hope we can still trade. I believe it's possible after discussions with her representatives. Trade is somewhat complex, but I'm confident we can find a solution. And she's doing a tremendous job, by the way.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, considering the increasing human and financial costs of the Iraq War, and the growing calls for a new approach, what specific metrics are you using to measure the success of the surge, and when will you deem it necessary to re-evaluate our strategy? [SEP] Look, the American people are understandably concerned about the war. It's a tough war, against a ruthless enemy. But we're making progress. We're seeing improvements in security in key areas. We're waiting for General Petraeus's report. He's the expert. I'm going to listen to him. And we're going to make decisions based on the facts on the ground, not on political pressure.
label: Deflection

sentence: Am I correct in understanding that the White House is encouraging the NIH and FDA to accelerate this process? [SEP] Well, if the data is as promising as I'm being told—I'm hearing numbers exceeding 50 percent, which is excellent. We've approved certain things at 31 percent, which is also satisfactory; that's not bad. And it's really had a tremendous impact. But, no, I have—you're telling me something right now that surprises me, but we'll check it out right after this.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, isn't this about more than just 'cancel culture'? Shouldn't schools teach a complete and honest account of our history, including slavery? [SEP] Absolutely, everyone needs to know our history, the good and the bad. I'm against cancel culture, you have to learn from the mistakes of the past. But they're trying to change our history, take down our monuments, rename the Washington Monument. It's ridiculous. That's not happening on my watch. Anyway, happy Labor Day, we're doing great with the vaccines, despite the plague that came from China. They should have stopped it.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. [inaudible]--of her accomplishments in the past, or is it as well an expression of the expectations that you would have for the future? And if so, where do you see areas globally where the Chancellor and Germany can do more?And, Madam Chancellor, addressed to you, Germany is, after all, actually being praised in America through its economic might, its progress. Does this mean, however, also that it entails certain enhanced responsibilities and where you have to live up to responsibilities, or do you think Germany needs to do more in the future? [SEP] With respect to the Medal of Freedom, it certainly is a recognition of the Chancellor's remarkable career. I think not only has she been an excellent steward of the German economy and the European project, but she represents the unification of Europe through her own life story and the capacity to overcome the past and point towards a brighter future.So the extraordinary work that she's already done, I think, would by itself merit the Medal of Freedom. Fortunately, she's going to be around quite a bit longer. And so she's going to be doing outstanding work in the future. Her leadership will be critical on economic issues of the sort that we just discussed in the euro zone. And I very much compliment her on the courage with which she approaches some of these very difficult political issues, at some significant political costs to herself.On the international stage, there's no issues that we don't coordinate closely with Germany. And our work in Afghanistan, our work together with NATO, the approach that we've taken with respect to the Middle East and the Arab Spring, our approaches to development issues and how we help the poorest countries find their place in the international economy, these are all going to be areas where, I think, Angela's leadership will be welcomed and will be absolutely critical for us to be able to achieve the kind of more peaceful and prosperous world that we want to see.So she's not finished yet; she's got a lot more work to do. I know sometimes she probably wouldn't mind a couple of days off, but she'll have to wait for that.. Well, I believe when you see me standing here before you today and receiving this prestigious award of the Medal of Freedom, it will perhaps also be a moment where one needs to look back to 1989 and German unification and what actually happened there.If you like, Germany entered into a qualitatively new phase. We were all of a sudden a reunited country, a country with all rights, but also with all the obligations.If I think back to the beginning of the nineties, we were struggling for a decision that would enable us to send ships on the Adria, taking part in reconnaissance missions. And if you compare this to where we are today, you see the road that we have traveled in the direction of assuming more international responsibility. Military missions, participating in military missions are part and parcel of that: on the Balkans, in UNIFIL, in Afghanistan, in combating piracy, and in many other areas.But what's also important in this context--and that's an approach that we both share, Barack and I--is that we need to combine military and civil engagement. And so I think we live up to our international responsibilities. The world is full of problems that we need to address. That's a reality, and you cannot have enough partners that work together with you in a coordinated way, and this is why this cooperation is so extremely important for our common future.I'm saying this also as someone who comes from Europe. The changes in North Africa are changes that happen on our doorstep. Those are our immediate neighbors, and we have a choice. Either this works out well or we have an enormous refugee problem.And so it's not only out of charity that we help people. There's not only a moral obligation. But we have also a vested interest in seeing to it that this continent, this region, comes on its feet.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, your opponent alleges that your handling of the pandemic – specifically, the testing delays, the mixed signals on social distancing and masks, and your perceived disregard for expert opinions – is responsible for a death every minute. Your reaction? [SEP] That's precisely why she was such a disastrous candidate, ultimately forced to withdraw. She's simply inaccurate. Her grasp of the facts is demonstrably weak. We've conducted more tests than any nation on Earth, surpassing even India and China. Our testing is superior. They all inquire about our methods. The sheer volume of our testing – exceeding 65 million individuals – naturally yields a higher case count. Many nations, such as Mexico, conduct minimal testing, focusing solely on symptomatic individuals. We lead the world in testing. Our performance has been exemplary, including the rapid production of ventilators. We are the world's ventilator leader, now supplying the globe. Furthermore, our overall statistics compare favorably to other nations, even those initially lauded for their response. Therefore, her assertions are factually incorrect, and I anticipate her failure. I eagerly await the debate between her and Mike Pence, confident he will decisively outperform her.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, the Iraq Study Group, chaired by James Baker, suggests direct talks with Syria and Iran, akin to our Cold War strategy with the Soviets. Is this something you'd consider? [SEP] Iran, plain and simple, they stop enriching uranium, we'll talk. Verifiably stop. We'll bring in the EU-3, Russia, the whole shebang. It's not exactly a state secret. The Iranian Foreign Minister says they'll talk after we leave Iraq? That's a joke. If they want to talk for their people's sake, they halt the enrichment. End of story. The Iranian people deserve better than being isolated. Great history, great culture, but their leader's stuck in the dark ages. That Holocaust conference? Unbelievable. It's hurting Iran's image. We're working on a Security Council resolution. I spoke with Secretary Rice about it this morning. The message? Iran's isolating itself. My message to the Iranian people: You deserve better. A leader who builds your economy, not one chasing nukes. There's a better path. Syria, same deal. We've talked to them. We've laid out what they need to do to improve relations. It's not rocket science. Stop letting those Saddam loyalists send money and weapons into Iraq. Leave Lebanon alone. Prime Minister Siniora's doing a fantastic job, standing up to Syria and Hezbollah. So, to sum it up, we've told them what they need to do. Congressmen visit Syria. If they want better relations, they need to start acting like it.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. In 2013, you said: I'm not the emperor of the United States. My job is to execute laws that are passed. Mr. President, what has changed since then? And since you've now had a chance to talk since July with your legal advisers, what do you now believe are your limits so that you can continue to be—act as President and not as emperor or king? [SEP] Well, the—actually, my position hasn't changed. When I was talking to the advocates, their interest was in me, through executive action, duplicating the legislation that was stalled in Congress. And getting a comprehensive deal of the sort that is in the Senate legislation, for example, does extend beyond my legal authorities. There are certain things I cannot do. There are certain limits to what falls within the realm of prosecutorial discretion in terms of how we apply existing immigration laws.And what we've continued to do is to talk to Office of Legal Counsel that's responsible for telling us what the rules are, what the scope of our operations are, and determining where it is appropriate for us to say we're not going to deport 11 million people. On the other hand, we've got severe resource constraints right now at the border not in apprehending people, but in processing and having enough immigration judges and so forth. And so what's within our authority to do in reallocating resources and reprioritizing since we can't do everything. And it's on that basis that I'll be making a decision about any executive actions that I might take.I will repeat what I have said before: There is a very simple solution to this perception that somehow I'm exercising too much executive authority. Pass a bill I can sign on this issue. If Congress passes a law that solves our border problems, improves our legal immigration system, and provides a pathway for the 11 million people who are here, working in our kitchens, working in farms, making beds in hotels—everybody knows they're there; we're not going to deport all of them; we'd like to see them being able, out in the open, to pay their taxes, pay a penalty, get right with the law—give me a bill that addresses those issues, I'll be the first one to sign it, and metaphorically, I'll crumple up whatever executive actions that we take and we'll toss them in the wastebasket, because we will now have a law that addresses these issues.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, looking back at the past year, after the Republicans lost control of Congress, you expressed a desire to find common ground. However, today you delivered a rather critical assessment of the Democrats. How would you evaluate your own performance in working with the Democrats over the past year? How successful have you been in collaborating with them on various issues, and do you believe you've done a satisfactory job in finding common ground? [SEP] We're finding common ground on Iraq. I know some in Congress say we shouldn't have been there, but the debate has shifted. David Petraeus and Ryan Crocker's testimony made a difference. I hope we keep finding common ground by funding our troops. We found common ground on FISA. Why change a good law? It works for national security. That's what people want, laws that help them. This law helps our intelligence find out what Al Qaida is up to. It needs to be enhanced by giving liability protection to the phone companies that helped us. So, we found common ground there. Hopefully, we can find more as Congress moves bills forward. I said what I said because there's a lot to do. I'm not a legislator, probably wouldn't be a good one. But as head of the executive branch, I need to call on Congress to make progress. It's hard to find common ground when bills aren't moving. Not one appropriations bill has reached my desk. How can you find common ground without an appropriations process? We found common ground on trade bills, really important. Exports helped us overcome the housing market weakness last quarter. So, let's open up markets. But no trade bills are moving. Veterans Affairs is another area. I asked Bob Dole and Donna Shalala to lead a Commission to make sure veterans get the benefits they deserve. I was worried about bureaucratic delays and a system that didn't recognize the nature of this war. I don't like seeing wives sitting by their husbands' beds in Walter Reed without government support. I'm concerned about PTSD. We sent up a bill, and I hope they move on it quickly. There's a place for common ground, Sheryl.
label: Implicit

sentence: As you prepare for your final foreign trip, what assurances can you give world leaders regarding your successor, given their expressed concerns about Donald Trump and the future of U.S. foreign policy? Furthermore, as the Democratic Party seeks to recover from a significant setback, what guidance would you offer regarding the party's future direction and leadership? [SEP] Well, one of the great things about the United States is that when it comes to world affairs, the President obviously is the leader of the executive branch, the Commander in Chief, the spokesperson for the Nation, but the influence and the work that we have is the result not just of the President. It is the result of countless interactions and arrangements and relationships between our military and other militaries and our diplomats and other diplomats and intelligence officers and development workers. And there is enormous continuity beneath the day-to-day news that makes us that indispensable nation when it comes to maintaining order and promoting prosperity around the world. That will continue. In my conversation with the President-elect, he expressed a great interest in maintaining our core strategic relationships. And so one of the messages I will be able to deliver is his commitment to NATO and the transatlantic alliance. I think that's one of the most important functions I can serve at this stage, during this trip, is to let them know that there is no weakening of resolve when it comes to America's commitment to maintaining a strong and robust NATO relationship and a recognition that those alliances aren't just good for Europe, they're good for the United States, and they're vital for the world.With respect to the Democratic Party, look, as I said in the Rose Garden right after the election, when your team loses, everybody gets deflated, and it's hard, and it's challenging. And so I think it's a healthy thing for the Democratic Party to go through some reflection. I think it's important for me not to be big-footing that conversation. I think we want to see new voices and new ideas emerge. That's part of the reason why I think term limits are a really useful thing.I think the Democrats should not waver on our core beliefs and principles: the belief that we should have an economy that works for everybody, not just a few; the belief that America, at its best, is inclusive and not exclusive, that we insist on the dignity and God-given potential and worth of every child, regardless of race or gender or sexual orientation or what ZIP Code they were born in. That we are committed to a world in which we keep America safe, but we recognize that our power doesn't just flow from our extraordinary military, it also flows from the strength of our ideals and our principles and our values.So there are going to be a core set of values that shouldn't be up for debate, should be our north star. But how we organize politically I think is something that we should spend some time thinking about. I believe that we have better ideas. But I also believe that good ideas don't matter if people don't hear them. And one of the issues that Democrats have to be clear on is that, given population distribution across the country, we have to compete everywhere. We have to show up everywhere. We have to work at a grassroots level, something that's been a running thread in my career.I won Iowa not because the demographics dictated that I would win Iowa, it was because I spent 87 days going to every small town and fair and fish fry and VFW hall. And there were some counties where I might have lost, but maybe I lost by 20 points instead of 50 points. There are some counties maybe I won that people didn't expect because people had a chance to see you and listen to you and get a sense of who you stood for and who you were fighting for.And the challenge for a national party is, how do you dig in there and create those kinds of structures so that people have a sense of what it is that you stand for? And that increasingly is difficult to do just through a national press strategy. It's increasingly difficult to do because of the splintering of the press.And so I think the discussions that have been taking place about how do you build more grassroots organizing, how do you build up State parties and local parties and schoolboard elections you're paying attention to and State rep races and city council racesthat all, I think, will contribute to stronger outcomes in the future.And I'm optimistic that will happen. And Ifor Democrats who are feeling completely discouraged, I've been trying to remind them everybody remembers my Boston speech in 2004; they may not remember me showing up here in 2005 when John Kerry had lost a close election, Tom Daschle, the leader of the Senate, had been beaten in an upset. Ken Salazar and I were the only two Democrats that won nationally. Republicans controlled the Senate and the House. And 2 years later, Democrats were winning back Congress, and 4 years later, I was President of the United States.Things change pretty rapidly. But it doesn'tthey don't change inevitably. They change because you work for it. Nobody said democracy is supposed to be easy. This is hard. And in a big country like this, it probably should be hard.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with Prime Minister Maliki cozying up to Iran, do you see eye-to-eye with him on that relationship, and what does that say to our friends and those who doubt Maliki's loyalties? [SEP] I haven't seen the reports you're referring to. I'd like to get a full picture from our people on the ground before I weigh in. You know how these things go – you try to be polite when you're meeting with someone.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, American companies have invested in India for a long time. Are you satisfied with India's investment rating, particularly on issues like multi-brand retail and e-commerce, where U.S. companies have significant interests? [SEP] I'm very satisfied because they're investing tremendous amounts of money. I met Mr. Patel a little while ago. He's the largest steel person in the world by far. He's going to be building a billion-dollar plant in Alabama. We had the press—I left them in there. Always a risky thing to do. But if you see, let's say we ask, you know, answered 15 questions, and they were talking about how much better it is to work in the United States now, in terms of their investment. They have done a fantastic job. These are some of the biggest entrepreneurs in the world. I'm not even sure if the media really understood who they were. I knew many of them, certainly heard of all of them. The job they've done is incredible. But Mr. Patel, who's the biggest steel—I think biggest steel company, certainly the biggest steel individual. But I think he's the biggest steel company by a lot. He's investing billions of dollars in the United States, and he's only doing it because of what I've done to bring back the steel industry. The steel industry was dead. Absolutely dead in the United States. And now it's a vibrant industry. It's incredible, and we need it. Again, we need it for defense. It's not just like certain industries that you don't need. We need it for defense. But he was glowing. And one of the reasons he's spending a billion dollars in Alabama, and more money in other places in the United States, is because we brought it back. So we're very proud of that. So I think what we'll do is we're going to see some of you on the plane on the way back. It's been an honor to be here. It's an incredible place with incredible leadership and an unbelievable future. And I just want to thank you all. And I'll see you back in the States. And I think some of you are on the plane, and we can talk a little bit on the plane too. Thank you very much, everybody. Thank you very much.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, China's economy seems to be hitting some snags. Do you worry this could destabilize things globally or make them more assertive, especially with Taiwan? Also, what about Putin and Kim Jong Un meeting up? Could that give Russia an edge in Ukraine? [SEP] China's got some tough economic issues right now, no question. It's a mix of global problems and their own choices. I don't think it means they're going to invade Taiwan. Actually, it might mean they're less able to. We're not trying to hurt China, though. We want them to do well, as long as they play by the rules. It's good for everyone. But they're having a hard time, especially with real estate. They're trying to figure out what to do. I'm not going to guess what they'll decide. We're not trying to cut them off. But I'm not going to sell them stuff that helps them build nukes or do things that are bad for the region. We're not trying to hurt them. Okay, next question.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the library's funding, sources indicate a $200 million goal. Is that accurate? And will you make donor information public, including any restrictions on who can donate and how much? [SEP] The budget's not final. We'll follow the rules on disclosure. Some donors like to stay private. What else?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Bush, why do you believe Mexicans would trust a migration reform, given its historical impossibility? What are the odds of this bill passing Congress? And President Calderon, what did you discuss with President Fox during your lunch? [SEP] They talked about... Excuse me, I wasn't there. That's a valid question: why now? The legislative process in the U.S. takes time. Legislators debate issues before reaching solutions. We haven't had a serious migration debate until recently. A law passed in 1986, but serious debate began after 2000. As Governor of Texas, I've always known this is an important issue and have elevated it. Congress has taken it seriously, but complex issues are hard to legislate. Many Americans felt we weren't enforcing our laws. We've shown a strong commitment to the rule of law, making Congress more open to my argument: migration reform reduces illegal border crossings, enhancing border security and allowing us to focus on drugs, terrorists, criminals, and guns. I'm optimistic. I don't predict legislative success, but the mood in Congress has shifted from skepticism to understanding that a comprehensive bill is in the nation's interest. Republicans and Democrats in the Senate are working together, facilitated by the administration. I'm not a betting man, but I'm optimistic about comprehensive reform. It's in both countries' interests. I met with former President Vicente Fox, whom I like, and we had a constructive conversation. He congratulated us on our first 100 days and offered his cooperation. I've met with other former Presidents and will continue to meet with President Fox. Here it comes.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, based on your assessment, is President Putin planning a military incursion into Ukraine? [SEP] Frankly, it's all up to Putin. He's calling the shots. Whether he decides to move in, and how, is entirely his prerogative. We're monitoring the situation, but we can't read his mind. It's his game to play.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, aren't you essentially kicking the can down the road with this plan? Is there a concrete timeline for implementation, say, by August? [SEP] Well, August was just a date that I floated, and it came to mind because I understand the challenges of getting things done late in the legislative session. The appropriations bills tend to dominate the calendar towards the end of the year, consuming a lot of time. So, my hope – and it's just a hope, not a promise – is that we can get something through the Senate and then to the House, so they can work out the details in the fall. That would be ideal. But I'm not the one who sets the schedule. I'm just a member of the executive branch. It's the legislative branch that decides the calendar. As for the Guatemalan people, they might have preferred a clearer and more positive response, like an end to deportations. But, as I've said, there's a legal framework that needs to be respected. However, I believe we're closer than ever to finding a solution to this problem. I was pleased to hear President Bush acknowledge that this is a problem they also face. It's not just a problem for migrants; it's a problem for American citizens too. We've never been this close to seeing a light at the end of the tunnel and changing the undocumented status for the 13 million illegal aliens living in the U.S.
label: General

sentence: Q. Do you think the election of these two Muslim women to Congress is a rejection of your rhetoric? [SEP] I didn't catch that. What?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, considering your emphasis on direct dialogue and your concerns about Russia and China, will you personally reach out to President Xi to request that China grant access to WHO investigators seeking to understand the origins of COVID-19? [SEP] Look, we have a business relationship. That's it. I'm dealing with China on many fronts, and we'll see what happens with the WHO. But let's not get carried away with this 'old friend' nonsense.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. I know what your answer has been. But do you think now, with the rising prices, the record high oil prices, it's time to change course? [SEP] In this case, I have analyzed the issue. And I don't think it would affect price for this reason: We're buying, at the moment, about 67,000 to 68,000 barrels of oil per day, fulfilling statutory obligations to fill up the SPRO. World demand is 85 million barrels a day. So the purchases for SPRO account for one-tenth of one percent of global demand. And I don't think that's going to affect price, when you affect one-tenth of one percent. And I do believe it is in our national interest to get the SPRO filled in case there's a major disruption of crude oil around the world.I mean, one of the—for example, one of the things the—Al Qaida would like to do is blow up oil facilities. Understanding we're in a global market, a attack on an oil facility in a major oil exporting country would affect the economies of their enemy—that would be us and other people who can't stand what Al Qaida stands for. And therefore, the SPRO is necessary, if that's the case, to be able to deal with that kind of contingency. And if I thought it would affect the price of oil positively, I'd seriously consider it. But when you're talking about one-tenth of one percent of global demand, I think the—if you—on a cost-benefit analysis, I don't think you get any benefits from making the decision. I do think it costs you oil in the case of a national security risk.Martha [Martha Raddatz, ABC News].
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Ukraine, if the cease-fire holds, will the US and Europe ease sanctions? Or are sanctions still needed? Also, can you detail the US contribution to the Rapid Response Force in terms of troops and equipment, beyond what was announced in Warsaw? [SEP] We hope the cease-fire works, but we're wary given past actions by separatists and Russia. It needs to be proven. Europe is finalizing its sanctions. Implementing President Poroshenko's plan will take time. So, keeping sanctions in place, but being ready to lift them if the plan is followed, is the best way to ensure compliance. This cease-fire is only happening because of existing sanctions and the threat of more, which are hurting Russia's economy and isolating them. Russia can rejoin the international community by respecting international law. The strong transatlantic alliance supporting Ukraine and imposing sanctions shows how seriously we take the principle that big countries can't bully smaller ones. I'm pleased with our work on the Ukraine crisis, and US leadership has been key. On the Rapid Response Forces, I announced $1 billion in Warsaw. A lot of that will go to the readiness action plan. We've increased troop rotations in the Baltics and have air policing and activities in the Baltic and Black Seas. This plan adds to that, coordinates it better, and gets more help from partners. It shows NATO's commitment to Article 5, especially after Russia's actions. A bigger presence deters Russian aggression.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Uribe, considering the discussions surrounding Chavez, could you share your thoughts on whether his impact on the region is being exaggerated? [SEP] My opinion on what, exactly?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Syria, you've repeatedly called for Assad to leave power. What's the timeline for this, and should we anticipate the Syrian tragedy dragging on into the coming year? [SEP] Ideally, Assad would have departed long ago. Our stance has been unwavering: he forfeited his legitimacy when he turned against his own population. As for the method, there's no straightforward solution. We require sustained international pressure and a more robust opposition. Negotiations in Geneva could potentially offer a path forward, but we'll continue to bolster the opposition and address the humanitarian crisis in close collaboration with Turkey.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, by conceding to discussions about spending caps or freezes with Republicans, are you not concerned that you've already compromised to a point where the economy could be pushed into a recession, effectively handing Mr. McCarthy a victory? [SEP] Absolutely not. I am confident we can reach a bipartisan agreement that is responsible and avoids harming our economy. We've already proposed significant cuts to the baseline spending, demonstrating our commitment to fiscal responsibility. However, it's not just about cutting spending; it's about looking at the whole picture, including revenue. Would you only consider cutting expenses when balancing your household budget? We must also address the tax structure. My Republican colleagues' insistence on maintaining the Trump administration's tax cuts, which disproportionately benefited the wealthiest Americans and negatively impacted the economy, is unacceptable. We need to ensure that everyone pays their fair share, including large corporations and billionaires. We can achieve a balanced approach that promotes economic growth and reduces the deficit.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, looking back, what was the most unexpected aspect of becoming president? How long did it take you to feel truly settled into the role, if ever? And did you discuss these experiences with President-elect Trump? [SEP] Well, I'd say I just started feeling comfortable about a week ago. Just kidding! The learning process is never-ending. This job is truly unique. It's a constant stream of information, challenges, and issues. That's even more true now because of the interconnectedness of the world. If you were president 50 years ago, the tragedy in Syria might not even have registered with the American people. Today, they see vivid images instantly. A financial crisis in Southeast Asia used to have no impact on our markets; today, it does. The amount of incoming information that any administration has to deal with today, and respond to much more rapidly than ever before, makes it different. I was watching a documentary where JFK had about two weeks before anyone reported on the Bay of Pigs crisis. Imagine that! Today, a president has about an hour to figure out their response. These are the kinds of points that I shared with the President-elect. It was a free-flowing and, I think, useful conversation. I tried to be as honest as I could about the things I think any president coming in needs to think about. Probably the most important point that I made was how you staff – particularly your Chief of Staff, your National Security Advisor, your White House Counsel – how you set up a process and a system to surface information, generate options for a president, understanding that, ultimately, the president is going to be the final decision-maker. That's something that has to be attended to right away. I have been blessed by having – and I admittedly am biased – some of the smartest, hardest-working, good people in my administration that I think any president has ever had. As a consequence of that team, I've been able to make good decisions. If you don't have that around you, then you'll get swamped. So I hope that he appreciated that advice. What I also discussed was the fact that I had been encouraged by his statements on election night about the need for unity and his interest in being the president for all people, and that how he staffs, the first steps he takes, the first impressions he makes, the reset that can happen after an election – all those things are important and should be thought about. I think it's important to give him the room and the space to do that. It takes time to put that together. But I emphasized to him that, look, in an election like this that was so hotly contested and so divided, gestures matter. How he reaches out to groups that may not have supported him, how he signals his interest in their issues or concerns – I think those are the kinds of things that can set a tone that will help move things forward once he's actually taken office.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Obama, given the apparent stagnation of the Trans-Pacific Partnership in Congress, and other nations awaiting U.S. leadership in approving the agreement, are you considering a revised strategy for securing its passage, particularly in light of the Boeing and GE deals announced today? Should the agreement be amended to address currency manipulation? Also, your comments on the killing of Taliban leader Mullah Mansur and Pakistan's concerns about the strike on its soil? Does this signal a new offensive in Afghanistan, and are you concerned about a more hardline leader emerging? [SEP] Well, on TPP, I’ve been around long enough to know that every trade deal is painful, because folks are always seeing if they can get an even better deal. And especially when you have multiple parties involved, folks are going to be scrutinizing it, they're going to be debating it, and in an election year, you can anticipate that some folks are going to try to score political points off it. Having said that, I remain confident we're going to get it done. And the reason I'm confident is because it's the right thing to do. It's good for the country. It's good for America. It's good for the region. It's good for the world. And I know I've sold this to you before, but let me reiterate: This is the fastest growing part of the world. This represents an enormous market for the United States. Most countries here already sell their stuff to the United States, and we have relatively low tariffs. In other words, we put relatively low taxes on goods that are coming into the United States. In contrast, tariffs are significantly higher for U.S. goods being sold here. So a deal that gets rid of 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods into the largest, fastest growing markets of the world, that's a good deal for American businesses and American workers. Number two, one of the biggest complaints about trade deals historically has been that it opens up our markets to countries with lower wages, harsher labor practices, less environmental regulations. Well, if you're signing up for the Trans-Pacific Partnership, you are making commitments that are enforceable to raise labor standards, to ensure that workers have a voice, to attend to environmental problems. And so this gives us the ability to engage with a country like Vietnam and work with them on all those fronts, the precise things that people, in the past, have been concerned about when it comes to trading with other countries. So I have not yet seen a credible argument that once we get TPP in place we're going to be worse off. We are demonstrably better off. American workers and American businesses are better off if we get this deal passed. And I'm confident we will get it passed. Now, the politics of it will be noisy. That was true when I, for example, inherited the Korean free trade agreement or the Colombian and Panamanian free trade agreements when I came into office. But we got them done. And I'm confident that we'll get them done this time, as well, although it will—there will be ups and downs and bumps along the way. With respect to currency manipulation, we have provisions in TPP that advance the transparency and reporting functions that allow us to monitor whether we think that currency manipulation is taking place. One of the debates that took place—and there have been some who argue that we should have enforceable provisions that if you see currency going down too far that we should be able to impose tariffs on that country. The problem is, is that it's very hard to sort out sometimes why currency is going down and whether it's actually being manipulated. And frankly, for us to bind other countries to commitments about their monetary policy would mean we were also binding our Federal Reserve to the claims of other countries in terms of how it implements our monetary policy, and that's not something that we would do. We would not give up sovereignty with respect to our monetary policy in that way. But we have strengthened a number of the provisions that are already contained in TPP that will allow us to put on notice folks who we think are engaging in competitive devaluations. Finally, on the Taliban leader, Mr. Mansur, it has been confirmed that he is dead. And he is an individual who, as head of the Taliban, was specifically targeting U.S. personnel and troops inside of Afghanistan who were there as part of the mission that I've set to be able to maintain a counterterrorism platform and provide assistance and training to the Afghan military forces there. So this does not represent a shift in our approach. We are not reentering the day-to-day combat operations that are currently being conducted by Afghan security forces. Our job is to help Afghanistan secure its own country, not to have our men and women in uniform engage in that fight for them. On the other hand, where we have a high-profile leader who has been consistently part of operations and plans to potentially harm U.S. personnel and who has been resistant to the kinds of peace talks and reconciliation that ultimately could bring an end to decades of war in Afghanistan, then it is my responsibility as Commander in Chief not to stand by, but to make sure that we send a clear signal to the Taliban and others that we're going to protect our people. And that's exactly the message that has been sent.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Madam President, while Brazil is emerging as a key global player, some in the U.S. still view it through a regional lens. How do you bridge this perception gap and ensure a balanced partnership? [SEP] Well, let me just say, the President's assessment is spot on. We see Brazil as a global force, no question. Look at the G-20, climate talks in Paris – Brazil's leadership is undeniable. Their renewable energy goals are proof. We need Brazil at the table on global health, terrorism, poverty – you name it. President Dilma and I have a great relationship built on trust and candor. She delivers on her promises, like the defense cooperation agreements. Sure, there will be differences, but our shared values and strong ties will keep us strong partners. And as she said, Brazil's resilience in overcoming crises makes it an even greater nation. We share a history, a large Black population, and a multicultural heritage. We're both strong democracies, and Brazil will overcome its current challenges, just like we did in 2008. We're committed to reducing inequality and building a middle-class society.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, considering the media's perceived impatience for bipartisan solutions, and with your third budget underway, why not directly invite Republicans to the table for negotiations? What tangible measures are you implementing to encourage bipartisan cooperation, and do you anticipate market stability enduring for another two years? [SEP] Woah, slow down there! You're throwing a lot at me at once. What was the initial question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. So the U.S. will negotiate in the same manner with China? [SEP] Absolutely. Great respect for China. Great respect for the leadership of China. Absolutely.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering the dynamic nature of the Libyan conflict, could you outline the key performance indicators that will trigger the transfer of command, and why is NATO the ideal entity to assume this role? [SEP] The situation on the ground is, as you might imagine, quite dynamic. The timing of this transfer is contingent upon the recommendations of our commanding officers, specifically when they determine that the initial phase of the mission, focused on neutralizing Libyan air defenses, has been successfully completed. This is essential for the effective operation of the no-fly zone and the safety of our coalition pilots. Humanitarian aspects are also a crucial consideration. I anticipate this transition occurring in a matter of days, not weeks. The Pentagon will provide further details. NATO's coordinating function is invaluable due to its unique capabilities. Regarding this partnership, it's a two-way street. Chile has much to offer, particularly in clean energy. We're exploring collaborations in education and security, addressing issues like narcotrafficking. This isn't about a developed nation aiding a less developed one; it's a collaboration among equals. Regarding Latin American integration, we lag behind Europe. While the idea of a free trade area from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego was once floated, it never materialized. Latin America needs to fulfill its potential, drawing on shared values and principles with the U.S. We seek a partnership that encompasses democracy, free trade, education, and innovation. We must also address energy and water challenges, as well as transnational threats. The time is ripe for a new international order, one that adapts to the needs of the 21st century. Latin America cannot afford to be late to the knowledge and information revolution.
label: General

sentence: You've emphasized state sovereignty as a cornerstone of international order. How do you reconcile that with the concept of 'responsibility to protect,' which used to be paramount for many victims? [SEP] I'm sorry, how do I reconcile that with the responsibility to protect, which used to be what?
label: Clarification

sentence: Can you give us any indication of the geographical area or specific nations involved? [SEP] I'm afraid I can't divulge that information at this juncture. The announcement is imminent, so please remain patient.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given my affiliation with the New York Times, may I ask a question before the next journalist? [SEP] Since you're with...?
label: Clarification

sentence: Just a ballpark figure, sir. How many are we talking about? [SEP] I don't have an exact count right now. I can direct my staff to get you a comprehensive report, if you'd like.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. What's your message to them—to those two-thirds of Americans? [SEP] Watch me. []
label: Explicit

sentence: President Obama, just to be absolutely clear, would you approve a budget that maintains government funding at the reduced levels established by the sequester, even if it's not your ideal scenario? [SEP] Listen, I'm not in the habit of making crystal-clear pronouncements, especially not for you all. But I think it's reasonable to say that we agreed to a certain budget, certain figures. There's no justification for revisiting that agreement. Speaker Boehner and the entire leadership team were party to that deal. And if the legislation that reaches my desk reflects those prior commitments, then, of course, I would sign it because I want to ensure that we continue to serve the American people. Okay? Next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: What are your thoughts on direct talks? [SEP] I'm not going to comment on that.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering the diverse demographics of America, do you believe your message resonates equally with all communities? [SEP] My message is for everyone. I want to make America great again for everyone, regardless of their background. We're creating jobs, we're lowering taxes, and we're making our country safer. These are things that everyone can get behind.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President, to clarify, can you provide a succinct recap of the exchange with President Putin that resolved his concerns regarding your earlier statement? [SEP] The situation is handled. Why re-open old wounds? It's time to focus on the future, not dwell on past disagreements.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you very much. Mr. President, I'd like to ask about two topics. First of all, what more specifically can the U.S. do to help Kenya in the fight against al-Shabaab? Do you still see Somalia as a counterterrorism model? And are you concerned about Kenyan authorities using counterterrorism as an excuse to commit human rights violations?Secondly, can you comment on the state of gay and lesbian—the treatment of gay and lesbians in Kenya, which rights groups have called dismal and President Kenyatta has called a nonissue?For you, sir, President Kenyatta, on the same themes, what more do you need from the United States to help fight al-Shabaab, and are you getting it? And can you please also respond to criticism about the state of gay rights in your country? [SEP] Well, this was an extensive topic of conversation and concrete action that we're now taking. There has been extensive and effective counterterrorism cooperation between the United States and Kenya dealing with primarily threats from al-Shabaab.In part because of the actions that we've taken not just with Kenya, but with AFRICOM, and the efforts, collectively, of countries to work together—Uganda, Ethiopia, others—we have systematically reduced the territory that al-Shabaab controls. We have been able to decrease their effective control within Somalia and have weakened those networks operating here in East Africa.That doesn't mean the problem is solved. As is true around the world, what we find is, is that we can degrade significantly the capacities of these terrorist organizations, but they can still do damage. The number of individuals involved in Garissa or Westgate Mall were not large, but when they're willing to target soft targets and civilians, and are prepared to die, they can still do a lot of damage.And so what we discussed was the importance of, number one, continuing the effort to root out al-Shabaab's capacity inside of Somalia, working jointly. And as we speak, Kenya is working with Ethiopia and with the United States and others to further degrade al-Shabaab's space of operations inside of Somalia. So we have to keep that pressure going, even as we're strengthening the Somalian Government. Because part of the reason that al-Shabaab was able to emerge as a significant threat to the region was a nonfunctioning Government, effectively a failed state in Somalia for so long.There is now a Government and a cabinet that is credible and is working with the international community in Mogadishu. And even as we put military pressure on al-Shabaab, we also have to make sure that we're standing up an effective governance structure inside of Somalia. And we've made progress there.In addition, we have to continue to make progress in intelligence-sharing and being able to identify and prevent threats before they occur here in Kenya and elsewhere in the region. And part of our announcement today involves additional funding, additional assistance that we're providing the Kenyan security forces to deal with these very specific counterterrorism threats, as well as additional training and assistance to make sure that the approach that's taken in rooting out potential terrorist threats don't create more problems than they're solving.And this goes to the other element of the question that you asked. What we have found, sometimes through hard experience—and I shared this with —is that if you paint any particular community with too broad a brush, if in reaction to terrorism you are restricting legitimate organizations, reducing the scope of peaceful organization, then that can have the inadvertent effect of actually increasing the pool of recruits for terrorism and resentment in communities that feel marginalized.And I shared with him that one of the strengths in the United States, part of the reason why, although we're seeing potential lone wolf attacks inside the United States, that we have not seen this sort of systematic networks and cells developing in many of our Muslim communities or immigrant communities inside of the United States is, is that we've been very conscious to make sure that law enforcement is reaching out and cooperating and working with them, because they are our partners in this process. And the only way we're going to fight the poison that's being fed to them—to their young people through social media—is to make sure that they're our eyes and our ears and they're counseling us on how we can more effectively build trust and increase cooperation. And that's proven successful.The same will be true here in Kenya. And I was very clear to : Ultimately, the Kenyan Government is accountable to the Kenyan people, and it will find its way through this process in cooperation with us, but our experience and best practices tell us that rule of law, respecting civil society—in fact, embracing civil society, particularly in those communities that may be targeted for recruitment by organizations like al-Shabaab—that becomes more important the more significant the threat is. And not only is that practical advice, but it's the right thing to do, and it's consistent with the Kenyan Constitution and with the values that you heard espouse.Similarly, with respect to the rights of gays and lesbians, I've been consistent all across Africa on this. I believe in the principle of treating people equally under the law and that they are deserving of equal protection under the law and that the state should not discriminate against people based on their sexual orientation. And I say that, recognizing that there may be people who have different religious or cultural beliefs. But the issue is, how does the state operate relative to people?If you look at the history of countries around the world, when you start treating people differently—not because of any harm they're doing anybody, but because they are different—that's the path whereby freedoms begin to erode and bad things happen. And when a government gets in the habit of treating people differently, those habits can spread.And as an African American in the United States, I am painfully aware of the history of what happens when people are treated differently, under the law, and there's—were all sorts of rationalizations that were provided by the power structure for decades in the United States for segregation and Jim Crow and slavery, and they were wrong.So I'm unequivocal on this. If somebody is a law-abiding citizen who is going about their business and working in a job and obeying the traffic signs—[]—and doing all the other things that good citizens are supposed to do and not harming anybody, the idea that they are going to be treated differently or abused because of who they love is wrong. Full stop. And the state does not need to weigh in on religious doctrine. The state just has to say, we're going to treat everybody equally under the law. And then, everybody else can have their own opinions. All right?
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, as the first African American President, do you believe you placed excessive demands on Americans, contributing to the current divisions? And do you perceive your successor as a potential threat to global security, especially considering their access to nuclear weapons? [SEP] My focus has always been on doing what I believe is best for the country, even when it's not politically popular. I trust that the American people will continue to strive for a more perfect union, and I remain optimistic about the future. As for my successor, I hope they will uphold the values and principles that have made America a beacon of hope for the world.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. As for criticism of your successor? [SEP] Ah. Look, I've said before, President Bush could not have been more gracious to me when I came in. And my intention is to, certainly for the next 2 months, just finish my job. And then, after that, to take Michelle on vacation—[]—get some rest, spend time with my girls, and do some writing, do some thinking. So I want to be respectful of the office and give the President-elect an opportunity to put forward his platform and his arguments without somebody popping off in every instance.As an American citizen who cares deeply about our country, if there are issues that have less to do with the specifics of some legislative proposal or battle, but go to core questions about our values and our ideals, and if I think that it's necessary or helpful for me to defend those ideals, then I'll examine it when it comes. But what I do know is, is that I have to take Michelle on vacation. []Juliet. Juliet Eilperin [Washington Post].'s Executive Authority/Syria/Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) Terrorist Organization
label: General

sentence: Q. Are you going to have that drink with Mitch McConnell now that you joked about at the White House Correspondents Dinner? [SEP] You know, actually, I would enjoy having some Kentucky bourbon with Mitch McConnell. [] I don't know what his preferred drink is, but—my interactions with Mitch McConnell, he has always been very straightforward with me. To his credit, he has never made a promise that he couldn't deliver. And he knows the legislative process well. He obviously knows his caucus well. He has always given me, I think, realistic assessments of what he can get through his caucus and what he can't. And so I think we can have a productive relationship.Phil Mattingly [Bloomberg Television].
label: General

sentence: Can you confirm reports that Chen Guangcheng is under U.S. protection in Beijing, and would the U.S. grant him asylum if requested? [SEP] I'm aware of the press reports, but I'm not going to make a statement on the issue. Every time we meet with , the issue of human rights comes up.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding the possibility of future relations between North Korea and the U.S., do you foresee a potential parallel with the U.S. and Vietnam? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, what are your thoughts on the QAnon movement, given its growing popularity during the pandemic? [SEP] Honestly, I'm not deeply familiar with the specifics of the movement. I do know they seem to be supportive, which is appreciated. But from what I gather, they're concerned citizens who are troubled by the state of affairs in cities like Portland and Chicago. They're patriots who want to see our country thrive. The Democrats' failure to govern these cities is a disgrace, and if they can't handle it, we'll step in with federal resources to restore order.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, will the Khalid Sheikh Mohammed trial ever take place, and when? [SEP] It's gotta happen. We're working with Congress, both sides, to get it done right. Due process, the Constitution, the whole deal. We gotta show the world we believe in the rule of law. Al Qaeda still uses Guantanamo as an excuse. We can try these guys in court and make sure they never attack us again. Simple as that.
label: General

sentence: Q. President Trump, regarding North Korea, you've stated that the crisis will be resolved. Can you identify any tangible achievements in your diplomatic strategy? And have you changed your view on the value of direct talks? [SEP] Look, you know I don't like to broadcast our wins in situations like this. We like to keep things close to the chest. But I will say this: it makes sense for , and for humanity, to do the right thing. There's a lot of good reason for it. With that, I think we're making real progress. We're showing tremendous strength. They understand we have strength like never before. We sent three of the biggest aircraft carriers, and a nuclear submarine. We hope to God we never have to use them. But I really believe it's in 's interest to come to the table and make a deal that's good for everyone. I see some movement, yes. But let's see how it plays out.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, what does it say about our justice system that 9/11 plotters and suspected terrorists are still awaiting trial? Why are you still convinced a civilian trial is right for Khalid Sheikh Mohammed? Why has it stalled? And will Guantanamo remain open for another year? [SEP] We've delivered on many campaign promises, but closing Guantanamo is one where we've fallen short. I wanted it closed sooner, but the politics are difficult. I firmly believe the American justice system is strong enough to convict those who murdered Americans and carried out terrorist attacks. We can lock them up and ensure they never see the light of day. We've done it before. But this issue has generated a lot of political rhetoric, and people are understandably fearful. However, we are a resilient nation and shouldn't be frightened by a handful of captured terrorists. There may be circumstances where a military tribunal is appropriate, for example, when evidence is difficult to piece together for an Article III court. We can reform the military commission system to meet high standards of due process. I'm prepared to work with both parties to set up a sensible system for prosecuting terrorists in either Article III courts or military tribunals, and then imprison them in secure facilities. The cost of holding them in Guantanamo is massively higher.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. ----and its allies. In that spirit and in that venue, will you call on Israel to declare its nuclear program and sign the Non-Proliferation Treaty? And if not, why wouldn't other countries see that as an incentive not to sign on to the treaty that you say is important to strengthen? [SEP] Well, Scott, initially, you were talking about U.S. behavior, and then suddenly, we were talking about Israel. Let me talk about the United States. I do think that as part of the NPT, our obligation as the largest nuclear power in the world is to take steps to reducing our nuclear stockpile. And that's what the START Treaty was about, sending a message that we are going to meet our obligations.And as far as Israel goes, I'm not going to comment on their program. What I'm going to point to is the fact that consistently we have urged all countries to become members of the NPT.So there's no contradiction there. We think it is important that we have a international approach that is universal and that rests on three pillars: that those of us who have nuclear weapons are making serious efforts to reduce those stockpiles; that we all are working against the proliferation of nuclear weapons, and those countries that don't currently have nuclear weapons make the decision not to pursue nuclear weapons; and that all countries have access to peaceful nuclear energy.And so whether we're talking about Israel or any other country, we think that becoming part of the NPT is important. And that, by the way, is not a new position. That's been a consistent position of the United States Government even prior to my administration.Let me call on Stephen Collinson of AFP [Agence France-Presse].
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, you asserted that Joe Biden has 'hurt God' and is 'against God.' Given the Vice President's public expressions of his Catholic faith and the solace he finds in it during personal hardships, could you elaborate on the basis for your statement? [SEP] Well, if you examine the manifesto they've put forth, and consider their position on religion and matters of faith, I don't believe a deeply religious individual would endorse the Bernie Sanders plan. It's simply incompatible with religious principles. That's why, if you analyze the polls—although I don't place much faith in them—our numbers are trending upward, while Joe's are declining. He'll likely need to emerge from his basement soon. But no, take a look at their manifesto. It's even further to the left than Bernie ever was. It's a disastrous prospect for our country. It will devastate us, trigger a depression, impose exorbitant taxes, and cripple our healthcare system. 180 million people will be deprived of their healthcare. It's a catastrophe.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, critics are suggesting that the recent election outcome is a referendum against your administration. Do you see this as a reflection of a changing America, one that's more diverse and multicultural? [SEP] With all due respect, let's focus on the data. The employment numbers for African Americans, Asian Americans, and Hispanic Americans are the best they've ever been. My approval ratings with these groups are also at an all-time high, according to recent polls. Median income is up, and overall, people are doing better than ever before. The polls reflect this positive change.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, there's been considerable legal speculation regarding potential preemptive pardons for administration officials involved in harsh interrogation tactics or the dismissal of U.S. Attorneys. Have you considered this, and do you intend to proceed with such pardons? [SEP] I will not be addressing the matter of pardons during this press conference.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. I am—[inaudible]—from Seoul newspaper. My question goes to President Obama.
