President Park has been talking about the Korean Peninsula trust-building process as a way to promote peace on Korean Peninsula. I wonder what you feel about this trust-building process on the Korean Peninsula? [SEP] Well, as I indicated before, 's approach is very compatible with my approach and the approach that we have been taking together for several years now. And as I understand it, the key is that we will be prepared for a deterrence that we will respond to aggression, that we will not reward provocative actions, but that we will maintain an openness to an engagement process when we see North Korea taking steps that would indicate that it is following a different path. And that's exactly the right approach.All of us would benefit from a North Korea that transformed itself. Certainly, the people of North Korea would benefit. South Korea would be even stronger in a less tense environment on the Peninsula. All the surrounding neighbors would welcome such a transition, such a transformation. But I don't think either or I are naive about the difficulties of that taking place. And we've got to see action before we can have confidence that that, in fact, is the path that North Korea intends to take.But the one thing I want to emphasize just based on the excellent meetings and consultation that we had today, as well as watching over the last several months dealing with the provocative escalations that have been taking place in North Korea, what I'm very confident about is, is tough. I think she has a very clear, realistic view of the situation, but she also has the wisdom to believe that conflict is not inevitable and is not preferable. And that's true on the Korean Peninsula. That's true around the world.And we very much appreciate her visit and look forward to excellent cooperation not only on this issue, but on the more positive issues of economic and commercial ties between our two countries, educational exchanges, work on energy, climate change, helping other countries develop.I've had a wonderful time every time I've visited the Republic of Korea. And what is clear is that the Republic of Korea is one of the great success stories of our lifetime. And the Republic of Korea's leadership around the globe will be increasingly important. And what underpins that in part has been the extraordinary history of the alliance between the United States and the Republic of Korea. And we want to make sure that that remains a strong foundation for progress in the future.So thank you so much, Madam President.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, can you provide specific examples of progress made by Latin American countries in promoting democracy since your call to action at the Summit of the Americas? [SEP] Well, I look forward to seeing President Bachelet. She's a very capable leader. Chile handled the recession well because they had surpluses. That's a good lesson for the United States. We think there's enormous possibilities of making progress in Latin America. I'll be talking about coordination and cooperation between the United State and Chile on clean energy. We're making important progress when it comes to exchanges on cancer research. We continue to have a robust trade regime with Chile. Chile has actually entered into some very interesting partnerships, not just with the Federal Government but also with State governments like California. It's a respectful policy. Chile is an important partner. I think that's the model that we want: partnership. The United States doesn't dictate how Chile should view its own interests, but in fact, we've achieved great cooperation. And I will be looking at President Bachelet giving us further advice in terms of how we can take the kind of relationship we have with Chile and expand that to our relationships throughout Latin America. Okay?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, if I may, concerning Canada's economic stimulus, did your discussions today touch upon the potential for increased Canadian stimulus measures? Furthermore, could you share your outlook on the Canada-U.S. relationship over the coming four years, specifically regarding the automotive sector, border regulations, and the establishment of a carbon market? [SEP] My goodness, that's quite a multifaceted inquiry. Did you rehearse that with someone beforehand? Is that--?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. Mr. President, the intelligence agencies today said that Russia is already meddling in this year's election to hurt Joe Biden, and that China is considering meddling to hurt you. Do you believe that intelligence? And what do you plan to do about it? [SEP] It could be. I mean, it could be—very much. I think that the last person Russia wants to see in office is Donald Trump because nobody has been tougher on Russia than I have, ever.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Just a quick question: Earlier, you said that President Obama never called the families of fallen soldiers. How can you make that claim? [SEP] I don't know if he did. No, no, no.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, if someone disagrees with you, is your response to sue them? [SEP] Well, when opinions are not just different, but demonstrably and completely wrong, and when those errors have consequences, then we'll see what the courts have to say. It's about accountability for false statements.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, isn't it true that by behaving this way, you are not being a good role model for the American people? [SEP] Look, folks, it's political, okay? They've got rules, they've got exceptions. It's not like I'm doing something illegal, alright?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. But what do you want? [SEP] I'll tell you what I think: It's such a hoax. I think it's so bad for our country. When we have the head of the World Trade Organization here, and he has to listen to this nonsense about a call that was perfect, that nobody talks about. I never see them talking about the transcription. I never see them talking about the call, because there's nothing to say.You read it—somebody should just sit there and read it. And everybody's going to say, You mean that's an impeachable event? If that were impeachable, Lyndon Johnson would have had to leave office in his first day. Kennedy would have had to leave office his first day. It's a hoax. And you understand it's a hoax better than anybody. It's a hoax. And that's the way it is.Yes, go ahead.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Is there anything in the Pledge to America that you think you can support? [SEP] I'm sure there are going to be areas, particularly around, for example, reforming how Washington works, that I'll be interested in. I think the American people want to see more transparency, more openness. As I said, in the midst of economic crisis, I think one of the things I take responsibility for is not having pushed harder on some of those issues. And I think if you take Republicans and Democrats at their word, this is an area that they want to deliver on for the American people. I want to be supportive of that effort.Jake Tapper [ABC News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, just to be clear on the Meng Wanzhou case, will that also be delayed until the very end, or is there a chance the U.S. might drop the extradition request? [SEP] About what now? Regarding what?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, to quickly clarify Meng Wanzhou's situation: are we looking at a potential early resolution, or is the extradition process set in stone? [SEP] When does this happen? On what?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the Seattle City Council's decision to cut funding for their police department, culminating in Chief Carmen Best's resignation, what message does this send about our nation, and what is your perspective on the 'defund the police' movement? [SEP] Seattle's a disaster zone. They let Antifa run wild, and now they're dismantling their police force. The Chief, a very talented woman, was forced out because they slashed her budget. It's a shame. They're going to see the consequences. Crime will skyrocket, and people will get hurt. It's a tragic error, a complete mess. Portland's in the same boat, clueless. They'll be begging for our help soon enough. We know how to fix these problems, very quickly. It's a simple solution, really.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, are you thinking about dismissing him? [SEP] I think about dismissing everyone. It's bound to happen eventually. Jennifer, you're working hard.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, given Russia's food import ban and Secretary Hagel's concerns about a potential invasion of Ukraine, does this suggest that the current sanctions regime is not achieving its objectives? [SEP] It's premature to conclude that the sanctions are ineffective. They are designed to apply considerable pressure to the Russian economy. If one considers the financial markets, the outflow of capital, and the projected growth rates, it becomes evident that the Russian economy has largely stagnated. The flight of capital has been substantial, and new investors are hesitant to enter the Russian market. This situation presents President Putin with a critical decision: to pursue diplomatic solutions to the issues in eastern Ukraine, recognizing Ukraine's sovereignty, or to persist on his current trajectory, which will ultimately be detrimental to his economy and his people. We are acting in accordance with our strategic objectives, and we are gratified that our European allies and partners are aligned with us in this effort. However, the underlying problem remains unresolved. Hostilities continue, civilians are losing their lives, and we have witnessed the tragic consequences in the loss of the Malaysian airliner. It is imperative that we resume serious discussions to ensure that the voices of all Ukrainians are heard, that they can participate in the political process, and that reforms are implemented to safeguard the rights of Russian speakers and to decentralize power. Only when President Putin acknowledges Ukraine's independence can we assert that the problem has been definitively resolved. In the interim, the sanctions are functioning as intended.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. What is your strategy? What are you going to do? [SEP] We talked a lot about Pakistan. I have a very good relationship with Prime Minister Khan—very good. We talked about it today at length, actually, and—Prime Minister Modi. And it's no question it's a problem, but it's a problem they have—they're working on it.India is—you know, it's a brave nation too. There's no pullback from India. And we just hope—and I said I'll help. I'll do whatever I have to do, if I can do that, because my relationship with both gentlemen is so good.But there has been difficulty in Pakistan, and we're seeing what we can do about it. Anything I can do to mediate, anything I can do to help, I would do.They're working on Kashmir. Kashmir has been a thorn in a lot of people's sides for a long time. And there are two sides to every story, but they've been working on that very hard.We discussed it at great length: terrorism. And I think we have some very good ideas. He's very, very strongly against terrorism. I'll tell you, Prime Minister Modi is a very—he's a very religious man, as you know, he's a very calm man, but he's actually a very, very strong person. Very tough, actually, when—I've seen him in action. And he's got that foremost on his mind, terrorism. He'll take care of it. Please.
label: Dodging

sentence: Can you share any details about your previous conversations with Kim Jong Un? What was the nature of those discussions? [SEP] Look, those conversations are private. What I will say is that we've built a strong foundation for future progress. We've established important relationships at various levels, and that's why we were able to reach an agreement. But I'm not going to get into the specifics of our private discussions.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I want to follow up on what you were saying about ISIL and ask, if you think that the objective here is to destroy and degrade them, are those the same thing in your mind? Is the goal to ultimately—Secretary Kerry said that there's no containing them, so is the goal to ultimately annihilate them? And also, you talked about the importance of expertise on the ground and building up capacity on the ground. Do you think since airstrikes are not going to do it here, if ultimately, action is needed in Syria, can you realistically expect the Free Syrian Army to do what's needed on the ground to really destroy, not just push back, ISIL? [SEP] You can't contain an organization that is running roughshod through that much territory, causing that much havoc, displacing that many people, killing that many innocents, enslaving that many women. The goal has to be to dismantle them.And if you look at what happened with Al Qaida in the FATA, where their primary base was, you initially push them back. You systematically degrade their capabilities. You narrow their scope of action. You slowly shrink the space, the territory that they may control. You take out their leadership. And over time, they are not able to conduct the same kinds of terrorist attacks as they once could.As I said, I think, in my last press conference, given the nature of these organizations, are there potentially remnants of an organization that are still running around and hiding and still potentially plotting? Absolutely. And we will continue to hunt them down the same way we're doing with remnants of Al Qaida in the FATA or elements of al-Shabaab in Somalia or terrorists who operate anywhere around the world.But what we can accomplish is to dismantle this network, this force that has claimed to control this much territory, so that they can't do us harm. And that's going to be our objective. And as I said before, I'm pleased to see that there's unanimity among our friends and allies that that is a worthy goal and they are prepared to work with us in accomplishing that goal.With respect to the situation on the ground in Syria, we will not be placing U.S. ground troops to try to control the areas that are part of the conflict inside of Syria. I don't think that's necessary for us to accomplish our goal. We are going to have to find effective partners on the ground to push back against ISIL. And the moderate coalition there is one that we can work with. We have experience working with many of them. They have been, to some degree, outgunned and outmanned, and that's why it's important for us to work with our friends and allies to support them more effectively. But keep in mind that when you have U.S. forces, other advanced nations going after ISIL and putting them on the defensive and putting them on the run, it's pretty remarkable what then ground forces can do, even if initially they were on the defensive against ISIL.So that is a developing strategy that we are going to be consulting with our friends, our allies, our regional partners. But the bottom line is, we will do what is necessary in order to make sure that ISIL does not threaten the United States or our friends and partners. Okay?One last question. Colleen. Colleen Nelson, Wall Street Journal.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia's announcement of scaling back military operations near Kyiv, do you interpret this as a genuine de-escalation, potentially signaling the war's end, or a strategic maneuver to regroup and intensify their efforts? [SEP] Well, it's a bit premature to draw any definitive conclusions. We'll have to monitor their actions on the ground to see if they align with their statements. Negotiations are ongoing, and I recently conferred with key NATO allies. The consensus is to remain cautiously optimistic but vigilant. In the meantime, we'll maintain robust sanctions and continue supporting Ukraine's defense capabilities. So, the situation remains fluid, and we're keeping a close watch.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. When is the soonest you expect a vaccine to be ready for Americans to take? [SEP] Well, I heard very positive things, but by the end of the year, we think we're in very good shape to be doing that. By the end of this year, we're going to—in terms of the vaccine. I think in terms of therapeutics, even sooner than that. Therapeutics, meaning, you go, and you give somebody, whether it's transfusion or shots or whatever it may be, and they heal, and they heal quickly.So we've had tremendous progress. We already have, if you look at remdesivir and if you look at some of the other things. But we'll have some announcements on that over the next 2 weeks.Yes, it is hope, but it's only hope, because we've gotten such incredible results, scientifically.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. You heard McConnell talk about nuclear power, offshore drilling, free trade. That's a lot of Republican stuff. Is your party going to go for that if you decide to support that kind of thing? [SEP] You know, I think that on energy, there should be a bipartisan agreement that we have to take a both-and approach rather than an either-or approach. What do I mean by that? I am very firm in my conviction that the country that leads the way in clean energy--solar, wind, biodiesel, geothermal--that country is going to win the race in the 21st-century global economy. So we have to move in that direction.What is also true is that given our energy needs in order to continue economic growth, produce jobs, make sure our businesses are competitive around the world, that we're going to need some of the old, traditional energy sources as we're developing these new ones and ramping them up. All right? So we can't overnight convert to an all-solar or an all-wind economy. That just can't happen. We're going to have needs in these traditional sources.And so the question then is, are we going to be able to put together a package that includes safe, secure nuclear power, that includes new technologies so that we can use coal, which we have in abundance and is very cheap but often is adding to our greenhouse gases? Can we find sequestration technologies that clean that up? Can we identify opportunities to increase our oil and natural gas production in a way that is environmentally sustainable? And that should be part of a package with our development of clean energy.And you know, my hope is that my Republican friends, but also Democrats, say to themselves, let's be practical and let's do both. Let's not just do one or the other, let's do both. Over time, I think the transition is going to be more and more clean energy, and over time, fossil fuels become less prominent in our overall energy mix. But we've got to do both.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding North Korea, if Kim Jong-un remains unwilling to negotiate and take required actions, will the U.S. consider strengthening sanctions and increasing pressure? [SEP] I'm not going to speculate on future actions. We have strong sanctions in place. I don't want to discuss increasing them. There are many good people in North Korea, and that matters to me. My perspective has evolved since getting to know Chairman Kim. They have their own viewpoint. I prefer not to delve into that. Hopefully, for the sake of , Japan, and frankly, the world, we can find a solution. I spoke with President Xi, who understands the situation. He doesn't want a nuclear state next door either. So, that's where we are. Now, I'm heading back to Washington, DC. Thank you all.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Just following up on Jake's question about Solyndra. The loan program--guaranteed loan program that you talked about was giving out $38 billion in guaranteed loans and promised to save or create 65,000 jobs, green jobs, in clean energy, and there's been reports that actually only 3,500 new jobs have been created in that industry. Why has that industry been so slow to respond to the investment that your administration has provided? And what do you see going forward as to how it will respond? [SEP] Well, I think that what has been true historically is that businesses that rely on new technologies, often--a lot of times it's going to take a while before they get takeoff. And there are a lot of upfront investments that have to be made in research and capital and so forth, a lot of barriers for companies that are trying to break in. Keep in mind that clean energy companies are competing against traditional energy companies. And traditional energy is still cheaper in a lot of ways.The problem is, is it's running out, it's polluting, and we know that demand is going to keep on increasing so that if we don't prepare now, if we don't invest now, if we don't get on top of technologies now, we're going to be facing 20 years from now China and India having a billion new drivers on the road, the trendlines in terms of oil prices, coal, et cetera, going up, the impact on the planet increasing. And we're not just going to be able to start when all heck is breaking loose and say, boy, we better find some new energy sources.So in the meantime, we've got to make these investments, but that makes it more difficult for a lot of these companies to succeed. What's also a problem, as I said, is that other countries are subsidizing these industries much more aggressively than we are. Hundreds of billions of dollars the Chinese Government is pouring into the clean energy sector, partly because they're projecting what's going to happen 10 or 20 years from now.So look, I have confidence in American businesses and American technology and American scientists and entrepreneurs being able to win that competition. We are not going to be duplicating the kind of system that they have in China where they are basically state-run banks giving money to state-run companies and ignoring losses and ignoring bad management. But there is a role to play for us to make sure that these companies can at least have a fighting shot. And it does mean that there are going to be some that aren't successful, and it's going to be an uphill climb for some. And obviously, it's very difficult for all companies right now to succeed when the economy is as soft and as weak as it.
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, critics argue you sidestepped the gun violence issue in your first term and in 2012. You backed the assault weapons ban, but didn't push further. Where were you during these years of repeated tragedies? [SEP] Jake, I've been running the country, facing the biggest economic meltdown since the Great Depression, saving the auto industry, and managing two wars. I haven't exactly been on vacation. We need to rethink our priorities in Washington. Protecting our kids should be number one. I'm all in on doing everything we can to make that happen. It's about healthcare, education, jobs – it's all connected. But gun violence has to be a top priority. That's why I'm confident Joe will tackle this head-on. Thanks, everyone.
label: General

sentence: Q. So, to be clear, you're refusing to confirm or deny U.S. drone activity in Yemen? Is that your position? [SEP] My focus remains on safeguarding our nation. Disclosing operational details would be imprudent and potentially jeopardize our strategic interests.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, after three and a half years in office, do you have any regrets regarding the alleged misinformation you've disseminated to the American public? [SEP] Excuse me, could you repeat the last part?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, considering the complexities of the geopolitical landscape in the Middle East, what specific assurances would you require from Iran and Syria before considering any form of cooperation, even if it were deemed strategically beneficial in Iraq? [SEP] We're looking for concrete actions, not just words. They need to demonstrate a genuine commitment to regional stability and a willingness to abide by international norms. That means ceasing all support for terrorist organizations, halting their pursuit of weapons of mass destruction, and respecting the sovereignty of their neighbors. Until we see tangible evidence of these changes, any talk of cooperation is premature.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, the statistics regarding anti-Semitism and hate crimes are deeply concerning. Anti-Semitic incidents have surged by 57 percent since 2016, and hate crimes are on the rise. What factors do you believe are contributing to this trend, and what specific actions will your administration take to address it? [SEP] It is indeed disheartening to witness such developments. I find it deeply regrettable. As you may recall, during our previous meeting, Prime Minister Netanyahu himself stated that I have done more for Israel than any other President. Those were his exact words. Jerusalem, our collaborative efforts, providing protection – numerous aspects. However, the most significant achievement is undoubtedly Jerusalem. Many previous Presidents have expressed their intention to establish the Embassy in Jerusalem, but it never materialized. Designating it as the capital of Israel – never happened. Yet, I accomplished it swiftly. Furthermore, we not only established the Embassy but also completed its construction. This undertaking would have typically required an additional 15 to 20 years and incurred costs of billions of dollars. We achieved it with minimal expenditure. It is already operational and open. No one has done more for Israel than Donald Trump. And the remarkable aspect is that this assessment is not solely my own; it is echoed by Prime Minister Netanyahu.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to the Supreme Court's ruling yesterday concerning climate change, what is your reaction, and does it not make broad greenhouse gas emission caps unavoidable? [SEP] The Supreme Court has made its decision, which we respect. We are currently examining its details. It specifically concerns emissions from automobiles. We have proposed a plan to address greenhouse gases from automobiles, mandating 35 billion gallons of alternative fuels by 2017, reducing gasoline usage by 20% and halting the growth of greenhouse gases from automobiles. Congress has a remedy available and should pass it quickly. More broadly, I take this issue seriously, acknowledging man's contribution to greenhouse gases. However, any solution must not harm economic growth, as it affects working people and requires expensive new technologies. International cooperation, especially with China, is essential. Our principles are: encouraging new technology, growing the economy, and ensuring China and India are part of a rational solution. Next question, please.
label: Deflection

sentence: So, are you suggesting that the climate situation is perhaps not as dire as some reports indicate? [SEP] Well, I'm waiting to hear President Putin's assessment following his meeting. What I'm particularly interested in is whether he still shares my concerns about nuclear proliferation. He reaffirmed in Australia that he recognizes the danger of nuclear weapons. They've been supportive in the UN, and we're working on a possible third resolution. So, my focus is on preventing nuclear proliferation. The pictures of the meeting are secondary. I'll continue working with Russia and other nations to send a clear message: continued nuclear ambitions will lead to isolation.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, are you now leaning towards eliminating the filibuster, given your recent comments? [SEP] That's been covered./National Security/Education Reform/A Stronger Middle Class.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, you mentioned studying other countries' reopening strategies. Can you provide specific examples of countries that have successfully reopened and the strategies they employed? Conversely, which countries have faced setbacks, and what lessons have you learned from their experiences? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to name names, okay? We're watching everybody. Some are doing great, some are having problems. It's a learning process. What's important is that we're taking all of that information and using it to make the best decisions for our country. We're going to open up in phases, state by state, and we're going to do it safely. We're not going to rush things. We're going to listen to the experts, and we're going to make sure that we're protecting the American people.
label: General

sentence: Q. And, President Quang, if I could ask a question of you. There are some people who believe that Vietnam could make an effective facilitator in bringing the United States and North Korea together to at least lay the groundwork, potentially, for negotiations. What do you believe Vietnam could bring to the table in that regard? [SEP] On issue, Vietnam is committed to seriously observing all the relevant resolutions of the UNSC, and we support the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula. And we'll do our utmost and do whatever we can to contribute to the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula.Thank you.
label: Explicit

sentence: Regarding [Country], what is the likelihood of the United States extending official recognition? [SEP] I recommend a thorough review of the Ahtisaari plan. Additionally, let's address the critical issue of deploying more peacekeepers to Darfur. The primary impediment has been the lack of a status of forces agreement between the U.N. and Sudan. With its recent signing, progress should be expedited. We have numerous volunteers, and as Chair of the African Union, we are actively seeking increased participation. We have committed to providing a battalion and will consider further contributions as needed.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, will you meet with President Putin on this trip, or would you rule that out? [SEP] I'm sure I'll see him. He's going to be there. It's important to remember the role Russia played in World War II, and that's what Normandy is about.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. ----on who--[inaudible]? [SEP] Sam Stein, Huffington Post--where's Sam? Here.
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, Democrats are accusing you of playing games with the debt ceiling. They say you are willing to risk the full faith and credit of the United States to get what you want. How do you respond? [SEP] The issue is whether or not America pays its bills. We are not a deadbeat nation. There's a very simple solution to this: Congress authorizes us to pay our bills. If the House and the Senate want to give me the authority so that they don't have to take these tough votes, if they want to put the responsibility on me to raise the debt ceiling, I'm happily to take it. But if they want to keep this responsibility, then they need to go ahead and get it done. There are no magic tricks here. There are no loopholes. There are no easy outs. This is a matter of Congress authorizes spending. They order me to spend. They tell me, you need to fund our Defense Department at such and such a level; you need to send out Social Security checks; you need to make sure that you are paying to care for our veterans. They lay all this out for me, and because they have the spending power. And so I am required by law to go ahead and pay these bills. Separately, they also have to authorize the raising of the debt ceiling in order to make sure that those bills are paid. And so what Congress can't do is tell me to spend X, and then say, but we're not going to give you the authority to go ahead and pay the bills.
label: Implicit

sentence: ——pursue nuclear armament? [SEP] I recognize your tactic. It's a subtle ploy to elicit a response, but I'm not taking the bait. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify, should President Zelenskyy cede territory to Russia for a ceasefire, and should Russia be removed from the G-20? [SEP] On the latter, my position is affirmative, contingent on the G-20's decision. It was discussed earlier today. I proposed that if consensus isn't possible – if Indonesia and others disagree – we consider allowing both to attend as observers. Now, what was your first question again?
label: Clarification

sentence: What specific steps are you taking to close that gap? Will the U.S. commit to further international vaccine donations? And realistically, can we still expect the pandemic to be over by 2022, considering the current challenges? [SEP] It might stretch out a bit longer globally. The U.S. will keep at it. We might be able to offer another billion doses sometime between 2022 and 2023, but that's not set in stone. I've tried to be upfront about what we know and what we can do during this pandemic, and only announce things when they're actually happening. I don't want to get ahead of myself. The G-7 folks all agreed that we're in this for the long haul, until everyone's needs are met. It's not just the right thing to do morally, but it's also in our own interest. You can't build a wall high enough to keep out new variants. This will be an ongoing project. And we might face other pandemics down the road. We need a system to spot potential threats early. As long as countries need vaccines, we'll be there to help. We're also helping countries make their own vaccines. It's one thing to ship vaccines, but it's another to have the means to administer them. India, for example, can manufacture vaccines, but they need the supplies. We're working on that. Last question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, if you were to choose the second option of the 2 trillion dollar package, would that need to include some form of stimulus, such as a payroll tax extension or the extension of unemployment insurance, for you to sign it? [SEP] A payroll tax cut and unemployment insurance are both beneficial for the economy. A payroll tax cut put money in the pockets of the average American family and offset some of the rising costs in gasoline and food. American consumers and businesses would benefit from a continuation of that tax cut next year. Unemployment insurance is important because unemployment is still too high. Many people are doing everything they can to find a job, but the market is still tight. We need to make sure that they are able to stay in their homes and support their families, which is important and contributes to the overall economy. We can take a little over a trillion dollars in serious discretionary cuts, meaningful discretionary cuts, and then start building on top of that some cuts in non-health-care mandatory payments, ethanol programs, or how we calculate various subsidies to various industries. That could potentially be layered on. And we could still do something like a tax cut for ordinary families that would end up benefiting the economy as a whole. That is not my preferable option, though. I think about this like a layer cake. You can do the bare minimum, and then you can make some progressively harder decisions to solve the problem more and more. If we're serious about this and everybody is willing to compromise, we can fix this thing for a decade or more. That would be good for the overall business climate and would encourage the American people that Washington actually is willing to take care of its business.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the situation with China, many analysts suggest that a purely economic approach overlooks the geopolitical dimensions of the relationship. How are you factoring in strategic considerations, such as China's growing influence in the South China Sea, into your trade negotiations? [SEP] Well, let me tell you, it's not just about the money, though the money is very important. It's about fairness. We were getting ripped off, plain and simple. And nobody, nobody had the guts to stand up to them. They were taking advantage of us for years, decades even. And frankly, Obama, Biden, they let it happen. They didn't have the strength, the will. But we're changing that. We're making deals that are good for America, good for American workers. And as far as the South China Sea, we're watching it very closely. We have a very strong military, the strongest in the world, and we're not afraid to use it if we have to. We're going to protect our interests, and we're going to make sure that China plays by the rules. It's very simple. We want a fair deal, a level playing field. And if they don't want to play fair, then we'll find somebody else who does.
label: Deflection

sentence: You've stated that mail-in voting is prone to fraud. Can you provide specific evidence of widespread fraud resulting from mail-in ballots in Nevada or other states? [SEP] If you read the papers, even the failing New York Times, they've had stories. You see them all over the internet.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the current economic downturn and its potential impact on global stability, especially regarding China's actions towards Taiwan, and the implications of the Putin-Kim meeting for the war in Ukraine, what are your thoughts? [SEP] Well, let's be clear, China's facing some serious economic headwinds due to global factors and their own policies. I don't foresee this leading to an invasion of Taiwan, in fact, it might actually reduce their capabilities. We're not looking to harm China, a prosperous China that plays by international rules benefits everyone. However, they're grappling with real estate issues and are currently weighing their options. We're not aiming to decouple, but we won't provide them with materials that could enhance their nuclear or defense capabilities that go against regional stability. Are we clear? Next question.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: So, is a formal signature required for this agreement to be valid? [SEP] Well, that's an interesting question. Since it's not legally binding, the technicalities of a signature become less clear. I'm not sure about the specific protocols. However, I want to emphasize that the United States is fully committed to this agreement, and we believe it's extremely important.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, considering the UK's exemption from the travel ban despite having more coronavirus cases than several Schengen countries, why are they receiving preferential treatment, particularly with their recent spike in infections? Are you considering adding them to the restricted list? [SEP] The decision was made based on advice from professionals, but we're continuously monitoring the situation with the most recent information. The figures from the UK have been increasing rapidly, so we may need to add them to the list. We might even include a couple of others, and frankly, we're also thinking about removing some countries from the list.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Sir, regarding the NHS, is it on the table for discussion? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Can you describe the weapon used? [SEP] That information is not currently available to me.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Lee, North Korea's impending rocket launch has raised international concerns. If they proceed with this launch, defying warnings, what specific actions will South Korea take? What sanctions are you considering, and what's the status of negotiations regarding extending South Korea's missile range? [SEP] Let me be clear: If North Korea proceeds with this launch, it will be a blatant violation of UN Security Council Resolution 1874 and a direct contradiction of their pledges to the international community. They will bear the full responsibility for the consequences. It will only deepen their isolation. The North Korean people will see that their leader is wasting vast sums of money on a missile launch while they suffer. We urge them to reconsider and act as a responsible member of the international community. Regarding extending South Korea's missile range, we did not discuss that today, although working-level discussions are ongoing. It is part of enhancing our overall defense capabilities against North Korea. We will remain calm, rational, and wise in our response.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Kieran Gilbert, Sky News Australia. General Mattis has called China a revisionist power and that there are growing threats from China. Yet, you're very positive about your relationship with Xi. Can you tell us, is it a friend or a foe?And on North Korea—the sanctions, if they don't work, are all options still on the table? Can I get your answer and also the Prime Minister's thoughts? [SEP] Well, to the second, we'll have to see. I don't think I'm going to exactly play that card. But we'll have to see. If the sanctions don't work, we'll have to go phase two. And phase two may be a very rough thing. May be very, very unfortunate for the world. But hopefully the sanctions will work. We have tremendous support all around the world for what we're doing. It really is a rogue nation. If we can make a deal, it'll be a great thing. And if we can't, something will have to happen. So we'll see.As far as General Mattis is concerned, I mean, he has that view, and a lot of people have that view. China is tough. They're getting stronger. They're getting stronger to a large extent, with a lot of the money they've made from having poor leadership in the United States, because the United States leadership has allowed them to get away with murder.With that being said, I think we can have a truly great even trading relationship with China. Hopefully that's going to work out. And hopefully the relationship I have with President Xi will make that happen. Only time will tell. Thank you. Well, I can confirm that President Trump and President Xi see eye-to-eye in every respect. And they have a—it's very clear at the meetings I've been at, which we've attended in the region—the East Asia Summit, and so forth, APEC—the respect that they have with each other. And I think it's the most—single most important relationship—between China and the United States. It's clearly very respectful, very frank, very clear-eyed.For our own part, we see China's rise as being overwhelmingly a positive for the region and for the world. The critical thing, of course, is the rule of law is maintained. You know, that is the—there are people that want to try to paint the United States and its allies, like Australia, as being against China in some sort of rerun of the cold war. That is not appropriate. It's not accurate.What we need to ensure is that the rules of the road, the rule of law, the rules-based system, where big countries can't push around little countries; where, to quote Lee Kuan Yew all those years ago, where you don't have a world where the big fish eat the little fish and the little fish eat the shrimps. Where you have that rule of law that protects everybody, that is what has enabled the great growth in our region. That's what's enabled hundreds of millions of people in our region, and including in China, to be lifted out of poverty. So maintaining that rules-based order is what we are committed to, and we all have a vested interest in doing so.And I just want to say again, to the President, that the—that his presence—his own personal presence in our region at the end of last year was—sent such a powerful message. The regular visits by Secretary Tillerson, Secretary Mattis, and of course, the presence of the United States Navy and so many other manifestations of American commitment to the region is so important to maintaining that rules-based order. Believe me, that has been the foundation of the success, the prosperity, and the security these last 40 or more years. I don't think we've ever had a better relationship with China than we do right now. The only thing that can get in its way is trade, because it's so one-sided, it's so lopsided. And the people that stood here for many years in this position, right where I am right now, should never have allowed that to happen. It's very unfair to the United States, and it's very unfair to the workers of the United States. Very, very unfair.And even today, it's extremely hard on companies that want to do business in China, because the barriers are incredible, whereas the barriers coming into our country are foolishly not. Foolishly. I believe in reciprocal trade. If they do something to us, we do something to them. Well, that never happened. And it's gotten worse and worse over the years. But we'll correct it. That can be the only thing that can get in the way of a truly long-term, great relationship. Because we have all the ingredients for friendship.From the Washington Examiner, Gabby [Gabby Morrongiello, Washington Examiner].
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. The Commerce Department reported today that the housing starts last month fell to the lowest level since 1993. How concerned are you that this housing recession will spill over into the broader economy, and what more can be done to prevent that from happening? [SEP] Ed, I'm encouraged by the rate of inflation, the job growth. We've had 49 consecutive months of uninterrupted job growth, which is a record here in America. I'm pleased with the fact that our deficit is shrinking. But like our Secretary of the Treasury, I recognize there's softness in the housing market. By the way, we had growth in the GDP because of exports. In other words, there's positive elements of our economy. But no question, the housing is soft.And the fundamental question is, what do we do to help homeowners? I don't think we ought to be providing bailouts for lenders, but I do think we ought to put policy in place that help people stay in their home. And that's why this FHA modernization bill is really important, because it'll extend the reach of the FHA and to help more people be able to refinance their homes.Part of the issue in the housing market has been that as a result of asset bundling, that it's hard sometimes for people to find somebody to talk to, to help them refinance. In other words, in the old days, you go into your savings and loan, your local savings and loan, and sit down and negotiate a house deal, and the person with whom you negotiated would be around if you had financial difficulties, to say, can't you help me restructure? Today, the originator of the note no longer owns the note in many cases.And the securitization of mortgages actually provided a lot of liquidity in the market, and that's a good thing. But it also creates a issue here in America, and that is, how do we get people to understand the nature of the mortgages they bought, and how do you help people refinance to stay in home—stay in their home? And so that's what Secretary Paulson, Secretary Jackson have been working on, particularly with the private sector, to facilitate the ability to people to refinance.And finally, we need to change the tax laws. You're disadvantaged if you refinance your home. It creates a tax liability. And if we want people staying in their homes, then it seems like to me, we got to change the Tax Code. That's why I talked to Senator Stabenow the other day and thanked her for her sponsorship of an important piece of tax legislation that will enable people to more likely stay in their homes.So there's some things we can do, Ed. In the meantime, you just got to understand, it's going to have to work out; when you got more houses than you got buyers, the price tends to go down. And we're just going to have to work through the issue. I'm not a forecaster, but I can tell people that I feel good about many of the economic indicators here in the United States.Peter [Peter Baker, Washington Post].
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you made what I would describe as an emotional talk or speech on the genocides of Rwanda, especially when you were visiting the memorial. But unfortunately, the perpetrators of the killings are still holed up in several parts of the country—also several parts of the world, especially the Congo. And you just mentioned that we need to see results being done—results being seen, and the civil arguments have been made. So I'm wondering, Mr. President, what is the U.S. going to do about these perpetrators that remain at large and are walking freely? [SEP] Yes.
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, given the current situation with the tunnels, is a realistic ceasefire even possible, or should we rethink our approach? [SEP] Look, the ceasefire that was on the table gave Israel the ability to keep taking out those tunnels, and they can do that without flattening Gaza. Those tunnels have to go. There's a way to do it without so much bloodshed. You see the costs in these conflicts. Kids are getting killed, women are getting killed, Israelis are living in fear. These are costs we can avoid if we get a ceasefire that protects Israel and guarantees they won't be constantly under rocket fire, while also recognizing the Palestinians' need to live a decent life. It's hard, there's a lot of anger and despair, but we have to keep trying. That's what American leadership is all about. These crises might have some risks for us, like with ISIS, but mostly, they aren't direct threats. We care because we have responsibilities. We have to be realistic about what we can do. We've been at war for a decade, and our resources are stretched thin. Still, we try. When John Kerry is out there trying to get a ceasefire, we should be supporting him, not complaining that it hasn't happened yet. Nobody else is even trying. And usually, because we get involved, things get better, not perfect, but better. That's true for the Middle East, Ukraine, and Iraq. Let me remind everyone that in my first term, all anyone wanted to talk about was the economy and jobs. Well, what we did worked. The economy is better. We've had six months of over 200,000 jobs created, that hasn't happened in 17 years. That shows you what happens when you stick with it.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Have you--you've talked with economists, you said that economists have agreed that a deal needs to be made. Have you worked with new U.S. business leaders at all to lobby Congress to raise the debt ceiling? And if so, who are you talking to? [SEP] I have spoken extensively to business leaders. And I'll be honest with you: I think that business leaders in the abstract want to see a resolution to this problem. What I've found is that they are somewhat hesitant to weigh in on some of these issues even if they're willing to say something privately to me, partly because they've got a whole bunch of business pending before Congress and they don't want to make anybody mad.So this is a problem of our politics and our politicians, but it's not exclusively a problem of our politics and our politicians. I mean, the business community is a lot like everybody else, which is we want to cut everybody else's stuff and we want to keep our stuff. We want to cut our taxes, but if you want to raise revenue with somebody else's taxes, that's okay. And that kind of mindset is why we never get the problem solved.There have been business leaders, like Warren Buffett, who I think have spoken out forcefully on this issue. I think some of the folks who participated in the Bowles-Simpson Commission made very clear that they would agree to a balanced approach even if it meant for them, individually, that they were seeing slightly higher taxes on their income, given that they're--I think the average CEO, if I'm not mistaken, saw a 23-percent raise this past year while the average worker saw a 0- to 1-percent raise last year.So I think that there are a lot of well-meaning businesspeople out there who recognize the need to make something happen. But I think that they've been hesitant to be as straightforward as I'd like when it says, this is what a balanced package means. It means that we've got some spending cuts, it means that we've got some increased revenue, and it means that we're taking on some of the drivers of our long-term debt and deficits.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, Brexit plan: changed your mind? Friendly to trash the PM? Prime Minister, Trump's right? How'd you feel? [SEP] Didn't change my mind. Respect the PM. Story's fake news, left out the good stuff. She decides. I just want to trade. We trade, they trade, big potential. Different way, still trade? Hope so. Tricky, but we'll do it. She's great. Prime Minister: No limit on trade after EU, Chequers deal. Delivers Brexit, ends free movement, court, payments. Our trade policy, deals everywhere. U.S. wants in, we're on it.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. To be clear, though, you just said, I know him well. Did Donald Trump's decision to run affect yours? Would you be running if he wasn't? [SEP] Yes, I think I still would be running if he wasn't. I do know him well. He's not hard to know, as you know. You know him well, too.And the question is whether or not—look, there's just—there's more to finish the job. We have an opportunity to put ourselves in a position where we are economically and politically secure for a long time.Look, there—we continue to have—and I know you don't like me—hearing me saying it. There's still a contest between autocracies and democracies, and we're the leading democracy in the world. And it's something I know a fair amount about. It's something I care about and something that I have found a willingness of an awful lot of our allies and friends to follow.So I think that, you know, we have to finish the job and nail it down.
label: Explicit

sentence: So, about that Meng Wanzhou thing, Mr. President. Is that gonna drag on forever, or is there any chance we just drop it? [SEP] Huh? What are you talking about?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, if you go ahead on your own on unemployment insurance, I'm wondering both where you're going to get the money to pay for that without Congress and will people still get $600 a week? [SEP] Yes, we have the money. We have the money. Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, some Democrats facing challenging elections in November are rumored to have requested a delay on immigration reform. To what extent have their concerns shaped your thinking, and do you perceive any drawbacks to postponing action until after the election? [SEP] My attention has been largely consumed by pressing foreign policy issues, such as the situation in Ukraine, combating ISIS, and reinforcing NATO alliances. On the matter of immigration, I've received initial recommendations from Johnson and Holder, which are under review. While my preference remains Congressional action on comprehensive immigration reform, I'm prepared to utilize executive authority to enhance border security, improve processing efficiency, and establish avenues for legal residency. A decision will be forthcoming shortly.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, regarding potential staff departures within the White House, specifically the rumors surrounding General Kelly's exit, can you confirm or deny these reports? [SEP] Look, in any administration, you're going to have people moving on. It's a natural part of the process. People leave.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Pope's actions on Palestinian state recognition, how will this affect your two-state solution plans? [SEP] Well, let me first say that Congress needs to act on this infrastructure bill. We're talking about rebuilding America, creating jobs, and modernizing our economy for the 21st century. This isn't just about roads and bridges; it's about high-speed internet, clean energy, and ensuring every American has the opportunity to succeed. Now, some folks are playing politics, trying to hold this bill hostage. But I'm confident that we can find common ground and deliver for the American people. And that's what I'm focused on. As for your other question, remind me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Beyond the stimulus, what concrete steps can you offer to those facing economic hardship? [SEP] Well, first, let's be clear, these tax cuts are crucial. We need to make them permanent. Now, I know some folks are worried about gas prices, maybe four bucks a gallon, who knows? That's a big deal. But if we keep those taxes low, that's one less thing to worry about. Plus, we gotta get serious about energy. Renewables are great, but we need more oil and gas right here at home. We haven't built a refinery in ages. I suggested building them on old military bases, but Congress didn't go for it. Less supply, same demand, prices go up. It's simple economics. And this idea of taxing oil companies? That's just going to make things worse. We need to be encouraging investment. So, yeah, it's tough out there, but this stimulus, these tax cuts, and a smart energy policy, that's the plan.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you very much, Mr. President. Grazie, Mr. Prime Minister.Mr. President, in your meeting with His Holiness Pope Francis, did he register any objections with you about the contraception coverage mandate in the Affordable Care Act or your efforts to advance the rights of gays and lesbians in the United States that worry so many Catholics? And what were his concerns?And on Russia, with reports of troops building on the Ukrainian border, by taking the military option off the table are you sending a signal to Vladimir Putin that other parts of Ukraine are his for the taking? And why not send multinational peacekeepers to the Ukrainian border as a deterrent?And to you, Mr. Prime Minister, the President said yesterday that the U.S. would defend any NATO ally. Are you making that same commitment when it comes to Russia? [SEP] That's a lot of questions there, Jim. [] Do the Italian journalists, by the way, do this—these sort of five-part questions? [] Same thing?[.] I can't say about Italian journalism. [] The—all right, let me try to remember this. In terms of the meeting with His Holiness Pope Francis, we had a wide-ranging discussion. I would say that the largest bulk of the time was discussing two central concerns of his. One is the issues of the poor, the marginalized, those without opportunity, and growing inequality.And those of us as politicians have the task of trying to come up with policies to address issues, but His Holiness has the capacity to open people's eyes and make sure they're seeing that this is an issue. And he's discussed in the past, I think, the dangers of indifference or cynicism when it comes to our ability to reach out to those less fortunate or those locked out of opportunity.And then we spent a lot of time talking about the challenges of conflict and how elusive peace is around the world. There was some specific focus on the Middle East, where His Holiness has a deep interest in the Israeli-Palestinian issue, but also what's happening in Syria, what's happening in Lebanon, and the potential persecution of Christians. And I reaffirmed that it is central to U.S. foreign policy that we protect the interests of religious minorities around the world.But we also touched on regions like Latin America, where there's been tremendous progress in many countries, but there's been less progress in others.I think what—the theme that stitched our conversation together was a belief that in politics and in life, the quality of empathy, the ability to stand in somebody else's shoes and to care for someone even if they don't look like you or talk like you or share your philosophy, that that's critical. It's the lack of empathy that makes it very easy for us to plunge into wars. It's the lack of empathy that allows us to ignore the homeless on the streets. And obviously, central to my Christian faith is a belief in treating others as they—I'd have them treat me. And what's, I think, created so much love and excitement for His Holiness has been that he seems to live this and shows that joy continuously.In terms of domestic issues, the two issues that we touched on—other than the fact that I invited and urged him to come visit the United States, telling him that people would be overjoyed to see him—was immigration reform. And as someone who came from Latin America, I think he was very mindful of the plight of so many immigrants who are wonderful people, working hard, making contributions, many of their children are U.S. citizens, and yet they still live in the shadows, in many cases have been deported, and are separated from families. I described to him how I felt that there was still an opportunity for us to make this right and get a law passed.And he actually did not touch, in detail, on the Affordable Care Act. In my Cardinal—in my meeting with his Secretary of State, Cardinal Parolin, we discussed briefly the issue of making sure that conscience and religious freedom was observed in the context of applying the law. And I explained to him that most religious organizations are entirely exempt. Religiously affiliated hospitals or universities or NGOs simply have to attest that they have a religious objection, in which case they are not required to provide contraception, although employees of theirs who choose are able to obtain it through the insurance company.And I pledged to continue to dialogue with the U.S. Conference of Bishops to make sure that we can strike the right balance, making sure that not only everybody has health care, but families, and women in particular, are able to enjoy the kind of health care coverage that the ACA offers, but that religious freedom is still observed.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, the lack of clear communication regarding the coronavirus has had serious consequences. Are you willing to commit to a comprehensive review of the government's communication strategy and implement reforms to ensure that the public receives accurate and timely information in future public health emergencies? [SEP] We're always looking for ways to improve our response to public health emergencies. We've learned a lot from this pandemic, and we're committed to applying those lessons to future challenges. We're constantly evaluating our communication strategies and working to ensure that the public has the information they need to make informed decisions. We're committed to transparency and will continue to work with experts to provide the best possible guidance to the American people.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Senate proceedings, what are your preferences for the trial's duration and scope? Also, your reaction to the reported tension between White House Counsel Cipollone and Jerrold Nadler? Finally, are you categorically opposed to John Bolton's testimony? [SEP] Many questions, indeed.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Syria, did your discussions with President Putin and President Hu reveal any willingness on their part for Assad to relinquish power, and did you achieve any concrete steps towards ending the violence? [SEP] Well, Syria was definitely a key focus in both meetings. The situation there, as everyone knows, is spiraling out of control, with civilians being targeted and Assad having clearly lost any claim to legitimacy. When you resort to massacres against your own people, it becomes impossible to imagine a peaceful transition that includes Assad. Now, achieving that transition is a complex matter. Russia, with its historical ties to Syria, and China, generally hesitant to interfere in other nations' internal affairs, have been reluctant to apply the necessary pressure. Our conversations were frank. While the U.S. and the international community aren't fully aligned with Russia and China on this, I believe they recognize the dangers of a full-blown civil war. I don't believe they condone the massacres, and they understand that a mechanism for ending the violence and establishing a legitimate government would benefit everyone. I've emphasized the importance of working with the UN and Kofi Annan on a political transition plan. Hopefully, we can continue these discussions and present a clear path forward to the Syrian people. However, it's premature to say that Russia and China are fully on board. They acknowledge the gravity of the situation and its negative impact on their interests and the Syrian people's. We all agree that helping the Syrian people find a resolution is in everyone's best interest. Personally, I don't see a scenario where Assad remains in power and the violence decreases. He failed to uphold his end of the Annan plan, leading to further escalation and the deaths of innocent civilians. Even the international monitors have had to withdraw due to the violence. While some argue that the opposition is also engaged in violence, the horrifying images from places like Homs are a direct result of the Syrian government's actions, for which Assad is ultimately responsible.
label: General

sentence: Regarding the Iraqi Prime Minister's visit, do you see Iraq as a potential buffer against Iranian and Russian influence under his leadership, and what are your thoughts on that possibility? [SEP] We have a good relationship. We're almost entirely out of Iraq. These endless wars are ridiculous, a mistake from the start. We're leaving, it's a slow process, but we're getting out.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify, do you anticipate that the issue of school reopenings will be a significant factor in the upcoming midterm elections, potentially aiding Republican efforts to regain suburban districts? [SEP] Look, anything *could* be a factor. But I think the American people are more focused on what really matters: their families, their jobs, their safety. They're not going to be easily distracted by political theater. The media environment is so polarized now. People are getting their information from sources that reinforce their existing beliefs. This has fundamentally changed the way politics works. As for the polls, they go up and down. The real question is whether voters are buying into the extreme narratives being pushed by some. So, while school reopenings *might* be a talking point, I don't think it will be the deciding factor.
label: Implicit

sentence:
Mr. President, it seems like every week there's another scandal involving a member of your party. Why is it so hard for Republicans to stay out of trouble? [SEP] Richard, let me be clear: anyone who breaks the rules should be held responsible, period. We need to have faith in our leaders, and that means holding them to a high standard. I take responsibility for my own actions, and everyone else should do the same. We're all supposed to be honorable. People can disagree, but we need to have standards, and we need to enforce them.

Thanks, see you on the campaign trail.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, can you update us on the Hong Kong business advisory and the status of the Build Back Better agenda? [SEP] Just those two? I thought we agreed on two questions each. Alright, the Hong Kong advisory: the situation there is getting worse. The Chinese Government isn't keeping its word. It's basically a warning about what could happen. Simple, yet complicated. Am I confident about Build Back Better? Absolutely. The press has written it off a million times. I don't think it's dead. I'm confident we'll get what I proposed and what we agreed to in the bipartisan infrastructure deal. I trust the Republican Senators who made promises. They're honorable folks, and I expect them to keep their word. The reconciliation process is how we get every Democrat on board with things like what I announced today. If you have kids and make less than $150,000, you'll get a significant tax cut. If you have a child under 7, you'll get a monthly payment, like a Social Security check. It's supposed to reduce child poverty by over 40%. We have ways to pay for both the infrastructure package and the human infrastructure package. There might be some last-minute haggling over the funding, but I believe we'll get it done. We talked about China, and we agree they're a competitor in many areas. Trade needs to be fair, with a level playing field and the same rules. We need to be technological leaders. We'll cooperate on things like CHIPS. We need to discuss internet norms and standards. We should coordinate our efforts with China. Our shared values should guide our relationship. On the pandemic, we can only beat it if everyone is vaccinated. We're trying to boost production and get as many people vaccinated as possible. We're investing in COVAX and helping companies make more vaccines. We're helping Africans build their own production sites. There's an imbalance, but we're working to overcome it.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. My question is from His Excellency, the President of the United States. First, if President-elect Obama brings any change in the war against terrorism in Afghanistan or any change in the strategy to—towards Afghanistan or in the policies? Being from the Republicans, will your party support his plannings?And second, regarding he said he was in Pakistan and the terrorists in Pakistan, what's your message to Obama that how he should deal with Pakistani Government regarding terrorists, about the diplomat— using diplomatic ways or using military? [SEP] Yes. Thank you. First, I am of a different political party than President-elect Obama. But I want him to succeed. I want him to do well. And to this end, we have worked hard to help the transition.Secondly, I think it is interesting that he has picked Secretary Gates, the Secretary of Defense under—the last couple of years under my administration, who will be the Secretary of Defense under his administration. And I think that should send a clear signal to the people of Afghanistan that the transition will be a smooth transition.I expect you'll see more U.S. troops here as quickly as possible in parts of the country that are being challenged by the Taliban. I remember when President Karzai and President Musharraf and I had the famous dinner at the White House. Yes. And it—you know, the discussions really are the same today as they were then, and that is that extremists and terrorists and people who use car bombs and suicide bombers to achieve political objectives are a threat to all of us. And that there needs to be a comprehensive strategy in helping the Pakistan Government deal with those who bring great harm on their citizens and bring harm on the citizens of Afghanistan.So to answer your question, I think it's a—we need to have a collaborative strategy. We need to work together in a constructive way. And we are making progress along those lines. You know, I was with President Zardari in—I think it was in New York. And I had never met him before, and I was reminding him that I'm, you know, a person who says that we will defend our country and defend our people. The most important job for the President of the United States is defend our people from attack.He said, You don't have to talk to me about extremists attacking people, extremists killed my wife. And so we're—there's a lot of consultations going on with the President—I think you're going to be meeting with President Zardari soon. Yes. And that's good, and I appreciate that.Olivier [Olivier Knox, Agence France-Presse].Military Operations in Afghanistan/
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the House Democrats' proposal for a second round of direct payments to Americans, what is your perspective? [SEP] Well, we are currently engaged in discussions with a multitude of individuals regarding that matter. My preference is for a payroll tax reduction, along with various other measures. My priority is ensuring the well-being of the workforce. We are presently negotiating with the Democrats, and the outcome remains to be seen. This represents a transition towards a period of exceptional prosperity, commencing in the coming year. I anticipate that we will achieve remarkable success. I view the third quarter as a transitional phase, potentially yielding positive results. The fourth quarter, I believe, will witness the emergence of substantial figures. Next year holds the potential for performance comparable to, or even surpassing, previous levels, owing to pent-up demand. Many individuals have been eager to engage in various activities, but have been constrained by the virus. Consequently, I anticipate a phenomenal year ahead, barring any disruptive interventions, such as tax increases proposed by a certain party, namely the Democrats. We presided over the greatest economy in history, and we shall replicate that success swiftly and effortlessly. Yes, ma'am.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, was he invited? [SEP] That's not something I handle directly. I don't manage the scheduling for press briefings. What I do know is that my team and the individual in question maintain a close and productive working relationship, which is of paramount importance.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding North Korea's potential nuclear test, could you elaborate on your discussions with President Xi? How much influence do you believe China wields in dissuading North Korea, and what consequences would a test have on U.S.-China relations? [SEP] Look, it's not a given that China has complete control over North Korea, plain and simple. I've told President Xi Jinping that they should try to make it clear to North Korea that they shouldn't do these nuclear tests. And I also said that if they do, we'll have to take defensive actions. These actions wouldn't be against China, but they'd send a clear message to North Korea. We're going to defend our allies, our soil, and our capabilities. I'm not sure if China has the power to stop them, but I'm sure they don't want North Korea escalating things. I've made it clear that we'll do what we need to defend ourselves and our allies, like South Korea and Japan. It wouldn't be because of China, but because of North Korea. We're working with China to try to resolve this, but it's not going to be easy. I don't think there's a need to worry about a new Cold War. I want to be clear with everyone, especially Xi Jinping, that I mean what I say. Misunderstandings are the biggest concern. We had a long meeting, and I think we understand each other, which is the most important thing.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, just to follow up with Terry's question a little bit. You talked about the mortgage markets and banks. Are there other entities in the economy that are so crucial to the stability and confidence in the economy—I'm thinking particularly of General Motors, which today is cutting jobs, announcing they're going into the credit market to raise billions of dollars—are there other entities that are so crucial to stability that require Government action to show support for them? [SEP] Government action—if you're talking about bailing out—if your question is, should the Government bail out private enterprise? The answer is, no, it shouldn't. And by the way, the decisions on Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac—I hear some say bailout—I don't think it's a bailout. The shareholders still own the company. That's why I said we want this to continue to be a shareholder-owned company.In this case, there is a feeling that the Government will stand behind mortgages through these two entities. And therefore, we felt a special need to step up and say that we are going to provide, if needed, temporary assistance through either debt or capital.In terms of private enterprises, no, I don't think the Government ought to be involved with bailing out companies. I think the Government ought to create the conditions so that companies can survive. And I've listed four. And one of the things I'm deeply troubled about is people who feel like it's okay to raise taxes during these times. And it would be a huge mistake to raise taxes right now.Plante [Bill Plante, CBS News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Roxham Road, the agreement has been ready for a year. Why the delay? And concerning the 15,000 migrants Canada will accept, why such a limited number? What concessions did we offer the U.S.? [SEP] Well, the Prime Minister's comments are insightful. Shutting down Roxham Road without a comprehensive solution would create more problems. People would seek alternative crossing points. Modernizing the Safe Third Country Agreement ensures that those crossing irregularly are treated the same as those seeking asylum in the first safe country. This complex process took time. We are protecting the system's integrity while upholding our obligations to asylum seekers. We'll also increase the number of asylum seekers from the Western Hemisphere to compensate for closing irregular crossings.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. With respect to the NHS, should it be included in the discussions? [SEP] Pardon? I didn't hear you clearly.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, could you clarify whether your administration's strategy is to completely destroy ISIS or simply contain their influence and push them back from their current territories? [SEP] Our objective is to ensure that ISIL is not an ongoing threat to the region. We can accomplish that. It's going to take some time and effort. As we've seen with Al Qaida, there are always remnants that can cause havoc, in part because of the nature of terrorist activities. You get a few individuals, and they may be able to carry out a terrorist act. But what we can do is to make sure that the kind of systemic and broad-based aggression that we've seen out of ISIL that terrorizes primarily Muslims—Shia, Sunni—terrorizes Kurds, terrorizes not just Iraqis, but people throughout the region, that that is degraded to the point where it is no longer the kind of factor that we've seen it being over the last several months.
label: General

sentence: Q. But you're willing to—[inaudible]—TikTok with them in these negotiations? [SEP] Well, we're not talking to them. No, we're talking to the companies. In theory, it's a company, but it's a company within China. That means China. And the deal will have to be substantially beneficial to the United States, and we need total security. Okay?
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering the current tensions, do you foresee a future where U.S.-North Korea relations mirror the normalization seen with Vietnam? [SEP] Say that again.
label: Clarification

sentence: And what's the estimated timeline for that? [SEP] Hard to say precisely, but things should move along at a good clip. Next question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Given the history of provocative actions coinciding with US outreach to Cuba, what is your understanding of Fidel Castro's involvement in the recent talks? Did his name arise during your discussions with Raul Castro? Furthermore, considering Republican opposition to lifting the embargo and establishing an embassy, will you personally engage with them to prevent efforts to block funding for a new embassy? [SEP] I think we're going to have to wrap this up here. We're running short on time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Prime Minister Netanyahu's stance on a Palestinian state, what concrete steps would convince you he's serious about peace? And can you address the allegations of Israeli spying during the Iran nuclear negotiations? [SEP] I don't discuss intelligence matters. Regarding Iran, we keep Congress, Israel, and our allies informed. Any agreement will be transparent and verifiable.
