That violates the core principles that were debated during the course of this election and that the American people determined was the wrong way to go.And so my hope is, is that the Speaker and his caucus, in conjunction with the other legislative leaders up there, can find a way to make sure that middle class families don't see their taxes go up on January 1; that we make sure that those things that middle class families count on like tax credits for college or making sure that they're getting some help when it comes to raising their kids through things like the child tax credit, that that gets done; and that we have a balanced package for deficit reduction, which is exactly what I've put forward.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the gravity of the allegations against Judge Kavanaugh, would you consider supporting a renewed FBI investigation to ensure a thorough and impartial assessment? [SEP] Typically, the FBI doesn't revisit these matters. Judge Kavanaugh has already been subjected to six background checks. He's an exceptional individual, possessing great intellect and serving as an outstanding judge with an unblemished record. I feel immense sympathy for him and his family during this ordeal. These allegations should have surfaced much earlier. Senator Feinstein had this information for quite some time; why didn't she raise it then? The Democrats are engaging in obstruction and resistance. Nevertheless, we must ensure a comprehensive process. I hope the accuser will come forward, and Judge Kavanaugh will have the opportunity to present his case before the Senate. Ultimately, they will vote based on his career and the evidence presented. He's an extraordinary individual, and I feel deeply for him and his family.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, given your earlier statements on Brexit, some perceive a contradiction between advocating for a strong U.K. and potentially hindering its trade prospects with the U.S. How do you reconcile these seemingly conflicting positions? [SEP] Look, I want the U.K. to be strong, very strong. They're great people. And I want them to be able to trade with us, absolutely. The Prime Minister is working hard, and she'll figure it out. We just need to make sure there are no restrictions, no barriers. We're their biggest trading partner, and we want to keep it that way. It's all about making deals, and I'm a dealmaker.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Madam President, while Brazil aspires to a global leadership role, the U.S. often views it as a regional player. How do you reconcile these differing perspectives and ensure a balanced partnership between our nations? [SEP] Well, let's be clear, Brazil's influence extends far beyond our region. We are a key player on the world stage, and our partnership with the U.S. is vital for addressing global challenges.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, just a quick question on rural America. In States like Indiana and North Dakota, folks turned out for Republican candidates. Could you talk a little bit about what this means for your agenda in terms of trade and the farm bill? [SEP] The farm bill is working really well. I mean, we could have had it approved any time. But we're looking to get work rules approved. The farmers want it. I'd like it. The problem is, the Democrats are not giving us the 10 votes that we need.We are—everybody wants it. The farmers want it. But the Democrats are not approving the farm bill with work rules. We could have it very fast without the work rules, but we want the work rules in, and the Democrats just don't want to vote for that. So, at some point, they'll have to pay maybe a price.Jeff [Jeff Mason, Reuters], go ahead.
label: General

sentence: Q. You mentioned that you have raised extensively the issue of human rights with Chairman Kim. The President. Yes. Q. I wonder what you would say to the group of people who have no ability whatsoever to hear or to see this press conference, the 100,000 North Koreans kept in a network of gulags. Have you betrayed them by legitimizing the regime in Pyongyang? [SEP] No, I think I've helped them, because I think things will change. I think I've helped them. There's nothing I can say. All I can do is do what I can do. We have to stop the nuclearization. We have to do other things, and that's a very important thing. So at a certain point, hopefully, you'll be able to ask me a much more positive question or make a statement.But not much I can do right now. At a certain point, I really believe he's going to do things about it. I think they are one of the great winners today, that large group of people that you're talking about. I think, ultimately, they're going to be one of the great winners as a group.Yes, sir. Go ahead. Go ahead. Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, with respect, when can we expect the next meeting with Chinese officials to take place? [SEP] That's something I can't really say right now. It could be soon, or it could be a while off. I honestly couldn't tell you. I'm hoping for soon, but it might not happen for quite some time.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding Libya, you've expressed a desire for Qadhafi to relinquish power. Are you willing to employ all available resources of the U.S. government to achieve this objective? If not, what constraints are preventing a more decisive intervention, considering the apparent shift in stance compared to other regional uprisings? [SEP] Well, our immediate concern was the safety of American citizens and embassy personnel in Libya, which we successfully addressed. Subsequently, we initiated the most substantial financial asset seizure in our nation's history. Following that, we imposed sanctions and mobilized international support through the UN, gradually intensifying pressure on Qadhafi. He's facing increasing international isolation through sanctions and an arms embargo. Furthermore, we've extended humanitarian aid to assist those crossing into Tunisia and Egypt, and we'll continue this support. Within NATO, we're exploring various options, from continuous surveillance to monitor the situation and respond swiftly to potential deterioration, to reinforcing the arms embargo, providing additional humanitarian assistance, and considering potential military actions, including a no-fly zone. NATO will convene on Tuesday to discuss a no-fly zone, and we've engaged with Arab and African nations to assess their support for such a measure. Secretary Clinton will also meet with the opposition in the coming days, and we're assigning a representative to liaise with them and identify ways to offer further assistance. In essence, all options remain on the table. It's crucial to recognize the speed with which the international coalition has acted to impose sanctions on Qadhafi. I firmly believe that Qadhafi's departure is in the best interest of the United States and, more importantly, the Libyan people. I haven't ruled out any possibilities. However, I take seriously the need for thorough consideration and consultation with Secretary Gates, Admiral Mullen, and relevant personnel before making any decisions involving U.S. military force. Deploying U.S. forces into potentially hostile environments entails risks and consequences, and it's my responsibility as President to carefully evaluate those risks. Politically, it's also vital to maintain the strong international coalition we've established.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. So if I understand you correctly, your view hasn't changed, but you'll put in abeyance the issue of whether to use that word in the future? [SEP] What I'd like to do is to encourage President Gul to move forward with what have been some very fruitful negotiations. And I'm not interested in the United States in any way tilting these negotiations one way or another while they are having useful discussions.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. ——that you think the Republican Party needs to be more inclusive. Who needs to hear that message inside the Republican Party? [SEP] Yes. You see, I am concerned that, in the wake of the defeat, that the temptation will be to look inward and to say, well, here's a litmus test you must adhere to.This party will come back. And—but the party's message has got to be that different points of view are included in the party. And take, for example, the immigration debate. That's obviously a highly contentious issue. And the problem with the outcome of the initial round of the debate was that some people said, Well, Republicans don't like immigrants. Now, that may be fair or unfair, but that's what—that's the image that came out.And you know, if the image is we don't like immigrants, then there's probably somebody else out there saying, Well, if they don't like the immigrants, they probably don't like me as well. And so my point was, is that our party has got to be compassionate and broadminded.I remember the 1964 elections. My dad happened to be running for the United States Senate then and, you know, got landslided with the Johnson landslide in the State of Texas. But it wasn't just George Bush who got defeated, the Republican Party was pretty well decimated at the time. At least that's what they—well, I think that's how the pundits viewed it. And then '66, there was a resurgence. And the same thing can happen this time, but we just got to make sure our message is broad-gauged and compassionate: That we care about people's lives, and we've got a plan to help them improve their lives.Jake, yes. How you doing?
label: General

sentence: Q. Given the history of provocative actions whenever the U.S. extends an olive branch, and considering the Republican opposition to your Cuba policy, what was Fidel Castro's role in the talks, and did you discuss him with Raul? Furthermore, will you personally lobby Congress to prevent them from blocking funding for the new embassy? [SEP] I appreciate your thoroughness, Lesley, but I'm going to have to cut this line of questioning short. We're running out of time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the National Security Adviser's memo suggesting a break between Prime Minister Maliki and Muqtada Al Sadr, can you confirm if this reflects your administration's strategy? Did you discuss this specific issue with the Prime Minister during your meeting this morning? Furthermore, Prime Minister, your close ties with Mr. Al Sadr have been cited as a key issue in Iraq. Did you assure the President that you would sever ties with Al Sadr, and could your government withstand such a separation? [SEP] With respect to Al Sadr, I'll defer to the Prime Minister's insights on that relationship. Our discussion centered on the Iraqi security landscape, a matter of grave concern for both of us. The Prime Minister's primary duty is the safety and security of the Iraqi people. His frustration stems from a lack of adequate resources to address lawbreakers. I was reassured by his dedication to a united, pluralistic society where accountability prevails, regardless of whether the perpetrators are criminals, Al Qaeda, or militia members. He shared his political realities, and I believe he's best positioned to discuss the Sadr group or any other internal factions. Our coalition isn't exclusive; the national unity government comprises various participating entities, representing a collective national responsibility. The Sadrists are merely one component within Parliament and the Government. Participation entails responsibility and mutual commitment, including upholding the Government, Constitution, and the law. Therefore, I'm focused on the state, the law, and commitments applicable to all government partners. Lawbreakers will be dealt with accordingly, prioritizing the sovereignty and power of the state.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, you've spoken about a shift towards decency and breaking the fever of the past few years. Do you believe this election signifies that the fever has finally broken? [SEP] Well, I don't think we're going to break the fever for the super-mega-MAGA Republicans. But I think they're a minority of the Republican Party. I think the vast majority of the members of the Republican Party, we disagree strongly on issues, but they're decent, honorable people. The rest of the world is looking at the United States. At the first G-7 meeting, one of the leaders turned to me and said: For how long? Another one went on to say, What would you say, Joe, if in fact you went—we went to bed tonight here in England, woke up the next morning and found out that thousands of people had stormed the Parliament of Great Britain—gone down the hall, broken down the doors, two cops ended up dying, a number of people injured, and they tried to stop the confirmation of an election? That's the way people were looking at us, like, When is this going to stop? Nothing like this has happened since the Civil War. They want to know: Is the United States stable? Do we know what we're about? Are we the same democracy we've always been?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. There's a report that your Director of National Intelligence has ordered a broad review—this is regards to the Boston Marathon bombing—that your DNI has ordered a broad review of all the intelligence gathering prior to the attack. There is also a series of senators—Susan Collins, Saxby Chambliss, Lindsey Graham—who allege that all these years after 9/11, there still wasn't enough intelligence shared prior to the attack. And now, Lindsey Graham, who is a senior member of the Armed Services Committee, has said that Benghazi and Boston are both examples of the U.S. going backwards on national security. Is he right? And did our intelligence miss something? [SEP] No, Mr. Graham is not right on this issue, although I'm sure it generated some headlines.I think that what we saw in Boston was State, local, Federal officials, every agency rallying around a city that had been attacked, identifying the perpetrators just hours after the scene had been examined. We now have one individual deceased, one in custody. Charges have been brought.I think that all our law enforcement officials performed in an exemplary fashion after the bombing had taken place. And we should be very proud of their work, as obviously we're proud of the people of Boston and all the first responders and the medical personnel that helped save lives.What we also know is that the Russian intelligence services had alerted U.S. intelligence about the older brother as well as the mother, indicating that they might be sympathizers to extremists. The FBI investigated that older brother. It's not as if the FBI did nothing. They not only investigated the older brother, they interviewed the older brother. They concluded that there were no signs that he was engaging in extremist activity. So that much we know.And the question then is, was there something that happened that triggered radicalization and actualan actual decision by the brother to engage in the attack that wethe tragic attack we actually saw in Boston? And are there thingsadditional things that could have been done in that interim that might have prevented it?Now, what Director Clapper is doing is standard procedure around here, which is when an event like this happens, we want to go back and we want to review every step that was taken. We want to leave no stone unturned. We want to see, is there, in fact, additional protocols and procedures that could be put in place that would further improve and enhance our ability to detect a potential attack? And we won't know that until that review is completed. We won't know that until the investigation of the actual crime is fully completed. And that's still ongoing.But what I can say is, is that based on what I've seen so far, the FBI performed its duties, the Department of Homeland Security did what it was supposed to be doing.But this is hard stuff. And I've said for quite some time that because of the pressure that we've put on Al aida core, because of the pressure that we've put on these networks that are well financed and more sophisticated and can engage in and project transnational threats against the United States, one of the dangers that we now face are self-radicalized individuals who are already here in the United States, in some cases, may not be part of any kind of network, but because of whatever warped, twisted ideas they may have, may decide to carry out an attack. And those are in some ways more difficult to prevent.And so what I've done for months now is to indicate to our entire counterterrorism team, what more can we do on that threat that is looming on the horizon? Are there more things that we can do, whether it's engaging in communitiesengaging with communities where there's a potential for self-radicalization at thisof this sort? Is there work that can be done in terms of detection? But all of this has to be done in the context of our laws, due process.And so part of what Director Clapper is doing, then, is going to be to see if we can determine any lessons learned from what happened.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President—[inaudible]—Valentinovna, Sputnik News Agency. Have you discussed the issue of possible inspections to North Korea's nuclear sites during your negotiations? [SEP] I'm sorry, I couldn't quite hear you. Can you please speak up and also tell me where you're from?
label: Clarification

sentence: Chancellor Merkel, given Iran's potential rejection of the EU's offer, what specific, concrete actions is Germany prepared to take, beyond existing sanctions, to pressure Iran to comply with international demands regarding its nuclear program? [SEP] We are in close consultation with our allies to determine the most effective course of action. We believe that a unified approach is crucial. We are considering all options, including additional sanctions, but any measures must be carefully calibrated to avoid unintended consequences. We remain committed to a diplomatic solution, but we are also prepared to take necessary steps to prevent Iran from developing nuclear weapons.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, is a signature required for this agreement to be considered valid? [SEP] That's a procedural detail I'm not entirely focused on right now. Since it's not a legally binding agreement, the necessity of a signature is, frankly, a secondary concern. What *is* important is that the United States is committed to this, and we believe it's a vital step forward. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your public conduct sets a poor example. How do you respond? [SEP] With all due respect, that's simply incorrect. My actions are within the bounds of political engagement, which has well-established precedents and exceptions.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning your meeting with Vladimir Putin, what specific red lines did you convey regarding Russian interference in democratic elections, and what consequences did you outline for future violations? [SEP] I had a frank and direct conversation with President Putin about a range of issues, including election interference. I made it clear that the United States will not tolerate any attempts to undermine our democracy. We will defend our elections and hold those who interfere accountable. As for the specifics, I prefer to keep those discussions private.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And what about your immediate family, Mr. President? [SEP] Excuse me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Chancellor Merkel, if Iran rejects the EU's proposal, what specific, tangible steps will Germany take to increase pressure on the Iranian regime, beyond simply discussing 'additional sanctions'? Will Germany commit to specific actions, such as restricting trade with Iran or freezing Iranian assets, and what is the timeline for implementing these measures? [SEP] We are actively engaged in discussions with our European partners and international allies to develop a comprehensive strategy. We are considering a range of options, including targeted sanctions and diplomatic initiatives. Our priority is to ensure that Iran complies with its international obligations and abandons its nuclear ambitions. We will continue to work closely with our partners to achieve this goal.
label: General

sentence: Concerning the goals for Prime Minister Maliki and the fight against Al Qaeda, are you suggesting the U.S. won't be involved in stopping sectarian violence in Iraq? Also, Prime Minister, why was last night's meeting cancelled? [SEP] I'm sorry, I missed the first part of your lengthy question. Could you repeat it?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Will you go visit? [SEP] But I think that—excuse me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, are you now leaning towards eliminating the filibuster? [SEP] I've addressed this matter previously./Infrastructure Investment/Climate Change Initiatives/Economic Recovery Plan
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Just to clarify, concerning your Cabinet? [SEP] Could you repeat that?
label: Clarification

sentence: On the matter of rockets and settlements, Mr. President, what specific actions do you believe Israel should undertake to address the growing threat from Gaza? And did the Prime Minister offer any new assurances regarding the removal of illegal outposts? [SEP] We are committed to de-escalating tensions.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, what prompted you to level these accusations at this particular moment? [SEP] The truth is out there, folks. They've practically raised their hands and admitted to targeting our farmers. It's not exactly a state secret. But allow me to elaborate a bit further, if I may...
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, President-elect Trump has mentioned the possibility of easing sanctions on Russia in exchange for significant reductions in their nuclear arsenal. Considering your own efforts in arms control, do you believe this is a sound strategy? Given your experience in office and your understanding of Mr. Trump's approach, what advice would you give his advisors to help him effectively manage his relationship with Vladimir Putin? And in light of your recent actions concerning Russia, do you think these sanctions should be viewed as leverage in future negotiations? [SEP] Well, let's break this down. First, it's in America's and the world's interest to have a constructive relationship with Russia. That's been my approach throughout my presidency. Where we've had common ground, we've worked together. Early in my term, I did what I could to encourage Russia to be a constructive player on the world stage, helping them diversify and strengthen their economy, and use the talents of the Russian people in more productive ways. However, it's fair to say that after President Putin came back into the presidency, an escalating anti-American rhetoric and a global approach seemingly based on the idea that anything America does must be bad for Russia, leading them to counteract our efforts, has revived a Cold War-era adversarial spirit, making the relationship more difficult. This was further solidified when Russia intervened in Crimea and parts of Ukraine. The sanctions, as you recall, weren't about nuclear weapons. They were a response to the violation of Ukraine's independence and sovereignty through force by Russia. This wasn't just our view; it was the view of the entire international community. Russia continues to occupy Ukrainian territory, meddle in Ukrainian affairs, and support military proxies who have violated fundamental international law and norms. I've told the Russians that the sanctions will be lifted as soon as they stop doing that. To maintain international norms, it's crucial that we don't confuse the reasons for these sanctions with other issues. On nuclear matters, we negotiated the START II Treaty during my first term, significantly reducing nuclear stockpiles for both Russia and the United States. I was prepared to go further, and I told President Putin that, but they weren't willing to negotiate. If President-elect Trump can restart those talks in a serious way, there's still considerable potential for further stockpile reductions. Our success in nonproliferation and nuclear security has been partly due to leading by example. I hope that continues. However, it's essential to remember that the sanctions against Russia are a direct result of their actions in Ukraine. The United States must uphold the fundamental principle that larger countries cannot invade and bully smaller ones. I've said before that I expect Russia and Ukraine to have a strong relationship, given their historical, cultural, and social ties. However, Ukraine is an independent nation. This situation exemplifies the vital role America must continue to play in preserving basic norms and values globally, whether advocating for human rights, women's rights, or freedom of the press. The United States hasn't always been perfect in this regard. At times, we must engage with allies and partners who may not fully meet our desired standards for international rules and norms. However, I can assure you that in every multilateral forum—the United Nations, the G-20, the G-7—the United States has consistently championed these values. It's crucial for us to continue doing so, because if the largest, strongest democracy in the world isn't willing to stand up for these values, then certainly China, Russia, and others will not.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Could you elaborate on your thought process regarding the commutations, particularly since a significant portion involved firearms offenses, given your stance on gun control? [SEP] Well, you know...
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. I appreciate you making it a slow news week. [Laughter]I wanted to ask you about your evolution on the surveillance issues. I mean, part of what you're talking about today is restoring the public trust. And the public has seen you evolve from when you were in the U.S. Senate to now. And even as recently as June, you said that these—the process was such that people should be comfortable with it, and now you're saying you're making these reforms and people should be comfortable with those. So why should the public trust you on this issue? And why did you change your position multiple times? [SEP] Well, I think it's important to say, Carol, first of all, I haven't evolved in my assessment of the actual programs. I consistently have said that when I came into office, I evaluated them. Some of these programs I had been critical of when I was in the Senate. When I looked through specifically what was being done, my determination was that the two programs in particular that had been at issue, 215 and 702, offered valuable intelligence that helps us protect the American people, and they're worth preserving. What we also saw was that some bolts needed to be tightened up on some of the programs, so we initiated some additional oversight, reforms, compliance officers, audits, and so forth.And if you look at the reports—even the disclosures that Mr. Snowden has put forward—all the stories that have been written, what you're not reading about is the Government actually abusing these programs and listening in on people's phone calls or inappropriately reading people's e-mails. What you're hearing about is the prospect that these could be abused. Now, part of the reason they're not abused is because these checks are in place and those abuses would be against the law and would be against the orders of the FISC.Having said that, though, if you are outside of the intelligence community, if you are the ordinary person and you start seeing a bunch of headlines saying, U.S.—Big Brother looking down on you, collecting telephone records, et cetera, well, understandably, people would be concerned. I would be too if I wasn't inside the Government.And so in light of the changed environment where a whole set of questions have been raised, some in the most sensationalized manner possible, where these leaks are released, drip by drip, one a week, to kind of maximize attention and see if they can catch us at some imprecision on something; in light of that, it makes sense for us to go ahead, lay out what exactly we're doing, have a discussion with Congress, have a discussion with industry—which is also impacted by this—have a discussion with civil libertarians and see, can we do this better?I think the main thing I want to emphasize is, I don't have an interest and the people at the NSA don't have an interest in doing anything other than making sure that where we can prevent a terrorist attack, where we can get information ahead of time, that we're able to carry out that critical task. We do not have an interest in doing anything other than that. And we've tried to set up a system that is as failsafe as so far at least we've been able to think of to make sure that these programs are not abused.But people may have better ideas, and people may want to jigger slightly, sort of, the balance between the information that we can get versus the incremental encroachments on privacy that, if haven't already taken place, might take place in a future administration or as technologies develop further.And the other thing that's happening is, is that as technology develops further, technology itself may provide us some additional safeguards. So, for example, if people don't have confidence that the law, the checks and balances of the court and Congress are sufficient to give us confidence that Government's not snooping, well, maybe we can embed technologies in there that prevent the snooping regardless of what Government wants to do. I mean, there may be some technological fixes that provide another layer of assurance.And so those are the kinds of things that I'm looking forward to having a conversation about.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Bolsonaro, concerning the Venezuelan border situation, would you entertain the notion of hosting a U.S. military base or personnel in Brazil for support? And did this subject arise in your conversation with President Trump today? [SEP] Affirmative, we engaged in discussions regarding the potential for Brazil to attain the status of a significant non-NATO ally. We recently requested assistance from the United States in facilitating the delivery of food through Boa Vista to provide humanitarian aid. That is our present stance. Brazil stands ready to exert every possible effort to resolve the issue of the Venezuelan dictatorship and restore freedom and democracy to that country, which was once a nation of considerable wealth but now grapples with starvation and violence. We must resolve this pervasive issue. Mr. President?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Are you familiar with the Red Cross's findings? [SEP] I'm not aware of the specific report. We stand against torture. Moving on.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President, after three years and budgets, and your claim of prioritizing tough choices over a second term, why not negotiate with Republicans directly now? What concrete steps are you taking to foster cooperation? And will the markets tolerate two more years of gridlock? [SEP] Could you perhaps summarize your points? My attention span is waning.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, if I may, I'd like to address two news items and then pose a COVID-related question. First, have you been briefed on the incident off the California coast involving the deaths of marines and a Navy hospital corpsman during a training exercise over the weekend? [SEP] That briefing is scheduled for later today.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Madam President, Simone Iglesias with Bloomberg. If the United States were to militarily intervene in Venezuela, what would be Brazil's official stance? [SEP] Certain issues, you understand, are strategically sensitive. Disclosing them would be detrimental. I'm reminded of a debate where a candidate declined to reveal their ISIS strategy, arguing it would hinder their effectiveness. We'll uphold our commitments, but some information must remain confidential.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Acknowledging media pressure for a bipartisan agreement, and given this is your third year, what specific actions are you undertaking to promote collaboration, since you won't be inviting Republicans to the table today? Furthermore, do you believe the markets will tolerate a two-year wait? [SEP] Goodness, Jackie, you've certainly loaded that question! I'm not sure my brain has the bandwidth for all of that right now.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. And the sanctions? [SEP] The sanctions will come off when we are sure that the nukes are no longer a factor. Sanctions played a big role, but they'll come off at that point. I hope it's going to be soon, but they'll come off. They—as you know, and as I've said, the sanctions right now remain. But at a certain point, I actually look forward to taking them off. And they'll come off when we know we're down the road—where it's not going to happen, nothing is going to happen. Okay?
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, given your powerful statements on nonviolence, how do you reconcile being a Nobel Peace Prize laureate with the prospect of military action in Syria? Also, how did your discussion with Prime Minister Reinfeldt advance the global effort to combat climate change? [SEP] I addressed similar themes in my Nobel Prize acceptance speech. I spoke about the tension between striving for peace and confronting the realities of violence and evil in the world. The question is, what is our responsibility in the face of such evil? I have worked tirelessly to end wars, strengthen diplomacy, and promote multilateral solutions. However, the question we all face is: at what point do we intervene when faced with actions that violate our common humanity? When I see hundreds of children gassed, and thousands of innocent civilians dying senselessly, and we have an opportunity to take meaningful action, even if it doesn't solve the entire problem, the moral imperative is to act. It is a difficult decision, and it is the most challenging part of my job. I would prefer to focus on education, but sometimes I must confront the use of chemical weapons against children. As President, I cannot avoid these questions. When atrocities occur, the world looks to the United States for leadership. That's the reality. Now, remind me of your second question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, following Rick Ledgett's remarks about Snowden, what's your stance on potential amnesty or a plea bargain, and how do you respond to those who see Snowden as a whistleblower who acted in the public interest? [SEP] I need to be careful here because Mr. Snowden is facing criminal charges, and the matter is with the Attorney General and the courts. So, I can't get into the specifics of the case. That said, I've said before that the conversation he started was important and necessary. But the way he did it caused damage to the U.S. and our intelligence capabilities. There was a way to have this debate without causing that damage. The U.S., despite its flaws, respects the rule of law, privacy, and civil liberties. Because of these disclosures, countries that actually do the things Snowden was worried about are able to criticize the U.S. That's a distorted view. So, while the debate was important, it's also important to remember the unnecessary damage to U.S. intelligence and diplomacy. I'll leave the specifics of Mr. Snowden's case to the courts and the Attorney General.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Hiroshima and Nagasaki, do you believe the United States was right to drop the atomic bombs? [SEP] Now, remind me, was that the only question you wanted to ask?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the library funding, you've touched on several points: the $200 million goal, donor transparency, and contribution restrictions. Could you clarify which aspect you'd like to address first? [SEP] Whoa, hold on a second! That's a multi-part question. [] Let me see... no, yes, maybe, depends. [] I haven't even seen the final budget yet. And as my foundation chairman says, we'll figure out the disclosure rules later. Some donors, you know, they like to be anonymous. So we'll consider that. What else did you ask?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, are you suggesting Dr. Birx is being dishonest in her assessment of the pandemic's severity? [SEP] I'm saying we're doing a fantastic job, and the Democrats and the fake news media refuse to acknowledge it. We've saved millions of lives! We're the envy of the world. Dr. Birx is part of the team, but sometimes she gets caught up in the negativity. We need to focus on the positive and keep moving forward.
label: Deflection

sentence: Beyond the stimulus checks, what hope can you offer to people facing dire economic circumstances? [SEP] The best thing we can do is keep the tax cuts permanent. There's a lot of economic uncertainty. And therefore, one way to deal with uncertainty is for Congress to make the tax cuts permanent.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, the public is demanding clarity on travel restrictions. While you mention monitoring, can you definitively state what benchmarks would trigger immediate action regarding travel to and from South Korea and Italy, or is this a purely discretionary decision? [SEP] We're constantly assessing the situation, and we're prepared to take action as needed. We're working with our experts to determine the best course of action. We're not going to telegraph our moves, but we're going to do what's necessary to protect the American people. We're monitoring the data, we're consulting with our partners, and we're making informed decisions. We're not going to be rushed into anything, but we're also not going to hesitate to act when the time is right. We're going to keep the American people informed every step of the way.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. So, the core of this conspiracy is that you're secretly saving the world from a satanic cult of pedophiles and cannibals. Sound familiar, Mr. President? [SEP] Honestly, I haven't heard that one. But, you know, the fake news media is always coming up with crazy stuff. What I *am* doing is fighting for the American people and against the radical left. They're the real threat to this country, with their open borders and defund the police nonsense.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, the Baker-Hamilton report advocates for direct engagement with Iran and Syria, similar to how we negotiated with the Soviet Union during the Cold War. Your thoughts? [SEP] Look, with Iran, it's straightforward. They halt their enrichment program, verifiably, and then we talk. We'll bring in the EU-3, Russia, the whole gang. It's not rocket science. The Iranian Foreign Minister says they'll talk after we leave Iraq? That's a non-starter. If they want to talk for the good of their people, they stop enriching uranium. Period. The Iranian people deserve better than being a pariah state. They've got a great history, a great culture, but their leader is stuck in the past. That Holocaust denial conference? Come on! It's hurting Iran. We're pushing for a Security Council resolution. I talked to Condi Rice about it this morning. The message is simple: Iran is isolating itself. To the Iranian people, I say: You can do better. You deserve a leader who builds your economy, not one who's chasing nukes. There's a better way. Syria's the same deal. We've talked to them. We've told them what they need to do to get back in our good graces. It's not like we're asking for the moon. Stop letting those Saddam guys send money and guns into Iraq. Leave Lebanon alone. Prime Minister Siniora's doing a great job, standing up to Syria and Hezbollah. So, bottom line, we've told them what they need to do. Congressmen go to Syria all the time. If they want better relations, they need to start acting like it.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Did you discuss Venezuela? [SEP] We did. []
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the recently unveiled economic proposals, why the timing during a contentious election season? Critics suggest it's a political ploy. And why the reluctance to use the term 'stimulus' for the infrastructure component, given the original stimulus's negative perception? [SEP] Upon assuming office, we confronted an economy teetering on the edge of collapse. We enacted a plan that, according to economists, significantly mitigated the risk of a depression. A third of that plan consisted of tax cuts. We haven't waited until now to act. We've implemented tax cuts for small businesses eight times in the past 18 months. These measures have had a tangible impact. Three million individuals have jobs that wouldn't exist otherwise. The economy would be in a far worse state. However, we're not yet where we need to be. Therefore, what further steps can we take? Our proposals have historically garnered bipartisan support: a research and development tax credit, accelerated business depreciation. Regarding infrastructure, we're enhancing the highway bill. We're rebuilding America. We'll finance these initiatives by eliminating tax breaks for companies that export jobs overseas. These are commonsense approaches. Historically, Republicans and Democrats have found common ground on infrastructure and R&D. Let's move forward. It's not that the previous stimulus was ineffective. It had a positive impact. It simply hasn't achieved the desired level of progress. We have a long way to go.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. But the military does not recognize civil unions, right? [SEP] I understand. And as I said, this is going to be an issue that is not unique to the military; this is an issue that extends to all of our society, and I think we're all going to have to have a conversation about it.Dan Lothian [CNN].
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Sir, can we access a transcript of your conversations with Kim Jong Un? [SEP] Huh?

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Afghanistan, what is your timeline for troop withdrawal, similar to the 16-month plan for Iraq? Also, will you reverse the Pentagon's ban on media coverage of fallen soldiers returning to Dover Air Force Base, as Senator Biden once criticized? [SEP] First, let me say how saddened I am by the loss of four American service members in Iraq today. My thoughts are with their families. It's a stark reminder of the weight of this office. As for media access to Dover, we're reviewing the policy in consultation with the Department of Defense, and I'll have an answer after a thorough evaluation. Afghanistan is a different beast. Iraq has seen progress, a functioning political system, but Afghanistan's government seems detached. The Taliban and Al Qaeda operate freely in the border regions. We're conducting a comprehensive review, involving General Petraeus and Ambassador Holbrooke, to develop a regional approach. We need better coordination between military, diplomatic, and development efforts. But let's remember why we're there: 9/11. We can't allow Al Qaeda to operate with impunity. I don't have a specific timetable yet, but I won't let them plan attacks on our homeland.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Are you worried that you might have regrets? [SEP] No, I made a decision. I stand by it. I'm now worried that the rest of the world needs to move as expeditiously, quickly. Therefore, we're—as I've told you in this little address here, we've got $100 million to help move people into Darfur. And nor am I regretful of the fact that we put serious sanctions on leaders in Sudan and companies owned by certain actors in Sudan. It was the right thing to do.I am trying to get other people to join. As you know, getting a universal sanction regime can be difficult. People sometimes have got different interests, different commercial interests. Our position is, is that human suffering ought to be—preempt commercial interests. And so I'm comfortable with the decision I made. I'm not comfortable with to how quickly the response has been.And nevertheless, there is a—we'll continue dealing with the issue. Every stop I made, I've talked about Darfur. And the President talked about it too. I've talked so long you probably forgot her question to you. [] I still remember, President. Certainly, we discussed Darfur, as we discussed other problem areas, especially on our continent. And I do want to agree with the President; problems are there. But I think the best approach is, indeed, to help Africans develop their capacity to deal with these problems. And more importantly, as the President said, we probably also have to invest our time and even resources in the monitoring and also preventing problems coming up, as they keep coming up in different places.But it is important to understand that, indeed, today we'll have Darfur; maybe tomorrow there will be another problem area, God forbid. But it's important that these problems are not to be seen as if they have to be resolved, attended to, by the United States. They must be attended to by the international community. They must also be attended to by people, if it is in Africa, by Africans. Primarily, they must develop this capacity. And they should be supported to develop this capacity so that we can prevent and we are prepared to prevent. Then you should be able to cope with these challenges, resolving the problems.So I think the approach taken by President Bush were realistic, in the sense that you also do not want to see every problem, United States being called upon to be the answer of that problem. And of course, we—the backlash, also, in the sense that, at the same time, they also start blaming the United States, that they are rushing everywhere solving problems and, of course, reading through that to mean they have other interests and so on and so forth.So I think that will lead the way of helping the people to solve their own problems, but of course, with the support of the United States with its huge capabilities in different areas. And walking together with the rest of the international community is perhaps more important than just blaming the United States, saying, Why didn't you go in and solve the problem? The problems and the solutions to those problems should not be taken away from the responsibilities of their action, should not be taken away from places where they're taking place and the people in those places.I think that is the best way I could— but we did talk about that. And we did talk about our own contribution and to how that can be enhanced. And the President is willing to support us—support has always been coming—so that we continue to move forward.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. They—both of them, both of them. The President. There's a question as to whether or not we're supposed to or whether or not we legally have to. I don't care. I think it would be great to have China involved and also, of course, South Korea. Okay? Q. Thank you.The President's Meetings With Chairman of the State Affairs Commission Kim Jong Un of North Korea  Q. Is there a transcript of your conversation? [SEP] What?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. ——is the country more unified—is the country more unified than when you first took office? [SEP] The answer is: Based on some of the stuff we've got done, I'd say yes, but it's not nearly unified as it should be.Look, I still contend—and I know you'll have a right to judge me by this—I still contend that unless you can reach consensus in a democracy, you cannot sustain the democracy.And so this is a real test—whether or not my counterpart in China is right or not when he says autocracies are the only thing that could prevail because democracies take too long to make decisions and countries are too divided.I believe we're going through one of those inflection points in history that occurs every several generations or even more than that—even more time than that, where things are changing almost regardless of any particular policy.The world is changing in big ways. We're going to see—you've heard me say this before—we're going to see more change in the next 10 years than we saw in the last 50 years because of technology, because of fundamental alterations and alliances that are occurring not because of any one individual, just because of the nature of things.And so I think you're going to see an awful lot of transition. And the question is: Can we keep up with it? Can we maintain the democratic institutions that we have, not just here but around the world, to be able to generate democratic consensus of how to proceed?It's going to be hard. It's going to be hard, but it requires—it requires—leadership to do it. And I'm not giving up on the prospect of being able to do that.Thank you.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. So you technically are willing to negotiate? [SEP] No, Julianna, look, this is pretty straightforward. Either Congress pays its bills, or it doesn't. Now, ifand they want to keep this responsibility; if John Boehner and Mitch McConnell think that they can come up with a plan that somehow meets their criteria that they've set for why they willwhen they will raise the debt ceiling, they're free to go ahead and try. But the proposals that they've put forward in order to accomplish thatonly by cutting spendingmeans cuts to things like Medicare and education that the American people profoundly reject.Now, if they think that they can get that through Congress, then they're free to try. But I think that a better way of doing this is to go ahead and say, we're going to pay our bills. The question now is, how do we actually get our deficit in a manageable, sustainable way? And that's a conversation I'm happy to have.All right. Matt Spetalnick [Reuters].
label: Explicit

sentence: President Biden, considering the multifaceted nature of the U.S.-Canada partnership, encompassing economic stimulus, the automotive industry, border management, and carbon emissions trading, which of these domains presents the most pressing challenge and opportunity for bilateral cooperation? I must await further developments. I am deliberately maintaining my distance. While I am the chief law enforcement officer, I believe it is more appropriate for the Attorney General to manage it. He has appointed Durham, a man of great reputation, to oversee the matter. We shall see what transpires. I cannot elaborate further.

sentence: Q. What about in the suburban districts? How do you get those back? [SEP] Excuse me. You—no, but you're telling me about—you're telling me about popularity. They said many of these people—when I said 9 out of 11—but I said—when many of these people—these weren't, like, easy races; these were tough races.And so I think the level of popularity—the first question I was asked was about: Well, what have you learned? What about your own popularity? I think that's what I learned, is my—I was very well received by this great country, by the people of our great country. And I'm very proud of that, because I love the people of this country. These people—we are the greatest people. I love the people of our country.

sentence: Prime Minister, in both official languages, could you address the concerns arising from the RCMP's visit to your party headquarters and Elections Canada's allegations? Were you aware of this scheme, and will it be employed again in future elections? [SEP] This is the same old story. Elections Canada believes some local spending should be considered national spending. We disagree. We investigated at the time and maintain our position. We always follow the law as we understand it, and more importantly, as it has been interpreted. In the last election, we followed past interpretations. If those interpretations change, we'll conform, expecting the same rules for all parties. [In French, then translated:] As I said, Elections Canada thinks some local expenditures should be national expenses. We disagree, hence our court challenge. Ultimately, we'll respect the law and its interpretations, as we have in the past.

sentence: Mr. President, following General Pace's widely discussed remarks on homosexuality, your perspective remains unclear. Do you personally consider homosexuality to be immoral? sentence: Mr. President, concerning a potential meeting with President Castro in Havana, what preconditions, if any, would need to be satisfied? Furthermore, regarding the recent cyberattack, while you've declined to disclose your intended response, are you contemplating the imposition of additional economic or financial sanctions on North Korea? Can you explicitly rule out the use of military force or a retaliatory cyber operation? [SEP] I shall reiterate my previous statement: we have definitively attributed the attack to North Korea and are currently developing a spectrum of response options. These options will be presented to me, and I shall render a decision based on my assessment of what constitutes a proportional and appropriate response to the nature of this transgression. With respect to Cuba, a visit to Cuba by myself or a visit to the United States by President Castro is not presently under consideration. I am uncertain as to the future trajectory of this relationship. I am, however, relatively young, and I anticipate that I shall, at some juncture in my life, have the opportunity to visit Cuba and engage with the Cuban populace. Nevertheless, there are no concrete plans for such a visit at this time.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Obama, Senator Leahy is advocating for a truth and reconciliation committee to investigate potential misconduct by the Bush administration. He argues that we must 'read the page' before turning it. What is your response? [SEP] I haven't had the opportunity to review Senator Leahy's proposal in detail, so I'm hesitant to offer a definitive opinion. However, I can assure you that my administration is committed to operating with the highest ethical standards, upholding the rule of law, and respecting human rights. We do not condone torture, we adhere to the Geneva Conventions, and we ensure due process, even as we aggressively pursue those who seek to harm our nation. These principles are not contradictory; they are mutually reinforcing. While no one is above the law and clear instances of wrongdoing should be addressed, my primary focus is on moving forward and uniting our country. This includes supporting the dedicated members of our intelligence community who have worked tirelessly to protect America, often facing unfair criticism. I will carefully consider Senator Leahy's proposal, but my overarching goal is to ensure that we are moving forward in a positive and constructive manner.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Do you believe Hillary Clinton will secure the nomination, sir? [SEP] Come again?

sentence: Mr. President, considering North Korea's past denials regarding the abduction issue, what specific leverage do you believe the US has to compel them to address it now? [SEP] We have tremendous leverage, the greatest leverage. We have a strong relationship with the Prime Minister, and we're working together to achieve a common goal. We're going to use all the tools at our disposal to get those folks home. You can count on it.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, considering your comments on a return to decency, do you believe this election marks a genuine turning point away from the intense polarization of the last few years? [SEP] Well, I don't anticipate a change of heart among the super-mega-MAGA Republicans. However, I believe they represent a minority within the Republican Party. The vast majority of Republicans, while we may hold differing views on various issues, are decent and honorable individuals. We have disagreements on matters of policy. But I've worked with many of these individuals in the Senate and the House for an extended period. They are honest and straightforward. Their perspectives may differ from mine, but they are, nonetheless, decent people. Consequently, I believe that the rest of the world, and many of you have reported from other parts of the world, is observing the United States. Perhaps the most effective way to articulate this is to reiterate something I've shared previously. At the first G-7 meeting, representing the seven largest democracies, which I attended shortly after my inauguration in January, I sat down at a roundtable with the six other world leaders from the European Union, Canada, and others, and declared, 'America is back.' One of them turned to me and asked, 'For how long?' It was a profoundly earnest question. And I looked at them. Then another individual, whom I won't name, proceeded to ask, 'What would you say, Joe, if you went to bed tonight in England, only to wake up the next morning to discover that thousands of people had stormed the Parliament of Great Britain, breached the doors, resulting in the deaths of two police officers, injuries to numerous individuals, and an attempt to halt the confirmation of an election?' It's not the same situation, obviously, as we have. And he said, What would you think? And what—I ask the rhetorical question: What would you all think? You'd think England was really in trouble. You'd think democracy was on the edge if that happened in Great Britain. And so that's the way people were looking at us, like, When is this going to stop? Nothing like this has happened since the Civil War. I don't want to exaggerate. But literally, nothing like this has happened since the Civil War. And so what I find is that they want to know: Is the United States stable? Do we know what we're about? Are we the same democracy we've always been? Because, look, the rest of the world looks to us—I don't mean that we're always—like we're always right. But if the United States tomorrow were to, quote, withdraw from the world, a lot of things would change around the world. A whole lot would change. And so they're very concerned that we are still the open democracy we've been and that we have rules and the institutions matter. And that's the context in which I think that they're looking at: Are we back to a place where we are going to accept decisions made by the Court, by the Congress, by the Government, et cetera?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Sir, you head back to the United States with the task of convincing the American people and Congress on two major foreign policy initiatives—the framework for a nuclear deal with Iran and, likely soon, the decision to remove Cuba from a list of state sponsors of terror. Recently, remarks by Supreme Leader Ayatollah Khamenei have raised doubts among some as to whether that deal can occur in Iran. And Senator Schumer, an ally of yours, has—wants Congress to have the right to vote on removal of sanctions. Presidential politics are likely to play a part in this Cuba decision inevitably. So I'm wondering if it would take a lot of political capital just to get one done, let alone two. Have you bitten off more than you can chew? [SEP] No. [] You may be surprised by that response, Jim. Let me take them in turn.First of all, with respect to Cuba, there is majority support of our policy in the United States, and there's overwhelming support for our policy in Cuba. I think people recognize that if you keep on doing something for 50 years and it doesn't work, you should try something new.And so the American people don't need to be persuaded that this is, in fact, the right thing to do. I recognize that there are still concerns and questions that Congress may have; we've got concerns and questions about specific activities that are taking place in Cuba and human rights and reform. And there were two members of the Cuban civil society that were in attendance at the meeting that I had yesterday who expressed much of what they have to go through on a day-to-day basis. They were supportive of our policy of engagement with Cuba.And so I don't think that it's so much we have to persuade anybody. The issue of the state sponsor of terrorism list, as you know, the State Department has provided a recommendation; it's gone through our interagency process. I'll be honest with you, I have been on the road, and I want to make sure that I have a chance to read it, study it, before we announce publicly what the policy outcome is going to be.But in terms of the overall direction of Cuba policy, I think there is a strong majority both in the United States and in Cuba that says our ability to engage, to open up commerce and travel and people-to-people exchanges is ultimately going to be good for the Cuban people.Now, with respect to Iran, I have always been clear: We are not done yet. What we were able to obtain was a political framework between the P-5-plus-1 nations and Iran that provided unprecedented verification of what is taking place in Iran over the next two decades that significantly cuts back on its centrifuges, that cuts off pathways for it to obtain a nuclear weapon, and that calls for, in return, the rolling back of sanctions in a phased way that allows us to snap back if Iran violates the agreement. That's the political framework. That was not just something that the United States and Iran agreed to, but Iran agreed to a political framework with the other P-5-plus-1 nations.Now, what's always been clear is, is that Iran has its own politics around this issue. They have their own hardliners. They have their own countervailing impulses in terms of whether or not to go forward with something, just as we have in our country. And so it's not surprising to me that the Supreme Leader or a whole bunch of other people are going to try to characterize the deal in a way that protects their political position. But I know what was discussed at—in arriving at the political agreement.What I've always said, though, is that there's the possibility of backsliding. There's the possibility that it doesn't get memorialized in a way that satisfies us that we're able to verify that, in fact, Iran is not getting a nuclear weapon and that we are preserving the capacity to snap back sanctions in the event that they are breaking any deal.And that's why the work is going to be so important between now and the end of June to memorialize this so that we can all examine it. And we don't have to speculate on what the meaning of a deal is going to be. Either there's going to be a document that Iran agrees with the world community about and a series of actions that have to be taken, or there's not. Part of the challenge in this whole process has been, opponents of basically any deal with Iran have constantly tried to characterize what the deal is without seeing it.Now, if we are able to obtain a final deal that comports with the political agreement—and I say if because that's not yet final—then I'm absolutely positive that that is the best way to prevent Iran from getting a nuclear weapon. And that's not my opinion; that's the opinion of people like Ernie Moniz, my Secretary of Energy, who is a physicist from MIT and actually knows something about this stuff. That's the opinion of a whole bunch of nuclear experts who examined the deal.I mean, very rarely do you see a consensus—consensus too strong a word—a large majority of people who are experts in the field saying this is actually a realistic, plausible, meaningful approach to cut off the pathways for Iran getting a nuclear weapon and that it is more likely to succeed not only than maintaining current sanctions or additional sanctions, but more likely to succeed than if we took a military approach to solving the problem.Again, that's not uniquely my opinion. That is—talk to the people who are not affiliated with the administration, some of whom were skeptical about our capacity to get a deal done and have now looked at it and said if we're able to actually get what was discussed in the political framework, it's absolutely the right thing to do.Now, there's politics and political pressure inside of the United States. We all know that. The Prime Minister of Israel is deeply opposed to it. I think he's made that very clear. And I have repeatedly asked, what is the alternative that you present that you think makes it less likely for Iran to get a nuclear weapon? And I have yet to obtain a good answer on that.And the narrow question that's going to be presented next week when Congress comes back is, what's Congress's appropriate role in looking at a final deal? And I've talked to not only Bob Corker, but I've talked to Ben Cardin, the ranking member on the Democratic side. And I want to work with them so that Congress can look at this deal when it's done. What I'm concerned about is making sure that we don't prejudge it or those who are opposed to any deal whatsoever try to use a procedural argument essentially to screw up the possibility of a deal.Last comment I'm going to make on this: When I hear some, like Senator McCain recently, suggest that our Secretary of State, John Kerry, who served in the United States Senate, a Vietnam veteran, who's provided exemplary service to this Nation, is somehow less trustworthy in the interpretation of what's in a political agreement than the Supreme Leader of Iran, that's an indication of the degree to which partisanship has crossed all boundaries. And we're seeing this again and again. We saw it with the letter by the 47 Senators who communicated directly—[]—to the Supreme Leader of Iran—the person that they say can't be trusted at all—warning him not to trust the United States Government.We have Mitch McConnell trying to tell the world, oh, don't have confidence in the U.S. Government's abilities to fulfill any climate change pledge that we might make. And now we have a Senator suggesting that our Secretary of State is purposely misinterpreting the deal and giving the Supreme Leader of Iran the benefit of the doubt in the interpretations.That's not how we're supposed to run foreign policy, regardless of who is President or Secretary of State. We can have arguments, and there are legitimate arguments to be had. I understand why people might be mistrustful of Iran. I understand why people might oppose the deal, although the reason is not because this is a bad deal per se, but they just don't trust any deal with Iran and may prefer to take a military approach to it.But when you start getting to the point where you are actively communicating that the United States Government and our Secretary of State is somehow spinning presentations in a negotiation with a foreign power, particularly one that you say is your enemy, that's a problem. It needs to stop.Jim Acosta [CNN]. Oh, I'm sorry, where's Jim?
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, isn't there a risk that your strong rhetoric could actually backfire, making it harder for the protesters to achieve their goals? We're working with our allies to coordinate our response and to send a clear message to the Iranian regime that violence and repression are unacceptable.

We need to await the investigation's results. We plan to continue communicating on this. This will be the last question.

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, the public deserves a concrete timeline. Can you provide any indication, even a rough estimate, of when this review will be completed and the infrastructure projects will commence? [SEP] Look, we're talking about a massive undertaking, the largest infrastructure investment in generations. We need to ensure that every dollar is spent wisely and effectively. Rushing into things would be a disservice to the taxpayers. So, while I understand the desire for immediate action, a measured approach is what's called for.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. And have you asked John Kelly to refute that story? [SEP] No, I don't understand it at all, no, because I've always been on the opposite side of John McCain. John McCain liked wars. I will be a better warrior than anybody, but when we fight a war, we're going to win them. And frankly, I was never a fan of John McCain. You know that; that's been very obvious. I was—but I had to approve his entire—his funeral. I wanted him to get—he deserved a first-class—you know, and it all was approved by me. We sent Air Force One to pick up the casket—a lot of things. But no, I was never a fan of John McCain, because he wanted the endless wars, and I didn't. I thought that the way the vets were taken care of—our great vets—was not good, not appropriate. And of course, he took the fake, dirty dossier and gave it over to the FBI. So this is not somebody—am I supposed to say, What a wonderful guy?So, you know what? I lived with him. He lived with me. But we had different philosophies. I think my philosophy is right. I think it's turned out to be right. But I wasn't a fan. But I respect people, and I respect a lot of people. That doesn't mean I necessarily have to agree with them, and I didn't agree with him on a lot of things.The story is a hoax, written by a guy who has got a tremendously bad history. The magazine itself—which I don't read, but I hear it's just totally anti-Trump; he's a big Obama person, he's a big Clinton person. And he made up the story. It's a totally made-up story.In fact, I was very happy to see Zach Fuentes came out and said now he's—that's—I think that's number 15—and these are people that were there. That's the 15th person. General Kellogg, everybody that was there knew what happened. And so I was happy to see that Zach came out and said it's not true. He just came out.And it's a disgrace. Who would say a thing like that? Only an animal would say a thing like that. There is nobody that has more respect for not only our military, but for people that gave their lives in the military. There's nobody—and I think John Kelly knows that. I think he would know that. I think he knows that from me.But Zach Fuentes, as you know, worked for John. And I think they both know that. But Zach came out, as you know, today or yesterday, last night, and said very strongly that he didn't hear anything like that. Even John Bolton came out and said that was untrue.Now, what was true is that we had the worst weather. I think it was as bad a rain as I've just about ever seen. And it was a fog you—you literally couldn't see. I walked out, and I didn't have—I didn't need somebody to tell me. I walked out and I said, There's no way we can take helicopters in this. I understand helicopters very well. And they said, No, sir, that's been canceled.They would have had to go—Secret Service, I have the whole list—they would have had through a very, very busy section, during the day, of Paris. They would have had to go through the city. The Paris police were asking us, Please don't do it, because they're not ready. When you do that, you need a lot of time. They take days and days and days to prepare for that.I wanted to do it very badly. I was willing to sit in the car for 2 hours, 3 hours, 4 hours. I didn't care. It didn't matter. And I had nothing else to do. I went there for that; I had nothing else to do. It was ended because of the terrible weather, and nobody was prepared to go through, in terms of Paris, the police, the military, and the Secret Service. And they came out very strongly and said, Sir, we can't allow you to make this trip. If I wanted to: Sir, we can't allow you, from a safety standpoint.It was a phony story, just like the dirty dossier—the fake, dirty dossier; just like the Russia collusion; just like all of the other phony stories. And there'll be more phony stories.But I do appreciate Zach coming out. But Zach now is the 15th person that's denied it. Zach now, I think, also talked about the weather aspect of it. And he's probably the 14th or 15th person that blamed it on weather. So that's enough of that.Yes, please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, what is your reaction to President Obama's recent statements concerning unidentified aerial phenomena? [SEP] That's a question for him, not me. Thank you. Next question.

sentence: Q. And I'm just wondering, in your opinion—or of your estimation—what percentage of those people do you believe are deserving of asylum in the U.S.? [SEP] Well, I won't get into percentages. But we are a nation of laws. We have to have borders. We don't have borders, we don't have a country. And I've been watching for weeks as the caravan came up. And you know, the Mexican laws are very tough on immigration, extremely tough. And it started out with way over a thousand people—I guess now it's down to about a hundred—going all through Mexico. People don't realize what a big country Mexico is. But it came down by a lot.And now we're working on the border with the worst laws any country—no matter where you go, all over the world, they can't even believe it. And we're doing the best we can with it. But we have to have changes in Congress, and we have to have it quickly. We need a wall, number one. And you see that right now. You know, where they are—even though it's not a particularly good wall and even though a small percentage can climb to the top, they have to be in extremely good shape. But a small percentage can climb that particular wall. We have a wall that's much more difficult.But if you didn't have that, you would have thousands of people just pouring into our country. You've got to have a wall. And we need border security, and we will have border security. As you know, we're sending many, many National Guardsmen down to the border—most of them are already there—and that's having a big impact. But we need a change in the law. Catch-and-release is ridiculous. If they touch our property, if they touch our country, essentially, you catch them, and you release them into our country. That's not acceptable to anybody. So we need a change in the law.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. At your Burma town hall a couple days ago you tried to inspire young leaders by saying governments need to be held accountable and be responsive to the people. I wonder how you square that with your former adviser, Jonathan Gruber, claiming you were not transparent about the health law? Because in his words, the American people, the voters, are stupid. Did you mislead Americans about the taxes, about keeping your plan, in order to get the bill passed? [SEP] No, I did not. I just heard about this. I get well briefed before I come out here. The fact that some adviser who never worked on our staff expressed an opinion that I completely disagree with in terms of the voters, is no reflection on the actual process that was run.We had a year-long debate, Ed. I mean, go back and look at your stories. The one thing we can't say is that we did not have a lengthy debate about health care in the United States of America or that it was not adequately covered. I mean, I would just advise all of—every press outlet here: Go back and pull up every clip, every story, and I think it will—it's fair to say that there was not a provision in the health care law that was not extensively debated and was fully transparent.Now, there were folks who disagreed with some of these various positions. It was a tough debate. But the good news is—and I know this wasn't part of your question—but since some folks back home who don't have health insurance may be watching, open enrollment just started, which means that those who did not take advantage of the marketplaces the first time around, they've got another chance to sign up for affordable health care; they may be eligible for a tax credit.So far, there were over half a million successful logins on the first day. Healthcare.gov works really well now; 1.2 million people used the window-shopping function since Sunday. There were 23,000 applications completed in just the first 8 hours and tens of thousands more throughout the day.Health care is working. More than 10 million people have already gotten health insurance; millions more are eligible. And contrary to some of the predictions of the naysayers, not only is the program working, but we've actually seen health care inflation lower than it's been in 50 years, which is contributing to us reducing the deficit and has the effect of making premiums for families lower that they otherwise would have been if they have health insurance. All right? Kristen Welker [NBC News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. But do you understand those people? [SEP] Oh, I understand them much better than you do.Okay. Yes. Go ahead. Go ahead. Thank you very much. Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Recession risk? What's your take? [SEP] You know, you need to talk to economists. I think I got a B in Econ 101. I got an A, however, in keeping taxes low—[]—and being fiscally responsible with the people's money. We've submitted a plan that will enable this budget to become balanced by 2012 so long as Congress learns to set priorities. And we can balance the budget without raising taxes.Caren [Caren Bohan, Reuters].

sentence: Mr. President, is there a significant economic disparity between the middle class and the wealthiest Americans? [SEP] The data clearly shows that middle-class incomes haven't kept pace with rising costs for a decade. Meanwhile, the top 1% have amassed wealth at levels unseen since the Roaring Twenties. These are undeniable facts, not political opinions. A strong middle class is the bedrock of the American Dream, and we must focus on creating opportunities for everyone. We celebrate success, like Steve Jobs' innovations, and expect such individuals to prosper in a free market. However, those who are fortunate must contribute to the broader community, ensuring that future generations also have the chance to succeed. This includes investing in quality education, infrastructure, and accessible colleges. This is the conversation we need to have in the coming years. Juan Carlos Lopez [CNN En Espanol].Development, Relief, and Education for Alien Minors (DREAM) Act/Border Security

We have presented a clear and compelling vision for the future, a plan that prioritizes the needs of working families and invests in the long-term prosperity of our nation. The American people understand this. The problem is not a failure to communicate; it's a refusal to listen.

I think they would be great places to invest. I would have no problem with it. Although, I think as President of the United States, they would call it a slight conflict of interest, perhaps. [] You might be hearing from these people.No, I think it would be a great place. I think all three would be a great place to invest. Okay?
