sentence: Q. Do you think you might have emergency powers that you could use after any default situation? [SEP] We have used a lot of our emergency powers. Jack Lew has used extraordinary measures to keep paying our bills over the last several months. But at a certain point, those emergency powers run out, and the clock is ticking. And I do worry that Republicans, but also some Democrats, may think that we've got a bunch of other rabbits in our hat. There comes a point in which, if the Treasury cannot hold auctions to sell Treasury bills, we do not have enough money coming in to pay all our bills on time. It's very straightforward.And I know there's been some discussion, for example, about my powers under the 14th Amendment to go ahead and ignore the debt ceiling law. Setting aside the legal analysis, what matters is, is that if you start having a situation in which there's legal controversy about the U.S. Treasury's authority to issue debt, the damage will have been done even if that were constitutional, because people wouldn't be sure. It would be tied up in litigation for a long time. That's going to make people nervous.So a lot of the strategies that people have talked about—well, the President can roll out a big coin, or he can resort to some other constitutional measure—what people ignore is that, ultimately, what matters is, what do the people who are buying Treasury bills think?And again, I'll just boil it down in very personal terms. If you're buying a house and you're not sure whether the seller has title to the house, you're going to be pretty nervous about buying it. And at minimum, you'd want a much cheaper price to buy that house because you wouldn't be sure whether or not you're going to own it at the end. Most of us would just walk away, because no matter how much we like the house, we'd say to ourselves, the last thing I want is to find out after I've bought it that I don't actually own it.Well, the same thing is true if I'm buying Treasury bills from the U.S. Government. And here I am sitting here, what if there's a Supreme Court case deciding that these aren't valid, that these aren't valid legal instruments obligating the U.S. Government to pay me? I'm going to be stressed, which means I may not purchase them. And if I do purchase them, I'm going to ask for a big premium.So there are no magic bullets here. There's one simple way of doing it, and that is Congress going ahead and voting. And the fact that right now there are votes, I believe, to go ahead and take this drama off the table should at least be tested. Speaker Boehner keeps on saying he doesn't have the votes for it, and what I've said is, put it on the floor, see what happens, and at minimum, let every Member of Congress be on record. Let them vote to keep the Government open or not, and they can determine where they stand and defend that vote to their constituencies. And let them vote on whether or not America should pay its bills or not.And if in fact some of these folks really believe that it's not that big of a deal, they can vote no, and that will be useful information for voters to have. And if it fails, and we do end up defaulting, I think voters should know exactly who voted not to pay our bills so that they can be responsible for the consequences that come with it.Ari Shapiro [National Public Radio].
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. And Brexit—sorry, sir, because you are going to the U.K.—what will be your message on Brexit? [SEP] Well, Brexit is a—you know, I've been reading a lot about Brexit over the last couple of days, and it seems to be turning a little bit differently where they're getting at least partially involved back with the European Union.I have no message. It's not for me to say. I own a lot of property there. I'm going to Scotland while I wait for the meeting. I have Turnberry in Scotland, which is a magical place, one of my favorite places. I'm going there for 2 days while I wait for the Monday meeting.But it's not for me to say what they should be doing in the U.K. I have great friendships. My mother was born in Scotland. I have great friendships over there. We have a wonderful Ambassador, Woody Johnson. And he's doing—by the way, Woody is doing a great job.But it's not for me to say. I'd like to see him be able to work it so it could go quickly, whatever they work out.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Good afternoon. You just mentioned the new leader of France, and I was going to ask you about him. Have you talked to him? Are you recruiting him as part of the coalition? Any messages for him?And you've sent Mr. Cheney to the Mideast to visit with the other neighbors. What specifically are the requests you are making of them? [SEP] Sure. First of all, Presidents don't recruit; the people elect a leader with whom I will work. And I had a— I did talk to President-elect Sarkozy; I think it was at about 8:03 Paris time. He won at 8:00, and I called him shortly thereafter. And I'm so grateful he took my phone call. I had met with him before when he came over here and found him to be a very engaging, energetic, smart, capable person. We will have our differences, and we will have our agreements. And I'm looking forward to working with him.Vice President Cheney is in the Middle East. His first message to the Iraqis was that they have got to speed up their clock, that—I agree with General Petraeus's assessment that there are two clocks: one ticking here in Washington and one ticking there. And they must understand that we are very serious when it comes to them passing law that enables this country to more likely reconcile. And then he'll be traveling to talk to other friends in the area.One of the questions that many ask is, do we understand the Iranian issue well? Do we understand the consequences of Iran having a nuclear weapon—which it looks like they want to try to achieve— to get. And the answer is, absolutely. And they'll find a stalwart friend in dealing with extremism in that vital part of the world. And that—Vice President will lay out our strategy of convincing others to join us in— on this Iranian issue. He will point out to them that we have worked hard to convince not only the EU-3 to join with the United States in sending a clear message but also now Russia and China, and that we do have a diplomatic front. And we've got to work—to continue to work together. We've got to work to keep it together, to send a focused, concerted message.He will also remind people that success in Iraq will be important for dealing with Iran, that if we were to listen to some of the voices in Congress and withdraw before the job was done, it would embolden Iran. In other words, there are strategic consequences to what is being said here in Washington, DC, about the Iraqi issue.And so he's got to—it's a vital trip, and I really appreciate him going. And it looked like he had a good stop yesterday. I haven't talked to him, but it looks like he's—it looks like he had a good day yesterday, and I'm looking forward—he'll check in.Mark [Mark Silva, Chicago Tribune].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, can you give us a timeline for how long Israel will pause its West Bank annexation plans? [SEP] What are *your* thoughts? Tell me. We're focusing all our efforts on peace. I can't give you a specific timeframe. We've prioritized peace over the sovereignty movement, but it's not off the table. It's just been postponed until we've given peace every possible chance.

sentence: Mr. President, QAnon's popularity is on the rise. What's your take on this, and what would you say to those who follow it? [SEP] Well, I must admit, I'm not entirely conversant with the QAnon movement, though I'm aware they hold me in high regard, which I find gratifying. It appears they're gaining momentum. From what I've gleaned, these are individuals deeply concerned about the state of affairs in cities like Portland and Chicago, witnessing the turmoil firsthand. This unease predates my arrival, stretching back almost four years. They're patriots who love our country and are disheartened by what they see. So, while my knowledge is limited, I appreciate their support and their desire to restore order in these Democrat-led cities. If the Democrats can't manage, we're ready to intervene with federal assistance—whether it be troops or law enforcement—to resolve the issues swiftly.

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. Did any good come out of President Carter's talks with Hamas? And did anyone in your administration ask him not to do it? And will it have any impact on your trip to the Middle East? [SEP] I didn't talk to him, and I don't know. I don't know what the conversations were, and I don't see Hamas changing. It's up to Hamas to change. And you get these meetings with these people, and they say one thing and do another. And this is the way it's been now for 71⁄2 years in this administration, watching Hamas be a destabilizing influence.And I supported the elections, by the way. And curiously enough, they won the elections against Fatah because they ran on a noncorruption campaign. The sad situation is, now they've been given power, they haven't delivered for the people in Gaza.And my mission is to—when I go to the Middle East—is to continue to work with both Israelis and the—President Abbas and his Government on a variety of fronts: one, coming up with the vision, helping them find the common ground on the vision; but also working with the Israelis to empower the Palestinians in the West Bank to be more in charge of security, to have less obstacles with which to deal with, to help the Palestinians with economic vitality and growth. There's some very interesting initiatives that are being developed there.I'm still hopeful we'll get an agreement by the end of my Presidency. Condi is heading back out there. I've been in touch with President Abbas here in the Oval Office, and I talk to Prime Minister Olmert, and the attitude is good. People do understand the importance of getting a state defined.But Hamas is—look, when you're Israel and you've got people lobbing rockets into your country, you're going to take care of business. But you got to ask, why is Hamas lobbing rockets? And one reason why is because they're trying to destabilize and create chaos and confusion. And to answer whether or not the people's conversations with them were more effective: That's all we got to do, is watch and see how Hamas behaves.Richard [Richard Wolf, USA Today].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. As you at this summit try to continue the work of stopping Afghanistan from reverting to its former role as a terrorist haven, terrorists today in Yemen massacred a hundred soldiers. Are you concerned that despite U.S. efforts, Yemen seems to be slipping further into anarchy? And what more can the U.S. do to slow that process? [SEP] We are very concerned about Al Qaida activity and extremist activity in . A positive development has been a relatively peaceful political transition in , and we participated diplomatically along with 's neighbors in helping to lead to a political transition, but the work is not yet done.We have established a strong counterterrorism partnership with the i Government, but there's no doubt that in a country that is still poor, that is still unstable, it is attracting a lot of folks that previously might have been in the FATA before we started putting pressure on them there. And we're going to continue to work with the i Government to try to identify AQAP leadership and operations and try to thwart them. That's important for U.S. safety. It's also important for the stability of and for the region.But I think one of the things that we've learned from the Afghanistan experience is for us to stay focused on the counterterrorism issue, to work with the Government, to not overextend ourselves, to operate smartly in dealing with these issues. And it's not unique to , by the way. I mean we've got similar problems in Somalia, what's happening now in Mali and the Sahel. And so this is part of the reason why not only is NATO important, but these partnerships that we're establishing is important, because there are going to be times where these partners have more effective intelligence operations, more diplomatic contacts, et cetera, in some of these parts of the world where the state is a little wobbly and you may see terrorists attempting to infiltrate or set up bases.Yes, I'm going to call on Jake Tapper [ABC News] because, Jake, Jay Carney told me that you've been talking to some of our troops in Afghanistan. And since so much of the topic of this summit has been on Afghanistan, obviously, none of this would be working were it not for the extraordinary sacrifices that they're making, so----
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. In your opinion, would you characterize it as a 'hard' Brexit scenario? [SEP] Or perhaps a 'harrowing' Brexit?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Given the goals of this conference and the goals of your administration on nuclear policy, why does it appear as if Pakistan is playing by a different set of rules? I know they have not signed on to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. But it appears they're expanding their nuclear program, and the proximity to Al Qaida--should there be more pressure internationally on Pakistan, not just coming from the United States, but the world? [SEP] I don't think 's playing by a different set of rules. I think we've been very clear to , as we have been to every country, that we think they should join the NPT. I have actually seen progress over the last several years with respect to 's nuclear security issues.I want to lower tensions throughout South Asia when it comes to nuclear programs. And I think that the fact that President Gilani came here, signed on to a communique, and made a range of commitments that will make it more likely that we don't see proliferation activities or trafficking occurring out of is a positive thing.Do we have a lot of more work to do? Absolutely. But I think that President--or Prime Minister Gilani's presence here was an important step in assuring that we do not see a nuclear crisis anywhere in South Asia. Okay?All right, Jeff Mason [Reuters].
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You promised to send more troops to Afghanistan. And since you've been very clear about a timetable to withdraw all combat troops from Iraq within 16 months, I wonder, what's your timetable to withdraw troops eventually from Afghanistan?And related to that, there's a Pentagon policy that bans media coverage of the flag-draped coffins from coming in to Dover Air Force Base. And back in 2004, then-Senator Joe Biden said that it was shameful for dead soldiers to be, quote, snuck back into the country under the cover of night. You've promised unprecedented transparency, openness in your Government. Will you overturn that policy so the American people can see the full human cost of war? [SEP] Your question is timely. We got reports that four American servicemembers have been killed in Iraq today, and obviously, our thoughts and prayers go out to the families. I've said before that--you know, people have asked me, When did it hit you that you are now President? And what I told them was the most sobering moment is signing letters to the families of our fallen heroes. It reminds you of the responsibilities that you carry in this office and the consequences of decisions that you make.Now, with respect to the policy of opening up media to loved ones being brought back home, we are in the process of reviewing those policies in conversations with the Department of Defense, so I don't want to give you an answer now before I've evaluated that review and understand all the implications involved.With respect to Afghanistan, this is going to be a big challenge. I think because of the extraordinary work done by our troops, and some very good diplomatic work done by Ambassador Crocker in Iraq, we just saw an election in Iraq that went relatively peacefully. And you get a sense that the political system is now functioning in a meaningful way.You do not see that yet in Afghanistan. They've got elections coming up, but effectively the national Government seems very detached from what's going on in the surrounding community.In addition, you've got the Taliban and Al Qaida operating in the FATA and these border regions between Afghanistan and Pakistan, and what we haven't seen is the kind of concerted effort to root out those safe havens that would ultimately make our mission successful.So we are undergoing a thorough-going review. Not only is General Petraeus now the head of CENTCOM conducting his own review, he's now working in concert with the special envoy that I've sent over, Richard Holbrooke, one of our top diplomats, to evaluate a regional approach. We are going to need more effective coordination of our military efforts with diplomatic efforts, with development efforts, with more effective coordination, with our allies in order for us to be successful.The bottom line, though--and I just want to remember the American people, because this is going to be difficult--is this is a situation in which a region served as the base to launch an attack that killed 3,000 Americans. And this past week, I met with families of those who were lost in 9/11, a reminder of the costs of allowing those safe havens to exist. My bottom line is that we cannot allow Al Qaida to operate. We cannot have those safe havens in that region. And we're going to have to work both smartly and effectively, but with consistency, in order to make sure that those safe havens don't exist. I do not have yet a timetable for how long that's going to take. What I know is, I'm not going to make--I'm not going to allow Al Qaida or bin Laden to operate with impunity, planning attacks on the U.S. homeland.All right. Helene Cooper [New York Times]. Where's Helene? There you are.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Bush, critics argue your dialogue with China on human rights is insufficient. Beyond expressing your views, what tangible actions will you take to address their human rights abuses? And President Lee, considering North Korea's history, what assurances can you provide that this round of six-party talks will yield different results? [SEP] For years, I've consistently conveyed to Chinese leaders the importance of religious freedom and freedom of expression. These are the bedrock of a prosperous society. I've reiterated this point in every discussion. My attendance at the Olympics serves two purposes: to show respect for the Chinese people and to cheer on our athletes. I hope our team achieves great success, but it's also an opportunity to emphasize our values. I don't require the Olympics to voice my concerns about religious freedom, as I've been doing it since day one. As for the six-party talks, skepticism is understandable given North Korea's track record. However, I commend President Bush's leadership in navigating this complex situation. Denuclearization is our top priority. We will remain patient, consistent, and dedicated to verification. We must all collaborate to ensure North Korea fulfills its commitments. Regardless of their intentions, the other members of the six-party talks must remain committed to our objective. We may encounter obstacles, but our resolve will not waver.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the agreement, with your departure imminent, who possesses the authority to finalize and sign it on behalf of the United States? The core elements of the agreement have been meticulously crafted, ensuring continuity and a seamless transition.

sentence: Mr. President, can you confirm reports that Chen Guangcheng is under U.S. protection? We've made it clear that provocations will lead to isolation and sanctions. We're unified in insisting that North Korea abide by international norms.

sentence: Q. Sir, are you implying that my question was 'nasty' and that's why you responded in that manner? [SEP] I'm not implying anything. I'm stating a fact. If you ask a question that is framed in a negative way, you're going to get a response. It's very simple.

sentence: Mr. President, what's your level of confidence that countries will agree on sanctions within the deadline you've set? And on Pakistan, is the U.S. certain their nuclear materials are safe from groups like Al Qaeda? [SEP] On Pakistan, let me just say that, following up on what was already asked, we are confident in the security measures surrounding their nuclear programs. But let's be clear, there's always room for improvement, everywhere. We had that little issue ourselves, remember? With the missiles on the bomber? Gates handled that right. Everyone needs to up their game on this. That's what this summit's about. As for sanctions, we've got a lot of support on the Security Council. But these things are never easy. I'm going to push hard to get strong sanctions that will make Iran think twice about its nuclear program. I'm not going to get into specifics beyond that.
label: General

sentence: Q. And polls also show that you're taking some hits with the public on both your overall job approval rating and also on factors like trust and honesty. Do you feel as though the flawed health care rollout has led to a breach in the public trust and confidence in Government? And if so, how do you plan to resolve that? [SEP] There is no doubt that people are frustrated. We just came out of a shutdown and the possibility that for the first time in over 200 years, we wouldn't pay our bills. And people breathed a sigh of relief when that finally got done, and the next thing they know is, is that the President's health care reform can't get the web site to work and that there are these other problems with respect to cancellation notices.And I understand why folks are frustrated. I would be too. Because sometimes, people look at what's taking place in Washington, and they say, not enough is getting done that helps me with my life. And regardless of what Congress does, ultimately, I'm the President of the United States, and they expect me to do something about it.So in terms of how I intend to approach it, I'm just going to keep on working as hard as I can around the priorities that the American people care about. And I think it's legitimate for them to expect me to have to win back some credibility on this health care law in particular, and on a whole range of these issues in general.And that's on me. I mean, we fumbled the rollout on this health care law. There are a whole bunch of things about it that are working really well, which people didn't notice, right, because they weren't controversial: so making sure kids could stay on their parents' plans until they were—through the age of 25, and making sure that seniors got more discounts on their prescription drugs. There were a whole bunch of stuff that we did well over the first 3 years.But we always knew that these marketplaces—creating a place where people can shop and through competition get a better deal for the health insurance that their families need—we always knew that that was going to be complicated and everybody was going to be paying a lot of attention to it. And we should have done a better job getting that right on day 1, not on day 28 or on day 40.I am confident that by the time we look back on this next year, that people are going to say this is working well, and it's helping a lot of people. But my intention in terms of winning back the confidence of the American people is just to work as hard as I can, identify the problems that we've got, make sure that we're fixing them. Whether it's a web site, whether it is making sure that folks who got these cancellation notices get help, we're just going to keep on chipping away at this until the job is done.Major Garrett [CBS News].
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Will you let us know the results? [SEP] We're working on that. We're working out a schedule.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, reports suggest that vulnerable Democrats have urged you to postpone immigration reform until after the midterms. How have these requests impacted your decision-making, and do you foresee any negative consequences from delaying action? [SEP] My primary focus this week has been on critical international challenges, including the crisis in Ukraine, the fight against ISIS, and bolstering NATO's capabilities. Concerning immigration, I've received preliminary proposals from Johnson and Holder, which I'm currently evaluating. While I strongly advocate for Congressional action on comprehensive immigration reform, I'm prepared to take executive measures to strengthen border security, improve processing procedures, and create pathways to legal status. An announcement regarding my course of action will be made in the near future.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Can I just clarify? [SEP] Sure.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, should Zelenskyy cede Ukrainian territory for a cease-fire with Russia? And should Russia be removed from the G-20? [SEP] On the G-20, I think so. Now, remind me of the other question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Regarding these one-on-one talks, could you outline the circumstances that would necessitate them? [SEP] I'm afraid I can't delve into the specifics of the negotiations. However, I can assure you that our focus is on reaching a resolution, and we won't be hindered by mere diplomatic protocols. If Iran is serious about a resolution, they will demonstrate it.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the breadth of your inquiry regarding Canada, could you perhaps prioritize the specific issues you'd like to discuss? [SEP] Okay, okay, pump the brakes! That's a whole series of questions. [] Which part are you most interested in hearing about? []
label: Clarification

sentence: Are you implying that the climate situation isn't as urgent as some claim? [SEP] I'm more interested in hearing President Putin's perspective after his meeting. My main concern is whether he continues to share my worries about nuclear weapons. In Australia, he confirmed that he understands the global danger of nuclear proliferation. They've been helpful at the UN, and we're collaborating on a potential third resolution. So, my focus is on nuclear security. The optics of the meeting are less important. I'll keep working with Russia and other countries to send a strong message: pursue nuclear weapons and face isolation.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Do you have to support the war to support the warrior? I mean, if you're one of those Americans that thinks you've made a terrible mistake, that it's destined to end badly, what do you do? If they speak out, are they by definition undermining the troops? [SEP] No, she actually asked the enemy, not the troops. But I'll be glad to answer your question. No, I don't think so at all. I think you can be against my decision and support the troops; absolutely. But the proof will be whether or not you provide them the money necessary to do the mission.I said early in my comment—my answer to Sheryl was that somebody who doesn't agree with my policy is just as patriotic a person as I am. And your question is valid. I mean, can somebody say, We disagree with your tactics or strategy, but we support the military—absolutely, Ron, sure. But what's going to be interesting is if they don't provide the flexibility and support for our troops that are there to enforce the strategy that David Petraeus, the general on the ground, thinks is necessary to accomplish the mission.Michael [Michael Allen, Politico]. Michael, who do you work for? []
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, are you saying that you believe lawsuits are the appropriate response to opinions that differ from yours? [SEP] It's not about different opinions. It's about deliberately false statements. When someone gets the facts completely wrong, and those falsehoods have real-world consequences, then we'll see what happens in the courts. It's about responsibility for what you say and do.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. You knew it was airborne. You knew—on February 7, you told Bob Woodward how it transferred from person to person in the air, how deadly it was. Why did you not come to the podium and calmly tell the people what to expect? [SEP] Well, let me ask you this: If Bob Woodward thought that was bad—because this is stuff that everyone knew. There's a report that I have here someplace where China said it was airborne earlier than the statements I made. People knew it was airborne. This was nothing—this was no big—when I say it was airborne, everybody knew it was airborne. This was no big thing.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, your newly installed Personnel Director has begun talking with agencies about finding people in the Government that are not loyal to you and perhaps moving them on. How large a list do you imagined this will be? Is this a big problem in your mind? What—how do you—could you describe for us the scale of the problem as you see it? [SEP] Yes. Yes, I don't think it's a big problem. I don't think it's very many people. I think we had a whistleblower who was a fake. Because if you look at the whistleblower, as an example—if you look at his report, and then you compare that to the transcripts, it bore no relationship. So that was a very sad situation and a lot of time—a lot of time wasted.Although, as you will admit—in fact, you wrote very nicely, and I appreciate it—the poll numbers have gone up very much. But that's not appropriate to have—to benefit by something like that.Then, there was supposed to be a second whistleblower. As soon as I released the transcripts, the second whistleblower was gone. Nobody ever—what happened to the second whistleblower? I'll ask you, where is he? Remember the second was—he or she—the second whistleblower was going to happen. It was just a matter of moments. And then I released the real call—the transcripts, which are now 100-percent accurate, even according to Lieutenant Colonel Vindman.So no, we want to have people that are good for the country, are loyal to our country, because that was a disgraceful situation.Please. Go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Sir, can you tell us if the person involved was carrying a weapon? [SEP] That's what I understand, but I can't confirm it definitively. You need to ask the authorities handling the situation.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the newly enacted energy legislation, co-authored with Speaker Pelosi and Senator Reid, aimed at curbing greenhouse gases, your administration has simultaneously blocked California from implementing stricter emission controls. Could you elaborate on the significance you attribute to fighting greenhouse gases, the rationale behind preventing states from exceeding national regulations, and whether you've recently conferred with Vice President Gore on climate change? [SEP] The core question here is about *efficacy*. We all agree on the *what* – reducing emissions. The debate is on the *how*. Is it more effective to have 50 different approaches, or a coordinated national strategy? Director Johnson's decision was rooted in the fact that this new law gives us a national strategy. We're talking about raising CAFE standards to 35 miles per gallon by 2020, and a major increase in alternative fuels. That's a unified plan. As for Vice President Gore, yes, we spoke, and I assured him I'm taking this seriously. We're building a strategy, and this bill is part of it. Replacing gasoline with alternatives is a big step. The bill I signed wasn't as strong as I wanted, but it's a start. We need to invest in cellulosic ethanol, not just corn. That's a real national plan. But let's be clear: this is a global issue. That's why I opposed Kyoto – China wasn't included. We need major emitters on board. We're working on that, as I explained at the G-8 and in Bali. I take this very seriously, but we can't destroy our economy in the process. We need to be prosperous to invest in new technologies. And if you're serious about greenhouse gases, you should be a strong supporter of nuclear power. It's the best way to generate electricity without emissions. So, we have a strategy: higher CAFE standards, alternative fuels, nuclear power. And we have 250 years of coal, so we need to find ways to use it cleanly. Our strategy is to bring others to the table, develop a national plan, and meet international goals. That's what we're doing.
label: General

sentence: President Bush, with respect, your response lacks concrete details. Can you outline the specific benchmarks the U.S. will use to assess the success of its African initiatives, and what contingency plans are in place should these programs fail to meet expectations? Moreover, what measurable impact do you hope to achieve during this tour, and how will you ensure these gains are not reversed after you leave office? [SEP] We care about Africa, and I came here early in my term to show that. We want to help with diseases, trade, and education. Being in Ghana proves that. African leaders are doing a great job. We've helped with conflicts, like in Liberia, and supported democracy. Our aid now expects things like fighting corruption. The leaders I've met are good people. This trip is important, and I appreciate Ghana's hospitality. John McKinnon from the Wall Street Journal is here, a very smart paper.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, I have a question about Russia, but first, could you clarify something quickly? Will Meng Wanzhou's case also be delayed indefinitely, or is there a chance the U.S. might drop the extradition request? [SEP] Regarding what? About what?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your refusal to discuss the details of your conversation with President Sarkozy is a sign of a lack of transparency. How do you respond to that? [SEP] Diplomacy requires discretion. I'm not going to jeopardize our relationships with key allies by airing private conversations in public. My commitment to transparency is unwavering, but it must be balanced with the need to protect national interests.
label: Declining to answer

sentence:
Two weeks ago, your Acting OMB Director projected 3 percent GDP growth for the coming year. Given the impact of the coronavirus on supply chains and financial markets, are you still confident in achieving that level of economic growth? [SEP] We're going to have incredibly low unemployment, setting records. This administration has the lowest average unemployment in history – 3.5, 3.6. However, it's hard to predict the impact on GDP.

It could be affected, but that's secondary to ensuring safety. Safety is our top priority.

This will have an impact on GDP. Boeing's situation has had a significant impact, maybe half a point to a point. The General Motors strike also affected GDP.

We're also paying interest rates, which I disagree with the Fed about. President Obama paid zero. We're paying interest, which is more conservative and benefits savers.

We should be paying the lowest interest rates, like Germany and other countries with negative rates. The Fed has made a terrible mistake, impacting our growth. We've had record increases, but we've been hurt by General Motors, Boeing, and the Federal Reserve, which has created a strong dollar.

We'll be watching closely. We're doing well despite the 2,000-point drop in the market.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, Mr. Ledgett's suggestion of amnesty for Edward Snowden has sparked considerable debate. Could you elaborate on your administration's stance, acknowledging the potential value of Snowden's disclosures while addressing the legal ramifications of his actions? Specifically, what benchmarks would need to be met for your administration to consider a plea agreement or amnesty, and how do you reconcile this with the message it sends regarding the handling of classified information? [SEP] Well, let me be clear: Mr. Snowden is facing serious charges, and I can't comment directly on his case while it's before the courts. That's the job of the Attorney General. However, I will say that the debate around surveillance is crucial. We must balance national security with civil liberties. While I believe his methods caused significant damage to our intelligence capabilities and diplomatic efforts, the conversation he started was necessary. We need to remember that the United States operates under the rule of law, unlike some nations who exploit these disclosures to deflect from their own abuses. Ultimately, it's up to the courts to decide the specifics of Mr. Snowden's case.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: On Benghazi, some State Department personnel claim they were prevented from testifying about the attack. Will you ensure they have the opportunity to share their accounts publicly and transparently? [SEP] I'm not aware of anyone being blocked. But what I can tell you is we want the truth. We want to know exactly what happened. We want to make sure our embassies are safe. And we want to bring the perpetrators to justice. I'll look into it.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Concerning the payment, could you elaborate on its nature? [SEP] I'm not sure what payment you're talking about. Can you be more specific?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Sir, you've called Iran part of the axis of evil and Syria a state sponsor of terrorism. You said earlier today that your administration will consider any proposal that will help us achieve victory. So, I'm wondering, if it's determined that Iran and Syria could help you achieve victory in Iraq, would you be willing to work with them? [SEP] understand full well that the world expects them to help Iraq. We've made that very clear to them.Let me talk about the Iranian issue. We've got a lot of issues with Iran. First is whether or not they will help this young democracy succeed. The second issue, of course, is whether or not they will help the Lebanese democracy succeed—the Siniora Government, which is—a priority of this Government is to help that Siniora Government. The big issue right now is whether or not Iran will end up with a nuclear weapon. And so our issues with Iran are many. And our position is very clear to the Iranians: There is a better way forward for the Government and the people than to be isolated.And we will continue to work to make it clear to the Iranian Government that all three accounts and the sponsor of terrorists will cause more isolation. We've got a very active diplomatic effort taking place. The Iranians know our position on Iraq, and they know it clearly. More importantly, they know the Iraqis' position relative to Iran. We're helping a sovereign government succeed. And the Iraqis have sent messages to the Iranians: To help us succeed, don't interfere in the internal affairs.As to Syria, our message to Syria is consistent: Do not undermine the Siniora Government in Lebanon; help us get back the—help Israel get back the prisoner that was captured by Hamas; don't allow Hamas and Hizballah to plot attacks against democracies in the Middle East; help inside of Iraq. They know our position as well, Jessica.
label: General

sentence: Sir, given the financial burden and the perceived unfairness to the American people, why not just terminate the arrangement? [SEP] Microphone to him, please. I've answered this already.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Hong Kong business advisory and the Build Back Better agenda, can you provide some clarity? [SEP] That's all? I thought we agreed on two questions. Anyway, about the business advisory: the situation in Hong Kong is worsening. The Chinese government isn't honoring its commitments. It's a warning about what might happen there. Simple as that, complicated as that. Am I confident about Build Back Better? Supremely confident that everything will work out perfectly. The press has declared it dead ten times already. I don't think it's dead. I'm confident we'll get what I proposed and agreed to in the bipartisan infrastructure deal. I trust the Republican Senators who made commitments. They're honorable people, and I expect them to keep their word. As for the reconciliation process, that's how we get every Democrat to agree on matters like what I announced today. If you have children and earn less than $150,000, you'll get a significant tax cut. If you have a child under 7, you'll get a monthly payment like a Social Security check. It's expected to reduce child poverty by over 40 percent. We have ways to pay for both the infrastructure package and the human infrastructure package. There might be some last-minute discussions about the funding mechanisms, but I believe we'll get it done. We discussed China and agreed that they are a competitor in many areas. Trade with China needs to be fair, with a level playing field and the same rules and standards for everyone. We need to be technological leaders. We'll cooperate on technologies like CHIPS. We need to exchange ideas on norms and standards for the internet. We should coordinate our efforts with China. We have shared values that should guide our relationship. On the pandemic, we can only overcome it if everyone is vaccinated. We're trying to boost production and get as many people vaccinated as possible. We're investing in COVAX and encouraging companies to increase vaccine production. We're helping Africans develop their own production sites. There's an imbalance, but we're working to overcome it.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: So, what's the timeline, Mr. President? When can we expect to see these 'openings' you mentioned? [SEP] We're talking months, not weeks. Diplomacy takes time. It's like planting a seed – you don't expect a tree overnight. We need to be patient, strategic, and ensure we're not sacrificing our core principles in the process. We're laying the groundwork for a new relationship, but it requires both sides to be committed to genuine progress.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. ——Mr. President. What has President Zelenskyy told you about the big counteroffensive? And maybe you can start by telling us whether it's actually underway or not.And also, I'd like to ask you about the F-16s. You've greenlit them now. Jake Sullivan said arms and equipment go to Ukraine according to what he called the exigencies of the conflict. So what exigency now exists that didn't exist that demands these planes? [SEP] Well, I'll tell you exactly when they're going to move, exactly where they're going to go. He told me—[]—come on. God love you. I'm going to—even if I knew precisely, you think I'm going to tell you what they're going to do in terms of their offensive?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you mentioned entitlements, and one of the big, hot-button issues for the Democratic Party is Social Security and the idea of partial privatization, which you have talked about. And I wonder if there's anything in your agenda in that way that you're willing to adjust, in the spirit of bipartisanship, or back off from, given how important that is to the core of the Democratic Party? [SEP] I told—Ken, I told Hank Paulson to tell the Members that we'd sit down and we'd listen to everybody's ideas. I put out my ideas, as you recall, I think in the State of the Union last time. And we want to hear their ideas. And hopefully, out of this concept of folks sitting around a table sharing ways forward, that we will come up with commonality, that we are able to then say to the American people, We've helped solve this problem.But this is a tough issue. Look, I fully understand how hard it is. Social Security is—people are generally risk-adverse when it comes time to Social Security. My problem with that is, is that the longer you wait, the more difficult the issue is going to become. And some will keep pushing it, and hopefully, we can get something done.Richard [Richard Wolffe, Newsweek].
label: General

sentence: Sir, isn't the reality that Assad has repeatedly defied international norms and used chemical weapons with impunity? Without a real threat of military action, what's to stop him from doing it again? [SEP] The point is, we're not ruling anything out. We're considering all options. We're talking to our allies. We're listening to Congress. We're making sure we have all the facts. This is a very serious situation, and we're taking it very seriously. I'm always open to suggestions. Let's take another question from the press.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the urgency, can you at least share your general thoughts on the qualities you seek in a Fed Chair, even if you can't name names? [SEP] The process is underway, and announcements will be made in due course. We have ample time to ensure qualified nominees are confirmed before their predecessors' terms expire. I've consulted extensively with my economic advisors, and we have a strong pool of candidates. However, I won't engage in speculation at this time.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Duda, after your meeting today at the White House, do you feel that the prospect of a permanent American military presence in Poland is closer to becoming a reality? [SEP] Look, today the President and I had a one-on-one, and then we met with our staffs. We had long talks, very honest, and pretty strong at times, about what's going on with military and energy security. I'm sure we're all going to learn from these talks. Like I said, we both laid out our positions on a lot of stuff. We see eye-to-eye on what's happening now and what we need to do to protect our security and interests, including business stuff. I think you're going to see the results of our meetings and the paper we signed. Of course, this is a long game, so you'll see how it plays out. You'll see real things happening, in deals and in what we buy. Next question.
label: General

sentence: President Calderon, the statements likening Lopez Obrador to figures like Hitler are causing quite a stir. How do you view this in relation to Mexican unity and the energy bill debate? [SEP] Those kinds of accusations say more about the people making them than anything else. The Congress is doing its job, and most parties are acting responsibly. I find these actions regrettable, as they damage the reputation of those involved. I hope we can focus on constructive dialogue. The authorities are looking into those TV ads, and I'm confident they will make the right call.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Following the NSA surveillance revelations, can you specify instances where the bulk metadata collection program definitively prevented imminent terrorist attacks, and do you still maintain that its advantages outweigh the associated privacy implications? [SEP] Let me start with the bigger picture. The independent panel I assembled provided 46 recommendations. I met with them extensively to review them. They did an excellent job. I charged them with examining all our operations and determining if they adequately address our security needs and prevent terrorist attacks, proliferation, and other threats. And are we also ensuring we uphold the rule of law and respect privacy? We're currently assessing all the recommendations. In January, I'll make a comprehensive statement outlining which recommendations are sensible, which require further refinement, and how they relate to our internal and international collaborations. I'm treating this with utmost seriousness because this is a necessary debate. The 215 program, involving the bulk collection of phone data, has garnered significant attention. The NSA believed it was crucial to track calls from known foreign terrorists to the U.S. to investigate threats. There have been no allegations of misuse of this data. However, public concern exists regarding potential abuse. We must determine if we can achieve the same objectives while enhancing public trust. I'm confident the NSA isn't snooping, but we may need adjustments to boost public confidence. We must also reassure the international community. We have extensive laws to prevent the NSA from spying on Americans, but fewer international constraints. In a virtual world, borders are blurred, and just because we can do something doesn't mean we should. Our values must extend beyond our borders.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. ——are you satisfied with your team here at the White House, sir? [SEP] I'm satisfied with the team.There's three things I'm going to do differently now that I will—now that I've gotten the critical crises out of the way, in the sense of that moving—knowing exactly where we're going.Number one, I'm going to get out of this place more often. I'm going to go out and talk to the public. I'm going to do public fora. I'm going to interface with them. I'm going to make the case of what we've already done, why it's important, and what we'll do if—what will happen if they support what else I want to do.Number two, I'm bringing in more and more—now that I have time—I mean, literally, like you, it's—I'm not complaining. It's, you know, 12, 14 hours a day. No complaints. I really mean that sincerely.But now that certain of the big chunks have been put in place and we know the direction, I'm also going to be out there seeking the—more advice of experts outside, from academia, to editorial writers, to think tanks. And I'm bringing them in, just like I did early on, bringing in Presidential historians to get their perspective on what we should be doing. Seeking more input, more information, more constructive criticism about what I should and shouldn't be doing.And the third thing I'm going to be doing a lot more of is being in a situation where I am able to bring—I'm going to be deeply involved in the off—these off-year elections. We're going to be raising a lot of money. We're going to be out there making sure that we're helping all of those candidates.And scores of them have already asked me to come in and campaign with them, to go out and make the case in plain, simple language as to what it is we've done, what we want to do, and why we think it's important.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Speaker Boehner's ability to deliver votes, do you have unwavering faith in his capacity to secure agreement within his caucus, especially given the internal divisions? [SEP] That's really a question best posed to the Speaker himself. I can only speak to my own experiences, which have been positive. He's a good man, trying to do what's right for the country, even if his party is a bit of a mess.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding China's slowing economy, could this potentially destabilize the global financial system or encourage more aggressive actions, particularly towards Taiwan? Also, your thoughts on the recent meeting between President Putin and Kim Jong Un and its potential implications for the conflict in Ukraine? [SEP] Look, China's facing some tough economic times due to a variety of factors, including global economic trends and their own policy decisions. I don't think it's going to lead to an invasion of Taiwan. In fact, it might even reduce their ability to do so. But let me be clear, we're not trying to hurt China. We all benefit when China prospers and plays by the rules. They've been having some real problems, especially in their real estate market, and they're trying to figure out how to address them. I'm not going to predict what they'll do, but we're not looking to decouple. We won't sell them materials that would enhance their ability to build more nuclear weapons or engage in aggressive military activities. But we're not trying to harm China. Who's next?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, in these debt talks, would you entertain tax incentives to boost the economy, even if it means a larger deficit? And on same-sex marriage, given the trend in states like New York, is it now your personal position to support it, irrespective of state laws? [SEP] I'm not going to break any news on that subject today. Better luck next time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. ——becoming NATOization of Finland. Based on your long experience, how does that change Finland's place in the world? [SEP] Well, first of all, the context in which I said that was: The gentleman who occupies a seat on the other side of the—your border, in Moscow, said he wanted—I said he wanted the Findalization [Finlandization; White House correction] of NATO. I said it was more likely he's going to get the NATOization of Finland. [] That's what—that's the context in which that was said.And what was the second part of your question?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. The question was whether you believe the U.S. was justified in dropping the atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, correct? [SEP] No, wasn't there a series of questions? You mentioned something about ?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Chen Guangcheng, is he under U.S. protection in Beijing? What's the plan? Asylum possible? Prime Minister Noda, North Korea nuclear test likely? Japan's response? What do you want the U.S. to do? [SEP] I'm not going to comment on the specifics of Chen's situation. We always discuss human rights with . We believe it's right and strengthens . On North Korea, our alliance is crucial. Provocations lead to isolation. They must follow international rules. Prime Minister?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Just to follow up. The unemployment rate was just north of 8 percent when the last Recovery Act was put in place. It's now 9.8 percent. Are you prepared to say today that the unemployment rate is going to go down as a result of this package? [SEP] My expectation is that the unemployment rate is going to be going down because the economy is growing. And even though it's growing more slowly that I'd like, it's still growing.Now, how fast it's going to go down, how quickly the economy is going to grow, when are private sector businesses going to start making the investments in plant and equipment and actually start hiring people again? There are a lot of economists out there who have been struggling with that question.So I'm not going to make a prediction. What I can say with confidence is that this package will help strengthen the economy--will help strengthen the recovery. That I'm confident about.Chuck Todd [NBC News].
label: General

sentence: Sir, how would you characterize the current state of affairs in Iraq, and what differentiates it from a civil war? Are you worried that designating it as a civil war would weaken the justification for our presence there as the primary battleground in the war on terror? [SEP] Zarqawi's explicit aim was to provoke sectarian conflict, as demonstrated by the Samarra bombing and subsequent incidents. This phase has been ongoing for a considerable period. Our primary goal is to collaborate with the Iraqi people to create an environment where a peaceful future is attainable for the majority. I intend to address this matter with Prime Minister Maliki in Jordan, concentrating on strategies to mitigate sectarian violence and ensure Iraq's self-governance and sustainability. We remain committed to pursuing Al Qaeda to prevent them from establishing a secure base of operations.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the recent policy shift, could you elaborate on the specific data and analysis that informed this decision, particularly regarding its potential impact on vulnerable populations? [SEP] We're always looking at data. It's a constant process. But the most important thing is that we're putting America first, and that's what this decision is all about.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: With China, Russia, and South Korea seemingly weakening sanctions against North Korea, what strategies do you have to uphold the sanctions regime and maintain influence over these nations? [SEP] Look, we have plenty of leverage. Tremendous leverage, in fact. Despite my good relationship with President Xi – a man I respect and like – we're having tough talks on trade, which likely affects China. But I have to do what's necessary. The border is more open now than when we started, but that's the reality. We have a massive trade deficit with China, and we must address it. This impacts my relationship in terms of the border. I don't believe it affects my personal feelings toward President Xi. We weren't initially ready to take this route, but as we prepared, it impacted the border, which is unfortunate. But I have no choice. For our country, I must act. South Korea will do whatever it takes to secure a deal. If that means no trade, then we won't trade. They won't trade either. They might pursue some work with our concurrence, as we're very far down the line on a document developed over months. The rhetoric and sanctions were both crucial. I'm unsure which was more important. They were both important.
label: General

sentence: So, the decision will be finalized tomorrow? [SEP] I'm going to watch. I want to see what happens. I have meetings with many countries tomorrow, but I'll find a way to watch. I'll also rely on some very fair and talented Republican Senators who—look, if we brought George Washington here, the Democrats would vote against him, just so you understand. He might have had a bad past, who knows? Accusations, maybe? Schumer and the con artists would vote against George Washington 100 percent. So, it doesn't matter what the FBI finds. Even if they found him perfect, he'd lose every vote. If the Republicans win tomorrow, some Democrats might vote yes. You know why? Politics. Okay, let's move on.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, many believe commuting Chelsea Manning's sentence undermines the gravity of leaking classified information, particularly concerning WikiLeaks' involvement in the 2016 election. Furthermore, Julian Assange has offered to come to the US. Will you pursue his extradition, and what charges would he face? [SEP] Let's be clear, Ms. Brennan, Ms. Manning served a significant prison term. Anyone contemplating leaking classified data should be under no illusion that it goes unpunished. My decision was based on the fact that she went to trial, accepted responsibility, and received a sentence disproportionate to others. I believe justice has been served. As for WikiLeaks, the intelligence community's findings on Russian hacking and WikiLeaks' role were inconclusive. I don't follow Mr. Assange's social media. Refer to the Justice Department regarding any investigations. Generally, we must balance accountability and transparency in this cyber age, while protecting ourselves from those who exploit our openness. My decision regarding Chelsea Manning was based on the specifics of her case, as with all commutations and pardons.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. The Prime Minister was pretty clear today at his own press conference that he considers this to be a temporary suspension and that the deal would still be open to him at some point in the future. I'm asking what you think he should do. Should he actually write it off? [SEP] No, right now all I can say: It's off the table. So I can't talk about some time into the future; that's a big statement. But right now it's off the table. Is that a correct statement, Mr. Ambassador? Yes. The word suspend was chosen carefully by all the parties. Suspend, by definition—look it up—that means temporary halt. It's off the table now, but it's not off the table permanently. . Go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, intelligence suggests a potential Russian incursion into Ukraine. Has your administration determined whether Putin plans to invade? [SEP] Putin's a complex character. He's making calculations, I'm sure. We're prepared for various scenarios, but predicting his next move is, frankly, impossible.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Considering the historical election of these two Muslim women, one of whom wears a hijab, to Congress, does this not undermine the message you've been promoting? [SEP] I'm not quite grasping the point you're trying to make. Can you rephrase that for me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Good afternoon, my name is Alexei Meshkov, Interfax information agency. I have a question to President Trump. During your recent European tour, you've mentioned that the implementation of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline makes Europe the hostage of Russia. And you suggested that you could free Europe from this by supplying American LNG. But this cold winter actually showed that the current model—current mechanism of the supply of fuel to Europe is quite viable. At the same time, as far as I know, U.S. had to buy even Russian gas for Boston.I have a question. The implementation of your idea has a political tinge to it, or is this a practical one? Because there will be a gap formed in the supply and demand mechanism, and first it's the consuming countries who will fall into this gap.And the second question: Before the meeting with President Putin, you called him an adversary, a rival, and yet you expressed hope that you will be able to bring this relationship to a new level. Did you manage to do this? [SEP] Actually, I called him a competitor And a good competitor he is And I think the word competitor is a—it's a compliment I think that we will be competing, when you talk about the pipeline I'm not sure necessarily that it's in the best interest of Germany or not, but that was a decision that they made We'll be competing—as you know, the United States is now, or soon will be—but I think it actually is right now—the largest in the oil and gas worldSo we're going to be selling LNG, and we'll have to be competing with the pipeline And I think we'll compete successfully, although there is a little advantage locationally So I just wish them luck I mean, I did I discussed with Angela Merkel in pretty strong tones But I also know where they're all coming from And they have a very close source So we'll see how that all works outBut we have lots of sources now, and the United States is much different than it was a number of years ago when we weren't able to extract what we can extract today So today we're number one in the world at that And I think we'll be out there competing very stronglyThank you very much If I may, I'd throw in some two cents We talked to Mr President, including this subject as well We are aware of the stance of And I think that we, as a major oil and gas power—and the United States, as a major oil and gas power as well—we could work together on regulation of international markets, because neither of us is actually interested in the plummeting of the pricesAnd the consumers will suffer as well, and the consumers in the United States will suffer as well, and the shale gas production will suffer Because beyond a certain price bracket, it's no longer profitable to produce gas, but nor we are interested in driving prices up, because it will drain juices—life juices—from all other sectors of the economy, from machine building, et cetera So we do have space for cooperation here, as the first thingThen, about the Nord Stream 2, Mr President voiced his concerns about the possibility of disappearance of transit through Ukraine And I reassured Mr President that Russia stands ready to maintain this transit Moreover, we stand ready to extend this transit contract that is about to expire next year, in case—if the dispute between the economic entities, dispute will be settled in the Stockholm arbitration courtWhite House Press Secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders The first question for a US journalist goes to Jeff Mason, from ReutersRussia-US Relations/
label: Deflection

sentence: President Bush, concerning the African continent, what critical actions are needed to drive progress, and what qualities should African leaders embody? How will the United States contribute to these efforts? Also, what do you hope to achieve during this visit, and how can you guarantee long-term results? [SEP] I've been to Africa before, and I want to remind everyone that it's in our interest to assist with diseases, trade, and education. Being in Ghana makes it real. Africa has improved since I became President, thanks to its leaders. We've assisted with conflict resolution, like in Liberia, and promoted democracy. We're simply trying to be a useful partner. Our aid program now requires good governance. I'm confident in the leaders I've met. That's why I'm here, and I'm pleased to be here. And I see John McKinnon from the Wall Street Journal.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, the Vice President mentioned a conversation about a significant risk of failure, even with optimal execution. Could you elaborate on the topic of that discussion and reassure the public that it wasn't related to critical economic recovery measures? [SEP] You know, I'm drawing a blank on the precise conversation Joe's referring to. But let me try to frame this a bit. What I think Joe was getting at, and I wouldn't necessarily put a number on it, is that the challenges before us are so enormous that any single action is only going to be a piece of the puzzle, not the whole thing. And as I've said before, not everything we do is going to pan out exactly as we hope. This is uncharted territory. While there's a general consensus among economists on the path forward, the need for a substantial recovery package, and a balanced approach, even if we get all of that right, we still have to deal with the financial system, the housing market, and creating a regulatory system that prevents future crises. These are all huge, complicated issues. So, I'm not sure if that's what Joe was talking about, but I hope that gives you some context.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, the American people deserve to know what you said to President Putin that resolved his concerns. Can you provide any insight? [SEP] My conversations with other world leaders are confidential. His satisfaction is the key takeaway here.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, Pakistan's nuclear program continues to raise concerns. Beyond diplomatic statements, what concrete measures are being implemented to verify the safety and security of Pakistan's nuclear arsenal, and what consequences will Pakistan face if they fail to meet international non-proliferation standards? [SEP] Pakistan is an important ally, a very important ally, and we are working with them. We have a strong relationship, a very strong relationship. We are confident that they are taking the necessary steps to secure their nuclear materials. We are constantly evaluating the situation, constantly evaluating. We are always prepared to take action if necessary, always prepared.
label: Dodging

sentence: President Obama, how optimistic are you that global consensus on sanctions against Iran will be reached soon? Also, can you guarantee the security of Pakistan's nuclear weapons from terrorists like Al-Qaeda? [SEP] On Pakistan, we are constantly working with them to ensure the security of their nuclear arsenal. It's an ongoing process, and we take it very seriously. As for Iran, we are pushing hard for strong international sanctions. It's a tough negotiation, but we believe it's essential to prevent Iran from developing nuclear weapons. I can't give you a specific timeline, but we are committed to achieving this goal as quickly as possible.
label: General

sentence: Regarding India, are you content with the current investment landscape, especially concerning multi-brand retail and e-commerce, sectors of significant interest to U.S. firms? [SEP] Absolutely. They're pouring in tremendous amounts of capital. I recently met with Mr. Patel, the world's largest steel magnate, who's constructing a billion-dollar facility in Alabama. The press was present, and they were discussing how much more favorable it is to invest in the U.S. now. These are some of the world's leading entrepreneurs. Mr. Patel is investing billions because of my efforts to revitalize the steel industry. It was virtually nonexistent, but now it's thriving, and it's essential for our defense. He was beaming. I anticipate seeing some of you on the plane. It's an incredible nation with exceptional leadership and a promising future. Thank you.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, why do you believe setting this example is acceptable for the nation? [SEP] With all due respect, that's simply not the case. It's a matter of political procedure, and these activities are exempt. It's all perfectly legal.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. So, just to be clear, is the National Health Service part of these trade negotiations? [SEP] Come again? I didn't quite catch that.
label: Clarification

sentence: What specific steps are you taking to advance your pro-life agenda? [SEP] We're pushing forward. I've been pushing, and we've made good progress. But it's a difficult issue with strong opinions on both sides.
label: General

sentence: Q. Yes, Mr. President, many Americans want to return to their normal lives, but they're afraid to do so. How can you ensure Americans that it's safe to go to their own workplaces when the most secure workplace in the country, the White House, cannot contain the spread of the coronavirus that's infected some of your own staff? [SEP] Well, when you say some, so we have a person and the person got—something happened right after a test was done. Three other people met that person, came into relative contact—very little contact—and they're self-quarantining. That is not exactly not controlling it. We—I think we've controlled it very well.We have hundreds and hundreds of people a day pouring into the White House. It's a massive office complex, including the very large building right behind us that you know so well. So I think we're really doing a very good job in watching it. And I think it's very well contained actually.And part of the reason, it is because of all the tests we're able to give. But it was one person, and the other people were only people—they're quarantined. You understand this, Phil; they're quarantined for a specific reason. The reason is, they were in the general proximity of the one person. And the one person, I believe, will be fine in a very short period of time.
label: Dodging

sentence: With the jobs bill facing gridlock, some say you'll campaign in 2012 with a weak economy and doubts about your ability to lead. What's your perspective? [SEP] The real question is why Congress won't pass a jobs bill that Americans, even Republicans, largely support. Usually, politicians react when the public is unhappy, but Congress, especially Republicans, seems indifferent to job creation. I'll keep fighting, even if it takes until the election or a new Congress. The bill includes tax cuts for the middle class, incentives for hiring veterans, and support for teachers, addressing issues like shortened school weeks in Hawaii. It also invests in infrastructure, crucial for competing globally, as evidenced by superior infrastructure in Asia. I'll keep pushing, and if they don't act, the voters will replace them.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. [Laughter] So, both options are on the table? [SEP] Both, you say? What was the premise again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the debt ceiling negotiations, would you consider tax breaks to stimulate the economy, even if they increase the deficit? And on same-sex marriage, given the progress in states like New York, do you personally support it now? [SEP] I'm not going to break any news on that front today. You almost got me there, though.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Question of both Presidents: Referring to what has been raised a moment ago, this European initiative—European reassurance initiative, doesn't do away with the division into old and the new members of the alliance. It doesn't mean that the deployment of ground troops of the United States, and Poland and other countries like the Baltic States counted on this very much. So what kind of American troops can we expect in Poland, specifically, within the next months or years? Is it going to be some components of the ground troops? And if so, when are they going to come? [SEP] Well, the—first of all, when you discuss old and new NATO members, I recall my first NATO meeting back in 2009, and I made very clear, at that first meeting, my belief that there's no such thing as new members of NATO and old members of NATO, there are just members of NATO. And because that was my strong view then and continues to be my strong view now, I immediately pushed to make sure that we were putting in place contingency plans for every NATO member. And those contingency plans have been steadily developed over the last several years.And part of what I think your President just indicated is very important is that our contingency plans are not just pieces of paper on a shelf, but we have the capacity to operationalize them. That means that there has to be resources pre-positioned, there has to be training, there have to be joint exercises. We have been conducting those, but there's no doubt that what has happened in Ukraine adds a sense of urgency when we meet in Wales in the next NATO summit.And part of what I discussed with Secretary General of NATO Rasmussen and now with the new Secretary General Stoltenberg is the need to make sure that the collective defense effort is robust, it is ready, it is properly equipped.That does mean that every NATO member has to do its fair share. Obviously, we all have different capacities. The United States is going to have different capacities than Poland; Poland is going to have a different capacity than Latvia. But everyone has the capacity to do their fair share, to do a proportional amount to make sure that we have the resources, the planning, the integration, the training in order to be effective.Some of that has to do with where our personnel is positioned. And obviously, as I indicated before, my administration has put U.S. soldiers on Polish soil for the first time. This new initiative that I'm putting forward gives us the option, the capacity, to add to those rotations.But I think it's important to recognize that the effectiveness of our defenses against any threat is not just going to be dependent on how many troops we have in any particular country; it has to do with how we are working collectively together to make sure that when any NATO member is threatened, all of us can respond rapidly, whether it's through air, sea, or land.And that's going to require some flexibility. It's going to require some additional planning. It's going to require some joint capabilities that right now we don't have. Frankly, NATO is very reliant on U.S. capabilities, but has not always invested in some joint capabilities that would be important as well. And it's going to require every NATO member to step up. We have seen a decline steadily in European defense spending generally. There are exceptions like Poland, like Estonia, but for the most part, we have seen a steady decline. That has to change.The United States is proud to bear its share of the defense of the transatlantic alliance. It is the cornerstone of our security. But we can't do it alone. And we're going to need to make sure that everybody who is a member of NATO has full membership. They expect full membership when it comes to their defense; then that means that they've also got to make a contribution that is commensurate with full membership. President Komorowski. For Poland, what is really fundamental is to make sure that nobody from outside of NATO claims the right to determine what NATO member states may do and what they may not do. And it also concerns the question of the presence of NATO troops and NATO infrastructure in the Polish territory.What is most important for us is to make sure that there are no second-category member states of NATO, that there are no countries about whom an external country—a third country like Russia—can say whether or not American or other allied troops can be deployed to these countries. That is why the decision of the United States of America to deploy American troops to Poland is really very important for us, both as an element of deterrence, but also as a reconfirmation that we do not really accept any limitations concerning the deployment of NATO troops to Poland imposed for some time or suggested for some time by a country that is not member of NATO.Another thing is the inadequacy of response to the existing situation. The Ukrainian crisis, the Russian behavior about Crimea, for example, forced the necessary response to it. And this response is both the real presence of American troops, reinforced aviation detachment, and then the ground troops that are—component, as well as the declaration of President Obama to increase this presence even more. I would like to remind you that Poland is also making a contribution in the reconfirmation of an equal right of every member state to decide whether or not they are going to receive NATO troops in their territories.So Poland is participating in the air policing mission that is a mission to provide security for the air space over the Baltic States. We do it together with other allies from NATO, and we don't ask anybody for acceptance except for what is agreed within NATO internally. The same goes for the Poland's participation in the Afghan operation in ISAF. It was the reconfirmation of full solidarity and full coresponsibility for the decisions which are made not only for the military effort, but also for political decisions. Poland has been and shall continue to be a spokescountry for the solidarity within NATO. And that this can be manifested also in the denial of the right of anyone from outside of NATO to decide whether we can do something or we cannot do it. President-Elect Petro Poroshenko of Ukraine/International Economic Assistance to Ukraine/Ukraine-U.S. Military Cooperation/President Vladimir Vladimirovich Putin of RussiaMr. Earnest. The second question from the American side will come from Margaret Talev with Bloomberg News.
label: Dodging

sentence: President Bush, concerning Russia's actions regarding NATO expansion and missile defense, how do you assess the level of pressure they are applying and the nature of their tactics? [SEP] Look, those Soviet-era flags you saw yesterday? Don't read too much into it. It's an interesting debate. Every nation assures me Russia won't have a veto over Bucharest's decisions, and I trust them. That's the right approach. I'm committed to Ukraine and Georgia joining MAP. It's in our, NATO's, and their best interests. On missile defense, I've clearly told President Putin it's not aimed at Russia. They could easily overwhelm it. It's for threats from the Middle East, like our Far East systems protect us from single or dual launches. We need to ease suspicions, but we're making progress. Ukraine's NATO membership is about national interest, not targeting anyone. Our history shows collective defense is vital for sovereignty and integrity. Joining MAP is the best response for Ukraine's future. Debates in Europe shouldn't create obstacles. We're on the right track, acting within our sovereignty. The open-door policy shouldn't be replaced by a veto from a non-member. The discussion is overheated, lacking respect. Wisdom should prevail. I want calmness, stability, and security for Ukraine.
