He's crunching the numbers on the consequences for Russia. My gut tells me he's still on the fence.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your comments on a return to civility, do you see the election as a sign that the 'fever' has broken, that we're moving past the recent era of division? [SEP] Look, those super-mega-MAGA folks? Probably not gonna change. But they're a small group. Most Republicans are good people we disagree with. I've worked with them for years, they're honest. The world's watching us. At the G-7, I said America's back. Someone asked, 'For how long?' Another asked what I'd think if Parliament was stormed to stop an election. Not the same, but it'd be bad. People are wondering if we're stable, if we're still a democracy. If we pulled out of the world, things would change. They want to know we still have rules and institutions.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, is President Karzai correct in blaming Pakistan's intelligence services for the recent attack in his country? And do you believe the new government in Pakistan is both willing and able to fight terrorists? [SEP] We are taking President Karzai's concerns seriously and investigating the matter. It is clear that extremists are operating along the border between Pakistan and Afghanistan. We are working with the Pakistani government, and we believe they are committed to fighting terrorism. However, they face significant challenges, and we will continue to support their efforts to combat extremism and promote stability in the region. It is a shared responsibility, and we must work together to address this threat.
label: General

sentence: Given Finland's proximity to Russia, what specific concerns have arisen recently regarding border security, and what additional measures do you believe are necessary to deter potential Russian aggression? [SEP] We have considered many potential scenarios and prepared accordingly. We are cautious and hope the situation remains calm. The Finnish people feel more secure, and we stand ready to protect our allies.
label: Dodging

sentence: So, you won't confirm or deny that we've conducted drone strikes in Yemen? [SEP] I'm not at liberty to discuss operational details. Ed Henry.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, regardless of the economic success you cite, are you concerned that your actions could be interpreted as impeachable offenses? [SEP] Look, I've done nothing wrong. Absolutely nothing wrong. I'm fighting for the American people, I'm standing up to the swamp, and they don't like it. They're trying to take me down, but they won't succeed. The American people are with me.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, 'You'll see' sounds dismissive and vague. Are you intentionally keeping our options open, or is there a lack of a clear plan regarding Iran's potential JCPOA violation? [SEP] We are prepared to act as necessary.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the ongoing Senate proceedings, could you share your preference for either an expedited conclusion or a comprehensive investigation of the evidence? What is your assessment of the interaction between White House Counsel Pat Cipollone and Jerrold Nadler? And do you maintain an unwavering opposition to John Bolton's testimony? [SEP] You're asking me a lot of things at once.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And, sir, as a follow-up—one follow-up? Q. Thank you so—do you want to do a follow-up? Or—— Q. Yes, if you don't mind. Q. Okay, yes. Is it okay? [SEP] Yes, go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering the confluence of economic factors – the war in Ukraine, the disruptions in China, and the high inflation rates in the United States – should the American people prepare for a potential recession? Is a recession a certainty at this point? [SEP] Absolutely not.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Was it a male or a female suspect? [SEP] I don't know. You'll have to get that—they'll have a detailed—maybe a briefing for you outside later.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Can you confirm whether or not your name was mentioned? [SEP] The situation is still developing.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Aside from Huawei, are there any additional Chinese technology firms that are being evaluated for potential restrictions on their operations within the United States? [SEP] Well, the big one is Huawei, isn't it? Huawei's not here, and I'm not letting them in. I've told European countries and others – Australia's been great, for example – that Huawei's not coming here. We even told some countries considering Huawei that they could use them, but we wouldn't share intelligence. They all backed away. Look at the UK, they seemed to be going that way, but now they've backed out – Scotland Yard.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Obama, the situation with Chen Guangcheng is developing rapidly. Can you provide any insight into the U.S. government's involvement, and what options are being considered regarding his potential asylum? [SEP] I understand the interest in this case, but I'm not in a position to offer any details at this time. However, I want to reiterate that human rights are a fundamental part of our dialogue with China. We believe that progress in this area is essential for China's long-term stability and prosperity.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning your discussions with Kim Jong-un, does a documented account of those exchanges exist? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I wanted to ask you about Afghanistan. You face a May 1 deadline for the withdrawal of U.S. troops from that country. As a candidate, in Foreign Affairs, you wrote that it is past time to end these forever wars. Can you commit to the American people that by May 2 the U.S. will no longer have forces in Afghanistan? [SEP] The answer is that it's going to be hard to meet the May 1 deadline. Just in terms of tactical reasons, it's hard to get those troops out. So what we've been doing—what I've been doing and what Secretary Blinken has been doing—has been—we've been meeting with our allies, those other nations that have—NATO allies who have troops in Afghanistan as well. And if we leave, we're going to do so in a safe and orderly way.We're in consultation, I said, with our allies and partners in how to proceed. And Secretary Blinken is meeting in Brussels this week with our NATO allies, particularly those who have forces there.And General Austin is—just met with Kayani [Ghani]* and I'm waiting for the briefing on that. He is the leader, quote, in Afghanistan and Kabul. And there's a U.N.-led process that's beginning shortly on how to mechanically get people—how to end this war.But it is not my intention to stay there for a long time. But the question is: How and in what circumstances do we meet that agreement that was made by President Trump to leave under a deal that looks like it's not being able to be worked out to begin with? How is that done? But we are not staying a long time.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, is ceding Ukrainian territory a necessary condition for a cease-fire with Russia? Also, should Russia be ousted from the G-20? [SEP] Yes, on the G-20. What was the initial question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. [Inaudible]—through a tax, or how? [SEP] Very simple. I mean we have—we have all the cards because, without us, you can't come into the United States. It's like if you're a landlord, and you have a tenant. The tenant's business needs a rent; it needs a lease. And so what I said to them is, Whatever the price is, a very big proportion of that price would have to go to the Treasury of the United States.And they understood that. And actually, they agreed with me. I mean, I think they agreed with me very much.Yes, please. In the back.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Does the United States want to maintain permanent bases in Iraq? And I would follow that by asking, are you willing to renounce a claim on permanent bases in Iraq? [SEP] Jim, any decisions about permanency in Iraq will be made by the . And frankly, it's not in much of a position to be thinking about what the world is going to look like 5 or 10 years from now. They are working to make sure that we succeed in the short term. And they need our help, and that's where our focus is.But remember, when you're talking about bases and troops, we're dealing with a sovereign government. Now, we entered into an agreement with the Karzai Government. They weren't called permanent bases, but they were called arrangements that will help this Government understand that there will be a U.S. presence so long as they want them there. And at the appropriate time, I'm confident we'll be willing to sit down and discuss the long-term security of Iraq. But right now we're discussing how to bring security to Baghdad and what do we do in Al Anbar Province, where Al Qaida still uses violent methods to achieve political objectives.You know, it's interesting, if you—I'm sure people who watch your TV screens think the entire country is embroiled in sectarian conflict and that there's constant killing everywhere in Iraq. Well, if you listened to General Casey yesterday, 90 percent of the action takes place in 5 of the 18 Provinces. And around Baghdad, it's within a 30-mile area. And the reason I bring that up is that while it seems to our American citizens that nothing normal is taking place—and I can understand why; it's a brutal environment there, particularly that which is on our TV screens—that there is farmers farming; there are small businesses growing; there's a currency that's relatively stable; there's an entrepreneurial class; there's commerce. General Abizaid was describing to me what it was like to go to Baghdad markets.There's a lot of work to be done, don't get me wrong, but it is—there are people living relatively normal lives who, I believe—strongly believe that they want to continue that normalcy. And it's up to Prime Minister Maliki to do everything he can to make the situation as secure as possible.Ann [Ann Compton, ABC News]. Sorry, Rutenberg, you're through.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Bush, considering the historical challenges in achieving migration reform, why should Mexicans, or anyone, believe that a breakthrough is now possible? And President Calderon, what were the key topics discussed during your lunch with President Fox? [SEP] Well, first off, let me say that legislative progress in the U.S. can be a bit of a marathon, not a sprint. I'm not sure how it works in Mexico, Mr. President, but here, debates can take time before a consensus emerges. We haven't had a truly serious national conversation about migration until recently. There was a law in '86, but the real debate didn't start until after 2000, if I recall correctly. As a former Governor of Texas, I've always understood the importance of this issue and have worked to elevate it over the years. Congress has taken it seriously, but crafting legislation on such a complex topic is tough. Many Americans were concerned about the lack of enforcement of our existing laws. Over the past year, we've demonstrated a strong commitment to the rule of law, which I believe has made Congress more receptive to the idea that comprehensive migration reform can actually enhance border security. By making it less necessary for people to cross illegally, we can free up resources to focus on drugs, terrorists, criminals, and guns moving in both directions. I'm optimistic about our chances. While I don't like to make predictions, the mood in Congress seems to have shifted from skepticism to a recognition that comprehensive reform is in the nation's best interest. Republicans and Democrats in the Senate are working together, and my administration is actively involved in helping them find common ground. I recently met with former President Vicente Fox, whom I admire, and we had a constructive conversation. He congratulated us on our first 100 days and expressed his willingness to cooperate with my government for the benefit of Mexicans. I've also met with other former Presidents, and I plan to continue those discussions.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Can I ask about something else, please? Mr. President——China  Q. Thank you, Mr. President. On the grounds that the Chinese Communist Party has been using slave labor in Xinjiang, your administration has imposed a limited ban on certain products coming out of Xinjiang, stopping short of a full region ban. What is your response to the Chinese Communist Party's spokespeople who are saying that this is an outright lie. Xinjiang does not have forced labor.And number two, have allies expressed interest in standing with this administration in taking action against forced labor imposed by the Communist Party? [SEP] Yes, we don't want to see that. We've been very strong on that. We're getting reports in. Over the next 2 or 3 days, we'll know very accurately what the story is, and we'll then take action one way or the other.Go ahead.World Trade Organization/-U.S. Trade
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Sir, is the NHS up for negotiation? [SEP] Pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, about the Kodak situation, with the SEC investigation, are you worried about potential issues with how the deal was structured? [SEP] I'm not in the loop on the specifics, so I can't really comment. The overall idea is a good one, but we'll investigate. We'll do a little digging and let you know.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you. The President-elect has said that he would consider lifting sanctions on Russia if they substantially reduced their nuclear stockpile. Given your own efforts at arms control, do you think that's an effective strategy? Knowing this office and Mr. Trump, how would you advise his advisers to help him be effective when he deals with Vladimir Putin? And given your actions recently on Russia, do you think those sanctions should be viewed as leverage? [SEP] Well, a couple of things. Number one, I think it is in America's interests and the world's interests that we have a constructive relationship with Russia. That's been my approach throughout my Presidency. Where our interests have overlapped, we've worked together. At the beginning of my term, I did what I could to encourage Russia to be a constructive member of the international community and tried to work with the President and the Government of Russia in helping them diversify their economy, improve their economy, use the incredible talents of the Russian people in more constructive ways.I think it's fair to say that after President Putin came back into the Presidency that an escalating anti-American rhetoric and an approach to global affairs that seemed to be premised on the idea that whatever America is trying to do must be bad for Russia and so we want to try and counteract whatever they do, that return to an adversarial spirit that, I think, existed during the cold war has made the relationship more difficult. And it was hammered home when Russia went into Crimea and portions of Ukraine.The reason we imposed the sanctions, recall, was not because of nuclear weapons issues. It was because the independence and sovereignty of a country, Ukraine, had been encroached upon, by force, by Russia. That wasn't our judgment, that was the judgment of the entire international community. And Russia continues to occupy Ukrainian territory and meddle in Ukrainian affairs and support military surrogates who have violated basic international law and international norms.What I've said to the Russians is, as soon as you stop doing that, the sanctions will be removed. And I think it would probably best serve not only American interests, but also the interests of preserving international norms if we made sure that we don't confuse why these sanctions have been imposed with a whole set of other issues.On nuclear issues, in my first term, we negotiated the START II Treaty, and that has substantially reduced our nuclear stockpiles, both Russia and the United States. I was prepared to go further. I told President Putin I was prepared to go further. They have been unwilling to negotiate. If President-elect Trump is able to restart those talks in a serious way, I think there is—remains a lot of room for our two countries to reduce our stockpiles. And part of the reason we've been successful on our nonproliferation agenda and on our nuclear security agenda is because we were leading by example.I hope that continues. But I think it's important just to remember that the reason sanctions have been put in place against Russia has to do with their actions in Ukraine. And it is important for the United States to stand up for the basic principle that big countries don't go around and invade and bully smaller countries. I've said before, I expect Russia and Ukraine to have a strong relationship. They are, historically, bound together in all sorts of cultural and social ways. But Ukraine is an independent country.And this is a good example of the vital role that America has to continue to play around the world in preserving basic norms and values, whether it's advocating on behalf of human rights, advocating on behalf of women's rights, advocating on behalf of freedom of the press.The United States has not always been perfect in this regard. There are times where we, by necessity, are dealing with allies or friends or partners who, themselves, are not meeting the standards that we would like to see met when it comes to international rules and norms. But I can tell you that in every multilateral setting—in the United Nations, in the G-20, in the G-7—the United States typically has been on the right side of these issues. And it is important for us to continue to be on the right side of these issues, because if we, the largest, strongest country and democracy in the world, are not willing to stand up on behalf of these values, then certainly China, Russia, and others will not.Kevin Corke [Fox News].
label: Dodging

sentence: Will this be over by the time you're out of office? And do you support Israel's behavior? [SEP] I certainly hope it will be. I'm all for a lasting cease-fire, and that means Hamas has to stop firing rockets into Israel. If they keep firing rockets, there's no way we can have a lasting cease-fire. I think it's up to Hamas. The best way to make sure we get a lasting cease-fire is to work with Egypt to stop weapons from being smuggled into Gaza, which is what lets Hamas keep firing rockets. Countries that are giving weapons to Hamas need to stop. The international community needs to keep the pressure on them. If Hamas wants a lasting cease-fire, they need to stop arming themselves. And countries near Gaza need to work together to stop the smuggling. It's not easy, because there are tunnels. What was the second part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Let me follow up on that. Would you strongly discourage Israel from going after Iran militarily? And do you believe, when you leave office, Iran will be pursuing a nuclear weapon? [SEP] I have made it very clear to all parties that the first option ought to be to solve this problem diplomatically. And the best way to solve it diplomatically is for the United States to work with other nations to send a focused message, and that is, that you will be isolated and you will have economic hardship if you continue trying to enrich.As you might remember, I worked closely with Vladimir Putin on this issue. When I said that—when asked at one of these innumerable press conferences, Did you— do you think they ought to have a civilian nuclear program? I said, Of course, they should, but they can't be trusted to enrich.And therefore, I agree with Russia that Russia—when Russia said she will provide enriched uranium for a civilian nuclear power program and will collect the enriched uranium, thereby negating the need for the ian regime to enrich at all.And so we will continue working diplomatically.Listen, thank you very much. I've enjoyed being with you. I hope you've enjoyed being with me. You haven't? Thank you.
label: Dodging

sentence: Given the recent elections in Pakistan and the apparent decline in President Musharraf's support, do you still consider him a reliable partner in the fight against terrorism, and what is your assessment of the future stability of Pakistan? [SEP] Look, America's got a big heart. We can help Africa and deal with Pakistan. It's a victory for the Pakistani people that they had fair elections. Musharraf did what he said he'd do. Now, it's up to the new government to be friends with us. We need Pakistan as an ally. We've got common enemies, these radical terrorists. They killed Bhutto. We can't let them have a safe haven to attack us or Pakistan. And about Africa, we're all connected now. If we don't help them, their problems become our problems. Terrorism knows no borders. We're all in this together.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Canada's stimulus plans and the future of the Canada-U.S. relationship, including the auto sector, border security, and carbon markets, could you address these points? [SEP] Whoa, hold on a second. That's a whole laundry list of questions. Remind me, what was the first one again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Quick—two quick ones, if I could, Mr. President. I know you were briefed on it; have you decided where are you're going to give your acceptance speech yet? [SEP] So we're looking at Gettysburg.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Do you have any—[inaudible]? [SEP] You know, some countries have and some countries haven't. I'm watching other countries. I'm studying other countries as they open. I mean, I don't want to go into names because, for some, it would be a little bit embarrassing. But I'm studying other countries as we go along.So, on that, we have looked at every country that's opened, some successfully, some okay. No total disaster, but some okay. And some have to go back to the hotspot and fix the hotspot. We think we're going to do it very successfully.Again, we have one country, but we have lots of different pieces. It's a puzzle. We have beautiful pieces, beautiful States with capable Governors. They know when it's time to open.And we don't want to put pressure on anybody. I'm not going to put any pressure on any governor to open. I'm not going to say to Governor Cuomo, You've got to open within 7 days. I want him to take his time, do it right, and then open New York. I'm not putting any pressure on the Governors. Some of them don't need pressure or not pressure. I mean, they're ready to go.And that's a good thing.So we'll open it up in beautiful, little pieces as it comes along. Please, go ahead. Behind you.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you. Mr. President, just to continue on that, when the NATO leaders gather in Chicago in May, do you expect that they'll be able to agree on a transition strategy? And are you concerned at all that the Koran burning and the episodes that have followed since then threaten your ability to negotiate with partners? [SEP] Well, keep in mind that the transition policy was in place and established at Lisbon, and we've been following that strategy that calls for us turning over increasing responsibility to Afghans and a full transition so that our combat role is over by the end of 2014. And our coalition partners have agreed to it. They are sticking with it. That continues to be the plan.What we are now going to be doing over the next--at this NATO meeting and planning for the next 2 years is to make sure that that transition is not a cliff, but that there are benchmarks and steps that are taken along the way, in the same way that we reduced our role in Iraq, so that it is gradual, Afghan capacity is built, the partnering with Afghan security forces is effective, that we are putting in place the kinds of support structures that are needed in order for the overall strategy to be effective.Now, yes, the situation with the Koran burning concerns me. I think that it is an indication of the challenges in that environment, and it's an indication that now is the time for us to transition.Obviously, the violence directed at our people is unacceptable. And President Karzai acknowledged that. But what is also true is President Karzai, I think, is eager for more responsibility on the Afghan side. We're going to be able to find a mechanism whereby Afghans understand their sovereignty is being respected and that they're going to be taking a greater and greater role in their own security. That, I think, is in the interest of Afghans. It's also in our interests. And I'm confident we can execute, but it's not going to be a smooth path. There are going to be bumps along the road just as there were in Iraq.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, can you provide specifics on the distribution of resources to minority communities, and your plans for improving the lives of African Americans during a second term, especially given the current surge in unemployment? [SEP] I appreciate the inquiry. We have witnessed a remarkable decline in poverty, particularly among African Americans. The employment statistics have reached unprecedented levels. Obviously, the coronavirus has created obstacles. Our priority is high-risk individuals and frontline workers. We have established thousands of distribution locations, specifically targeting minority and low-income regions. Prioritizing testing at Historically Black Colleges and Universities is also a crucial goal. It's regrettable to observe some individuals attempting to generate apprehension regarding the vaccine. It is safe, effective, and imperative for everyone, particularly those at elevated risk, to receive it. This negativity surfaced when it seemed we might have a vaccine before the election. It's entirely political, fueled by disinformation. Similar to the deceptive football advertisement or the erroneous narrative about me. They are denouncing the vaccine out of apprehension. Nevertheless, we are approaching a breakthrough, with widespread distribution anticipated within weeks, prioritizing seniors. We are conducting extensive testing at HBCUs, an initiative I suggested. We will soon exceed one hundred million tests. This enables us to pinpoint areas of concern. Other nations, lacking testing, report no cases. We take pride in our testing initiatives. So, indeed, we are achieving substantial advancements. Next question.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your silence on Israel's nuclear program undermines your non-proliferation efforts. How do you respond to those who say you're applying a different standard to Israel? [SEP] Well, I appreciate the question, but it's important to remember the broader context. The United States has a long-standing relationship with Israel, and we're committed to their security. Our focus is on promoting peace and stability in the region, and we believe that a comprehensive approach to non-proliferation is the best way to achieve that goal. We've consistently urged all countries to adhere to the NPT, and we'll continue to do so. But I'm not going to single out any one country for criticism. Our goal is to work with all nations to create a safer and more secure world. Next question, please.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the border, and following up on the busing question, do you believe busing is a feasible method for school integration, and does it inform your upcoming policy announcement? [SEP] Look, busing has been around for a while, right? It's not like there are a ton of ways to get kids to school. It's been tried and tested. Sometimes it's been smooth, sometimes not so much. But it's a tool. If Biden had handled that question differently, things would be different. They really went after him on that one. But yeah, it's a common way to get kids to school.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, yesterday you discussed Usama bin Laden's plans to turn Iraq into a terrorist sanctuary. What do you think your own reaction would have been 5 years ago had you been told that towards the end of your term, he would still be at large with that kind of capability, from Iraq, no less, and why—can you tell the American people—is he still on the run? Why is he so hard to catch? [SEP] I would say that 5 years ago—like I said, we're going to pursue him. And we are pursuing him. And he's hiding. He is in a remote region of the world. If I knew precisely where he is, we would take the appropriate action to bring him to justice. He is attempting to establish a base of operations in Iraq. He hasn't established a base in operations. My points yesterday were, here was his intentions, but thankfully, of the three people I named, all of them no longer are a part of his operation.My point is, is that—I was making the point, Jim, as I'm sure you recognized, that if we leave, they follow us. And my point was, was that Usama bin Laden was establishing an external cell there, or trying to. And he's been unable to do it, precisely my point. That's why we've got to stay engaged. Had he been able to establish an internal cell that had safe haven, we would be a lot more in danger today than we are. His organization is a risk. We will continue to pursue as hard as we possibly can. We will do everything we can to bring him and others to justice.We have had good success in the chief operating officer position of Al Qaida. Khalid Sheikh Mohammed, Ramzi al Rabium—there's a lot of names that I— some of whom I mentioned yesterday, that are no longer a threat to the United States. We will continue to work to bring him to justice; that's exactly what the American people expect us to do, and, in the meantime, use the tools we put in place to protect this homeland.We are under threat. Now, some may say, well, he's just saying that to get people to pay attention to him, or try to scare them into—for some reason. I would hope our world hadn't become so cynical that they don't take the threats of Al Qaida seriously, because they're real. And it's a danger to the American people. It's a danger to your children, Jim. And it's really important that we do all we can do to bring them to justice.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Was he forced out because he wasn't sufficiently loyal to you? [SEP] No. Not at all. Not at all. He was pushed out because, frankly—he wasn't pushed out. He would have had to get out. On March 11, he would have had to leave.But we're going to be making a decision on DNI very shortly.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Eighty days before an election, sir? Is this the right time? [SEP] Well, wait a minute. You just threw—look, I just read last night that now New Jersey is going to try the universal mail-in voting. Well, they didn't know this. So now, all of a sudden, New Jersey is going to be hit with millions of ballots to be sent out. They didn't know anything about this.So how does a Post Office—how does a Postal Service that doesn't know about it, now all of a sudden, New Jersey is supposed to take out, and millions of ballots are going to be sent all over New Jersey?And if you look at some of the things they say, like in—take the State of Nevada, take that little scam that's going on over there with the clubhouse politician Governor. Take that, where the votes don't even have to be in until 7—they get counted 7 days after November 3. That means if—Nevada is a very important State. I think we have a great chance of winning that State. If the votes don't have to be in for 7—and they're not counting the votes—7 days later, that means how are they going to predict a winner on November 3?
label: Implicit

sentence: Critics argue that focusing on the future ignores the need for accountability for past actions. How do you balance the desire for a strong relationship with Chile with the need to address historical injustices? [SEP] It's important to acknowledge the past and learn from it, but we can't let it define our future. We're committed to working with Chile to address any remaining concerns and build a relationship based on mutual respect and shared values. We believe that focusing on the present and future is the best way to honor the victims of the past and ensure that such injustices never happen again.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, were you the target of any personal attacks from those demonstrators? [SEP] I honestly couldn't say. I didn't inquire. It might not have been related to me at all. It occurred outside the White House perimeter, beyond the fence. As you know, the new fencing is quite robust. But it was on the exterior. The Secret Service will be issuing a comprehensive report shortly.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Did you ask the Ambassador in Brazil to focus his efforts to lower, to eliminate ethanol tariffs in Brazil? [SEP] We haven't really discussed that too much, but at some point, we probably will be. And we don't want people tariffing us. And if they tariff us—although, I must tell you, I have a very good relationship with President Bolsonaro. He's great. He's—and I hear he's doing well. He's recovered from having COVID. Having COVID-19, as they say. And that's great. And send him my regards.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, some analysts believe this is a crucial turning point in the conflict. Do you share that assessment? [SEP] I'm not going to speculate on that. It's too early to tell. We're focused on supporting Ukraine and holding Russia accountable.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. One more on deescalation, sir. Do you still believe there's an off-ramp for Vladimir Putin here? [SEP] Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, it's been suggested that you strategically avoided addressing gun violence during your initial term and in 2012. While you supported renewing the ban on semiautomatic rifles, your actions were perceived as limited. In light of repeated instances of horrific gun violence, where have you been on this critical issue? [SEP] Jake, I have been serving as President of the United States, grappling with the most severe economic crisis since the Great Depression, the near-collapse of the auto industry, and two ongoing wars. My time has been fully occupied. We must all engage in critical self-reflection regarding our priorities. Ensuring the safety of our children must be paramount. I am fully committed to taking every possible measure to achieve that goal. This encompasses a broad range of factors, including access to quality healthcare, education, and employment opportunities for parents. These are not peripheral issues. However, addressing gun violence is of central importance. That is why I am confident that Joe will treat this matter with the utmost seriousness in the coming months. Thank you.
label: General

sentence: So, a meeting is uncertain at this point? [SEP] Well, I'm going to evaluate the situation. I just came from those meetings. The issue of fighting crime and drug trafficking is a serious one for all of us, and we need to approach it effectively.
label: Deflection

sentence: Why are you pushing so hard to pull the country so far to the left in your first year? [SEP] With all due respect, I disagree with the premise. I don't believe my policies are 'far to the left.' If you're referring to investments in COVID relief, bipartisan infrastructure, and support for working-class families, I fail to see how that constitutes a radical agenda. These are measures designed to ease burdens and create opportunities. You and others have tried to paint me as some kind of socialist, a Bernie Sanders clone. I respect Bernie, but I'm a mainstream Democrat, always have been. And the overwhelming support I've received from my fellow Democrats in the Senate proves that.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Aso, with the Kyoto News Service. On North Korea, I'd like to ask questions of the two leaders. First, President Bush, North Korea recently submitted their declaration on nuclear development programs, but that declaration did not include a declaration regarding nuclear weapons. Are you satisfied with that sort of declaration, Mr. President?And also in connection with this—or in connection with the declaration, Mr. President, you expressed—no, you decided to notify Congress about removing North Korea from the status of state sponsors of terrorism list. There is rising concern about abduction in Japan. You said you will not forget about abduction, but would there be—after the removal of North Korea from the list, what sort of means will there remain for the United States to press North Korea to resolve the abduction issue?Now, Mr. Fukuda, I wonder in your discussions you asked the President to rethink the President's decision to remove North Korea from the list. If not, why didn't you ask? Now, following the removal of North Korea from the list, what sort of specific cooperation would you seek from the United States to advance the abduction issue? [SEP] North Korea is the most sanctioned nation in the world and will remain the most sanctioned nation in the world. And the way for them to get off their sanctions is to honor their commitments in a verifiable fashion.Somehow there's this notion—inherent in your question is the delisting therefore took away their sanctions. That's just not an accurate statement on your part if you think that. I'm not assuming you do think that, but it's—they're a highly sanctioned regime. And they will—as I said, they've got a lot of obligations that they must fulfill in order for these sanctions to leave.And that's why I said it is action for action. And the first step was taken. Now, one thing is for certain, I repeat—I don't know if you saw it on your—on the TVs here, but the destruction of the cooling tower was verifiable action. And that's a positive step. But as I mentioned in my opening statement, we have other concerns, and one such concern, of course, is the abduction issue. Well, the North Korean declaration on their nuclear pro-grams—well, when you think about the abduction issue, I think the suggestion of your question—what you were suggesting is that we should seek U.S. to rescind that decision. Well, as far as nuclear issue is concerned, well, we have moved on to a new phase. And I think we need to make sure this will be successful because it will be in the interest of Japan as well. At the same time, in parallel, we need to bring the abduction issue to successful conclusion as well.So against this backdrop of progress in the nuclear front, we need to also strive for progress on the abduction front as well. And to that end, we need to have good-faith discussions with North Korea. And so far, we have not seen any progress, but we need to engage in negotiations so that progress will be produced. Because abduction is not progressing, on the nuclear front we should not make progress—that is something we should not—we should avoid. And I believe we need to make progress on both fronts, because that will be important for Japan, and I think that will be necessary for North Korea as well.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Your Cabinet nominees are overwhelmingly male. South Korea consistently ranks low among developed countries on professional advancement of women. And you, yourself, during your Presidential campaign, proposed abolishing the Ministry of Gender Equality.What role should a leading world economy like South Korea play in improving the representation and advancement of women? And what will you and your administration do to improve the state of gender equality in this country? [SEP] If you look at the public officials sector, especially the Ministers in the Cabinet, we really didn't see a lot of women advancing to that position thus far. Probably in various regions, equal opportunities were not fully ensured for women. And we have actually a quite short history of ensuring that. So what we're trying to do is to very actively ensure such opportunities for women.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, are you concerned that differing state laws on certain issues might evoke comparisons to the era of segregation? [SEP] Well, Chuck, I think what we're seeing is a growing understanding that everyone deserves equal treatment. People are realizing that our LGBTQ+ friends, family, and neighbors are just like everyone else, and they should be treated that way. I believe that principle will ultimately prevail. It won't be a smooth ride, and as President, I can't dictate every detail. But I'm confident that we're moving towards greater equality, and that's a positive thing. Next question.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the memo from your National Security Advisor regarding a potential rift between Prime Minister Maliki and Muqtada Al Sadr, is this indeed the official US policy? And, did you bring this up with the Prime Minister earlier today? Prime Minister, it's been suggested that your alliance with Mr. Al Sadr is a major obstacle in Iraq. Did you promise the President you'd cut ties with Al Sadr, and could your government survive such a move? [SEP] I'll let the Prime Minister address his relationship with Al Sadr directly. We spent considerable time discussing the security situation in Iraq. I voiced my concerns, and he shared his own – after all, ensuring the safety of the Iraqi people is his top priority. The Prime Minister is frustrated by the lack of resources to deal with those who break the law. I was encouraged by his commitment to a pluralistic, politically unified society where people are held accountable for their actions, be they criminals, Al Qaeda, or militia members. He discussed his political situation with me, and I think he's the best person to speak about the Sadr group or any other group within Iraq. Our coalition isn't limited to one entity. The national unity government is made up of all participating entities, representing a shared national responsibility. Mr. Sadr and the Sadrists are just one part of the Parliament and Government. Participation in the Government is a responsibility, a mutual commitment, and those involved must uphold the Government, the Constitution, and the law. I'm focused on the state, the law, and the commitments that apply to all partners in the Government. We'll deal with lawbreakers equally, because the most important principle is the sovereignty and power of the state.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, given the outreach to the Indian American community during the conventions, and the potential for your family to campaign on your behalf, what are your thoughts on the current state of the U.S.-India relationship? [SEP] To be frank, I didn't follow every detail of your question. Nevertheless, I'm well-acquainted with India, and the young individuals you mentioned are quite impressive. Their connection to India is substantial, as is mine. Prime Minister Modi is a friend, and he's doing a commendable job under difficult circumstances. On a related note, the situation on the border between China and India is rather tense. We're prepared to offer assistance if needed and are in dialogue with both countries. I appreciate your kind remarks. My family and I have a deep appreciation for India, and I hold your Prime Minister in high esteem. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Have you seen evidence of an acceleration, though? [SEP] You know, I'm not going to talk about any intelligence that I've seen, one way or the other. But I do want you to know how seriously we take the ian nuclear issue. As a matter of fact, it is the cornerstone of our ian policy. It is—and that's why we spend a lot of time in working with friends, allies, concerned people to rally international support, to make it clear to the ian people that there is a better option for them.Now, we have no problem, no beef with the ian people. We value their history; we value their traditions. But their government is making some choices that will continue to isolate them and deprive them of a better economic future. So we take the issue very seriously.Ken Herman [Cox News].
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Given your administration's stance, Mr. President, isn't your messaging—in suggesting that these children are and will be allowed to stay in this country—effectively encouraging families like Yossell's to come? [SEP] The suggestion that I would ever let a child starve at the border is preposterous. Only Trump would do that. My administration is focused on addressing the root causes of migration. We're working with leaders in Honduras, Guatemala, and El Salvador to address issues like violence, poverty, and natural disasters. We're investing in programs to improve conditions on the ground, so families don't feel they have no choice but to send their children on this dangerous journey.
label: Deflection

sentence: President, regarding the situation in Xinjiang, where the Chinese Communist Party is accused of using slave labor, your administration has placed a partial ban on certain products originating from the region, but not a complete ban. What's your response to the CCP's assertion that these claims are fabricated and that there is no forced labor in Xinjiang? Also, have any of our allies indicated a willingness to collaborate with us in addressing the alleged forced labor imposed by the CCP? [SEP] Absolutely, we are not going to stand for that. We have been very vocal about it. We are getting information as we speak. In the next few days, we will have a much better understanding of the situation, and we will then determine what actions need to be taken. Next question. World Trade Organization/-U.S. Trade
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, do you support a congressional inquiry into the release of the Lockerbie bomber, and Prime Minister Cameron, will your government launch its own investigation? [SEP] Let me begin. We were all surprised and upset about the release. We welcome any information that sheds light on the decision. I support Prime Minister Cameron's efforts to understand what happened. The important thing is that we disagreed with the release. It was a mistake. We have a strong partnership with the UK in fighting terrorism, and we must continue that cooperation. Regarding an inquiry, the Scottish Parliament has already conducted one. We'll see if further information needs to be released. We'll cooperate with the congressional hearing.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. No worries. Do you believe the country's slowdown and growth could risk destabilizing the global economy or cause China to be more aggressive defensively, including with Taiwan?And separately, sir, are you worried about the meeting between President Putin and Kim Jong Un, if that could mean Russia has more gains in the war in Ukraine? [SEP] Look, I think China has a difficult economic problem right now for a whole range of reasons that relate to the international growth and lack thereof and the policies that China has followed.And so I don't think it's going to cause China to invade Taiwan. And matter of fact, the opposite: It probably doesn't have the same capacity that it had before.But as I said, I'm notwe're not looking to hurt China, sincerely. We're all better off if China does well, if China does well by the international rules. It grows the economy.But they have had some real difficulty in terms of their economy of late, particularly in real estate. Asidethat end of their bargain. And I think the actions that they're going to have to take are ones that arethey're in the process of deciding right now. And I'm not going to predict what way it will come out. But we're not looking to decouple from China.What I'm not going to do is, I'm not going to sell China material that would enhance their capacity to make more nuclear weapons, to engage in defense activities that are contrary to what is viewed as most people would think was a positive development in the region.Andbut we're not trying to hurt China.Okay. Let'sBBC. Laura. Am I correct? Is that correctLaura?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the situation with Russia and Ukraine, back in June you expressed the belief that President Putin didn't desire a cold war. However, we've since witnessed a significant build-up of Russian troops near Ukraine, cyber attacks, and demands for a sphere of influence that would require the withdrawal of American forces from the former Soviet bloc. Do you still hold the same view of President Putin's intentions, and if not, how would you respond to a potential invasion? [SEP] Well, let me put it this way. I still believe a full-blown war isn't what he's after, but make no mistake, he'll test the resolve of the West, especially the US and NATO. However, he'll face consequences he hasn't fully considered. As for his motivations, he's grappling with what he sees as the tragedy of Russia – the fall of the Berlin Wall, the loss of empire. He's got vast resources, but he's trying to find his place between China and the West. Frankly, I'm not entirely sure he knows what he'll do. My hunch is he'll make a move. He feels he has to. He wants guarantees: no NATO membership for Ukraine and no strategic weapons stationed there. We might find common ground on the latter, depending on his actions. As for the former, international treaties suggest Ukraine has the right to choose its alliances, but NATO membership isn't likely in the near future anyway. So, there's room for negotiation, but I probably shouldn't say any more.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. To follow up on what you were saying about the shutdown, sir, are you saying that you would be willing to shut the Government down in September if it does not fully fund $25 billion worth of your border wall and also deliver all of the immigration priorities that you listed in your tweet? Or are you leaving some room for negotiation there? [SEP] I'll always leave room for negotiation. But this has been many years; this isn't just Trump administration. We're new. This has been many years, even decades. We have immigration laws. We have border security. We have all sorts of things going on that are—it's disgraceful. We are doing a phenomenal job. We're setting records. But we have laws that don't work. So we're working around those laws, and it's unfortunate.I have to take my hat off to the Border Patrols, for the law enforcement, to ICE, which really has been maligned by the Democrats. The job they do, they go into these MS-13 nests, nests of bad, bad people, killers, in many cases. And they go in there fearless, and they do an incredible job. And they get them out. They either go to jail, or they get out of the country. So I want to just take my hat off to ICE and the brave people that have really been maligned by the Democrats.We need border security. Without a border, as this gentleman can tell you also—because the Prime Minister really was—it was a very big factor in his win and other people's win in Italy—but it was a big factor in my win. We need border security. Border security includes the wall, but it includes many other things. We have to end the lottery. We have to end the chain. The chain is like a disaster. You bring one person in, and you end up with 32 people. We have to end these horrible catch-and-relief—release principles, where you catch somebody, you take their name, and you release them. You don't even know who they are. And then, they're supposed to come back to a court case, where they want us to hire thousands of judges. The whole thing is ridiculous. And we have to change our laws, and we do that through Congress.So I would certainly be willing to close it down to get it done. As you know, we are already approving things in various bills, including, we're going to be taking care of the military. We always put the military and law enforcement very high. But I would be certainly willing to consider a shutdown if we don't get proper border security. Thank you.Please.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, the Tucano aircraft are vital for Nigeria's security. Can we anticipate the delivery of a couple before 2020? Furthermore, when might we expect you to visit Nigeria? [SEP] Nigeria is a truly remarkable country, known for its exceptional beauty. I would very much like to visit. Regarding the first part of your question, I didn't quite understand. Could you please repeat it?
label: Clarification

sentence: In your opinion, will the issue of school reopenings and closures play a significant role in the Republican Party's strategy to reclaim suburban districts in the midterm elections? [SEP] That's a possibility, but I'm hopeful that voters are becoming more discerning about the agendas of political actors. Their priorities are their families, their jobs, and their well-being. They're less susceptible to sensationalized narratives. Historically, many presidents have seen similar polling numbers at this stage of their presidencies. The public is actively engaged in separating fact from fiction. Their choice of news sources significantly influences their beliefs. Cable news is experiencing a decline in viewership. The way news is reported and consumed has undergone a dramatic transformation due to the internet and the rise of self-selected perspectives. The media landscape has fundamentally shifted.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the unauthorized disclosure of the Hadley memo, did you, or anyone under your direction, initiate an inquiry before your discussion with Prime Minister al-Maliki? And if not sanctioned, do you believe someone within your administration is actively working against your Iraq strategy or attempting to derail your meeting with the Prime Minister? [SEP] I'm trying to recall if I specifically ordered an investigation. The details are a bit hazy. What I do recall is expressing my strong disapproval of the constant flow of leaks. The press is always digging for information, and that's their job, but I can't condone the leaking of classified material. It's a persistent problem, not unique to this administration, but one that any administration faces when trying to enact policy. We've had many leaks, some from sources I can't even identify, so I won't engage in speculation. Finding the leaker is notoriously difficult, which is an advantage you have in your line of work. We can complain about it, but it's tough to pinpoint those within the government who are willing to leak sensitive documents, like Hadley's. There could be an investigation underway; I honestly don't know for sure. If there is, and I was briefed, it's not something I'm actively thinking about. But I do believe that it's important to find and hold accountable anyone within our government who is leaking classified information, which is against the law. The best way to prevent leaks is to ensure there are real consequences for those who do it.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the allegations in the New Yorker regarding the Red Cross report and the CIA's interrogation tactics at Guantanamo, could you share your perspective on those findings? Furthermore, regarding your commitment to closing Guantanamo, despite your initial pledge, progress appears to be limited, allegedly due to internal opposition. Could you clarify who is ultimately responsible for this decision? Are you actively pursuing the closure, and do you anticipate its completion before the end of your term? [SEP] The closure of Guantanamo, while a stated objective, presents considerable logistical and diplomatic challenges. A primary obstacle is securing the cooperation of other nations in accepting the repatriation of detainees. The recent Senate vote, reflecting widespread reluctance to house these individuals domestically, underscores the complexity of this issue. To suggest that no progress has been made is inaccurate. We are actively engaged in negotiations with foreign governments to facilitate repatriation, while also ensuring humane treatment upon their return. Furthermore, the establishment of fair and transparent trial procedures is paramount. We are collaborating with the judiciary and the Department of Defense to expedite these proceedings. While I remain committed to the objective of closing Guantanamo, its ultimate realization is contingent upon overcoming these significant obstacles. The Senate's position, as evidenced by their recent vote, highlights the practical difficulties involved. And your subsequent inquiry, sir?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. And today, Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlüt Çavuşoğlu said Turkey wants Patriot air defense system from the United States. Are you in talk with Turkish Government regarding this topic? [SEP] We're speaking to President Erdogan a lot, and we are talking to him about exactly what you're referring to.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, Rick Ledgett's suggestion of amnesty for Edward Snowden has sparked debate. What was your reaction to this proposal? Under what conditions would you consider a plea agreement or amnesty? And how do you respond to Americans who believe Snowden's actions were justified in exposing the scope of government surveillance? [SEP] I must tread carefully here, as Mr. Snowden faces indictment and criminal charges. This matter falls under the purview of the Attorney General, a judge, and a jury. Therefore, I cannot offer specific commentary on the case at this juncture. However, I will attempt to address the underlying spirit of the question. I have previously stated that this is a necessary conversation. I have also stated that the manner of these disclosures has harmed the United States and our intelligence capabilities. There was a way to have this debate without causing such damage. For example, the United States, despite its imperfections, adheres to the rule of law, values privacy and civil liberties, and respects our Constitution. As a result of these disclosures, countries that explicitly engage in the very actions Mr. Snowden claims to be concerned about—surveillance of their own citizens, targeting political dissidents, suppressing the press—are able to criticize the United States for its surveillance and intelligence operations. This is a distorted view. While this debate is important and necessary, it is crucial to remember that it has caused unnecessary damage to U.S. intelligence capabilities and diplomacy. I will defer to the courts and the Attorney General to publicly address the specifics of Mr. Snowden's case.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Do you still have confidence in Secretary Azar? [SEP] I wish everyone well. Who are we talking about again?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, considering the growing concerns about Iran's nuclear program, what is your reaction to the emerging debate in Israel regarding a potential military option, and what steps are being taken to address the underlying security concerns in the region? [SEP] If you were living in Israel, you'd be pretty nervous right now. You've got a leader in the region who's openly talking about destroying your country. And a nuclear weapon would certainly help him do that. So, we need to stop them. There's a real sense of urgency, and we're working hard to find a solution. And I believe we can also achieve a global agreement on climate change. It's a must.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, I'd like your perspective on the proposed construction of a mosque near Ground Zero. While the organizers have a constitutional right to build, what message would it send if they were dissuaded from doing so? Also, has the Florida minister's threat to burn Korans endangered American lives? [SEP] On your second point, it's undeniable that deliberately provoking the passions of over a billion Muslims worldwide, especially when our troops are stationed in many Muslim countries, creates a problem. It complicates the already challenging task of our men and women in uniform. Regarding the mosque in New York, I've stated my position clearly: this nation upholds the principle that all individuals are created equal and possess inalienable rights, including the freedom of religious practice. If a church, synagogue, or Hindu temple can be built on a site, so should a mosque. I acknowledge the extreme sensitivities surrounding 9/11. I've met with families of 9/11 victims and understand their enduring pain and loss. But we are not at war with Islam. We are at war with terrorist organizations that distort Islam or misuse its name for destructive purposes. We must be clear about this, because to effectively combat terrorism, we need allies. Al Qaeda seeks a war between the West and Islam. Fortunately, most Muslims are peace-loving and share our aspirations: good jobs, education for their children, safety, and improved lives. They reject violent ideology. From a national security standpoint, we must identify the true enemy: a small minority engaged in horrific acts, primarily targeting Muslims. We also have millions of Muslim Americans, our fellow citizens, who are our neighbors, friends, and coworkers. When we suggest their religion is offensive, what message do we send them? Muslims serve in our armed forces in Afghanistan, risking their lives for us. We must affirm that they are Americans and honor their service, ensuring they understand we don't differentiate between them and us. That's a vital principle to uphold.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, thank you. The communique states in no uncertain terms that all of the unprecedented cooperation for which you're calling will be done on a voluntary basis, not a binding commitment. What's the likelihood that countries which have been at odds over these issues for a number of years are now going to cooperate? How can this be enforced? [SEP] Well, let's just take a specific example, Bill. For about 10 years, we had been encouraging Ukraine to either ship out its highly enriched uranium or transform it to a lower grade--a lower enriched uranium. And in part because of this conference, Ukraine took that step, announced that it would complete this step over the next couple of years.So all the commitments that we talked about are ones that we've already booked, even before the communique and the work plan gets put into place. And that indicates the degree to which I think that there's actually strong unanimity about the importance of this issue as a threat to the global and international community.Now, keep in mind that we also have a number of international conventions that have been put in place. Not all of them have been ratified. In fact, the United States needs to work on a couple of these conventions dealing with the issues of nuclear terrorism and trafficking. But what this does is it sets out a bold plan. And what I'm encouraged about is the fact that we've already seen efforts that had been delayed for years--in some cases, since the end of the cold war--actually finally coming to fruition here at this summit.
label: General

sentence: Concerning the possibility of a White House meeting with Barbara Lagoa, can you confirm whether such a meeting is planned? [SEP] Excuse me, I didn't quite catch that. Could you speak up?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning your remarks at the fundraiser, did labeling President Xi a dictator negatively impact your administration's efforts to maintain a stable relationship with China? And secondly, regarding India, what do you say to those who argue that your administration is turning a blind eye to the persecution of religious minorities in Prime Minister Modi's India? [SEP] The answer to your initial inquiry is no. When communicating with our allies and partners, including India, the idea that I would self-censor or avoid expressing my honest assessment of the situation with China is simply not something I'm prepared to do. I maintain that the alarm surrounding our relationship with China is largely exaggerated. We encountered an incident that generated some uncertainty, to put it mildly. However, Secretary Blinken's visit to China was successful, and I anticipate meeting with President Xi in the not-too-distant future. I don't believe my comments have had any material effect. And could you please restate your second question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Diplomacy: Can you define what you mean? And former President Obama warned the incoming President Trump that North Korea was the top foreign policy issue that he was watching. Is that how you assess the crisis in North Korea? [SEP] Yes.Okay. Hang on a second here. Kristen.Nancy [Nancy Cordes, CBS News], CBS.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you. Is that on? There. What is your current view on Brexit, sir? Should Britain leave the European Union if there is no agreement by October 31?And for the Prime Minister, what would be the ramifications for the U.K. if there is not a deal? [SEP] Well, I don't like to take positions in things that I'm not, you know, really—I understand the issue very well. I really predicted what was going to happen. Some of you remember that prediction. It was a strong prediction, made at a certain location, on a development we were opening the day before it happened. And I thought it was going to happen because of immigration more than anything else, but probably, it happens for a lot of reasons.But I would say, yes, I would think that it will happen and it probably should happen. This is a great, great country, and it wants its own identity. It wants to have its own borders. It wants to run its own affairs. This is a very, very special place. And I think it deserves a special place. And I thought maybe for that reason—and for others—but that reason, it was going to happen.Yes, I think it will happen, and I believe the Prime Minister has brought it to a very good point where something will take place in the not-too-distant future. I think she's done a very good job. I believe it would be good for the country, yes.. And from my point of view, I believe it is important for us to deliver Brexit. We gave that choice to the British people. Parliament overwhelmingly gave the choice to the British people. We should now deliver on that choice. I continue to believe that, actually, it's in the best interests of the U.K. to leave the European Union in an orderly way with a deal. I think we have a good deal. Sadly, the Labour Party and other MPs have, so far, stopped us from delivering Brexit and that deal.But we will—but obviously, this is an issue that is going to continue here in the U.K. I think the important thing is we deliver Brexit. And once we're out of the European Union, we will be able to do what we've been talking about today and develop not just that free trade agreement, but a broader economic partnership into the future.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, given that Mr. Howard has made climate change a central theme of the APEC meeting, and considering your parallel meeting in Washington, could you elaborate on how these efforts align? Additionally, what is your perspective on the significance of ratifying the Kyoto Protocol in the context of addressing climate change? [SEP] Alright, let's break this down. Regarding Kyoto, it simply wasn't the right fit for the United States. The Senate made that abundantly clear. We're taking a different approach, one focused on energy efficiency and new technologies. And we've actually reduced greenhouse gases while growing our economy. Now, as for John's efforts, I fully support addressing climate change, but it requires a global solution. We need to involve everyone, including countries like China and India. We can't just impose solutions; we need collaboration. And John's idea of reducing tariffs on clean technologies is a smart one. We need to get these technologies to developing nations. Our strategy is the most effective way to deal with this issue in a serious way. I commend John for his leadership on this.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, is this your final offer, or are you prepared to concede more ground in these negotiations? [SEP] This is a balanced package, no question. We've made real cuts in spending, difficult choices across the board. By any measure, even Republican ones, this is a substantial deficit reduction, the largest in two decades. Add to that increased revenue from the wealthy paying a little more, and we stabilize the debt for ten years. Now, the Speaker wants to protect tax cuts for the wealthy, raise taxes on the middle class, and avoid any cuts. That's illogical. They're considering raising taxes on millionaires, which they say they don't want to do, while rejecting spending cuts they supposedly support. It makes no sense. Anyone objective would see this as a balanced plan. It's time to get it done. The country needs stability, focus, compromise. This is a critical test.
label: General

sentence: Just to be absolutely clear, you're saying that climate considerations weren't essential for your endorsement? [SEP] I must confess, I didn't follow that line of questioning. Could you rephrase it?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, the war in Iraq has lasted almost as long as World War II for the United States. And as you mentioned, October was the deadliest month for American forces this year—in a year. Do you think we're winning, and why? [SEP] First of all, this is a different kind of war than a war against the fascists in World War II. We were facing a nation-state—two nation-states—three nation-states in World War II. We were able to find an enemy by locating its ships or aircraft or soldiers on the ground. This is a war against extremists and radicals who kill innocent people to achieve political objectives. It has a multiple of fronts.Afghanistan was a front in this war against the terrorists. Iraq is now the central front in the war against the terrorists. This war is more than just finding people and bringing them to justice. This war is an ideological conflict between a radical ideology that can't stand freedom and moderate, reasonable people that hope to live in a peaceful society.And so it's going to take a long time, Terry. I am confident we will succeed. I am confident we'll succeed in Iraq, and the reason I'm confident we'll succeed in Iraq is because the Iraqis want to succeed in Iraq. The ultimate victory in Iraq, which is a government that can sustain itself, govern itself, and defend itself, depends upon the Iraqi citizens and the doing the hard work necessary to protect their country. And our job is to help them achieve that objective. As a matter of fact, my view is, the only way we lose in Iraq is if we leave before the job is done.And I'm confident we can succeed in the broader war on terror, this ideological conflict. I'm confident because I believe the power of liberty will defeat the ideology of hate every time, if given a chance. I believe that the radicals represent the few in the Middle East. I believe the majority of people want to live in a peaceful world. That's what I believe.And I know it's incumbent upon our Government and others who enjoy the blessings of liberty to help those moderates succeed, because otherwise, we're looking at the potential of this kind of world: a world in which radical forms of Islam compete for power; a world in which moderate governments get toppled by people willing to murder the innocent; a world in which oil reserves are controlled by radicals in order to extract blackmail from the West; a world in which Iran has a nuclear weapon. And if that were to occur, people would look back at this day and age and say, What happened to those people in 2006? How come they couldn't see the threat to a future generation of people?Defeat will only come if the United States becomes isolationist and refuses to, one, protect ourselves, and two, help those who desire to become—to live in a moderate, peaceful world. And it's a hard struggle, no question about it. And it's a different struggle.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the recent midterm results, which many see as a rebuke of your policies, will you reconsider your agenda and how you engage with the Republican Party? [SEP] The American people have made it clear that Washington isn't working for them, and as President, I'm accountable. I represent all Americans and must bridge the divides. My focus is on achieving results and collaborating with Congress. On issues like the minimum wage, voters have shown their support. The key is finding areas of overlap with Republican ideas. While we won't agree on everything, there are areas like infrastructure and exports where we can find common ground. I'm committed to listening to Republicans and finding areas where we agree, even if it's not 100%. Building trust and improving Washington's processes will restore the American people's faith in their government.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: So, Mr. President, do you have confidence in Secretary Azar? [SEP] I wish him well. In who now?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. I'm back here. Thank you, Mr. President. One of the noneconomic issues you covered here was Afghanistan. And I'm curious whether you believe that the talks that Pakistan is reportedly brokering between the Taliban and President Karzai of Afghanistan hold promise, or do they concern you? And a related question--not a second question--[Laughter]--is, do you agree with the new Prime Minister of Great Britain, David Cameron--David, to you--that the--we can be totally out of Afghanistan by 2015 and turn the lights off? [SEP] I'm not sure that's a quote from David, but I'll take the second question first. We have been in Afghanistan now for 9 years. Next year, we will have been there for a decade. This is now America's longest war. And what that means is that all of us have an interest not in occupying Afghanistan, but an interest in making sure Afghanistan is stable, can stand on its own two feet when it comes to security issues, and is not a base for terrorist activities launched against the United States of America.Now, I think that we're going to need to provide assistance to Afghanistan for a long time to come. They are still building up a national government. They are in a very tough neighborhood. They are a very poor country. So on a whole range of issues--from economic, development, setting up courts, setting up effective police forces, a political system that is transparent and fair, as well as with respect to security--we intend to be a partner with Afghanistan over the long term. But that is different from us having troops on the ground.Now, I've been clear about the policy that we're pursuing. It was announced last November, and we're several months into it. The policy involves us sending in additional troops--we already had approximately 68,000; we put in an additional 30,000--with the intent of providing the Afghan Government the space and the time to build up its security forces, for us to be able to help blunt the momentum of the Taliban, to clear some of the areas in which the Taliban had gotten a very fierce foothold, to start moving Afghan security forces in, even as we are improving governance and we're improving the legitimacy and credibility of the civilian Government.That is the policy that General McChrystal was pursuing. That is the policy that General Petraeus is pursuing. That is the policy that all of our ISAF allies have fully endorsed, as has President Karzai.Now, it's tough. It is a tough challenge, for reasons that have been amply recorded. As I said, this is a--this is the third poorest country in the world. It has an extraordinarily high illiteracy rate. It has suffered through 30 years of war. And so this is going to be tough. But what I expect is that by the end of this year, we will have seen progress on the strategy that was laid out. We will conduct a full review. Those things that are not working, we will fix. Those things that are working, we will build on, both on the civilian side and on the military side, as well as on the diplomatic side. Because ultimately, as is true in--as was true in Iraq, so will be true in Afghanistan: We're going to have to have a political solution, not simply a military solution.Now, with respect to the negotiations and efforts at reintegration, I think it's too early to tell. I think that we have to view these efforts with skepticism, but also openness. The Taliban is a blend of hardcore ideologues, tribal leaders, kids that basically sign up because it's the best job available to them. Not all of them are going to be thinking the same way about the Afghan Government, about the future of Afghanistan. And so we're going to have to sort through how these talks take place. But I think that President Karzai's peace jirga was a useful step. He's going to be having a Kabul conference that I think will be a useful step in this direction.I think that conversations between the Afghan Government and the Pakistani Government, building trust between those two Governments is a useful step. I think to the extent that we can get all the regional players to recognize that it is in everybody's interests that this region between Pakistan and Afghanistan are not used to launch terrorist attacks, that will be a useful step. And that's what we're moving towards.Peter Maer [CBS Radio].
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. And also, did you touch on Afghanistan and the safe withdrawal of troops? [SEP] Yes. Yes, yes, and yes. Let me go back to the first part.The reason it didn't go longer is: When is the last time two heads of state have spent over 2 hours in direct conversation across a table, going into excruciating detail? You may know of a time; I don't. I can't think of one.So we didn't need, as we got through, when we brought in the larger group—our defense, our intelligence, and our foreign—well, our—my Foreign Minister—wasn't the Foreign Minister—my Secretary of State was with me the whole time—our Ambassador, et cetera. We brought everybody in. We had covered so much.And so there was a summary done by him and by me of what we covered. Lavrov and Blinken talked about what we had covered. We raised things that required more amplification or made sure we didn't have any misunderstandings. And so it was, kind of—after 2 hours, there, we looked at each other like, Okay, what next?What is going to happen next is, we're going to be able to look back—look ahead in 3 to 6 months, and say: Did the things we agreed to sit down and try to work out, did it work? Do we—are we closer to a major strategic stability talks and progress? Are we further along in terms of—and go down the line. That's going to be the test.I'm not sitting here saying because the President and I agreed that we would do these things, that all of a sudden, it's going to work. I'm not saying that. What I'm saying is, I think there's a genuine prospect to significantly improve the relations between our two countries without us giving up a single, solitary thing based on principle and/or values.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Obama, did President Trump's stance on climate change and Russia alleviate any of your concerns? Are you worried about the future of European policy toward Russia? And will you announce your candidacy after the election? [SEP] Well, I've always believed in respecting the political processes of other nations, so I won't comment directly on their internal affairs.
