I can say that Chancellor Merkel has been a remarkable partner. She's been a constant presence since I took office, and we've navigated many challenges together. While we haven't always agreed on everything, her commitment to core values, her integrity, and her dedication to the German people have been unwavering. It's her decision whether to run again, and ultimately, the German people will decide. As for Russia, my approach has always been consistent. They are a significant global player, and cooperation is essential for addressing many global challenges. However, we must also be realistic about our differences, particularly regarding democracy, human rights, and international law. I hope the incoming administration will find areas for cooperation while also standing firm on these principles. I'm encouraged by President-elect Trump's commitment to NATO. As for my conversations with President Putin, I've made it clear that we will not tolerate interference in our elections or cyberattacks on our institutions. We need to establish international norms in cyberspace to prevent a cyber arms race. Finally, I'm impressed by the smooth transition of power in the United States, which reflects our commitment to democratic principles. We will continue to cooperate with Germany, and I will approach my interactions with President-elect Trump with an open mind. From a European perspective, maintaining peace depends on respecting the territorial integrity and sovereignty of all nations. We must stand firm against any attempts to undermine this principle. We hope for political solutions, such as the Normandy process, in coordination with the United States. Russia is our neighbor, and we want a good relationship, but we must also address our differences. I will announce my candidacy at the appropriate time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding China's human rights record, critics point to increasing suppression of free speech and religious expression. While you've stated you discuss these issues with President Hu, many feel stronger action is needed. Beyond expressing your views, what concrete steps are you prepared to take to address China's treatment of its people? And President Lee, on North Korea, are you confident in their commitment to verifiable denuclearization, given past failures? [SEP] Look, I've been engaging with Chinese leadership for quite some time now, and my message has been consistent: a society flourishes when it embraces freedom of thought and belief. Suppressing these fundamental rights is a mistake, plain and simple. I reiterate this point in every discussion. My attendance at the Olympics is a demonstration of respect for the Chinese people, and to support our athletes. I want our team to bring home the gold, but it's also an opportunity to underscore our values. I've consistently voiced my concerns about religious freedom, long before the Olympics. Now, regarding the six-party talks, skepticism is understandable. North Korea's past behavior warrants caution. However, I commend President Bush's leadership in navigating this complex situation. Denuclearization remains our unwavering objective. We will remain patient, consistent, and committed to achieving verifiable progress. We must all work together to ensure North Korea fulfills its commitments. Regardless of their intentions, the other members of the six-party talks must remain focused on our goal. We may face setbacks, but our resolve will not waver.
label: General

sentence: Q. On the subject of Meng Wanzhou, will her case be subject to the same delays, or is there a chance the US could abandon the extradition? [SEP] I'm sorry, when did this happen? What are you referring to?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, Rick Ledgett suggested a conversation about amnesty for Edward Snowden. What's your reaction to this, and under what circumstances would you consider a plea agreement or amnesty? What do you say to Americans who believe Snowden acted justly in revealing surveillance practices? [SEP] I have to tread carefully here, as Mr. Snowden is under indictment and charged with crimes. This falls under the purview of the Attorney General and the courts. I can't comment on the specifics. However, I can address the broader issue. I've said before that this was a necessary conversation, even though the disclosures damaged the US and our intelligence capabilities. There was a way to have this debate without such damage. The US respects the rule of law, privacy, and civil liberties. Snowden's actions have allowed countries that actually engage in surveillance and target dissidents to criticize us. While the debate is important, it's crucial to remember the damage to US intelligence and diplomacy. I'll leave the specifics of Snowden's case to the courts.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. With Ghislaine Maxwell in custody, do you anticipate her naming powerful figures? You've spoken about Prince Andrew and Bill Clinton in the past. [SEP] I haven't really kept up with that story. I just hope she's doing okay, frankly. I've met her over the years, particularly in Palm Beach. I'm not familiar with the details regarding Prince Andrew. I'm just not aware. Who's next?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you have said that you have the Baker-Hamilton report; you also have the—you're waiting to hear from the Pentagon; you're waiting to hear from the State Department. This report was prepared by a bipartisan group, the only one you'll get. Secretary Baker has a special relationship with the family. Should this report not get extra consideration? Does it not carry more weight than any of the others? [SEP] That's an interesting question. It's certainly an important part of our deliberations, and it was certainly an important part of our discussions this morning. Some reports are issued and just gather dust. And truth of the matter is, a lot of reports in Washington are never read by anybody.To show you how important this one is, I read it, and our guest read it. The Prime Minister read a report prepared by a commission. And this is important. And there are some—I don't think Jim Baker and Lee Hamilton expect us to accept every recommendation. I expect them—I think—I know they expect us to consider every recommendation, Jim, that we ought to pay close attention to what they advise. And I told them yesterday at our meeting that we would pay close attention and would seriously consider every recommendation. We've discussed some of their recommendations here at this press conference. And we are—we will spend a lot of time on it.And I—and so you ask its relative importance. I'd call it a very important report and a very important part of our working to a new approach, a new way forward in Iraq.And I can't—I really do thank those citizens for taking time out of busy lives to spend time helping us look at different options. These are distinguished souls. They got plenty to do. They're busy people, and yet they took 9 months out. And they talked to a lot of people; they went to Iraq; they thought about it a lot. And it was a very considerate, important report. And I will take their recommendations very seriously. Strategy
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. So you think there should be more indictments as a part of this investigation? [SEP] Well, I think—just on what I read in your wonderful papers, I think—and see what, you know, just looking at the media—not even what I know. I think Comey is a disgrace to our country. I think Strzok—who just wrote a book, which is a total fake—is a disgrace. I think Page—Lisa Page, his lover—is a disgrace to our country. I think that when you look at McCabe, where his wife got $700,000 in campaign contributions from Hillary Clinton—right?And then Hillary Clinton is under investigation, and yet she paid the head of the FBI—one of the top people, but actually the head, because he took over for the other guy, who fortunately I fired. I made a good move when I fired. That was a smart move, because they were looking to take down this administration, duly elected administration. So I fired him. That was a great move when I fired him. Because maybe, if I didn't, I wouldn't be here talking to you as President.But when McCabe's wife gets $700,000 in campaign contributions when she was running for whatever office she was running from—from Virginia—and yet he's in charge of the investigation of Hillary Clinton. Now, he says, Well, I wasn't really in charge. Of course, he was in charge. He was totally in charge. He knew exactly what was going on.These people got caught in the—probably the biggest political scandal in the history of our country. They got caught.Now, what the Durham report is going to say, I can't tell you. But if they say half as much as I already know—just from seeing it. You know, you have people—I watch some of the shows. I watch Liz McDonald; she's fantastic. I watched Fox Business. I watched Lou Dobbs last night, Sean Hannity last night, Tucker last night, Laura. I watched Fox and Friends in the morning. You watch these shows; you don't have to go too far into the details. They cover things that are—it's really an amazing thing.They got caught in the biggest political scandal in the history of our country. They were spying on their opponent's campaign. Not only spying; they were making up fake dossiers. You have the dirty dossier. They were making up the dirty—and it was all made up. It was all fiction. It turned out to be fiction. And then, they were using that in the FISA courts—this revered court. Well, it's not so revered anymore, because when you look at what they did and how they played it—and they hurt a lot of people.General Flynn is still being hurt, and he's being hurt very badly. He's a wonderful person. I spoke to General Milley about General Flynn 2 weeks ago. I said, What do you think of General Flynn? He said: He's a great soldier, sir. And he's a wonderful, wonderful human being. He's been destroyed. He's been destroyed. No, I think that this—without knowing anything about what Durham is going to release—the Durham report, we'll call it, or maybe it's going to be more than a report. Maybe it's going to be much more than a report, I don't know. Maybe it's a report or maybe it's much more than that.But when I look at the—the things that everybody in this room knows, just from reading about it from yourselves back and forth, I think it's a disgrace to our country. And I think if people don't pay a very, very substantial price, it will happen again. And this should never ever happen to another President.Thank you very much. Thank you, everybody.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the heated rhetoric on both sides regarding women's issues, do you believe, as your Democratic National Committee chair suggests, that Republicans are waging a 'war on women'? [SEP] I believe women are intelligent and will decide who best represents their interests. My marriage to Michelle taught me not to presume what she thinks. Women consider many issues, not just contraception or a single comment. They prioritize family security, economic stability, and their children's education. Democrats have a better plan for strengthening the middle class and ensuring opportunity for all. I don't see women as single-issue voters, and I believe we have a compelling message for them.
label: Deflection

sentence: Considering the recent Executive Actions, is it safe to say that the prospect of any further stimulus legislation has been shelved until after the election cycle? [SEP] We're already putting money in people's pockets with the $400 payments, and we're coordinating with Governors on potential contributions. Furthermore, we've enacted a substantial payroll tax cut, a major incentive for businesses to hire and for workers to get back on the job. The Democrats wouldn't even consider it. If I win, my plan is to eliminate the payroll tax completely and fund Social Security through the general fund. Biden would raise taxes and impose a mountain of new regulations, which would cripple the economy. We reduced regulations, and that's why we're seeing such a robust recovery.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the situation in Gaza, will the conflict be resolved before your term ends, and do you approve of Israel's actions? [SEP] Well, that's quite a loaded question, isn't it? I'm hoping for a sustainable cease-fire, which, let's be clear, means Hamas has to stop firing rockets into Israel. It's their choice, really. We're working with Egypt to stop the flow of weapons into Gaza, which is what allows Hamas to keep attacking. Countries supplying those weapons need to stop, and the international community needs to pressure them. Hamas needs to disarm if they're serious about a cease-fire. Neighboring countries need to stop the smuggling. It's tough, with the tunnels and all. Now, remind me, what was the second part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, you spoke of changing the tone in Washington, yet before the election, you accused Democrats of supporting terrorists. What's changed? And will your administration cooperate with potential Congressional oversight? [SEP] Well, the election's over, and the Democrats won, so now we're going to work together. As for the Democrats, they need to decide how they're going to operate. I'll be talking to their leadership soon about these issues.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, what specific actions have you threatened against Pakistan if they don't hand him over? [SEP] I'm not going to get into the specifics of our diplomatic conversations. What I will say is that we've made our position very clear, and we expect them to cooperate fully. It's a matter of national security.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And I wanted to ask about a specific example that a lot of people thought was a phony moment. As San Francisco DA, she oversaw, according to the Mercury News, 1,900 marijuana convictions. But she was asked in an interview last year if she had smoked marijuana, and she appeared to joke and, according to some people, lie, and say that she was listening to Snoop Dogg and Tupac, while—their music hadn't come out at the time, while she said she was smoking pot and listening to it. Why would she lie about that? Do you see that as more evidence? Is her past on marijuana a liability? [SEP] Well, she lied. I mean, she said things that were untrue. She is a person that's told many, many stories that weren't true. She's very big into raising taxes. She wants to slash funds for our military at a level that nobody has—can even believe. She is against fracking. Fracking is—she's against petroleum products. I mean, how do you do that and go into Pennsylvania or Ohio or Oklahoma or the great State of Texas? She is against fracking; fracking is a big deal.She is in favor of socialized medicine, where you're going to lose your doctors, you're going to lose your plans. She wants to take your health care plans away from 180 million Americans, 180 million Americans that are very happy with their health insurance. And she wants to take that away.So she was my number-one pick. I mean, she was—as they would say, because, hopefully, you'll start college football—she was my number-one draft pick. And we'll see how she works out.She did very, very poorly in the primaries, as you know. She was expected to do well, and she was—she ended up at right around 2 percent and spent a lot of money. She had a lot of things happening. And so I was a little surprised that he picked her. I've been watching her for a long time, and I was a little surprised.She was extraordinarily nasty to Kavanaugh—Judge Kavanaugh then, now Justice Kavanaugh. She was nasty to a level that was just a horrible thing. The way she was—the way she treated now-Justice Kavanaugh. And I won't forget that soon.So she did very poorly in the primaries, and now she's chosen. So let's see how that all works out.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Does this mean the war in Afghanistan is over? Is the Taliban in charge? And secondly, Congressman John Ratcliffe, why are you renominating him? [SEP] Well, he's a terrific man. He's been fantastic at everything he's done. He's highly respected. He wanted to wait until after the IG report came in, as you saw originally. I don't think he was officially or formally nominated. His name was thrown out. But he wanted to wait until after the IG report. The IG report has now come, and we've learned a lot of very bad things from the IG report, as you know very well.And I think he'll go through a process, and it will go fairly quickly. He's a very respected man, somebody that I've gotten that like; somebody who really has—he's someone who's really distinguished himself and, I think, over the last year and a half, 2 years, in particular. So we're very happy with that.As far as the Taliban is concerned, everybody wanted this to happen. The Taliban wanted it to happen. President Ghani was very much involved in this, as you know. And he's now dealing with the Taliban.But we're talking about 19 years we've been there. Nineteen years. And other Presidents have tried to do this. The Taliban has given a pledge—and a very strong pledge—and we'll see how that all works out. We hope it's going to work out very well. I think they have big incentives to do it, but they have to take care of the terrorists and kill the terrorists. We'll be working in a different kind of a fashion toward that end.But the job we've done has been fantastic—a fantastic one in terms of terrorists and terrorism, and it's time for our people to start coming home.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, intelligence agencies claim Russia is interfering to harm Joe Biden, and China might interfere to harm you. Do you believe this, and what's your plan? [SEP] It's a possibility, absolutely. But let me tell you, Russia would prefer anyone but Donald Trump in office. No one has been tougher on Russia than I have, ever. Nobody.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Obama, considering the TPP's apparent deadlock in Congress and other nations looking to the U.S. for leadership, are you contemplating a new strategy to secure its approval, especially given the recent Boeing and GE announcements? Should the agreement be amended to address concerns about currency manipulation? Also, your reaction to the killing of Taliban leader Mullah Mansur and Pakistan's concerns about the strike on their soil? Does this indicate a new offensive in Afghanistan, and are you worried about a more hardline leader emerging? [SEP] Well, on TPP, I’ve been around long enough to know that every trade deal is painful, because folks are always seeing if they can get an even better deal. And especially when you have multiple parties involved, folks are going to be scrutinizing it, they're going to be debating it, and in an election year, you can anticipate that some folks are going to try to score political points off it. Having said that, I remain confident we're going to get it done. And the reason I'm confident is because it's the right thing to do. It's good for the country. It's good for America. It's good for the region. It's good for the world. And I know I've sold this to you before, but let me reiterate: This is the fastest growing part of the world. This represents an enormous market for the United States. Most countries here already sell their stuff to the United States, and we have relatively low tariffs. In other words, we put relatively low taxes on goods that are coming into the United States. In contrast, tariffs are significantly higher for U.S. goods being sold here. So a deal that gets rid of 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods into the largest, fastest growing markets of the world, that's a good deal for American businesses and American workers. Number two, one of the biggest complaints about trade deals historically has been that it opens up our markets to countries with lower wages, harsher labor practices, less environmental regulations. Well, if you're signing up for the Trans-Pacific Partnership, you are making commitments that are enforceable to raise labor standards, to ensure that workers have a voice, to attend to environmental problems. And so this gives us the ability to engage with a country like Vietnam and work with them on all those fronts, the precise things that people, in the past, have been concerned about when it comes to trading with other countries. So I have not yet seen a credible argument that once we get TPP in place we're going to be worse off. We are demonstrably better off. American workers and American businesses are better off if we get this deal passed. And I'm confident we will get it passed. Now, the politics of it will be noisy. That was true when I, for example, inherited the Korean free trade agreement or the Colombian and Panamanian free trade agreements when I came into office. But we got them done. And I'm confident that we'll get them done this time, as well, although it will—there will be ups and downs and bumps along the way. With respect to currency manipulation, we have provisions in TPP that advance the transparency and reporting functions that allow us to monitor whether we think that currency manipulation is taking place. One of the debates that took place—and there have been some who argue that we should have enforceable provisions that if you see currency going down too far that we should be able to impose tariffs on that country. The problem is, is that it's very hard to sort out sometimes why currency is going down and whether it's actually being manipulated. And frankly, for us to bind other countries to commitments about their monetary policy would mean we were also binding our Federal Reserve to the claims of other countries in terms of how it implements our monetary policy, and that's not something that we would do. We would not give up sovereignty with respect to our monetary policy in that way. But we have strengthened a number of the provisions that are already contained in TPP that will allow us to put on notice folks who we think are engaging in competitive devaluations. Finally, on the Taliban leader, Mr. Mansur, it has been confirmed that he is dead. And he is an individual who, as head of the Taliban, was specifically targeting U.S. personnel and troops inside of Afghanistan who were there as part of the mission that I've set to be able to maintain a counterterrorism platform and provide assistance and training to the Afghan military forces there. So this does not represent a shift in our approach. We are not reentering the day-to-day combat operations that are currently being conducted by Afghan security forces. Our job is to help Afghanistan secure its own country, not to have our men and women in uniform engage in that fight for them. On the other hand, where we have a high-profile leader who has been consistently part of operations and plans to potentially harm U.S. personnel and who has been resistant to the kinds of peace talks and reconciliation that ultimately could bring an end to decades of war in Afghanistan, then it is my responsibility as Commander in Chief not to stand by, but to make sure that we send a clear signal to the Taliban and others that we're going to protect our people. And that's exactly the message that has been sent.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Hypothetically, if Putin were to step aside, would that constitute a victory in your eyes? [SEP] The priority is to ensure he no longer commands forces against the populace. He needs to relinquish his power; that's the bottom line.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Regarding the G-7 oil price cap, can you assure Americans it will reduce gasoline costs, and what's a reasonable timeframe for them to bear the financial burden of this war, without delving into the plan's specifics? [SEP] One moment, could you repeat the latter part of your question? Was it related to the price impact?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Obama, TPP faces congressional hurdles. Will you adjust your strategy, particularly with Boeing and GE deals? Should it address currency manipulation? Also, your thoughts on Mullah Mansur's death, Pakistan's concerns, a new Afghan offensive, and a more extreme Taliban leader? [SEP] Regarding TPP, every trade agreement is a challenge. Everyone seeks a better deal. With multiple parties involved, scrutiny is high. In an election year, some will try to score political points.However, I'm confident we'll succeed because it's the right thing to do. It benefits America, the region, and the world.This is the fastest-growing region. It's a huge market for the U.S. Most countries already sell to us with low tariffs. Conversely, tariffs are higher for U.S. goods sold there. A deal eliminating 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods in these markets is good for American businesses and workers.Historically, trade deals have been criticized for exposing our markets to countries with lower wages, poor labor practices, and weak environmental regulations. TPP requires enforceable commitments to raise labor standards, empower workers, and address environmental issues. This allows us to engage with countries like Vietnam and work on these concerns.I haven't seen a credible argument that TPP will make us worse off. We'll demonstrably benefit. American workers and businesses will gain if TPP passes. I'm confident it will.The politics will be noisy. This was true for the Korean, Colombian, and Panamanian free trade agreements I inherited. But we got them done. I'm confident we'll do it again, despite the challenges.Regarding currency manipulation, TPP includes transparency and reporting mechanisms to monitor it. Some argue for enforceable provisions allowing us to impose tariffs if currency is devalued too much. However, it's difficult to determine if devaluation is manipulation. Binding other countries on monetary policy would mean binding our Federal Reserve, which we won't do. We've strengthened provisions to address competitive devaluations.Finally, Mullah Mansur's death is confirmed. As Taliban leader, he targeted U.S. personnel in Afghanistan, who were there to maintain a counterterrorism platform and train Afghan forces. This doesn't change our approach. We're not re-entering combat operations. Our job is to help Afghanistan secure itself.However, when a high-profile leader consistently plans to harm U.S. personnel and resists peace talks, I must act to protect our people. That's the message we've sent.President Quang, let me address the Trans-Pacific Partnership. We view TPP as a significant economic link, driving economic growth in our country and the Asia-Pacific region. Vietnam's participation is a step in our international integration.President Ob. Mr. President, sorry to interrupt. We're not getting translation. Testing one, two, three.President Ob. For you? Can you hear, Mr. President?President Ob. Okay. Testing one, two, three.President Ob. It's just, I'm sure that he was saying something very wise and important, and we wanted to make sure that we all heard it.President ung. So I would like to add that Vietnam, together with other TPP countries, have been making efforts to narrow differences, to promote cooperation in the spirit of mutual understanding and mutual respect. And we will try to reduce differences in the spirit of constructiveness and understanding and paying attention to one another's legitimate interests. And the finalization of TPP is also the successful outcomes of all 12 members of the TPP, rather than any individual effort. And we are prepared to ratify TPP, and we stand ready to implement all the commitments under TPP.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, some say calling Xi a dictator undermines progress with China. Thoughts? And what's your message to those who think you're turning a blind eye to human rights issues in India? [SEP] Nah. Doesn't undermine anything. I'm not gonna sugarcoat things just because we're talking to allies like India. This whole China meltdown narrative is a bunch of hooey. We had a little bump in the road, but Blinken sorted it out. I'll be seeing Xi before you know it. Doesn't change a thing. Remind me of that second question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. And what do you say, Mr. President, to other companies who may look at this and say, I don't know if we're ready for all of this? [SEP] Well, I think, you know, we have a lot of people in the White House. And we had one. Basically, we had one person. So—and we had a lot of people that work here. This building is shocking, if you looked at the numbers. And it's also tremendous numbers of people coming in. Normally, you wouldn't do that. But because we're running a country, we want to keep our country running. So we have a lot of people coming in and out. Many of those people—most of those people are tested depending on what portion of the Oval Office area they're going in. Everybody coming into the President's office gets tested. And I've felt no vulnerability whatsoever, John.But the two people, as I said, and three people, are—they have been tested, and it's negative, and be probably out of quarantine very quickly. Okay?Jon [Jonathan Karl, ABC News]./ and Technology
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, the Romanian people, the Romanians have a great expectations with regards to the very good ties, political and economic, between the two states. In a very practical manner, they will ask, when will we have the same regime as the other citizens from the European Union with regards to the visas? Could we have a deadline for this when we could travel freely to the United States? [SEP] First of all, your President was very articulate on the subject of visas. One of the benefits of having a good friendship is that he's not afraid of telling me what's on his mind. [] And he made it abundantly clear that visa policy in America must take into account Romanian past and also Romanian future and present. In other words—and I fully understand the frustrations of the Romanian people. I understand it. I understand that a citizen says: Wait a minute. We're contributing soldiers in Iraq, and yet we're not necessarily treated like other nations in the European collective or European Union.And those frustrations are clearly understandable. That's why I went to Congress and tried to get them to modernize the visa law. And all they—although they changed the law, it still creates certain hurdles for nations like Romania. And I assured the President that we will work with him as best as we can to adhere to our law and to, at the same time, understands the contradictions.It's—hopefully, the new law will—and our cooperation—will make it easier for Romanian citizens to come and visit their relatives. And obviously, to the extent that somebody tries to come and not come back is something we all got to guard about. That's—but the idea of somebody coming to visit a relative or a long-lost cousin to say hello and to see what America is like and then come back to Romania is an issue that we just got to be thoughtful about.And so yes, I mean, this is—this subject came up. It is clear there's a level of frustration. I explained our new law is in effect, and we'll work closely with the Romanian Government to meet our law and, at the same time, meet the demands of a strong and good ally.Thank you. Thank you very much. Thank you very much. Right, you want to go over here? Just a moment. Oh, you got—— Just a moment. He's not through. The information would like to add to refer to two delicate issues, issues that are visible for the Romanian public. We have also approached— we have also addressed the visa issue and also the Teo Peter issue. And we hope to find, in time, the decision taken by President Bush was that, in the near future, we will launch the bilateral mechanism that—apart from the European ones. And referring to the other issue, to find as fast as possible a reasonable solution acceptable for the family of Teo Peter.Thank you. He's going to show me this wharf out here. []
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. One of your chief allies in the war on terrorism, President Musharraf of Pakistan, has faced so much instability and civil strife recently that there has been talk of declaring a state of emergency. How concerned are you about President Musharraf's situation and whether this might undermine Pakistani efforts against the Taliban and Al Qaida elements in the bordering areas of his country, which have been roundly criticized recently? [SEP] You know, I've seen the reports of what they call an emergency declaration. I have seen no such evidence that he's made that decision. In my discussions with President Musharraf, I have reminded him that we share a common enemy, extremists and radicals who would like to do harm to our respective societies. In his case, they would like to kill him, and they've tried.I have made it clear to him that I would expect there to be full cooperation in sharing intelligence, and I believe we've got good intelligence sharing. I have indicated to him that the American people would expect there to be swift action taken if there is actionable intelligence on high-value targets inside his country. Now, I recognize Pakistan is a sovereign nation, and that's important for Americans to recognize that. But it's also important for Americans to understand that he shares the same concern about radicals and extremists as I do and as the American people do.So my focus in terms of the domestic scene there is that he have a free and fair election. And that's what we have been talking to him about, and I'm hopeful they will.Yes, we'll just go down the line here. Yes, you.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, what's your strategy for resolving the situation in Crimea and removing Russian influence? [SEP] We'll see what happens. It's a process, a complex one. I can't reveal my strategy, that would be foolish. But we're monitoring it closely. Crimea, like North Korea, was a problem I inherited. We're making great progress with North Korea, as you know. No more nuclear tests, no missile launches. We even got our hostages back. Good things are happening. Crimea is a different situation, but we're looking at all options. It's going to take time, but I'm used to that.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, given the recent revelations, is it still feasible for Paul Wolfowitz to effectively lead the World Bank? [SEP] First, I believe everyone involved acted in good faith. I regret this situation. I admire Paul Wolfowitz, his dedication, and especially his focus on helping the poor. The board is meeting as we speak. All I can say is that Paul Wolfowitz wants what's best for the Bank and ensuring it focuses on human suffering and the human condition. I applaud his vision and respect him greatly. Again, I regret that it's come to this.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, after the UK's departure from the EU, which leader will you prioritize: Macron of France or Johnson of the UK? [SEP] Well, look, both France and the UK are important allies. France, under President Macron, is undergoing significant changes, and I respect his efforts to modernize the country. Boris, on the other hand, faces the challenge of navigating Brexit. The EU itself is a formidable entity, and we're working towards a fair trade agreement with them. Ultimately, our relationships will be based on mutual interests and what benefits the American people. It's about getting the best deal for America, plain and simple.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, you campaigned on reversing what you saw as executive overreach by your predecessor. Given the gridlock in Congress, do you feel compelled to use executive orders more frequently, even if it invites accusations of imperial presidency? [SEP] Look, my guiding principle is always the Constitution. I'm bound by the Constitution; I'm bound by separation of powers. I believe in working with Congress whenever possible, but when they fail to act on critical issues facing the American people, I have a responsibility to explore every legal avenue to deliver results. Congress has the power of the purse, for example. I would love to fund a large infrastructure proposal right now that would put millions of people to work and boost our GDP. We know we've got roads and bridges and airports and electrical grids that need to be rebuilt. But without the cooperation of Congress, what I can do is speed up the permitting process, for example.
label: Dodging

sentence: Regarding the reopening of the country, Mr. President, could you name some specific countries you've been studying and what metrics you're using to evaluate their success or failure? [SEP] Well, you know, we're looking at a lot of different places. I don't want to single anyone out, because, frankly, some of them are doing better than others. We're learning from everyone's experiences. We're seeing what works and what doesn't. We're taking all of that into account as we develop our own strategy. We're watching, we're learning, and we're adapting. We're going to do this the right way, and we're going to do it safely. We're going to open up this country in a smart and responsible manner.
label: General

sentence: Q. Is that—were you the one who required that, sir? [SEP] Yes, I did. I did. I required it. Yes.Please. Go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Bush, considering the challenges facing Africa, what key actions and leadership qualities are needed to transform the continent, and how can the U.S. best support this transformation? Also, what are your specific goals for this five-nation tour, and how will you ensure the continuity of your initiatives? [SEP] Thanks. I actually visited Africa early in my presidency as well. This is my second trip, and I'm here to remind everyone that it's in our interest to help African nations combat diseases like malaria and HIV/AIDS, promote trade, and invest in education. Ghana is a great place to highlight these efforts. It's one thing to give speeches in America, it's another to see the progress firsthand. Africa has changed positively since I became president, thanks to African leaders. We've seen conflict resolution, like in Liberia, where we helped install the first democratically elected female president. We're a partner, not an imposer. Democracy is also advancing, thanks to leaders like John Kufuor. Our aid program now demands accountability, like fighting corruption and investing in education. I believe in setting high standards for African leaders. The leaders I'm meeting are committed to their people and honest government. They prioritize education over self-serving agendas. That's why I'm here, and I'm glad I am. It's been a great trip. John McKinnon from the Wall Street Journal.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, could you elaborate on the specifics of the executive action and how it will be enforced given potential Republican opposition? And is the target still around 2 million people? [SEP] The specifics are still being finalized, but rest assured, the executive action will be robust. As for the numbers, those are still being evaluated. We'll have more to say on that soon enough.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, you sent your CIA Director to Pyongyang, but the three detained Americans weren't released, and there were no clear concessions from North Korea. Will you meet with Kim Jong Un if Americans are still held there? Will you demand concessions for gestures like sending a potential Secretary of State to North Korea? [SEP] Thank you. They do have three prisoners. We're discussing them, negotiating hard. They've been there a while, treated harshly. We fought to get Otto Warmbier back, but he was in terrible shape. A sad situation. We're working hard to get the three citizens back. I think we have a good chance. We're having good talks. We'll keep you updated. We've come far with North Korea. For years, they've talked, but nothing happened. Past administrations should have handled this. We put strong sanctions on. I thank President Xi of China, who's done more than any other leader for us. He's tightened the border. He didn't think he'd go this far, and I appreciate it. It's put pressure on them. 93% of North Korea's goods come from China. Xi knows this is important. He doesn't want a nuclear Korea. He's helping China too. He's been terrific. Can he do more? Always. But he's been good, and it's made a difference. We've never been in this position with that regime. I hope for a successful meeting. If it won't be successful, we won't have it. If it's not fruitful, I'll leave, and we'll continue what we're doing. I'm flexible. President Moon said the Olympics would have failed without me. Our involvement made it successful. Ticket sales were low before North Korea got involved. We've gotten this far, and I think we'll succeed. But if I don't think we will, we end it.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with the Kodak deal under scrutiny, and the SEC investigating, are you at all concerned about the optics of this situation, given your administration's push for this initiative? [SEP] Well, I'm not directly involved in the day-to-day. It's a good concept, a really good concept. But we'll have to see what comes out of the investigation. I'm sure everything will be fine, but we'll look into it.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. But you're not concerned about the ethics, that you're trying to boost your own brand? [SEP] No. Not at all. Go ahead, Jonathan.
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, regarding India, are you happy with the investment environment there, especially in sectors like retail and e-commerce where American companies are heavily involved? [SEP] I'm thrilled because they're pouring money in. Patel, the steel guy, is building a billion-dollar plant in Alabama. The press was there with some of the world's biggest business minds, and they all said the US is the place to be for investment. Steel was dead, now it's booming. We need it for our defense. Patel's investing a billion in Alabama because we made it happen. We're proud of that.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that creating a new agency is just a way to appease certain political interests and avoid addressing the fundamental issues with the existing regulatory structure. How do you respond to those accusations? [SEP] Well, those critics are entitled to their opinions, but they're simply wrong. This isn't about politics; it's about protecting the American people from another financial meltdown. We've seen what happens when regulators are asleep at the wheel, and we're not going to let that happen again. The new agency is a crucial part of a comprehensive plan to strengthen our financial system and prevent future crises. And I'm confident that when people see the details of the plan, they'll understand why this is such an important step.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with Congress requesting an additional $6 billion beyond your proposed budget, what is the upper limit of funding you are prepared to authorize to address the ongoing emergency? [SEP] We'll have to see, but we'll take care of the states. They're working hard, setting up hospitals and quarantine areas. We're working really well with them. It's a big part of it. So, if Congress wants to give us the money, we'll take it. It wasn't easy for the wall, but we got that one done. We'll just do a good job with it.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to Russia's announcement, some analysts suggest it's a ruse. What's your assessment of their intentions, and how are you advising our allies to interpret this development? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to speculate on their motives. What matters are their actions on the ground. We're consulting with our allies, maintaining a united front, and providing Ukraine with the resources they need to defend themselves. We'll know soon enough if this is a genuine shift or just a smokescreen.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Hello. A question from Agence France-Presse on behalf of the French press. As you arrived, Mr. President, you were saying that there was no plan B; that the Iran deal was to be preserved. Now you're talking about a new deal with Iran. Why do you change your mind? Did you join the strong approach suggested by President Trump? Is it because you could not convince him? And in addition, do you think the others who signed the agreement, the deal, will follow you? [SEP] When I said there was no plan B, I usually refer to the fact that there is no B planet. It was about climate rather than Iran. Rather—now, regarding Iran, I've always been coherent, and you can go back to what I said at the U.N. General Assembly in September. I always said that there was the JCPOA, but we needed to add three pillars: post-2025, the ballistic issue, and the regional influence. I do not know what will decide regarding the JCPOA, and it is his responsibility.The JCPOA is the first pillar of this framework I just described. So I'm not saying that we're moving from one deal to another. I'm saying it is one aspect of the problem. I haven't—have never been as critical of the JCPOA as has, because I believe that we can usefully add to it.But no matter the decision that will take, what I would like is to work, as from now, on a new deal with four pillars, including what is already covered by the JCPOA, that is ongoing nuclear—I mean, the current nuclear activities, the longer nuclear activities, the ballistic activities, and the regional influenceSo this is constant. But over the past few weeks and over—and in particular today, we've been able to go and to very much talk in details about this topic, including the situation in the region. And I believe that we've converged on a common reading of what is happening in Syria, in Yemen, in Iraq, in particular.And on the fact that the nuclear issue is not the only one, that indeed there is a problem with the ballistical activity of Iran and their presence in a number of countries in the region. And that our willingness was indeed to set the conditions for the stability of the region. Once we've built this convergence of view, the idea of moving on to a new deal that would include the solution for Syria, I believe, is a strong step forward thanks to the discussions we've had today.So I very much would like us to work together with all of our partners. And the Ministers of Foreign Affairs already gathered the small group, and they will be doing it again anytime soon. The purpose is to have some—the allied powers—and we amongst them—and of course, also the regional powers, to work at the level of this small group. We also shall have some privileged discussions with Russia and Turkey on regional topics, including Syria. So as from now, we will work using that method in favor—work towards a deal.I believe we can both combine our common views and our differences, because we are not in a vacuum. I always said we should not tear apart the JCPOA and have nothing else. I think this would be—that would not be the good solution. But once we are placing ourselves in a momentum, the purpose of which is to put together a broad agreement covering the four topics I just mentioned, it's very different because, first of all, we can take on board the concerns and the criticism of regarding this deal, which, like I said, once again, this deal was supported by a former American administration and previous American administration.But we can work, and it is also about respecting the sovereignty of the states of the region. It's not about intervening no matter what. It is rather about building a stable framework that will contribute to stability and to peacebuilding. And I think this is what we've been agreeing upon today. It's not about tearing about an agreement and have nothing, but it's about building something new that will cover all of our concerns. And if I might add, they—states and, as I alluded to—that—and countries that are in the area, some of which are immensely wealthy, would not be there except for the United States and, to a lesser extent, France. But they wouldn't be there except for the United States. They wouldn't last a week. We are protecting them. They have to now step up and pay for what's happening, because I don't think France or the United States should be liable for the tremendous cost.The United States is embarrassingly into the Middle East. As of a few months ago, as you've heard me say before—and I don't take responsibility, but I would be very embarrassed if I had to—$7 trillion. And when we want to build, Mr. President, our infrastructure, everybody says, Oh, we want to be careful with our money. When we want to fix a highway or we want to build schools and lots of other things—tunnels, bridges—they say, Oh, let's be careful with our money. And yet we have spent $7 trillion in the Middle East, and we've gotten nothing for it. Nothing. Less than nothing, as far as I'm concerned. That's over an 18-year period.The countries that are there, that you all know very well, are immensely wealthy; they're going to have to pay for this. And I think the President and I agree very much on that. And they will pay for it. They will pay for it. We've spoken to them. They will pay for it. The United States will not continue to pay. And they will also put soldiers on the ground, which they're not doing. And we will, in fact, bring lots of people home. We will have a strong blockage to the Mediterranean, which to me is very important—because if we don't, you have Iran going right to the Mediterranean. Not going to have that.But there is a chance—and nobody knows what I'm going to do on the 12th, although, Mr. President, you have a pretty good idea—but we'll see. But we'll see also, if I do what some people expect, whether or not it will be possible to do a new deal with solid foundations. Because this a deal with decayed foundations. It's a bad deal. It's a bad structure. It's falling down. Should have never, ever been made. I blame Congress. I blame a lot of people for it. But it should have never been made, and we're going to see what happens on the 12th.But I will say, if Iran threatens us in any way, they will pay a price like few countries have ever paid. Okay?Yes, John. Please. John Roberts of Fox./Senate Confirmation Process
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You put the Vice President in charge of coronavirus coordination across the Government. When he was Governor of Indiana, the Vice President allowed HIV outbreak to spiral out of control because he did not heed the advice of his public health professional advisers who said the needle exchange was necessary at the beginning of the outbreak.What guarantee can you give Americans that political considerations and ideological issues will play no role in your Government's response to this virus? [SEP] Well, let me just respond quickly, and then I'm going to have Mike say something about that, because I've heard very good explanations, actually.When it came to health care, Indiana has been a leader, an absolute leader. And it was really started with others, but by Mike Pence, and he's done a phenomenal job on health care. One of the best, if not the best, in the country.And with that, I'll let Mike respond specifically, if you want to. Sure. Thank you, Mr. President. When I was Governor of the State of Indiana, we actually had two experiences with the spread of infectious diseases. The first was in 2014, when Indiana was where the very first MERS case in the United States arrived. Obviously, an infectious disease much more deadly than the coronavirus that we're dealing with today.It was then, when I was Governor, that I learned of the extraordinary capabilities of CDC. I worked with my health officials in the State of Indiana. I worked with Federal officials and, maybe most importantly, learned the invaluable role that local health officials play in dealing with the spread of infectious disease.I'm proud to say that the State of Indiana secured that patient, found out everyone they'd ever contacted. There were no additional infections, and that patient recovered. There was only one other MERS disease.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Are you worried about the signal that it would send to Russia by doing this? [SEP] I think it sends a very strong signal to Russia. But I think a stronger signal sent to Russia is the fact that Germany is paying Russia billions of dollars to purchase energy from Russia, and—through the pipeline. And I'm saying, What's that all about? You're spending billions of dollars to Russia, then we're supposed to defend you from Russia.So I think it's a very bad—I think the people of Germany are very unhappy about it. I have many friends from Germany, and the people in Germany are very unhappy about it. They don't like it, but that's what they chose to do. So they're spending billions of dollars to buy Russian energy, and then we're supposed to defend them from Russia. So that doesn't work too well.But Poland has been very, very terrific. In fact, I don't believe Poland is actually accepting any of the energy from the pipeline from Russia. So that sends a signal right there.With all of that being said, we expect to get along with Russia; we expect to get along with everybody. But Germany has—they really owe a lot of money in NATO, and this has been going on for many years. When you add it all up, you're probably getting close to a trillion dollars. And that's not treating NATO fairly, but it really isn't treating the United States fairly.You know, the United States is a very—is the major participant in NATO. We pay more than anybody else, by far; have for many, many years. So we defend Europe, but Europe also takes tremendous advantage of the United States on trade, advantage like you wouldn't believe. So we're trying to work that out.And I would imagine they'd like to wait until after the election so that maybe they could deal with somebody other than But after the election, they'll just have to pay more, but that's the way it is. Okay?Thank you very much. Please. Sir, first of all, I do respect very much both Mr. President, Donald Trump, and the United States of America—a wonderful, great state which today is the largest military and economic superpower in the world.And I wouldn't dare say to the President of the United States of America where he should send his soldiers, because this is the decision which is always taken by the United States. This is a very responsible decision.However, I do not deny that I requested Mr. President that he would not withdraw U.S. forces from Europe, because the security of Europe is very important to me, from Europe as such. I'm talking about the united Europe for which the American presence, since the end of the Second World War, is a huge security guarantee.However, if I'm asked by anybody if I am ready that Poland receives more U.S. troops in our country, of course, I am ready. In 2014, Russia attacked Ukraine. It annexed Crimea. It occupies Luhansk and Donetsk. Before that, it had attacked Georgia. 2014 was a year of huge fears—huge fears in the Baltic States and very big ones, very considerable ones among the Polish society.Today, the presence of NATO troops and, first and foremost, of U.S. troops in Poland demonstrates that article 5 of the North Atlantic Treaty is treated seriously. And it shows that if anyone wanted to attack Poland, it won't be a soft landing for that entity; that it won't pay off for such an aggressor, because the strongest army of the world is present and they would help Polish soldiers to defend our borders if such a case arises.One hundred years ago, we repelled Russians from Warsaw. In a great battle in 1920, we defeated the Soviet Army Bolsheviks, and we drove them back to the east. That was a great victory, but we managed to stop them only very near to Warsaw, at the outskirts of our capital city. We would never want to see that situation repeated again. That is why the Allied presence is crucially important to us today and it is a very important security guarantee to us.So I'm very pleased that both within NATO, as well as in the United States, and today, that President of the United States understands the history of Europe and he understands the realities in Europe, and that he also understands the situation as it is developing in Europe.So today, this generates peace to my country; it brings security. And thanks to that, Russian—unfortunately, the very strong imperial ambitions which have been revived over the last tens of years, I can say, because Georgia was attacked in 2008—thanks to this, those ambitions have been stopped for the time being, at least in this part of the world. And I have no doubt whatsoever that this is also a huge merit of the policy of the United States. I'm grateful for that, just like all my compatriots are. Thank you very much. I just want to add: 2014, which the President was talking about, that was a year where Russia had a good time with the United States. To the best of my knowledge, President Obama and Sleepy Joe Biden, they were in power. They were the ones that were doing it. This was before us. It hasn't happened with us, and it won't happen with us either.Please, go ahead.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, can you explain why you believe the Treasury is unable to accept payments related to this deal? What specific legal or regulatory obstacles are preventing this, and are you exploring any legislative solutions to overcome them? [SEP] It's unbelievable, frankly. You'd think the government would be happy to take money, right? But apparently, there are all these rules, these regulations, nobody knows why. The lawyers are telling me it's never been done before, nobody's ever asked for it before. Can you believe that? I'm saying, 'We made this deal happen, we should get a piece of the action!' It's only fair. We're looking into it, we're exploring all options. Maybe we need to change the law, maybe we need to find a loophole, I don't know. But we're not going to let this go. We're going to find a way to get the government its fair share. It's the right thing to do.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, following your conversation with Prime Minister Abe, are you still contemplating a withdrawal from the U.S.-Japan Security Treaty? And could you share his reaction to your concerns? [SEP] The idea of withdrawal is not on the table. However, the fundamental inequity of the agreement persists. I've stressed this point to Prime Minister Abe for the past six months. To illustrate, an assault on Japan compels our immediate and comprehensive military response. Conversely, an attack on the United States does not mandate a similar commitment from them. This imbalance is unacceptable. It reflects a pattern of disadvantageous agreements that have been detrimental to our nation. I've informed the Prime Minister that a revision is essential. While I trust that we will not be attacked, it is conceivable that a scenario could arise where we require their support. In such an event, I am confident that they would reciprocate. He understands this imperative. Moving on.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify, are you suggesting that the desire for donor anonymity outweighs the public's right to know who is funding your Presidential library, especially given the potential for perceived influence? [SEP] It's not about outweighing anything. It's about respecting people's privacy. We're building a library, not running a secret operation. The details will come out when they're ready. We're focused on making it a world-class institution. What was the question again?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the attack on the Inter-Continental Hotel, are you worried about the Afghan forces' readiness to take over security responsibilities after our withdrawal? [SEP] We anticipated difficulties. The drawdown is yet to commence. The Taliban is still active. Incidents will occur. The crucial question is whether Afghan capacity is increasing. Kabul is safer than previously, and Afghan forces are performing adequately. Nevertheless, attacks may still occur. Our work is incomplete. However, the tide of war is receding. We are in a transition phase, akin to Iraq. They are maintaining a democratic government, despite sporadic attacks. Afghanistan is emerging from conflict. It's a perilous place. We can improve their capacity to defend themselves. Who's next?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are you deliberately ignoring my question? [SEP] I'm prioritizing the questions that I believe are most relevant to the American people. If you have a legitimate concern, perhaps you should phrase it in a way that doesn't sound so accusatory.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. But the offer still stands? [SEP] That's a choice the ians are going to have to make.David Jackson [USA Today].
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your administration's policies on surveillance and data collection infringe on civil liberties and are ineffective in preventing terrorism. How do you respond to these concerns, and what specific safeguards are in place to protect the privacy of American citizens? [SEP] The issue of reviewing social media for those who are obtaining visas, I think, may have gotten garbled a little bit, because there may beit's important to distinguish between posts that are publicsocial media on a Facebook pageversus private communications through various social media or apps. And our law enforcement and intelligence professionals are constantly monitoring public posts, and that is part of the visa review process, that people are investigating what individuals have said publicly and questioned about any statements that they maybe made.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, the agreement regarding Roxham Road has been finalized for a year. What factors contributed to the delay in its implementation? Furthermore, considering the acceptance of 15,000 migrants by Canada, what specific concessions were made to the U.S. in exchange? [SEP] Well, look, no, I'm not disappointed. This is a very difficult situation. How do we deal with what's going on in Haiti, where gangs have essentially taken over the government? They run the show. So, I think what the Prime Minister has said makes sense. The most important thing we can do, and it will take time, is to improve the capacity of the police departments to deal with the problems. That will take a while. We're also looking at whether the international community, through the UN, can play a larger role. There's a real concern because there are several million people in Haiti, and the diaspora could cause some real, shall we say, confusion in the Western Hemisphere. So, I think what the Prime Minister is suggesting, and we're also contributing, is to increase the efficiency and capacity of the police training and methods. We're also talking to others in the hemisphere who are prepared to help. It's a work in progress.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, the public is clearly bewildered by the shifting coronavirus guidelines, and your approval ratings are suffering. Why are you standing by your team and refusing to make changes at the CDC or other relevant agencies? [SEP] The ever-changing understanding of the virus is the primary source of any confusion. Scientists are constantly learning, and guidelines are adapted as new information emerges. The CDC's communication efforts have been a key area of focus, and we are actively working to improve them. We should not forget the remarkable speed with which a vaccine was created.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, there's ambiguity in the statement that you have no recollection about the existence and destruction of the CIA interrogation tapes. Why can't you say yes or no about the tapes and their destruction? And regardless, do you think the destruction of the tapes was a responsible thing to do? [SEP] It sounds pretty clear to me when I say I have—the first recollection is when Mike Hayden briefed me. That's pretty clear. Secondly, I am confident that the preliminary inquiry conducted by the AG and the IG of the CIA, coupled with the oversight provided by the Congress, will end up enabling us all to find out what exactly happened. And therefore, over the course of these inquiries and oversight hearings, I'm going to reserve judgment until I find out the full facts.I know I'm going to be asked about this question a lot as time goes on. I'm just going to prepare you—until these inquiries are complete, until the oversights are finished, then I will be rendering no opinion from the podium.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you very much, Mr. President. On Venezuela, you did the tough sanctions, and you sent the aid, but it seems like Maduro is no closer to leaving. And I'm wondering if you're getting worried about losing momentum. And how long are you being told that this going to take? [SEP] I'm not being told any specific time. They've been there a long time, between him and his predecessor. At some point, I would imagine, things will change. But we really haven't done the really tough sanctions yet. We can do the tough sanctions. And all options are open, so we may be doing that. But we haven't done the toughest of sanctions, as you know. We've done, I would say, right down the middle. But we can go a lot tougher if we need to do that.But it's a very sad thing, and we're not looking for anything other than taking care of a lot of people that are starving and dying in the streets. What's happening there is a disgrace. This was one of the wealthiest countries in the world, and all of a sudden, it's just—it's grief stricken, poverty stricken, no food, no water, no air conditioning, no anything. No power for a long time last week. No power. And that's going to break down again, because it's being held together by threads.So it's very sad, Roberta. Very sad to see. Okay?
label: General

sentence: Q. May I ask President Bolsonaro? President Bolsonaro, are you open to the idea of allowing a U.S. base or U.S. military personnel, a military presence in Brazil to provide support on the border with Venezuela? And is that something that you talked about with President Trump today? [SEP] Yes, we have discussed the possibility of Brazil, becoming a great allied extra-NATO. Recently, we requested that food was sent through Boa Vista, the capital of Roraima State, through our friends from America, so that humanitarian aid was provided to .At this point in time, this is where we stand. So for as much as it is possible for us to do together to sort out the issue of the n dictatorship, Brazil will be more than willing and ready to fulfill this mission and take freedom and democracy to that country, which up until recently was one of the wealthiest countries in South America. But nowadays, people are starving to death; they are suffering violence, lack of medication. They're—it's something terrible that's going on in there. And we need to put an end to this issue, which is pervasive to the whole wide world. . Mr. President, please.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Uribe, considering the widespread commentary on Chavez, could you provide your judgment on whether his impact in the region is being amplified beyond its actual extent, in your view? [SEP] Could you clarify what you're asking my opinion on?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, economists say that the Nation is at increasing risk of recession. What do you say? [SEP] I say that the fundamentals of our Nation's economy are strong. Inflation is down. Job markets are steady and strong. After all, the national unemployment rate is 4.6 percent. Corporate profits appear to be strong. Exports are up. There is no question that there is some unsettling times in the housing market and credits associated with the housing market. And that's why I look forward to working with Congress to modernize the FHA loans so that people can refinance their homes and to change the Tax Code so that if somebody renegotiates a loan, they don't have to pay a penalty, a tax penalty, in so doing.I'm optimistic about our economy. I would be pessimistic, however, if the Congress has its way and raises taxes. I believe the worst thing that can happen now is to allow the Congress to do that which they have said they want to do, which is to raise the taxes on people, and—because I think taking money out of the hands of investors and consumers and small-business owners would weaken the economy.And so, as I say, I'm optimistic. But I would be pessimistic if I thought Congress was going to get their way. And they're not; they're not going to raise taxes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. I'd like to follow on Iran. Critics say that you are using the same quality of intelligence about Iran that you used to make the case for war in Iraq, specifically about WMD that turned out to be wrong, and that you are doing that to make a case for war against Iran. Is that the case? [SEP] I can say with certainty that the Qods Force, a part of the ian Government, has provided these sophisticated IEDs that have harmed our troops. And I'd like to repeat: I do not know whether or not the Qods Force was ordered from the top echelons of Government. But my point is, what's worse: them ordering it and it happening or them not ordering it and it's happening? And so we will continue to protect our troops.David, our strategy is comprehensive in order to resolve problems that will affect our own peace and the peace in the world. And the biggest problem I see is the ians' desire to have a nuclear weapon. And as you know, we've been dealing with this issue ever since you've been covering me and pretty much ever since I've been the President. And we've made it very clear to the ians that if they would like to have a dialog with the United States, there needs to be a verifiable suspension of their program. I would hope that they would do that. I would like to be at the—have been given a chance for us to explain that we have no desire to harm the ian people.But my focus is on making sure that this weapon is dealt with—the program is dealt with in a constructive, peaceful way. And we'll continue to work toward achieving our common objectives with other nations in the world in a peaceful way.Sheryl [Sheryl Stolberg, New York Times].
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, you've stated you're prepared to walk away from the North Korea summit if it's not successful. What specific conditions would constitute a failure, leading you to terminate negotiations? And if the summit is deemed a success, what specific steps would you take to normalize relations with North Korea, including a potential invitation to Kim Jong Un to visit the United States? [SEP] Look, I'm going to go into that meeting with an open mind. I want to see if we can make a deal that's good for everybody. But I'm not going to be taken advantage of. If I don't think it's going to work, I'm going to walk away. I've done it before, and I'll do it again. But I'm hopeful that we can make progress. I believe that Kim Jong Un wants to do something good for his people. And if we can reach an agreement, it would be a great thing for the world.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, if August isn't feasible, what's the backup plan? Are there alternative timelines we should be aware of? [SEP] We're exploring all options, believe me. We're leaving no stone unturned. But I don't want to get ahead of myself. We're focused on August. If that doesn't work out, we'll recalibrate. We're flexible, adaptable. We'll find a way to get this done. It's too important to fail. We're talking about the future of this country, after all.
label: General

sentence: Q. On trade, Mr. President, you announced new trade tariffs against China. Trade tariffs are a very important part of your economic and trade policy. In you first year in office, the U.S. trade deficit increased by 12 percent. And last month, we saw the trade deficit increase to, I believe it was, $72 billion. So my question to you is, is your trade tariffs policy working? [SEP] Well, we just started. We didn't do anything with respect to China because we wanted to have the benefit of China having to do with North Korea. And they have been helpful. I hope they're still helpful; there's a question about that. But it got to a point where the numbers were too big. This should have been done for the last 20 years.If you look at the WTO, the World Trade Organization, that's when China really happened, economically. That's—it was like a rocket ship, because they took advantage of the rules of the WTO.And whoever was standing at this podium in this incredible White House, in the Oval Office, they should have done something about this long ago.Over the last number of years, China has taken out of this country $500 billion and more—a year. $500 billion. That would go a long way for Poland, wouldn't it? You could rebuild your whole country. And that's what China did. They rebuilt their country with tremendous amounts of money pouring out of the United States. And I've changed that around. And if you look at what's going on, our market is going up like a rocket ship. I don't want their market to go down, but their market is down 32 percent in 3 months. Because we can't let them do anymore what they've done.And I watch trade deficits, because to me, deficits are very important. They're not everything, and they're not exact. Sometimes, you can have, you know, a deficit, and that's not such a bad thing. But when you have $375 billion in trade deficits and then many billions of dollars in other liabilities of all different types, you have to do something about it.We are the piggybank to the world. We have been ripped off by China. We've been ripped off by—excuse me, Mr. President—the European Union, of which you're a part of. [] We've been ripped off by everybody. And I want to protect the American worker, the American farmer, the ranchers, the companies. And we're not being ripped off, you will see, in a little while.Speaking of that, we've come to a conclusion with Mexico. We have a wonderful deal for both parties. It was a very one-sided deal. Now it's a good deal for both parties. Very happy with it.The new President had conversation and it was terrific. I think we're going to have a very good relationship. We'll see. We'll see. We want help on the border because we have the worst immigration laws in the history of mankind or womankind. We have horrible, horrible immigration laws, so we want help. But we've come to a conclusion with Mexico. Canada has taken advantage of our country for a long time. We love Canada. We love it. Love the people of Canada. But they are in a position that's not a good position for Canada. They cannot continue to charge us 300-percent tariff on dairy products, and that's what they're doing.So this is a process. It takes a little time. The European Union wouldn't talk to us. They wouldn't talk to President Obama. Wouldn't even talk to him. And then I said, That's okay, you don't have to talk to me. Jean-Claude is a tough man. He's a very good man. I like him, but he's tough. He's nasty. [] The kind of guy I want negotiating for me. But he's a tough, tough cookie. And I said to him, We have to renegotiate the deal. He said: But, Mr. President, we are very happy with the deal. We don't want to negotiate. I said, You may be happy with the deal, but I'm not happy with the deal.And he didn't want to renegotiate. And after three times, he still didn't want to renegotiate. I said, That's okay, we don't have to renegotiate any longer. We're going to put a tariff on all of the millions of cars you send into the United States. And honestly, he was in my office so quickly, from Europe, that I didn't know they had airplanes that flew that fast. [] I said, Where did you find this plane? []And we have the semblance of a deal. Because it's, to a large extent, economically all about cars. Cars are a very big factor. And they send millions of BMWs and Mercedes into our country.So we are working on trade very hard. It's very important to me. It has been for 30 years. I've been saying for 30 years. It started with Japan. I talked about Japan; I was right. I talked about China; I was right. It's what I do. And I like doing it. But I like doing it for the people because our country has been abused and taken advantage of by virtually every country that it does business with. And we're just not letting that happen anymore. And that includes what I said previously about the military.Please.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, Macron says the Inflation Reduction Act is 'super aggressive' to Europe. Will you grant exemptions to European companies? [SEP] Let me answer the question I understood. We aren't apologizing for this legislation, especially since I wrote it. It's a huge investment in climate change, the biggest ever, so there are bound to be some issues. For example, the free trade agreement thing was meant to apply to allies, not everyone. We can fix that. The main thing is that the US, and hopefully Europe, doesn't have to depend on other countries' supply chains. We want to be self-sufficient and share that with our allies. We can make adjustments to help European countries participate or stand on their own. I never meant to exclude our allies. The point was to avoid situations like the pandemic, where we couldn't get computer chips because China wouldn't sell them to us. We invented those! So, we're back in business, Europe is back in business, and we're going to create manufacturing jobs here, but not at Europe's expense.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Sir, was the suspect carrying a weapon at the time of the incident? [SEP] I believe so, but I'm not entirely certain. You should direct that question to the people in charge of the investigation.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, in light of your commitment to withdrawing troops from Iraq within a specific timeframe, what is your anticipated timeline for a similar withdrawal from Afghanistan, and will you consider lifting the ban on media coverage of the return of fallen soldiers? [SEP] First and foremost, I must acknowledge the recent tragic loss of four American service members in Iraq, and extend my deepest condolences to their families. The most somber aspect of this office is signing letters to the families of our fallen heroes. Concerning the policy on media coverage, we are currently engaged in a review process in collaboration with the Department of Defense. I prefer to refrain from providing an answer until I have thoroughly evaluated the findings of that review. Afghanistan presents a formidable challenge. Unlike Iraq, where we have witnessed a relatively peaceful election, the government in Afghanistan appears disconnected from the populace. The Taliban and Al Qaeda maintain a presence in the border regions. We require a concerted effort to eradicate those safe havens. We are undertaking a comprehensive review, and we must enhance coordination across our military, diplomatic, and development endeavors. We cannot allow Al Qaeda to operate in that region. While I do not yet have a definitive timeline, I will not permit Al Qaeda or bin Laden to plan attacks against the U.S. homeland.
