I felt that would be extraordinarily dangerous for this young democracy, that the violence in Baghdad could escalate mightily and then spill out across the country, creating chaos, vacuums into which extremism would flow. Or make the decision I made, which is to reinforce the troops that were on the ground, to help this Iraqi Government and security force do what they're supposed to do.Sir, you dropped?
label: General

sentence: Q. So you don't see that forecast being accurate, the one that I cited you? [SEP] No, look. Look. Yes, but you didn't hear me. If we didn't do what I said, we would be at 2 million deaths right now.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I have a policy question and a personal one. The policy question is, you talked about how the immediate goal is the Bush tax cuts and making sure that they don't expire for those who earn under 200, 250,000. Republicans disagree with that strongly. They want all of the Bush tax cuts extended. Are you willing to compromise on that? Are you willing to negotiate at all, for instance, allow them to expire for everyone over $1 million? Where are you willing to budge on that?And the second one is, President Bush, when he went through a similar thing, came out and he said, This was a thumpin'. You talked about how it was humbling, or you alluded to it perhaps being humbling. And I'm wondering, when you call your friends, like Congressman Perriello or Governor Strickland, and you see 19 State legislatures go to the other side, Governorships in swing States, the Democratic Party set back, what does it feel like? [SEP] It feels bad. [] The toughest thing over the last couple of days is seeing really terrific public servants not have the opportunity to serve anymore, at least in the short term. And you mentioned--there are just some terrific Members of Congress who took really tough votes because they thought it was the right thing, even though they knew this could cause them political problems and even though a lot of them came from really tough swing districts or majority-Republican districts. And the amount of courage that they showed and conviction that they showed is something that I admire so much. I can't overstate it.And so there's a--not only sadness about seeing them go, but there's also a lot of questioning on my part in terms of could I have done something differently or done something more so that those folks would still be here. It's hard. And I take responsibility for it in a lot of ways.I will tell you, they've been incredibly gracious when I have conversations with them. And what they've told me is, you know, I--we don't have regrets because I feel like we were doing the right thing. And they may be just saying that to make me feel better, which, again, is a sign of their character and their class. And I hope a lot of them continue to pursue public service because I think they're terrific public servants.With respect to the tax cut issue, my goal is to make sure that we don't have a huge spike in taxes for middle class families. Not only would that be a terrible burden on families who are already going through tough times, it would be bad for our economy. It is very important that we're not taking a whole bunch of money out of the system from people who are most likely to spend that money on goods, services, groceries, buying a new winter coat for the kids.That's also why I think unemployment insurance is important. Not only is it the right thing to do for folks who are still looking for work and struggling in this really tough economy, but it's the right thing to do for the economy as a whole.So my goal is to sit down with Speaker-elect Boehner and Mitch McConnell and Harry and Nancy sometime in the next few weeks and see where we can move forward in a way that, first of all, does no harm; that extends those tax cuts that are very important for middle class families; also extends those provisions that are important to encourage businesses to invest and provide businesses some certainty over the next year or two.And how that negotiation works itself out, I think, is too early to say. But this is going to be one of my top priorities. And my hope is, is that given we all have an interest in growing the economy and encouraging job growth, that we're not going to play brinksmanship, but instead we're going to act responsibly.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. I'll try to be succinct. Mr. President, 2 years ago, you said that you were ready to expend political capital on the Israel-Palestinian situation. With hindsight, do you think you've fulfilled that intention? How closely do you see a linkage between what happens in Israel-Palestine and a settlement in Iraq, achieving your goals?And Prime Minister, given that you were so recently in the Middle East and the situation hasn't exactly improved since then, is there anything specific you're hoping to achieve next week when you go back? [SEP] Want me to start? I'm getting older, so you're going to have to repeat the second part of your question. [] Let me answer the first part. What's important is for people to accept the goal of two states living side by side for peace. And what has changed in the Middle East is that Israel and Palestine— at least the current leadership of both countries, or both—one entity and one country—accept that goal. That's important.To that end, the previous Prime Minister made a decision to unilaterally withdraw from Gaza, which I felt was a good decision, which would expedite the potential arrival of a state. And so to answer your question, yes, we're spending a lot of capital getting people headed in the same direction, which if you look at the history of the Middle East, is a change.Secondly, one of the reasons why there hasn't been instant success is because radicals and extremists are trying to stop the advance of a Palestinian state. Why? Because democracy is a defeat for them. That's what I strongly believe. I find it interesting that when Prime Minister Olmert reaches out to Palestinians to discuss a way forward on the two-state solution, Hizballah attacks Israel. Why? Because radicals and extremists can't stand the thought of a democracy. And one of the great ironies is that people in the Middle East are working hard to prevent people in the Middle East from realizing the blessings of a free society in a democracy.And so no question, progress has been spotty. But it's important for people to understand, one of the reasons why is, is because radicals are trying to prevent it, and they're willing to kill innocent people to prevent progress. Now, our goal is to help the Abbas Government strengthen its security forces, and we're doing that. Our goal is to help the Abbas Government form a government that adheres to the principles of the Quartet. We can't abandon the principles of the Quartet just because it may sound easy. We can't do that. When nations lay out principles, you've got to adhere to those principles, just like when we laid out a vision, you adhere to that vision.And so the Prime Minister's visit, like Condi's visit recently to the Middle East, are all aiming to help countries remove obstacles necessary to achieve the vision. And it's hard work, but it's necessary work. And so I do believe there is a—I know there's a change of attitude. And now the fundamental question is, can we help the moderates prevail? And make no mistake about it, radicals and extremists will kill in order to stop the progress. And that's what's difficult. But it should be a signal to those of us who have got the comfort of liberty to understand the consequences of this ideological struggle we're fighting. One of the consequences is the denial of a Palestinian state.This is ironic, isn't it? I think it is, and it's sad. I mean, I think, first of all, it's important to understand how much has begun—how much work there's been. I mean, I know I've had many, many meetings on this issue over the past few months. I know Secretary Rice has been immensely active on it over these past months as well. Now, some of that is visible and out there at press conferences and meetings, and a lot of it is behind the scenes.But in essence, what we've got to do is to try to resolve two issues. First of all, we need to get the release of Corporal Shalit, which, as Prime Minister Olmert made clear the other day, would then allow the release of many Palestinian prisoners as well. And this is obviously a very important issue.But then, secondly, and this is, I think, really—one of the core questions is, we are prepared to release the money to the Palestinian Authority. We are prepared to take the peace process forward and get into a process of negotiation. But we need a government on both sides that is committed to the basic principles of that negotiation. And at the present time, we are not able to achieve a national unity government on the Palestinian side. And the reason for that is that we are saying, not as a matter of dogma at all, but you can't have a government that everyone can deal with and you can then negotiate a peace between Israel and Palestine, unless it's on the basis that everyone accepts the other's right to exist. So that's the difficulty. It's not a kind of technical point; it's absolutely at the heart of it.Now, what we have got to do is to find either a way of unlocking the problem of forming that national unity government, on the principles laid down by the United Nations as well as the rest of the Quartet, or alternatively, a different way forward, but whatever way forward will have to be on the basis you get an empowered Palestinian Government with whom everyone can negotiate and deal with.Now, you know, again, it's a very, very obvious thing. It's not just for the Israelis and the Palestinians but also for the whole of the region. You know, you can't negotiate this unless everyone accepts the basic principles of the negotiation. But if people were to do that—and after all, we're only asking people to accept the position that the United Nations and, really, the whole of the international community—you could move this forward quickly. I mean, I don't think there's any doubt at all that if you could get an empowered Palestinian Government able to negotiate, Israel has made it clear it is prepared to negotiate.I'm not saying there aren't very tricky issues. There are—things like Jerusalem, the right of return, which are very, very difficult. But actually, it's not beyond our wit to put it together. We could put it together. But you need to get these initial steps taken.Now, what I'm wont to do when I go out there is just explore what is the way that we get that ability to get the negotiation underway, trying to work round these obstacles. And it's something—we were talking about Iran and Syria moments ago; it's something all of those countries could help with if they wanted to help with it. So I kind of feel one thing that is important is that everyone understands that there's no shortage of willingness, energy, commitment on our side.And believe me, I've talked about this with the President many, many times, and I don't believe there's any shortage of those qualities on his part at all. But we need to get this—we need to get the door unlocked because it's kind of barred at the moment. It needs to be opened. And that's the task, I think, for the next period. Thank you. L.A. Times man, Jim [Jim Gerstenzang].
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. What powers will you use to speed it up? [SEP] I think Democrat, Republican, liberal, conservative—this process is going to go very quickly. The head of the FDA is on your right. The President. And you know, that was—excuse me? The head of the FDA is here, if you want to call on him. The President. Yes. We can do that. You want to do that? We're expedited. The President. Okay. Would you like to say something? All right. Okay. Excuse me for interrupting.
label: General

sentence: If I may, sir, just one quick follow-up question? [SEP] Perhaps. We'll see how we're doing on time. []
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Kenya, what specific actions will the U.S. take to aid in the fight against al-Shabaab? Do you still consider Somalia a viable counterterrorism model? And are you concerned about potential human rights abuses by Kenyan authorities under the guise of counterterrorism? And for President Kenyatta, what further assistance do you require from the U.S. in combating al-Shabaab, and are you satisfied with the current level of support? Also, could you both address the criticism surrounding the treatment of LGBTQ+ individuals in Kenya? [SEP] Well, this has been a topic of extensive discussion and concrete action that we're now undertaking. There has been extensive and effective counterterrorism cooperation between the United States and Kenya dealing with primarily threats from al-Shabaab. In part because of the actions that we've taken not just with Kenya, but with AFRICOM, and the efforts, collectively, of countries to work together—Uganda, Ethiopia, others—we have systematically reduced the territory that al-Shabaab controls. We have been able to decrease their effective control within Somalia and have weakened those networks operating here in East Africa. That doesn't mean the problem is solved. As is true around the world, what we find is, is that we can degrade significantly the capacities of these terrorist organizations, but they can still do damage. The number of individuals involved in Garissa or Westgate Mall were not large, but when they're willing to target soft targets and civilians, and are prepared to die, they can still do a lot of damage. And so what we discussed was the importance of, number one, continuing the effort to root out al-Shabaab's capacity inside of Somalia, working jointly. And as we speak, Kenya is working with Ethiopia and with the United States and others to further degrade al-Shabaab's space of operations inside of Somalia. So we have to keep that pressure going, even as we're strengthening the Somalian Government. Because part of the reason that al-Shabaab was able to emerge as a significant threat to the region was a nonfunctioning Government, effectively a failed state in Somalia for so long. There is now a Government and a cabinet that is credible and is working with the international community in Mogadishu. And even as we put military pressure on al-Shabaab, we also have to make sure that we're standing up an effective governance structure inside of Somalia. And we've made progress there. In addition, we have to continue to make progress in intelligence-sharing and being able to identify and prevent threats before they occur here in Kenya and elsewhere in the region. And part of our announcement today involves additional funding, additional assistance that we're providing the Kenyan security forces to deal with these very specific counterterrorism threats, as well as additional training and assistance to make sure that the approach that's taken in rooting out potential terrorist threats don't create more problems than they're solving. And this goes to the other element of the question that you asked. What we have found, sometimes through hard experience—and I shared this with —is that if you paint any particular community with too broad a brush, if in reaction to terrorism you are restricting legitimate organizations, reducing the scope of peaceful organization, then that can have the inadvertent effect of actually increasing the pool of recruits for terrorism and resentment in communities that feel marginalized. And I shared with him that one of the strengths in the United States, part of the reason why, although we're seeing potential lone wolf attacks inside the United States, that we have not seen this sort of systematic networks and cells developing in many of our Muslim communities or immigrant communities inside of the United States is, is that we've been very conscious to make sure that law enforcement is reaching out and cooperating and working with them, because they are our partners in this process. And the only way we're going to fight the poison that's being fed to them—to their young people through social media—is to make sure that they're our eyes and our ears and they're counseling us on how we can more effectively build trust and increase cooperation. And that's proven successful. The same will be true here in Kenya. And I was very clear to : Ultimately, the Kenyan Government is accountable to the Kenyan people, and it will find its way through this process in cooperation with us, but our experience and best practices tell us that rule of law, respecting civil society—in fact, embracing civil society, particularly in those communities that may be targeted for recruitment by organizations like al-Shabaab—that becomes more important the more significant the threat is. And not only is that practical advice, but it's the right thing to do, and it's consistent with the Kenyan Constitution and with the values that you heard espouse. Similarly, with respect to the rights of gays and lesbians, I've been consistent all across Africa on this. I believe in the principle of treating people equally under the law and that they are deserving of equal protection under the law and that the state should not discriminate against people based on their sexual orientation. And I say that, recognizing that there may be people who have different religious or cultural beliefs. But the issue is, how does the state operate relative to people? If you look at the history of countries around the world, when you start treating people differently—not because of any harm they're doing anybody, but because they are different—that's the path whereby freedoms begin to erode and bad things happen. And when a government gets in the habit of treating people differently, those habits can spread. And as an African American in the United States, I am painfully aware of the history of what happens when people are treated differently, under the law, and there's—were all sorts of rationalizations that were provided by the power structure for decades in the United States for segregation and Jim Crow and slavery, and they were wrong. So I'm unequivocal on this. If somebody is a law-abiding citizen who is going about their business and working in a job and obeying the traffic signs—[]—and doing all the other things that good citizens are supposed to do and not harming anybody, the idea that they are going to be treated differently or abused because of who they love is wrong. Full stop. And the state does not need to weigh in on religious doctrine. The state just has to say, we're going to treat everybody equally under the law. And then, everybody else can have their own opinions. All right?
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, critics argue your stance on alliances gives Putin leverage. How do you respond? [SEP] They're wrong. Plain and simple. I'm the only one who can stand up to Putin. Everyone else has been played. I'm making America strong again, and that includes reassessing these outdated agreements.
label: Dodging

sentence: Looking back, Mr. President, at what point did you feel fully acclimated to the demands of the presidency, especially given the economic challenges you faced upon entering office? [SEP] Acclimation wasn't a priority when we were losing nearly a million jobs monthly. My situation was, frankly, unprecedented. Unlike FDR, who inherited an ongoing crisis, we were in a complete tailspin. The financial system was frozen, the auto industry collapsing, and the housing market devastated. I was too consumed with immediate action to consider personal comfort. The incoming administration, while facing challenges, benefits from a stronger economic foundation – low unemployment, rising wages, and a stable financial system. They have the opportunity for deliberate decision-making, a direct result of my administration's work.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Obama, despite your efforts to reform healthcare with the Affordable Care Act, millions of Americans remain uninsured or underinsured. What specific steps do you believe should be taken to further expand access to affordable healthcare, and what are the key obstacles to achieving universal coverage? [SEP] We made tremendous progress with the Affordable Care Act, but there's still more work to be done. We need to build on what we've already accomplished, strengthen the exchanges, and find ways to lower costs. The biggest obstacle is political gridlock. We need to find common ground and work together to ensure that every American has access to quality, affordable healthcare.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, why the delay in releasing the photos? It seems like a straightforward request. [SEP] Well, Helen, that's a bit of a tangent, isn't it? The bigger picture here is showing the Iranian people that we're watching and that they're not alone. What happens inside Iran is what truly matters. Remember Dr. King's words: the arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends towards justice. We have to believe that justice will win out.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify, what concrete measures will you implement to counter this interference you mentioned? [SEP] We're going to be taking a hard look at that. I understand this has just come to light, and we're aware of it. We're going to be monitoring it very closely. But let's not forget, this whole thing started with Russia.
label: General

sentence: Do you anticipate that the debate surrounding school reopenings and closures will significantly influence Republican efforts to win back suburban voters in the upcoming midterm elections? [SEP] It's certainly possible, but I believe voters are becoming increasingly savvy about the motivations of politicians. They're primarily concerned with their families, their livelihoods, and their safety. They're less likely to be fooled by exaggerated claims. Historically, many presidents have experienced similar polling numbers at this point in their terms. The public is actively trying to distinguish between truth and falsehood. Their choice of news outlets heavily shapes their perceptions. Cable news viewership is declining. The way news is disseminated has fundamentally changed due to the internet and the proliferation of partisan viewpoints. The media landscape has been transformed.
label: Implicit

sentence: So, Mr. President, are we to assume that your administration's policy on Syria is classified, and you're unwilling to provide any details? [SEP] Elaine, I appreciate the question, but I'm not going to telegraph our strategy on that matter. We're keeping all options on the table.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with Americans dying daily, why frame this as a global competition? [SEP] Well, people are dying everywhere, not just here. Maybe you should direct your inquiries to the source, to the country where it all began. They might have a different perspective. Next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Afghanistan, how can you criticize Hamid Karzai for corruption when the U.S. is funding many corrupt individuals? Also, should Netanyahu extend the settlement moratorium, and if not, what steps will you take to prevent the Palestinians from abandoning negotiations? [SEP] On Afghanistan, we're engaged in a vital but challenging project. Let's remember why we're there: Al Qaeda attacked us on 9/11. We must dismantle Al Qaeda and prevent Afghanistan from becoming a base for attacks again. Afghanistan is also incredibly poor with a high illiteracy rate and ethnic divisions. We're working to train Afghan security forces, promote a political settlement, and encourage a government that serves its people and reduces corruption. We've made progress on corruption, but there's more to do. I constantly remind Karzai that reducing corruption is essential for a stable government.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, some critics argue that your response is a typical politician's answer, avoiding any real commitment or specific action. Can you provide a more concrete plan for addressing the issues of domestic protests, advising your successor, and stopping the violence in Aleppo? [SEP] These are complex issues with no easy solutions. I am committed to working with all parties to find common ground and to address these challenges in a responsible and effective manner. I will continue to advocate for peaceful protests, to offer my advice to my successor, and to work with the international community to find a solution to the conflict in Syria.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. So if you ease up on these guidelines now, how many more Americans do you think are going to die? [SEP] Well, I'm not easing up. First of all, we'll have guidelines, even for the States that open. And they'll be guidelines. But we will not have any problem with that.Your question is a very interesting question, but the States that are opening are not States which will have a problem with that. Plus, they will have to adhere to guidelines until a certain point into the future when the enemy is vanquished.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to the Senate proceedings, would you prefer a swift resolution or a thorough examination of the facts? What are your thoughts on the disagreement between White House Counsel Pat Cipollone and Jerrold Nadler last night? And are you unequivocally opposed to John Bolton's testimony? [SEP] You're posing numerous questions at once.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the substantial GDP growth you've overseen, how do you respond to criticisms that these gains haven't translated into tangible benefits for the average American worker, particularly when compared to the austerity measures imposed on countries like Greece by international financial institutions? [SEP] Well, let's be clear, comparing the U.S. and Greece is like comparing apples and, shall we say, a very small orange. We inherited an economy hemorrhaging jobs, a situation far graver than any recession since the Great Depression. We acted decisively, applying proven strategies to stabilize and reignite growth. Our approach emphasizes structural reforms and responsible fiscal management alongside a pro-growth agenda. When the economy expands, revenues increase, easing the debt burden. Unlike some, we don't believe in solely cutting spending during a downturn, which can further contract the economy. Now, the U.S. benefits from the dollar's status as the world's reserve currency, granting us flexibility others lack. But the core lesson remains: investing in our people, spurring economic activity, and addressing structural deficits are key to sustainable growth. We're on the right track, and I am confident that our policies will continue to deliver results for all Americans.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, you presented a video showing you and Kim Jong Un on equal footing, discussing the future of North Korea. How can you justify portraying a dictator in such a favorable manner? [SEP] I don't view it that way at all. I'm committed to doing whatever it takes to make the world a safer place. If sitting down with Chairman Kim can potentially save millions of lives, I'm more than willing to do it. I'm willing to travel there with pride and enthusiasm. They've already made significant concessions, even before the Olympics. Their participation in the Olympics transformed what was projected to be a failure into a resounding success. If I can save millions of lives by building a relationship with a powerful figure who has firm control over a country with formidable nuclear capabilities, it's an honor to do so.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, could you elaborate on the specific options discussed with Chairman Kim regarding the advancement of denuclearization on the Korean Peninsula? [SEP] We discussed many ways. And the denuclearization is a very important—it's a very important word. Become a very well used word. And a lot of people don't know what it means, but to me it's pretty obvious: We have to get rid of the nukes.I think he's got a chance to have one of the most successful countries—rapidly, too—on Earth. Incredible country, incredible location. You're right between—if you think of it, you have, on one side, Russia and , and on the other, you have , and you're surrounded by water and among the most beautiful shorelines in the world.There is tremendous potential in North Korea, and I think he's going to lead it to a very important thing, economically. I think it's going to be an absolute economic power.Yes. Go ahead. Please. Go ahead. Yes.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, regarding the situation in the Middle East, when do you foresee a resolution, and do you condone Israel's actions? [SEP] Well, let me be clear. We all want peace, right? A lasting peace. And a lasting peace means Hamas can't be launching rockets. So, it's really up to them, isn't it? We're working with Egypt, good people, to stop the flow of weapons. Those countries fueling the fire need to stop. Now, about Israel, they have a right to defend themselves. But we also need to address the humanitarian situation. So, it's complicated. What was the second part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, the Kremlin claims a 'fundamental scale back' of military action near Kyiv. Is this a genuine de-escalation, or a deceptive ploy to buy time for a renewed offensive? [SEP] Frankly, it's anyone's guess at this point. We need to see verifiable actions, not just empty promises. Negotiations are ongoing in Turkey and elsewhere. I've consulted with our NATO partners – France, Germany, and Great Britain – and we're all taking a cautious approach. We'll continue to enforce sanctions, provide support to the Ukrainian military, and monitor the situation closely. Time will tell.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Good morning, Mr. President, Prime Minister. I'd like to ask you both about Iran. President Bush, you've talked about it at every stop. A similar process, it seems, that is deterring North Korea from its nuclear ambitions has basically allowed North Korea to make progress toward nuclear weapons. At what point are you willing to draw a line here with Iran? And isn't Iran seemingly learning a lesson from the North Korea experience? [SEP] Ed [Edwin Chen, Bloomberg News], I just strongly disagree with your premise that the six-party talks has encouraged Iran to develop nuclear weapons. I don't know why you have even come to that conclusion because the facts are, the six-party talks is the only way to send a message to the North Koreans that the world isn't going to tolerate them having a weapon.I mean, in other words, they are—we'll see what they disclose, but we, hopefully, are in the process of disabling and dismantling their plutonium manufacturing. We're, hopefully, in the process of getting them to disclose what they have manufactured and eventually turning it over. We're, hopefully, in the process of disclosing their proliferation activities, and it's a six-party process. I mean, the only way, in my judgment, to diplomatically solve these kinds of problems with nations like Iran and North Korea, nontransparent nations, is through a multilateral process where there's more than one nation sending the same message to the leaders of these respective countries.And so I disagree with your premise. As a matter of fact, the Iranians must understand that when we come together and speak with one voice, we're serious. That's why the Prime Minister's statement was so powerful, and that's the lesson that the North Koreans are hearing. And so it's— I said the other day that, you know, one of the things that I will leave behind is a multilateralism to deal with tyrants, so problems can be solved diplomatically.And the difficulty, of course, is that sometimes economics and money trumps national security interests. So you go around asking nations—by the way, it's not a problem for Great Britain—so you say to your partners, don't sell goods; you know, let's send a focused message, all aiming to create the conditions so that somebody rational shows up. In other words, people, hopefully, are sick of isolation in their respective countries, and they show up and say, we're tired of this; there's a better way forward.And in order for that to be effective, Ed, there has to be more than one voice. So if I were the North Koreans and I were looking at Iran, or the Iranians looking at North Korea, I'd say, uh-oh, there are coalitions coming together that are bound tightly, more tightly than ever, in order to send us a focused message.And you know, let me just say one thing about the Iranian demand for civilian nuclear power: It's a justifiable demand. You just heard the Prime Minister talk about the spread of civilian nuclear power, which I support—starting in my own country, by the way. We need to be building civilian nuclear power plants.And so when the Iranians say we have a sovereign right to have one, the answer is, you bet. You have a sovereign right; absolutely. But you don't have the trust of those of us who have watched you carefully when it comes to enriching uranium because you have declared that you want to destroy democracies in the neighborhood, for example. Therefore—and this is the Russian proposal, by the way—therefore, we'll provide fuel for you, and we'll collect the fuel after you've used it so you can have your nuclear—civilian nuclear power, which undermines what the Iranians are saying, and that is, we must enrich in order to have civilian nuclear power. You don't need to enrich to have civilian nuclear power. The Russian proposal is what we support. This proposal wouldn't have happened had there not been a multilateral process.And so what these nations need to see is, we're serious about solving these problems. And the United States spends a lot of time working with our partners to get them solved.Thank you very much. Thank you all very much.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the looming budget cuts, many are concerned about their impact on vulnerable populations. How do you respond to those anxieties, and specifically, what's your stance on Congressman Fattah's Debt Free America Act, or any similar Republican proposals? [SEP] Look, I understand the concerns, I really do. This recovery hasn't been felt equally, and those with less are feeling it the most. My focus, since day one, has been on those families working hard, playing by the rules, but still struggling to stay afloat. I hear from them, I see them, and I'm fighting for them. Now, as for specific legislative proposals, we're evaluating all options. The key is to find a solution that addresses both the immediate needs of struggling families and the long-term fiscal health of the nation. We need to be smart and targeted in our approach.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the media's desire for a deal and this being your third budget, you've stated you'd prefer a single term if it means doing what's necessary. Why not invite Republicans to negotiate now? What actions are you taking to encourage cooperation? And will the markets remain patient? [SEP] That's a mouthful, Jackie. My brain is getting full.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Not energy, I'm sorry, the economy. When, in your guesstimation, will this country see a turnaround as relates to the softening economy? When will it become strong again?And also, on the Sudan, the Sudanese Government is looking to the United Nations for help in this situation with the ICC. And this is a body that they have ignored before. What are your thoughts about what's happening with the Sudan? [SEP] Well, we're not a member of the ICC, so we'll see how that plays out.My thought on is, is that the United Nations needs to work with this current Government to get those troops in to help save lives—AU hybrid force. I talked to Williamson, who's the Special Envoy to , yesterday. There's two aspects to the ese issue. One is the north-south agreement, and he was talking about the need to make sure that there is a clear understanding about how oil revenues will be shared between north and south in a certain part of the border region there, so as to make sure that there is— that this agreement that Ambassador Danforth negotiated stays intact and stays full.And the other aspect, obviously, is Darfur. And that's a very, very complex issue. We're trying to make—we're trying to work with the rebel groups so that they speak more with one voice. We're trying to work with Bashir to make sure he understands that there will be continued sanctions if he doesn't move forward. We're trying to help get this—AU troops in Africa—throughout Africa into . And we're working with the French on the issue of Chad.And it's a complex situation, and sadly enough, innocent people are being displaced and are losing their life. And it's very difficult and unacceptable. And as you know, I made the decision not to unilaterally send troops. Once that decision was made, then we had to reply upon the United Nations. And I brought this issue up at the G-8 with our partners there. There's the same sense of consternation and the same sense of frustration that things haven't moved quicker. I talked to Ban Ki-moon about the issue, and he told me—I think he told me that by the end of this year, a full complement of AU troops will be there. Then the question is, will the Government help expedite the delivery of humanitarian aid?Anyway, the other question?
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, can you provide an update on the status of the peace process between Israel and Palestine? [SEP] Next question, please.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. Bush, after the previous intelligence failures, what specific steps have you taken to ensure the accuracy of the intelligence regarding Iran's involvement in providing IEDs? [SEP] Look, the facts are clear. These IEDs are there, they're hurting our troops, and they're coming from Iran. We're not going to stand by and let our soldiers get blown up. My job is to protect them, and that's exactly what we're going to do. We're responding appropriately, and we'll continue to respond appropriately.
label: General

sentence: Sir, wouldn't you agree that public pressure is essentially your only card to play against a recalcitrant Congress? [SEP] The beauty of our system is its inherent checks and balances. Right now, we've got Kevin McCarthy leading the House and Mitch McConnell steering the Senate. My job is to present the strongest arguments possible and rally the American people to our cause. Now, have they always jumped on board? No. Take the debt ceiling debacle, for instance. But we keep pushing. The thing is, and I said this in my State of the Union, the election's just around the corner. I'd much rather be focused on governing than campaigning, if only we could find some common ground. But when you're dealing with a Senate leader who's openly declared his mission to undermine me, not to create jobs or grow the economy, you've got to take your message directly to the people. See if they can get through. Where's Maria?
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, considering the challenges of global vaccine distribution and the potential for new variants, what specific international partnerships are you prioritizing to ensure equitable access and prevent future outbreaks? [SEP] The bottom line is, we're committed to helping the world get vaccinated. We're working with our partners to make sure everyone has access to the vaccines they need. We're looking at how to ramp up production and distribution, and we're working with other countries to make sure we're all on the same page. It's a global problem, and it requires a global solution. We are committed to that.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. How long before health care ceases to become a political football, do you think? Are we talking years? Months? [SEP] I think it's hard to say. It's interesting, I spoke at the LBJ Library the other day, and most of us weren't around to pay real close attention to those debates, or they're pretty distant now in the past. Apparently, it took several years before people realized, hey, Medicare actually works, and it's lifting a lot of seniors out of despair and poverty.So we've been through this cycle before. It happens each and every time we make some strides in terms of strengthening our commitments to each other and we expand some of these social insurance programs.There's a lot of fear-mongering and a lot of political argument and debate, and a lot of accusations are flung back and forth about socialized medicine and the end of freedom. And then it turns out that, you know what, it's working for a lot of folks, and we still live in a free-market society, and the Constitution is intact. And then we move on. And I don't know how long it's going to take. But in the meantime, how about us focusing on some things that the American people really care about? All right?Thank you, everybody.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Sir, during your discussions, did you address potential Canadian stimulus increases? And for both leaders, what's the anticipated state of Canada-U.S. relations in four years? Including the auto industry, border regulations, and carbon market initiatives? [SEP] Hang on a minute! You've crammed a whole series of questions into one. Were you addressing that to Jonathan?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, critics like Robert Novak are saying you're incredibly isolated, even more so than Nixon during Watergate. What's your reaction? [SEP] What does he mean by 'isolated,' exactly?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, you've stated that voting by mail is an invitation to fraud. Can you provide specific evidence of widespread fraud related to mail-in ballots in Nevada and other states? [SEP] If you look at the Washington Post and the New York Times, they've both published concerning articles about mail-in voting. You can find numerous examples online. In Nevada, they don't even verify signatures in some cases. You could have a completely different signature, and it would still be accepted. Plus, they have up to seven days after the election to approve ballots, so you won't even know who won the state.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, some analysts argue that your comments on Ukraine's NATO membership could be interpreted as a sign of weakness, potentially prolonging the conflict. How do you address those concerns? [SEP] The situation is very clear. Ukraine will be part of NATO. But you can't join NATO while a war is raging. That's just a fact. As for Putin, he's already lost this war. He's in a terrible position. He can end it whenever he chooses. But the outcome is inevitable.
label: Deflection

sentence: Can you definitively rule out a shutdown scenario? [SEP] I'm not in the business of making predictions, especially about something as volatile as that. Let's just say the situation is dynamic, and I'm not prepared to commit one way or the other at this juncture.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Sir, if Saudi Arabia is found culpable in Khashoggi's murder, what specific actions will the United States take in response? [SEP] We're looking at all options. It's a very complex situation. We have a lot of interests involved. I'm consulting with Congress, with our allies. I'll be making a decision very soon, a very strong decision. We're going to get to the bottom of this, believe me. Next question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. It was whether or not you believe that the U.S. dropped a nuclear weapon on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, it was right? [SEP] No, there were three sets of questions, right? You asked about ?
label: Clarification

sentence: What specific steps will your administration take to ensure that the US does not repeat the mistakes of the past and interfere in the internal affairs of Chile or other Latin American countries? [SEP] Our policy is clear: we respect the sovereignty of all nations and believe that each country has the right to determine its own future. We're committed to working with our partners in Latin America on a basis of mutual respect and non-interference, focusing on shared challenges and opportunities.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Bush, given the existing protectionist measures within your government, how adaptable will you be in pursuing a trade agreement with Uruguay, and what advancements have been achieved today? President Vazquez, did you seek President Bush's mediation in the ongoing dispute between Uruguay and Argentina concerning the mill plants? [SEP] We spent considerable time addressing Uruguay's market access concerns. The President raised issues such as quotas on cows and sheep, and I assured him I would consider his requests. You may think I'm joking about blueberries, but Uruguay produces excellent ones. The key question is whether their blueberry growers can sell to the U.S. We discussed various produce. I told the President, 'You can't solve problems unless you address them directly. We'll assist where possible and explain why we can't where necessary.' I'm concerned about protectionism globally, not just in our country. Free and fair trade helps alleviate poverty. I support completing the Doha round of the WTO. I shared our strategies with President Lula. The U.S. is prepared to reduce agricultural subsidies, but we require market access. Our trade minister is in Sao Paulo engaging with her Brazilian counterpart to advance this complex deal. Regarding your first question, I concur with President Bush. We've established a platform for experts and ministers to discuss bilateral issues. Uruguay advocates for free trade and reduced tariffs and subsidies. We've also explored the GSP. Concerning the second question, I didn't discuss the Argentina issue with President Bush because we'll be dialoguing with Argentina soon, thanks to the King of Spain. We'll seek a friendly resolution to our differences.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, about Prime Minister Maliki, are there any deadlines for meeting these goals? You keep mentioning the U.S. goal is to fight Al Qaeda. Does that mean you think it's up to the Iraqis to stop the sectarian violence, and the U.S. troops won't be involved? And, Prime Minister Maliki, why did you cancel the meeting last night? [SEP] What was the first part of your question again?
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, critics argue that commuting Chelsea Manning's sentence undermines the consequences for leaking classified information, particularly concerning WikiLeaks' involvement with Russian interference. Furthermore, what is your stance on Julian Assange's offer to come to the United States, and would he be subject to charges upon arrival? [SEP] Let's not forget that Chelsea Manning served a significant prison sentence. This was not a light matter. In my judgment, due process was followed, she accepted responsibility for her actions, and the sentence was disproportionately severe compared to similar cases. Given the substantial time she had already served, commuting her sentence was a reasonable course of action. I am confident that justice has been served, and a clear message has been conveyed regarding the importance of national security. Individuals with legitimate concerns should utilize established channels and avail themselves of whistleblower protections. While some may find these protections inadequate, we must recognize that national security often involves individuals in the field whose lives are at risk. Regarding WikiLeaks, I have refrained from making broad statements. The intelligence community's findings regarding Russian hacking and WikiLeaks' potential involvement were inconclusive. I do not closely follow Mr. Assange's social media activity. I would direct you to the Justice Department for any information regarding criminal investigations or extradition matters. In this digital age, we must strive to find the right balance between accountability, transparency, and the need to safeguard ourselves from those who seek to exploit our openness. We must preserve the integrity of our democracy while ensuring that our national security agencies can operate effectively without compromising sensitive information. In the case of Chelsea Manning, I carefully considered the specific circumstances and concluded that commuting her sentence was entirely justified.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. So are you doing anything to provide that? [SEP] ——the Post Office is tripling up instead.The problem is the Democrats are not approving the funds necessary. It's in there. Now, they have $25 billion. I've seen $15 billion. I've seen a lot of money. I don't know how you're going to spend that much, but that's what they're saying. They're saying. So not only do they want a trillion dollars to hand out as welfare to all these States that are run by Democrats doing badly, they want $25 billion for the Post Office. But they're not approving it.Now, what I want is a lot of money—thousands of dollars—to go to people because they need money. They really—despite the good numbers, despite numbers like that, they need money to live. And I want that to happen. The Democrats don't care about that. They just want to give bailout money to their friends running big States poorly.
label: Dodging

sentence: President Biden, concerning the recent announcement regarding the acceptance of citizens from Venezuela, Haiti, Cuba, and Nicaragua, what is the expected timeline for this initiative? Are there any plans to expand the number of accepted individuals or include additional countries in the program? Additionally, could you provide details on the amount of investment being made in technological improvements within the United States? And President López Obrador, how is Mexico preparing to accommodate the migrants who will be expelled from the United States? What is the intended purpose of the new migration center being established in the southern part of Mexico? Following this summit, do you anticipate any significant changes in migration policies or the overall treatment of migrants? Finally, President Biden, what specific actions are you planning to implement to address the issue of fentanyl, and what impact has the detention of Ovidio Guzmán had on this effort? And did you discuss energy sector consultations under the USMCA? [SEP] We had a broad discussion about migration, focusing on cooperation with the U.S. while also emphasizing our commitment to protecting migrants. President Biden's proposal is fundamentally sound: migrants face significant risks when crossing our country, including exploitation by human traffickers who charge exorbitant fees. These traffickers operate extensive networks and use trucks to transport hundreds of people, often leading to tragic accidents. Furthermore, many migrants are kidnapped and murdered, which is deeply distressing. Our aim is to find a comprehensive, long-term solution. As President Biden has rightly pointed out, people do not leave their homes, families, and countries for pleasure; they do so out of necessity. We must address the root causes of migration by investing in development in countries struggling with inequality and poverty, thereby making migration a matter of choice rather than a forced circumstance. In the meantime, Mexico is doing its part with limited resources, working with communities in El Salvador and Honduras, and soon expanding our efforts to Guatemala and Belize. However, we need to further promote development and well-being to ensure that those who are compelled to migrate have opportunities in their home communities. We have no plans to construct a migration center in southeastern Mexico; instead, we are focusing on providing assistance through shelters, healthcare services, and food. We applaud the U.S. administration's decision to implement an orderly migration process, as exemplified by the program for Venezuelan citizens. Since the announcement of humanitarian visas for Venezuelans, we have observed a decrease in migration flows. This new approach offers hope, allowing individuals to submit their requests through established channels. Canada's actions in this regard are also commendable. Historically, migration patterns have primarily involved individuals from Central America and Mexico, with a significant number of Mexicans seeking better opportunities in the United States. Today, there are approximately 40 million Mexicans residing in the U.S., either born in Mexico or the children of Mexican immigrants. Through our efforts to promote well-being, we have successfully reduced the number of Mexican migrants. Currently, 30 million Mexican families are benefiting from at least one well-being program. Senior citizens receive pensions, and students from low-income families receive scholarships. We have also launched a major reforestation program, providing employment to 400,000 peasants. These programs are designed to help people remain in their communities. We have built the Dos Bocas refinery and are constructing the Mayan train, both of which are creating jobs. Development is the key to addressing migration. I commend both Canada and the U.S. for adopting this approach. Unfortunately, some politicians are acting inhumanely, such as governors who are sending migrants to New York and Washington. We must seek alternative solutions and address the underlying causes of violence. For too long, we neglected our youth, labeling them as unproductive and uneducated. We now have a program that provides opportunities for young people, employing 2.4 million as apprentices and steering them away from criminal groups. My administration is committed to combating corruption and ensuring that crime and authority remain separate. We have reached agreements to work together to promote peace and security in all three countries.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, you campaigned on limiting executive overreach, criticizing President Bush's expansion of power. With Congress seemingly unable to agree on anything, do you now see it as your duty to push the boundaries of executive authority to get things done, even if it invites criticism of being an 'imperial president'? Or are you more concerned about being labeled a 'do-nothing' president due to congressional inaction? [SEP] I operate under the Constitution, period. There's no 'green light' to ignore the separation of powers. Congress controls the money, end of story. I'd love to fund a huge infrastructure project, put folks to work, and boost GDP. But without Congress on board, I'm limited. I can speed up permits, work with the private sector, but they have to pass a budget. So, no green light. What I will do, consistently, is use my legal authority to help middle-class families. Whether it's fair wages for contractors, equal pay for women, or better student loan programs, I'll seize those opportunities. That's what Americans expect. I'd rather work with Congress; they can do more, and it lasts longer. Look at immigration reform. We had a bipartisan bill in the Senate, but House Republicans are blocking it. The American people want action, and there's common ground. In that situation, I'll find ways to make progress within my authority. We'll stay within the limits of executive power. But I won't just sit around waiting for Congress. I'll keep reaching out to both parties, trying to find ways to move forward, even if it's step by step.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, any decision on the Federal Reserve Chair? What are you considering? It's getting late. Are you worried about the timeline, especially if you're not renominating Powell? [SEP] No, no, and no. Not discussing it. It's in progress. Announcement soon. It's been in the works. Plenty of time for approvals. I've thought about it, met with advisors. Good choices. No speculation. Nancy, CBS, question?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, could you elaborate on your middle class tax plan? [SEP] You know what my plan is? You know what my plan is? I'll ask them. And if they say yes, I'm all for it. And if they say no, there's nothing you can do, because you need their votes. Next question.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, you've mentioned potential talks with President Putin. What's your strategy going into those discussions, especially considering President Zelenskyy's insistence on the return of Crimea as a precondition for negotiations? [SEP] Let's be clear: the only rational path forward is for Putin to withdraw from Ukraine. But he seems unwilling to do that. He's paying a steep price, but the carnage he's inflicting on Ukrainian civilians is horrific. I have no immediate plans to contact Putin. However, I'm open to dialogue if he demonstrates a genuine interest in ending the war. If that happens, I'll consult with our allies before engaging. The focus now must remain on supporting the Ukrainian people. Putin has miscalculated at every turn. He thought he'd be welcomed with open arms. He was wrong. Now, how he gets himself out of this mess is the question. I'm prepared to explore that, but only in close coordination with our NATO allies. As for Zelenskyy's conditions, we must acknowledge Ukraine's right to self-determination. They're the ones suffering the war crimes and leading the counteroffensive. President Zelenskyy has presented a 10-point peace plan, and we need to engage with him on that. He was sincere in his willingness to negotiate. The one who wanted war was Putin.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: If the Republicans take the House, what's the likely outcome? [SEP] Well, if they take control, it's going to be a lot closer. The predictions of a red wave were off. We're not losing 30 to 50 seats. There are always enough people on the other side that the opposing party can try to win over. It's hard to say for sure. For example, do you think Senator Johnson will try to cut Medicare and Social Security? And if he does, how many Republicans will support him? It all depends.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. I have two questions for you, sir, if I may, the first on the 2020 election. There's a growing number of Democratic candidates who have endorsed the idea of adding seats to the Supreme Court. Is that an idea that you would entertain in the remainder of your term or possible next term? Or is that not something that you agree with? [SEP] No, I wouldn't entertain that. The only reason is—that they're doing that is they want to try and catch up. So if they can't catch up through the ballot box by winning an election, they want to try doing it in a different way. No, we would have no interest in that whatsoever. It will never happen. It won't happen—I guarantee it won't happen—for 6 years.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, the American people are looking for clarity, not vague promises. Are you prepared to commit to specific, measurable goals for economic recovery, and to hold your European counterparts accountable for their financial commitments? [SEP] Absolutely. We are committed to transparency and accountability. We will continue to provide regular updates on our progress, and we will work with our European partners to ensure they are meeting their obligations. We are all in this together, and we will succeed by working together.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Can you tell me what is the outlook for getting an agreement with the emerging economies that will limit emissions in a meaningful way in the midterm? What's the outlook for that, and how are you going to get them to come around? [SEP] Yes, well, the first thing, John, is to make sure we get a understanding that all of us need to agree on a long-term goal. And part of the reluctance has been—on some nations that are major economies—to participate at all, because initially, I'm confident, they thought they were going to get a free pass from any international agreement. I mean, after all, the Kyoto international agreement excluded major economies. And therefore, they probably think, well, maybe history will repeat itself.The idea is to say, look, we want to be effective. Effectiveness comes when major economies come to the table. The first step is to agree to a long-term goal. And I've talked to our sherpa about that, and he feels pretty good that people are now coming to that clear understanding that we're going to have to come to a long-term goal. Hopefully we can do it at this meeting. If not, we'll continue to press forward to get it done.Secondly, one of the—a lot of the developing world says, well, it's unfair; the developed world gets to develop, and we don't. Well, our attitude about that is, why don't we set up a technology fund, and that— make it easier for people to be able to afford the new technologies that nations like ours and others will bring to the marketplace.Thirdly, if you really do want to make sure technologies move around the world, we got to reduce these trade barriers and tariffs that prohibit technologies from moving like they should.And so I—we'll see, John. I mean, this is a tough issue. It's tough to get consensus. People—there's a consensus that it's a problem, but it's tough to get a consensus that all of us have a responsibility to do something about it—not just some, but all of us, so that whatever we do is effective.Bret Baier [FOX News].
label: Explicit

sentence: President Yoon, while you emphasize cooperation with countries sharing 'universal values,' some critics argue that economic security measures can be protectionist and harm global trade. How do you balance the need for secure supply chains with your commitment to free and open trade? [SEP] It's a delicate balance, certainly. We're not aiming to create barriers or isolate ourselves. Our goal is to build resilient supply chains with partners we trust, based on shared values and principles. This doesn't mean excluding others, but rather prioritizing cooperation with those who uphold the same standards of transparency, fairness, and respect for international law. We believe that a strong network of like-minded nations can actually strengthen global trade by promoting stability and predictability. We're committed to working within the framework of international organizations like the WTO to ensure that our economic security measures are consistent with our obligations and contribute to a more open and prosperous global economy.
label: General

sentence: Q. Did the recent leaks revealing that the U.S. was spying on South Korea come up at all in your discussions? And did President Biden provide you any assurances? [SEP] With regard to that, we are communicating between our two countries, and we are sharing necessary information. I believe that investigation is underway in the United States, so various and complex variables are always in play. We need time to wait for the investigation results by the United States. And we plan to continue to communicate on the matter. This will be the last question.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with the UK expressing strong reservations about Gary McKinnon's extradition, and Prime Minister Cameron's intervention, is there any possibility of a more compassionate resolution? [SEP] This is a matter of ongoing discussion between the US and UK. I don't want to prejudice those discussions. We understand the gravity of the charges against Mr. McKinnon. I have discussed this with the US Ambassador and the Prime Minister, and I hope a resolution can be found. Cybersecurity is a growing challenge, and we must cooperate. The President doesn't get involved in these matters. My team will follow the law and work closely with our ally. I trust we'll find a solution that underscores the seriousness of the issue, but also underscores the fact that we work together and we can find an appropriate solution.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. But you're—are you going to notify Congress of pulling out of NAFTA? [SEP] What we're probably going to do is call it the USMC. Like the United States Marine Corps, which I love. General Kelly likes it even more. Where's General Kelly? He likes that. USMC—which would be U.S., Mexico, Canada. But it'll probably or possibly be just USM. It will be United States and Mexico.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, do you know if he was invited? [SEP] I honestly couldn't tell you. I don't manage the guest list for these things. I do know that my staff and their staff work hand-in-glove, and that close collaboration is essential for effective governance.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the situation with Russia and Ukraine, you indicated that you think Putin will 'move in.' Has your administration assessed whether President Putin has decided to invade or otherwise move into Ukraine? [SEP] Look, the bottom line is this: Putin is calling the shots, period. Nobody else is influencing his decision. Frankly, it might depend on what side of the bed he wakes up on. He might want to talk about strategic doctrine and force structures in Europe, but who knows if he's made up his mind? Our meetings haven't produced anything because the people negotiating with him don't seem to know what he's planning. He could try to occupy the whole country, but he'd have to wait for the ground to freeze. We're giving Ukraine defense support and keeping an eye on the Baltic and Black Seas. He's weighing the consequences for Russia, but I don't think he's made a final decision.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, critics contend that despite your discussions with Chairman Kim, concrete progress on denuclearization remains elusive. Can you provide specific details on the options you've explored and the roadmap for achieving verifiable denuclearization? [SEP] We talked about a lot of things. Denuclearization is a big word, everybody uses it, but it's pretty simple: get rid of the nukes. He's got a chance to have one of the most successful countries on Earth, and fast. Incredible country, incredible location. Russia on one side, China on the other, surrounded by water, beautiful shorelines. Tremendous potential in North Korea. He's going to lead it to something very important, economically. It's going to be an economic power. Go ahead, next question.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, is there a specific reason you've avoided attending? [SEP] Look, I'm not saying I wouldn't like to. In fact, I think it would be great, tremendous even. But, you know, sometimes you just can't.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Given the administration's stated concerns about Speaker Pelosi's visit, what specific diplomatic strategies are being employed to engage with Syria, and what measurable benchmarks are being used to assess progress towards changing their behavior? [SEP] We're using every tool at our disposal: sanctions, diplomatic pressure, working with our allies to isolate the regime. We're looking for concrete action: stopping the flow of foreign fighters, reining in Hamas and Hezbollah, ending the destabilization of Lebanon. These are the benchmarks, and we're not seeing progress. That's why these solo missions are so damaging; they give Asad a lifeline he doesn't deserve.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Was that a concession on the part of the United States? [SEP] No, not at all. Because if you look at it, I mean, it said we are going to—let's see here—it will be gone. We—I don't think you can be anymore plain than what we're asking—issues related to the establishment of the new U.S.-D.P.R.K relations—the building. We talk about the guarantees, and we talk about unwavering commitment to the complete denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula. This is the document that we just signed.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. And also, the fate of the Christians? [SEP] Yes.
label: Dodging

sentence: What are the necessary conditions for a potential meeting with President Castro in Havana? Also, is the administration considering additional economic, military, or cyber measures against North Korea? [SEP] We are focused on seeing tangible improvements in Cuba before considering a meeting. As for North Korea, we are evaluating a range of responses and will act decisively to protect our interests.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about budget process. In the past, you've negotiated along with the debt ceiling with the Blue Dogs, for instance, in 2009, 2010—along with a debt ceiling increase then. Pay-as-you-go reform, you named a fiscal commission. The Republicans today are talking about maybe another committee that would work out our differences over the next few weeks. Is that something that you could talk about on the side, something that wouldn't necessarily be a concession, but something that would be a format for getting a deal done? [SEP] Yes, here's the thing, Steven. I know that Speaker Boehner has talked about setting up some new process or some new supercommittee or what have you. The leaders up in Congress, they can work through whatever processes they want. But the bottom line is either you're having good-faith negotiations in which there's give and take, or you're not.Now, there is already a process in place called the Budget Committees that could come together right now—Democrats have been asking for 19 months to bring them together—make a determination how much should the Government be spending next year. The Appropriations Committees could go through the list, and here's how much we're going to be spending for defense and here's how much we're going to be spending for education. And that's a process that's worked reasonably well for the last 50 years. I don't know that we need to set up a new committee for a process like that to move forward.What has changed, or what seems to be motivating the idea we have to have a new process is, Speaker Boehner, or at least some faction of the Republicans in the House and maybe some in the Senate, are holding out for a negotiation in theory, but in fact, basically, Democrats give a lot of concessions to Republicans, Republicans don't give anything, and then that's dubbed as compromise. And the reason that Democrats have to give is because they're worried that the Government is going to stay shut down or the U.S. Government is going to default.And again, that—you can dress it up any way you want. If that's the theory that the Republicans are going forward with, then it's not going to work.So let me just give you one specific example. I've heard at least—and I can't confirm this—that one of the ideas of this new committee is, you could talk about reductions in discretionary spending, you could talk about entitlement reform and reductions in mandatory spending, you could talk about how long you'd extend the debt ceiling, but you couldn't talk about closing corporate loopholes that aren't benefiting ordinary folks economically and, potentially, if you closed them, would allow us to pay for things like better education for kids.Well, I don't know why Democrats right now would agree to a format that takes off the table all the things they care about and is confined to the things that the Republicans care about.So again, I don't know that that's exactly what's being proposed. My simple point is this: I think Democrats in the Senate and the House are prepared to talk about anything. I'm prepared to talk about anything. They can design whatever formats they want. What is not fair and will not result in an actual deal is ransom-taking or hostage-taking, and the expectation that Democrats are paying ransom or providing concessions for the mere act of reopening the Government or paying our bills. Those are not things that you do for me, and they're not things that you do for the Democrats.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. How long for Khalid Sheikh Mohammed? Will that trial ever happen? [SEP] Well, I think it needs to happen. And we're going to work with Members of Congress--and this is going to have to be on a bipartisan basis--to move this forward in a way that is consistent with our standards of due process, consistent with our Constitution, consistent also with our image in the world of a country that cares about rule of law. You can't underestimate the impact of that.Al Qaida operatives still cite Guantanamo as a justification for attacks against the United States--still, to this day. And there's no reason for us to give them that kind of talking point when, in fact, we can use the various mechanisms of our justice system to prosecute these folks and to make sure that they never attack us again. Okay?Ed Henry [CNN].
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, your approval ratings have taken a hit lately. How do you plan to regain the trust of the American people and convince them you're the right leader to guide us through these challenging times? [SEP] The polls? They're all rigged, folks! We're winning everywhere. Leading in North Carolina, Pennsylvania, Arizona, Florida, Georgia – bigly! The fake news media is pushing these suppression polls to discourage our supporters, but they won't succeed. Remember 2016? They said I couldn't win, and I won every swing state. It's happening again, believe me. The enthusiasm is off the charts!
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the UK's exemption to the travel ban despite having a comparable number of coronavirus cases to Schengen countries, and a recent surge in cases, could you elaborate on the rationale behind this decision? Are you open to reconsidering their inclusion on the restricted list? [SEP] Well, the situation is fluid, and we're constantly evaluating the data as it comes in. The professionals made an initial recommendation, but we're certainly not averse to adjusting our approach based on the latest figures. We're monitoring the UK's situation very closely, along with several other countries, and we'll make the necessary adjustments to the list as needed. It's a dynamic situation, and we're prepared to be flexible.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. In your view, does Kim Jong Un stand on equal footing with you? [SEP] How do you define 'equal' in this situation?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given the limited number of tests conducted in the U.S. compared to other countries, are you confident that your administration is accurately assessing the scope and severity of the coronavirus outbreak? [SEP] We're doing what we need to do. We're testing the people who need to be tested. And frankly, we're not seeing a widespread problem. It's like the flu, really. People should wash their hands, stay home if they're sick. Many people who get it don't even know they have it. They might just have a sniffle or feel a little off. We're working on a vaccine, just like we have for the flu. So, we're on top of it. We're handling it very well. The numbers are very low, relatively speaking.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Just to make it 100 percent clear, you'd sign a budget that continues to fund the Government even at the lower levels of the sequester, even if you don't prefer to do that? [SEP] Zach, I'm not going to—I never want to make myself 100 percent clear with you guys. [] But I think it's fair to say that I made a deal for a certain budget, certain numbers. There's no reason why that deal needs to be reopened. It was a deal that Speaker Boehner made as well and all the leadership made. And if the bill that arrives on my desk is reflective of the commitments that we've previously made, then obviously, I would sign it because I want to make sure that we keep on doing what we need to do for the American people. All right?Jessica [Jessica Yellin, CNN].
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the potential use of chemical weapons, while I understand you can't divulge specific intelligence, can you at least confirm if the administration has observed any activity that raises concerns about a possible deployment by President Putin? And to reiterate, would any use of such weapons trigger a military response from the U.S. or NATO? [SEP] Look, what I can say is this: we are watching the situation very, very closely. I'm not going to telegraph our punches, and I'm certainly not going to compromise any sources or methods. But let me be clear, any use of chemical weapons would be met with a response. The severity of that response? That's something we'll determine based on the specifics.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Obama, while acknowledging the progress in Chile, the shadow of the past still looms large for many. Beyond simply considering requests, will the U.S. proactively offer assistance to Chilean investigations, perhaps by forming a joint commission to review historical documents and provide support for truth and reconciliation efforts? [SEP] We recognize the importance of addressing the past, and we're open to exploring ways to further cooperate with Chile on these issues. We're committed to a strong relationship with Chile, based on shared values and mutual respect. As for specific mechanisms, we're open to discussing various options with the Chilean government to determine the most effective way to support their efforts. Our focus is on building a stronger future for both our nations, and that requires acknowledging and learning from the past.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. You signed a document with Kim Jong Un. It's essentially a piece of paper. Yesterday we had a briefing from the Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. He said the following: Many Presidents previously have signed off on pieces of paper only to find that the North Koreans either didn't promise what we thought they had or actually reneged on those promises. What makes this time different, Mr. President? [SEP] Well, you have a different administration. You have a different President. You have a different Secretary of State. You have people that are—you know, it's very important to them. And we get it done. The other groups, maybe it wasn't a priority. I don't think they could have done it if it was a priority, frankly. I don't think they honestly could have done it even if it was a priority.And it would have been easier back then. It would have been—for me, it would have been much easier if this were 10 years ago or 5 years ago. And I'm not just blaming President Obama. I mean, this goes back—for 25 years, this should have happened. I was given a very tough hand. I was given this, I was given the Iran deal and plenty of other problems.But we are—we're doing really well. And the Iran deal, I have to be honest, we—I did it because nuclear is always number one to me. Nuclear is number one. But on the Iran deal, I think Iran is a different country now than it was 3 or 4 months ago. I don't think they're looking so much to the Mediterranean. I don't think they're looking so much at Syria, like they were, with total confidence. I don't think they're so confident right now.But I hope—with that being said, I hope that, at the appropriate time, after these sanctions kick in—and they are brutal, what we've put on Iran—I hope that they're going to come back and negotiate a real deal, because I'd love to be able to do that. But right now it's too soon for that.Yes, please.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Biden, what specific assurances, if any, did you provide to President Erdogan regarding his request for new F-16 fighter jets for the Turkish military?
