So, beyond your stated refusal to negotiate, is there any contingency plan under consideration, and if not, why is every alternative being dismissed? [SEP] Look, folks, let's be clear. This isn't about fancy legal maneuvers or pulling rabbits out of hats. This is about whether the United States honors its obligations. We're not some fly-by-night operation that skips out on its bills. The solution is straightforward: Congress needs to authorize us to pay what we already owe. If they're too timid to make the tough choices themselves, they can hand me the reins. Senator McConnell floated a similar idea before, and I'd gladly take him up on it. But if they insist on holding the purse strings, then they need to do their job and get this done. There are no shortcuts, no loopholes, no easy escapes. Congress authorizes the spending, they mandate the expenditures, and then they conveniently forget to raise the debt ceiling to cover it? That's not how this works. Raising the debt ceiling isn't about greenlighting new spending; it's about paying for what Congress has already approved. The consequences of default would be catastrophic, as I've already stated. So, while I appreciate the desire for a quick fix, there's only one real solution: Congress needs to authorize the payment of the bills they've already incurred. The notion that some Republicans would hold the nation's credit hostage to get their way on spending priorities is, frankly, un-American. They have their views, the Democrats have theirs, and they need to find a compromise.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. On any of them? Ukraine? [SEP] Well look, I think, Bill, that the nature of being President is that you're always asking yourself what more can you do. But with respect to, let's say, the Israeli-Palestinian issue, this administration invested an enormous amount to try to bring the parties together around a framework for peace and a two-state solution. John Kerry invested an enormous amount of time. In the end, it's up to the two parties to make a decision. We can lead them to resolve some of the technical issues and to show them a path, but they've got to want it.With respect to Ukraine, I think that we have done everything that we can to support the Ukrainian Government and to deter Russia from moving further into Ukraine. But short of going to war, there are going to be some constraints in terms of what we can do if President Putin and Russia are ignoring what should be their long-term interests.Right now if—what we've done is impose sufficient costs on Russia that, objectively speaking, they should—President Putin should want to resolve this diplomatically, get these sanctions lifted, get their economy growing again, and have good relations with Ukraine. But sometimes, people don't always act rationally, and they don't always act based on their medium- or long-term interests. That can't deter us though. We've just got to stay at it.Wendell [Wendell Goler, FOX News].
label: General

sentence: Q. I'd like to ask you about Iraq. General Petraeus and Gates are talking about a pause in troop reductions once we get to the pre-surge levels in July. Will that be it, or is it possible that there will be additional drawdowns before you leave office?And also, does the Iraqi Government's decision to host Ahmadi-nejad in Baghdad undermine your efforts to isolate Tehran? [SEP] To the latter, I—look, I mean, he's a neighbor. And the message needs to be, quit sending in sophisticated equipment that's killing our citizens, and that the message will be that we're negotiating a long-term security agreement with the United States precisely because we want enough breathing space for our democracy to develop.My message is for him, stop exporting terror, and that the international community is serious about continuing to isolate Iran until they come clean about their nuclear weapons ambitions. And that's why there will be action in the United Nations here early next week as we work collaboratively to continue to send a clear message.In terms of troop levels, there is going to be enormous speculation, again, about what decision I will make. I can only tell you, Deb, that it's going to be based upon the recommendations of Secretary Gates, General Petraeus, the Joint Chiefs. My sole criterion is, whatever we do, it ought to be in the context of success.If we fail in Iraq, the consequences for world peace will be enormous; the consequences for the security of the United States will be enormous. And therefore, my question is, what does it take to succeed? And we're not going to let politics drive my decision—again. If I worried about polls and focus groups, I wouldn't have sent more troops in. I sent more troops in because the situation was unacceptable. And now we're succeeding. And so therefore, Ryan Crocker—the Ambassador—and General Petraeus will be coming back, and they'll report to the country, and they'll report to me. And the decisions—you'll see them evolve.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, who in the Republican Party needs to hear the message of inclusivity? [SEP] Well, I'm concerned that, following the defeat, the inclination will be to look inward and impose strict ideological requirements. This party will rebound. But the party's message must be that different viewpoints are included. Take, for example, the immigration debate. It's a very contentious issue. The problem with the initial debate was that some people said, 'Republicans don't like immigrants.' Now, that may be fair or unfair, but that's the image that emerged. And if the image is that we don't like immigrants, then there's probably someone else out there saying, 'Well, if they don't like the immigrants, they probably don't like me as well.' So, my point is that our party has got to be compassionate and broadminded. I remember the 1964 elections. My dad happened to be running for the United States Senate then and, you know, got landslided with the Johnson landslide in the State of Texas. But it wasn't just George Bush who got defeated, the Republican Party was pretty well decimated at the time. At least that's what the pundits viewed it. And then '66, there was a resurgence. And the same thing can happen this time, but we just got to make sure our message is broad-gauged and compassionate: That we care about people's lives, and we've got a plan to help them improve their lives.
label: General

sentence: Q. Where is that? And do you have confidence in the investigation? [SEP] Well, I can't tell you that yet. I have to see. I'm not involved in it. I purposely stayed uninvolved. I'm, I guess, considered the chief law enforcement officer of the country. I could be involved if I wanted to. I thought it would be better if I wasn't. I think it's better if our great Attorney General handle it. He has Durham, who is a very, very respected man, and we're going to see what it is. I can't tell you that.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the shooting you mentioned occurring 'outside,' could you specify the distance from the White House? [SEP] A full briefing will be provided to you all shortly.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering the Roxham Road agreement's year-long finalization, what factors contributed to the extended delay? Furthermore, in light of Canada's acceptance of 15,000 migrants, what specific concessions were made to the U.S. in exchange for this arrangement? [SEP] Well, no, I'm not disappointed. This is a very difficult situation. How do we deal with what's going on in Haiti, where gangs have essentially taken over the government? They're running the show. So, I think what the Prime Minister has said makes sense. The most important thing we can do, and it will take time, is to improve the capacity of the police departments to deal with the problems. That will take a while. We're also looking at whether the international community, through the UN, can play a larger role. There's a real concern because there are several million people in Haiti, and the diaspora could cause some real, shall we say, confusion in the Western Hemisphere. So, I think what the Prime Minister is suggesting, and we're also contributing, is to increase the efficiency and capacity of the police training and methods. We're also talking to others in the hemisphere who are prepared to help. It's a work in progress.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Voting by mail is a scam? [SEP] ——at a level—they are never going to be able to count them. Let me ask you——
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning potential discussions with President Putin, what's your strategy? And with the Ukrainian war seemingly at a turning point, do you think President Zelenskyy's demand for Crimea's return as a condition for negotiations is realistic? [SEP] Well, there's only one rational way this war ends: Putin pulls out of Ukraine. Number one. But it appears he's not going to do that. He's paying a very heavy price for failing to do it, but he's inflicting incredible, incredible carnage on the civilian population of Ukraine, bombing nurseries, hospitals, children's homes. It's sick what he's doing. But the fact of the matter is, I have no immediate plans to contact Mr. Putin. Mr. Putin is—let me choose my words very carefully—I'm prepared to speak with Mr. Putin if in fact there is an interest in him deciding he's looking for a way to end the war. He hasn't done that yet. If that's the case, in consultation with my French and my NATO friends, I'll be happy to sit down with Putin to see what he wants—has in mind. He hasn't done that yet. In the meantime, I think it's absolutely critical what Emmanuel said: We must support the Ukrainian people. The idea that Putin is ever going to defeat Ukraine is beyond comprehension. Imagine them trying to occupy that country through the next 2, 5, 10, 20 years if they could—if they could. He's miscalculated every single thing he initially calculated. He thought he'd be greeted with open arms by the Russian-speaking portions of the Ukrainian population.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President, following up on the Putin matter, can you share any details about the substance of your exchange that led to his reported satisfaction? [SEP] The matter is closed. His reaction speaks for itself. Let's move on.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And he'll be here for the remainder of your term? [SEP] Yes, he will. Thank you.Suzanne [Suzanne Malveaux, Cable News Network].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, your recent remarks on Brexit seem to diverge sharply from your stance earlier in the week. You implied the Prime Minister's plan would kill a trade deal with the UK, a nation with whom we supposedly share a 'special relationship.' Is this the behavior of a true ally? And Prime Minister, are you concerned that the President's critiques might hold merit, potentially hindering future trade deals? [SEP] Look, let's be clear. I wasn't criticizing the Prime Minister. I have tremendous respect for her. The media, as usual, twisted my words. Thankfully, we record these interviews now. It's called fighting fake news. The Prime Minister will make her own decisions. All I ask is that we ensure open trade, no restrictions. We want to trade with the UK, and they want to trade with us. We're their biggest partner, and we can double, triple, quadruple that. If they go a different route – and they want independence, of course – I just hope they can still trade with the US. Some say it's impossible, but I believe it's absolutely possible after talking with their people. So, trade is a little complicated, but we'll figure it out. And she's doing a fantastic job, by the way.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to the Senkaku Islands, could you clarify your position? If China were to take military action, would the United States intervene militarily? Some see this as a potential repeat of the Syria situation, where a 'red line' was drawn but not enforced. Also, concerning North Korea, are you issuing a direct warning against further nuclear tests? And Prime Minister Abe, given the West's perceived inaction in Ukraine, do you have full faith in President Obama's assurances regarding your security? [SEP] Let's break that down. The treaty with Japan isn't something I just invented; it's been the consistent interpretation for years that Japanese-administered territories are covered. So, no new 'red line' from me. We're simply applying the existing agreement. That being said, I've told the Prime Minister that escalation isn't the answer. We need dialogue and trust between Japan and China, and we'll be pushing for that through diplomacy. As for international law, we believe in it. When you gas kids or invade another country, you're breaking the rules. But that doesn't mean the U.S. has to go to war every single time. We've gotten 87% of Syria's chemical weapons out without firing a shot – that's a win. On Russia and Ukraine, a military solution isn't in the cards. We've already hit Russia with sanctions, and we're still hoping for a diplomatic fix. They seemed to be on board after Geneva, but they haven't followed through. Meanwhile, Kiev is making real progress with reforms. If Russia keeps ignoring the agreement, there will be more consequences. These are tough problems, but we're standing up for what we believe in. Remind me about North Korea?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President—[inaudible]—Valentinovna, Sputnik News Agency. Have you discussed the issue of possible inspections to North Korea's nuclear sites during your negotiations? [SEP] You're going to have to speak a little louder. And where are you from? Where are you from?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, what's your strategy for resolving the situation in Crimea? [SEP] Well, we're going to see what happens. It's a process. If I had a magic bullet, I wouldn't tell you, because that would ruin everything. But we're looking at it. Crimea was another mess I inherited, like North Korea. We're doing great with North Korea. No nuclear testing, no missile launches, no rocket launches. We got our hostages back. So, we'll see what happens with Crimea. It's going to take time, but I'm used to that.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Senator McCain advocates for a more confrontational approach towards Vladimir Putin. Do you believe this is the right strategy, and what is your assessment of the long-term prospects for democracy in Russia under Putin's continued leadership? [SEP] My leadership style is about influence, and that comes from personal relationships. It allows me to speak frankly without damaging relations. That's how I've approached Vladimir Putin. We disagree on many things, but we agree on some, like counterterrorism and nuclear proliferation. Good diplomacy requires good relations at the leadership level. In Slovakia, I told him we were concerned about the press becoming less free. He didn't like it, but it didn't ruin our relationship. He told me going into Iraq was a mistake. That's good diplomacy. I'll keep doing that. As for changing Russia's DNA, that's hard. We've made it clear that good relations with the West are in their interest. That means checks and balances and respecting freedoms. Russia is a complex relationship, but it's important.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Brexit, you seemed to shift your position from earlier in the week, suggesting the current plan would jeopardize a U.S.-U.K. trade deal. Considering our supposed 'special relationship,' wasn't publicly criticizing the Prime Minister's policy, and even her personally, a bit much? And Prime Minister, how did you react to President Trump's comments on your Brexit plan and its potential limitations on future trade deals? [SEP] Look, about the Prime Minister, I have tremendous respect for her. The media, as usual, twisted my words. They conveniently left out the good stuff I said. Thankfully, we record these things now – a great way to combat 'fake news,' you know? The Prime Minister will make her own decisions. I just want to make sure we can trade, no restrictions. We want to trade with the U.K., and they want to trade with us. We're their biggest trading partner, by far. Huge opportunity to grow that. If they go a different route – and they want independence, which is fine – I just hope they can still trade with the U.S. Some say it won't be possible, but I believe, after talking to her people, it will be. So, based on that, and our relationship in general – which will be fine – trade is a little tricky. We both want to trade, and I think we'll get there. She's doing a terrific job, by the way.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, Rick Ledgett of the NSA suggested a conversation about amnesty for Edward Snowden. Were you pleased by this suggestion? Under what conditions would you consider a plea agreement or amnesty? And what do you say to Americans who believe Snowden's actions were proper and just, alerting us to surveillance scope? [SEP] I must tread carefully, as Mr. Snowden faces indictment and criminal charges. This falls under the purview of the Attorney General, a judge, and a jury. Thus, I cannot comment on the specifics. However, I can address the spirit of the question. I've stated before that this was a necessary conversation. However, the disclosures caused damage to the U.S. and our intelligence capabilities. There was a way to have this debate without such harm. For example, the U.S., despite its flaws, upholds the rule of law, values privacy, civil liberties, and our Constitution. These disclosures allow countries that explicitly engage in surveillance, target dissidents, and suppress the press to criticize the U.S. This distorts the reality. While this debate was important, it caused unnecessary damage to U.S. intelligence and diplomacy. I'll defer to the courts and the Attorney General on the specifics of Mr. Snowden's case.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. So, just to confirm, the business sector benefits, and the climate is addressed, but your direct involvement isn't essential? Is that a fair summary? [SEP] I'm sorry, I missed part of that. Could you say it again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. What specifically do you expect to see coming out of Secretary Rice's visit in Kenya for a few hours on Monday? How much can get done on Monday?And for both of you, at what point does it take more active intervention by an American President in some of the trouble spots here in Africa? [SEP] Well, first, you know, I've been very active, in this sense: Every time I meet with a world leader that could affect the outcome of a particular issue, I bring it up and expect there to be, you know, focus and concrete action. For example, I've spent a fair amount of time with Hu Jintao on Darfur, talking about the need for us to work collaboratively on Darfur, same in Burma. In other words, what—these meetings give me an opportunity to talk about ways forward in trouble spots.In terms of Condi's visit, I will—the key is, is that the leaders hear from her firsthand U.S. desires to see that there be no violence and that there be a power-sharing agreement that will help this nation resolve its difficulties. That's what diplomacy is, and we've been very active on all fronts. Ours—after all, back to Darfur, ours is the first and probably only nation that's declared it a genocide.And you know, I had a tough decision to make early on, and that is whether to send troops into Darfur. And I think I've discussed this with you all before, that I made the decision not to, upon the recommendation of a lot of the groups involved in Darfur as well as other folks. I've listened very carefully to their—whether we should or shouldn't, but once you make that decision, then there's not many other avenues except for the United Nations and the peacekeeping forces. And that's where we spend a lot of time and energy trying to get there to be an effective response.The African Union stepped forward initially. And one of the reasons I'm going to Rwanda is to thank President Kagame for his strong efforts in Darfur as a—as one of the real leaders in providing peacekeepers.But we've been plenty active on these issues. And we'll continue to be active on these issues because they're important issues for the U.S. security and for our interests.Well, Mr. President, thank you. Like, press conference over. []
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, are you confident the conflict will be over by the end of your presidency? And what is your opinion on Israel's conduct? [SEP] I'm hopeful. I support a durable cease-fire. A durable cease-fire requires Hamas to cease rocket fire into Israel. There will not be a durable cease-fire if they continue. I think it's up to Hamas. The best way to ensure a durable cease-fire is to collaborate with Egypt to halt the smuggling of arms into Gaza that enables Hamas to continue firing rockets. Countries supplying weapons to Hamas must stop. The international community must pressure them to stop providing weapons. Hamas, if they desire a durable cease-fire, must stop arming. Countries bordering Gaza must work to stop smuggling. It's a difficult task, with tunnels and opportunities for those who want to disrupt democracy to provide weapons. Remind me of the second part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, Afghan President Karzai accuses Pakistan's intelligence of aiding terrorists. Reports suggest Al Qaeda is back to pre-9/11 levels along the Pakistan-Afghanistan border. Is Karzai right? And can Pakistan's new government fight these terrorists? [SEP] First, we'll look into Karzai's claims with his help. No doubt, some extremists cross from Pakistan into Afghanistan. That's a problem for us, for Afghanistan, and for Pakistan. We share an enemy: extremists who use violence to disrupt or prevent democracy. Al Qaeda is still there. We've hit them hard globally, including in Pakistan, and we'll keep the pressure on with our Pakistani friends. I hope the Pakistani government understands the danger of extremists in their country. I think they do. I'll discuss it with their Prime Minister on Monday. Pakistan is an ally, a friend. We all – US, Pakistan, Afghanistan – share an enemy. I recall a White House meeting with Presidents Musharraf and Karzai where we discussed cross-border cooperation to stop dangerous elements from training and entering Afghanistan, then returning home with skills to use against the government. We made some progress, but it's still a tough fight. We were encouraged by the provincial elections there. We'll keep helping the government fight extremists and develop a counterinsurgency strategy using aid to boost the economy. It's a challenge, and we're better together. Alright, thanks for your time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Considering your reputation for evolving positions, how can the British Prime Minister have confidence in your commitments to a post-Brexit trade agreement and NATO? Also, what personal affinities have you found with the Prime Minister, given your seemingly disparate styles? [SEP] Look, people say I change my mind, but my core principles remain the same: America first. And I think the Prime Minister and I see eye-to-eye on that. We're both strong leaders who want what's best for our countries. Brexit's a game-changer, a chance for the UK to thrive. And we're going to make sure they have the best trade deal possible. It's going to be a win-win.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. My question is: Will it exist by May 1? [SEP] The individual Governors have testing. The individual Governors—we have many forms of testing, and new testing is being developed.Our country has to get open, and it will get open, and it will get open safely and, hopefully, quickly, some areas quicker than other areas. But there is tremendous testing and the Governors will use whatever testing is necessary. And if they're not satisfied with their testing, they shouldn't open. But they'll use whatever is testing—whatever testing is necessary.Go ahead. Please./World Trade Organization
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, can you detail the specific intelligence assessments that link the Qods Force directly to the provision of these IEDs, beyond simply stating that 'we know they're there'? [SEP] We have a responsibility to protect classified information. What I can tell you is that we have strong evidence, and we're acting on that evidence. We're not going to compromise our intelligence sources or methods by revealing specific details. The focus should be on the fact that our troops are in danger, and we're taking action to address that danger.
label: General

sentence: Q. ——about Russia meddling. You did seem to be joking there with the Russian President. Are we taking that to be wrong? [SEP] No.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. If there were an alternative, would you want those tires swapped out? [SEP] Yes, I would do that. I would. I would swap them out, based on what I heard. We'll see what happens. Hey, look, you're going to have a lot of people not wanting to buy that product anymore, and they'll buy from a competitor, made in the U.S.A. too. Okay?Please. Go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Germany's energy situation, could you detail the specific actions being taken to lessen their reliance on Russian energy? Also, how do you respond to those who believe Germany's dependence on Russian gas is hindering Europe's ability to effectively address the Ukraine crisis? [SEP] Look, we're exploring all avenues to compensate for any potential gas shortages from Russia, particularly through LNG. We're in discussions with our allies worldwide to assess how we can collectively address this issue. We believe we can offset a significant portion of any losses. But let's not forget, Russia is also heavily reliant on selling its gas and oil. It's a major source of their revenue. If that revenue stream is disrupted, they'll feel the pinch too. This isn't a one-sided situation. We're working diligently to help Europe mitigate any immediate gas supply disruptions. We're coordinating closely with our European partners, including Germany, to ensure a unified approach. We are ready to react at any time. The biggest volume of LNG used across the world is the gas, and that is part of the debate. We will modernize our economy. And where gas is being used, we will switch to hydrogen. This will be a process that will happen faster than many might imagine today, and that will create a bright future for all of us.
label: General

sentence: Q. Four-point-nine. [Laughter] The GDP of your country, you managed to grow it almost 3—2.6 trillion. So, on the contrary—of course, there is nothing to compare between Greek and United States economy—but on the contrary, Greece, the last 7 years is following the treatment of the financial institutions—the foreign financial institutions, and we're still in the eye of the storm of the recession. So, in the same time, there is no discussion about the debt relief. So my question is, how far this economy can go with this reform programs without any discussion of the debt relief? How far this relationship between Greece and the foreign institutions can last? [SEP] Well, you're right that it—you can't entirely compare between the United States and Greece for a range of reasons, not just because of the size of the economy We went through a very severe contraction We were losing 800,000 jobs a month when I came into office In fact, the economy was contracting faster than it did during the Great Depression But we were able to intervene, apply lessons learned, and stabilize and then begin growth againBut I do believe that one of the lessons we tried to apply is that it is important to combine structural reforms and good fiscal stewardship with a growth strategy Because when your economy is growing and more revenue is coming in, that helps relieve debt And sometimes, if your only approach is cutting spending at a time when the economy is contracting, then the economy will contract further, and that could add debtNow, the advantage we had is that the dollar is the reserve currency of the world Even in the midst of crisis, people were still buying US Treasury bills We were not part of a broader arrangement like the euro zone So it gave us some additional flexibilityAnd—but the key lesson that we've drawn from our experience—and it's true that we recovered faster and better, frankly, than most of Europe—is that particularly when the economy is still struggling, putting people back to work, finding ways to spur economic activity ultimately can help to reduce the structural deficits and debts that countries experienceI think the path that Greece is currently on is the right one You've engaged in some very difficult structural reforms And I think the Greek people—although it is difficult and challenging, and the politics of it, I know, are not good—should appreciate the fact that in this global economy, the Greek economy was going to have to go through some structural reforms We all do, all the time The United States has to go through structural reforms in terms of improving our education system or revamping our infrastructure or looking at some regulations that weren't properly controlling excesses on Wall Street So we initiated—or health care reform—we had to initiate a whole range of structural reformsThey're not the same as the ones that Greece has had to do, but these were necessary reforms And the Prime Minister and his government being willing to move forward on those, I think will lead to Greece being more competitive and a more attractive place for investment in the future Look, and the Greek people are entrepreneurial There are enormous resources in this country My hope is, is that more and more investors around the world see an opportunity to do business here in Greece But even as you have those structural reforms, our argument has always been that when an economy contracted this fast, when unemployment is this high, that there also has to be a growth agenda to go with it And it is very difficult to imagine the kind of growth strategy that's needed without some debt-relief mechanismNow, the politics of this are difficult in Europe And I think in fairness to some of the governments up north that I know are not always popular here in Greece, it's important to recognize that they have their own politics And their populations and their institutions often are resistant to some of these debt-relief formulasBut I think that having seen Greece begin many of these difficult steps toward structural reform, having shown a commitment to change, with the Greek people having endured some significant hardships for many years now, there should be an opportunity, I think, for both sides to recognize that if we can come up with a durable solution, as opposed to each year or every 6 months having a new negotiation, that that could potentially be good for everyone And now that the Greek economy is growing again, the timing may be rightWhite House Press Secretary Joshua R Earnest The first question from a White House reporter will come from Jerome Cartillier of AFP [Agence France-Presse] Jerome
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, the Benghazi attack remains a sensitive issue. Critics allege a cover-up. Will you pledge to appoint an independent investigator to review all aspects of the incident and provide a comprehensive report to the American people? [SEP] I'm not familiar with the details you're mentioning. But what I can say is, we're committed to finding out what happened. We're committed to the safety of our embassies. And we're committed to bringing those responsible to justice. That's our focus.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Given the public's confusion regarding the coronavirus response, why haven't you made personnel changes at the CDC or other agencies? [SEP] The confusion stems from the scientists' evolving understanding. It's a new virus, a new phenomenon. Look at how quickly we developed a vaccine. Was everything flawless? Of course not. But I'm digressing.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, are you sure this plan will benefit everyone, or are you raising expectations that you cannot meet? [SEP] Look, people want to see results. They are tired of the same old promises. We are doing things differently. If someone wants to stand in the way of progress, that's their choice. But the American people deserve better. They deserve to see their government working for them, not against them.
label: Deflection

sentence: But I see you didn't mention your supporters also being in Portland this weekend, firing paintball guns and some form of pepper spray at people. So, would you like to take this opportunity to condemn what your supporters did in Portland? [SEP] Well, from what I understand, there were a lot of supporters there, but it was a peaceful protest. And paint isn't really that harmful, it's a defensive thing, not bullets.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Is it okay if I give it to the New York Times, Mr. President? [SEP] Go ahead. That's enough, please.
label: Dodging

sentence: If Israel hadn't agreed to temporarily halt annexation, do you think a deal would have been possible? [SEP] Pardon? Could you repeat that, please?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, following the passage of the energy bill, your administration has faced criticism for preventing California from implementing stricter tailpipe emission standards. How do you reconcile your stated commitment to combating greenhouse gases with this decision, and can you share any insights from your discussions with Vice President Gore regarding climate change strategies? [SEP] Well, let me clarify the situation regarding California's emission standards. Our goal is to have a comprehensive national strategy for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, and we believe that a unified approach is more effective than a patchwork of state-level regulations. The recently passed energy bill provides a framework for achieving that national strategy, including increased fuel efficiency standards and investments in renewable energy. I had a productive conversation with Vice President Gore, and we discussed the importance of international cooperation and technological innovation in addressing climate change. We're committed to working with all stakeholders to develop a sustainable energy policy that protects our environment and strengthens our economy.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, the video you presented seemed to portray you and Kim Jong Un as equals discussing the nation's future. How do you respond to that? [SEP] No, that's not how I see it at all. I'll do whatever it takes to make the world safer. If sitting on a stage with Chairman Kim saves 30 million lives, or maybe even more, I'm willing to do it. I'm willing to travel there proudly and gladly. They've given up a tremendous amount, even before. And let's not forget the Olympics. They turned a potential failure into a tremendous success by participating. So, if I can save millions of lives by sitting down and establishing a relationship with a powerful man who controls a country with powerful nuclear weapons, it's my honor to do it.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Good afternoon, Mr. President. Good afternoon, Mr. Prime Minister. I'd like to ask a question about Roxham Road. The agreement has been ready for a year. Why did you wait so long?And for the 15,000 migrants that Canada will welcome, why so few? What have we offered to the U.S. in exchange?Prime Minister Trudeau. Thank you, Christian. We've known for a long time theoretically what modernization needed to be made to the Roxham Road, to the agreement. We couldn't simply shut down Roxham Road and hope that everything would resolve itself, because we would have had problems. The border is very long. People would have looked for other places to cross.And so that's why we chose to modernize the Safe Third Country Agreement so that someone who attempts to cross between official crossings will be subject to the principle—the same principle as someone who should seek asylum in the first safe country they arrive at.Now, for people who are coming from the U.S., that is where they should be asylum seekers, using this means of uniformly applying the agreement, which we knew theoretically would be the solution, but it takes complex processes to manage the border. It took months before we could move forward with the announcement. But by doing so, we protected the integrity of the system. And we're also continuing to live up to our obligations with respect to asylum seekers.At the same time, we continue to be open to regular migrants, and we will increase the number of asylum seekers who we accept from the hemisphere—the Western Hemisphere—in order to compensate for closing these irregular crossings.Thank you.Haiti [The reporter spoke in English as follows.] Q. Mr. President, this question is for you, but Mr. Trudeau——[The reporter continued in French, and his remarks were translated by an interpreter as follows.]Please feel free, Mr. Trudeau, to answer as well.Are you disappointed that Canada is not part or hasn't taken a bigger role in the multilateral forces in Haiti? And what would you like Canada to do more, in addition to the $100 million announced today? [SEP] Well, no, I'm not disappointed. Look, this is a very, very difficult circumstance, the idea of how do we deal with what's going on in , where gangs have essentially taken the place of the Government, in effect. They run—they rule the roost, as the saying goes.And so I think that what the Prime Minister has spoken about makes a lot of sense. The biggest thing we could do, and it's going to take time, is to increase the prospect of the police departments in having the capacity to deal with the problems that are faced. And that is going to take a little bit of time.We also are looking at whether or not the international community, through the United Nations, could play a larger role in this event, in this circumstance. But there is no question that there is a real, genuine concern, because there are several million people in , and the diaspora could cause some real—how can I say it?—confusion in the Western Hemisphere.And so—but I think that what the Prime Minister is suggesting, and we are as well going to be contributing, to see if we can both increase the efficiency and capacity of the training and the methods used by the police department, as well as seeing if we can engage other people in the hemisphere, which we've been talking to, and they're prepared to do some. So it's a work in progress.[] For 30 years, Western countries have been involved in to try to stabilize the country, to try to help the Pearl of the Antilles. And the situation is atrocious. It's affecting the security of the people of . We must take action.And we must keep the an people in the approach that we build for security. And that's why the approach that we are working on with the U.S. involves strengthening the capacity of the an National Police, bringing more peace and security and stability. This won't happen tomorrow. It will, of course, be a long process, but we will be there to support the capacity of the police in , the National Police.At the same time, part of the insecurity and instability in is because of the an elite, who have for too long benefited from the misery of the an people. They work for their own political gain, their own personal gain. And this has prevented the country from recovering. And that's why we're proceeding with sanctions. We will continue to bring pressure to bear on the elite, the political class in , to hold them accountable for the distress facing the an people, but to hold them accountable for ensuring their well-being.We're going to continue to work together. We fully understand how important this task is.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, you used the word 'thumpin'' to describe the recent election results. Given your experience, doesn't this outcome suggest a certain distance between you and the American people? And, on a lighter note, does Nancy Pelosi remind you of anyone you've encountered before in your political career? [SEP] The Pelosi question is just a bit of fun. On the election, I'm naturally optimistic. We expected to lose some seats; the exact number was the only surprise.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, considering the gravity of the Kavanaugh allegations, wouldn't a thorough investigation, regardless of initial details, have been the responsible course of action for the White House? [SEP] The FBI has already investigated Judge Kavanaugh multiple times over the years. Furthermore, the initial allegations lacked crucial details like location, time, and year. It was a 'he said, she said' situation with no concrete leads for the FBI to pursue. Besides, as Joe Biden himself has stated, such investigations aren't typically within the FBI's purview. The Democrats are simply playing political games, knowing full well Kavanaugh's qualifications. They are attempting to smear a good man and his family for political gain. The American people see through this charade and will remember it at the ballot box. Even if the FBI had cleared Kavanaugh completely, the Democrats would have continued their obstructionist tactics. However, in states where I won by large margins, a few Democrats might break ranks and support us. But make no mistake, this is a partisan witch hunt designed to undermine my administration and divide the country.
label: Deflection

sentence: Why is this massive aid package to Puerto Rico being proposed now, just weeks before the election? [SEP] It's been a long process, a very long process. Getting anything through Congress is tough, especially with the Democrats fighting us every step of the way. They probably didn't want this to happen before the election, but we got it done. It's a big package, a really big package. And the best part is bringing back the pharmaceutical industry. They used to be there, but the tax laws drove them out. We're going to fix that, create jobs, and help Puerto Rico rebuild.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Biden, Russia has announced a supposed 'scaling back' of operations near Kyiv. Is this a sign of progress towards peace, or a cynical attempt to regroup for a renewed assault? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to speculate on Putin's motives. We'll judge them by their actions, not their words. Negotiations are ongoing, and I've been in close contact with our allies in France, Germany, and the UK. We're all aligned in our approach: maintain pressure through sanctions, support Ukraine's defense, and monitor the situation vigilantly. We'll see what happens.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, what's your biggest takeaway from the Kim meeting? And how do you respond to Michael Cohen's accusations of being a liar, conman, and racist? [SEP] It's wrong. I tried to watch as much as I could. I've been a little bit busy. But I think having a fake hearing like that and having it in the middle of this very important summit is really a terrible thing. They could've made it 2 days later or next week, and it would've been even better. They would've had more time. But having it during this very important summit is sort of incredible. And he lied a lot, but it was very interesting, because he didn't lie about one thing. He said no collusion with the Russian hoax. And I said, I wonder why he didn't just lie about that, too, like he did about everything else? I mean, he lied about so many different things, and I was actually impressed that he didn't say, Well, I think there was collusion for this reason or that. He didn't say that. He said, No collusion. And I was, you know, a little impressed by that, frankly. Could've—he could've gone all out. He only went about 95 percent instead of 100 percent. But the fact is, there is no collusion. And I call it the witch hunt. This should never happen to another President. This is so bad for our country. So bad. You look at this whole hoax, it's a—I call it the Russian witch hunt and now add the word hoax. It's a very, very bad thing for our country. But I was impressed with the fact that he—when—you know, because the most important question up there was the one on collusion. And he said he saw no collusion. So we'll see what happens. But it was pretty shameful, I think.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with Israeli Opposition Leader Netanyahu's recent public confirmation of Israel's bombing raid in Syria, could you disclose the target, your stance on the raid, and its potential consequences for regional stability, specifically concerning Syria, Iran, and Israel, and the possibility of U.S. involvement? [SEP] I'm going to refrain from commenting on that matter. Do you have another question?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, after your European trip, you're facing domestic challenges: your Attorney General's under pressure, General Pace's setback, stalled immigration reform, and poor poll numbers. Do you still have the political capital to tackle these issues, and how will you use it? [SEP] Ed, it was a fantastic trip, a chance to promote liberty and collaborate with allies. The immigration debate is indeed tough, with resistance from both parties. I was disappointed by the bill's derailment. It's odd that they'd prioritize a political resolution on my Attorney General, which won't affect his service. I believe we can pass immigration reform, requiring leadership from Senate Democrats and my continued engagement with willing Republicans. I contacted Republican senators to find a way forward, including working with Senator Kennedy. Addressing this issue is crucial, and I believe we can succeed. Progress was made through tough decisions, but it's two steps forward, one step back. I'll work with those committed to immigration reform and aim for a bill signing.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify your position on the UK's Brexit strategy: You initially voiced concerns about its potential to hinder trade deals with the US. Now, you seem more optimistic. Has the Prime Minister provided specific guarantees regarding the UK's ability to independently negotiate trade agreements post-Brexit? If so, what are those guarantees? Prime Minister, can you address the President's initial concerns and reassure the American public that the Chequers agreement will not impede future trade relations between our nations? [SEP] Let me be perfectly clear: I have complete faith in the Prime Minister's ability to deliver a Brexit deal that works for both the UK and the US. My initial comments were simply a reflection of my desire to ensure that trade remains a priority. I've had productive conversations with the Prime Minister and her team, and I'm confident that we'll be able to forge a strong and mutually beneficial trade relationship in the years to come. The Prime Minister is doing a fantastic job, and I fully support her efforts. We're going to make a deal that's good for everybody. It's going to be great.
label: General

sentence: Q. Do you have any willingness to reconsider a no-fly zone? [SEP] Julie, throughout this process, I think people have constantly looked for a easy, low-cost answer All right? Whether it's we should have sent more rifles in early and somehow then everything would have been okay; or if I had taken that shot even after Asad offered to give up his chemical weapons, then immediately, things would have folded—or the Asad regime would have folded, and we would have suddenly seen a peaceful SyriaThis is a hugely, difficult, complex problem And I would have hoped that we would have learned that from Afghanistan and Iraq, where we have devoted enormous time and effort and resources with the very best people and have given the Afghan people and the Iraqi people an opportunity for democracy But it's still hard, as we saw this week in Afghanistan That's not by virtue of a lack of effort on our part or a lack of commitment We've still got 10,000 folks in Afghanistan We're still spending billions of dollars supporting that Government, and it's still toughSo when I make a decision about the level of military involvement that we're prepared to engage in, in Syria, I have to make a judgment based on, once we start something, we've got to finish it, and we've got to do it well And do we, in fact, have the resources and the capacity to make a serious impact, understanding that we've still got to go after in ISIL ISIL Iraq, we still have to support the training of an Iraqi military that is weaker than any of us perceived, that we still have business to do in Afghanistan And so I push, and have consistently over the last 4, 5 years sought out a wide range of opinions about steps that we can take potentially to move Syria in a better directionI am under no illusions about what an incredible humanitarian catastrophe this is and the hardships that we're seeing and the refugees that are traveling in very dangerous circumstances and now creating real political problems among our allies in Europe and the heartbreaking images of children drowned trying to escape war and the potential impact of such a destabilized country on our allies in the region But what we have learned over the last 10, 12, 13 years is that unless we can get the parties on the ground to agree to live together in some fashion, then no amount of US military engagement will solve the problem And we will find ourselves either doing just a little bit and not making a difference and losing credibility that way or drawing our—finding ourselves drawn in deeper and deeper into a situation that we can't sustainSo—and when I hear people offering up half-baked ideas as if they are solutions or trying to downplay the challenges involved in this situation, what I'd like to see people ask is, specifically, precisely, what exactly would you do, and how would you fund it, and how would you sustain it? And typically, what you get is a bunch of mumbo jumbo []So these are hard challenges They are ones that we are going to continue to pursue The topline message that I want everybody to understand is, we are going to continue to go after ISIL We are going to continue to reach out to a moderate opposition We reject Russia's theory that everybody opposed to Asad is a terrorist We think that is self-defeating It will get them into a quagmire It will be used as a further recruitment tool for foreign fightersWe will work with the international community and our coalition to relieve the humanitarian pressure On refugees, we are working with the Turks and others to see what we can do along the border to make things safer for people But ultimately, we're going to have to find a way for a political transition if we're going to solve Syria Okay?Jon Karl [ABC News]Republican Presidential Candidate John E Jeb Bush/Gun Control
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, after a disappointing midterm election, do you acknowledge the need to adjust your agenda and approach to working with Republicans, given the message voters sent? [SEP] Well, look, the American people have spoken, and they're clearly frustrated with the gridlock in Washington. As President, I take that seriously. I represent all Americans, not just one party or region, and my job is to find solutions. So, yes, we need to find a way to work together. Now, that doesn't mean abandoning my priorities. Take the minimum wage, for example. Voters have consistently supported raising it. The key is to identify areas where we can find common ground with Republicans. Infrastructure, trade – there are opportunities there. I'm committed to reaching out, listening to their ideas, and finding that 70, 80, 90 percent agreement. If we can build trust and show the American people that Washington can actually function, that's a win for everyone.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. In just the course of the last couple of minutes, you have disputed some of what the officials that are working in your administration behind you have said about the risk of coronavirus and its spread. Do you trust your health officials to give you good information? [SEP] Oh, sure.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the potential use of chemical weapons, has your administration gathered specific intelligence indicating that President Putin is deploying or considering the use of these weapons? And if he were to use them, would the U.S. or NATO respond with military force? [SEP] On the first question, I can't share specific intelligence. Number one, that's classified. Number two, let me be clear, we would respond if he uses chemical weapons. The nature of that response would depend on the specific nature of their use. Next question.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. And the retirement age? [SEP] I'm not going to get into specifics. As I said, Jake, everything that you mentioned are things that we have discussed. But what I'm not going to do is to ask for even--well, let me put it this way: If you're a senior citizen and a modification potentially costs you a hundred or 200 bucks a year more or--even if it's not affecting current beneficiaries--somebody who's 40 today, 20 years from now is going to end up having to pay a little bit more, the least I can do is to say that people who are making a million dollars or more have to do something as well.And that's the kind of tradeoff, that's the kind of balanced approach and shared sacrifice that I think most Americans agree needs to happen.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, what is the timeline for introducing legislation to ban assault weapons? [SEP] We'll have something to say about that soon. Stay tuned.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify, is your strategy to destroy ISIS, contain them, or merely push them back? [SEP] Our goal is to ensure that ISIL no longer poses a significant threat to the region. We can achieve this, but it will require time and effort. As we've seen with Al Qaeda, remnants can always cause trouble due to the nature of terrorist activities. A few individuals can carry out attacks. However, we can degrade ISIL's systemic and broad-based aggression, which terrorizes Muslims, Kurds, Iraqis, and others throughout the region, to the point where it's no longer the dominant force it has been.
label: General

sentence: Q. President Duda, welcome back to the U.S. As it relates to U.S.-EU relations, as the President mentioned, you are a proud—Poland is a proud member of the European Union. How would you describe U.S.-EU relations right now? Did you talk about improving that relationship? Did you carry a special message to the President from Mr. Juncker? [SEP] Sir, I would be very happy if it was Poland which would disrupt the trade balance of the United States. I really would be happy if that was the case. Because my understanding, as far as politics is concerned, and carrying for the matters of your country is similar to the view of Mr. Mr. Trump is saying America first, and I'm saying, Poland first. So we understand each other very well.And it is hard for me to be surprised with the fact that Mr. President being a very experienced man—a man of success, as far as business is concerned—knows how to calculate. He knows how to calculate, and I think nobody puts that into question either in the U.S. or in another place. And he takes care of the United States. It lies in the interest of the country to have a balanced trade exchange, and this is something that you have to take care of. And of course, there is a clash of interest. However, objectively looking, it is hard not to understand it.So there is always competition of interest. There is—every kind of business is a competition of interests. And I represent Polish interests, whereas President Trump represents American interests. The whole thing is as follows: On important matters, you have to strike an agreement to make sure that both countries wins and lose as little as possible. And then, we have an understanding, an agreement. And then, we can say that we are cooperating with each other on equal level. And I believe this is the kind of cooperation that Mr. President would like to have with the European Union. And it is—it will be hard to be surprised with that.I'm listening kindly to that, and I would like Poland to be such a country, such an economic superpower, that it would be a very important partner to the United States. I said jokingly, in the beginning, that I wish it was Poland which disturbed the trade balance of the United States and our exports to the United States, but I do believe that our cooperation is going to develop well on partners, like principles. The trade deal with South Korea has been fully renegotiated and is ready for signature. We may sign it at the United Nations or shortly thereafter. That was a terrible deal for the United States. Now it's a fair deal. But that's been fully renegotiated, in addition to Mexico and some of the others that are very close.Thank you very much, everybody. We appreciate it. Thank you. Thank you, Mr. President.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, some analysts suggest that the election results indicate a disconnect between your administration's policies and the needs of a multiethnic and multicultural America. How do you respond to these claims, particularly in light of concerns about racial and economic inequality? [SEP] Look, the numbers speak for themselves. African American, Asian American, and Hispanic American employment is at a historic high. A recent poll showed my support among Hispanics and African Americans is the highest it's ever been. That poll was just a few days ago. Median income is up, and all the employment numbers are great. It's all reflected in the polls. Yes?
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, concerning the bank bailout, will you stipulate that banks use the funds to expand credit access? And if not, how do you convince the public this bailout will succeed where the last one failed? [SEP] Look, Helene, I'm not trying to get ahead of my Treasury Secretary here – you all should be at his press conference, he's going to knock it out of the park. But – and this is connected to Jake's question from earlier – what I'm really focused on is whether credit is getting to the people who need it. Is it going to businesses, big and small? Is it going to consumers? Are they able to do what they need to do to create jobs and grow the economy on Main Street? That's what this package is all about. But I'm going to let Tim have his moment in the sun tomorrow. Who's next?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, you've spoken about the rise of crude nationalism. Would you advise protestors at home to stop demonstrating against Donald Trump's rhetoric? Did you advise your successor to be mindful of worrisome trends when making staff picks? And in your final weeks, can you stop Assad and Putin from bombing Aleppo? [SEP] Protesting is a great part of our democracy. I've been protested against for 8 years. I wouldn't tell people to be silent. But elections matter, voting matters, being informed matters. Don't take our government for granted. Democracy is hard work. If 43% don't vote, democracy is weakened. If we can't tell facts from propaganda, we have problems. If people won't compromise, democracy breaks down. Understand the foundations of democracy and engage continuously. There's complacency. Young people forget the Cold War. There's an easy equivalence between the U.S. and Russia, but we have flaws and make mistakes. The U.S. has been good for Germany, providing security and rebuilding it. We've tried to apply free speech and civil liberties in our foreign policy. Remember that in an age of misinformation. Don't equate overzealousness with severe repression. If everything seems the same, we won't know what to protect. That was a long answer.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, Nigeria urgently requires Tucano aircraft to address its domestic challenges. Is it possible to release at least two before 2020 to aid the country? Furthermore, when might we anticipate a visit to Nigeria from you? [SEP] Visiting Nigeria is something I'd very much like to do. I understand it's an absolutely stunning country. So, yes, I'd like to go. Regarding the first part of your question, I didn't quite understand it. Could you please repeat it?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Senate proceedings, do you prefer a swift resolution or a comprehensive examination, and what's your take on the clash between Pat Cipollone and Jerrold Nadler? Also, are you categorically opposed to John Bolton's testimony? [SEP] That's a lot to unpack. We'll see how it plays out.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Are all bets off? [SEP] No. If they do that, then it's just—all it is, is a warlike posture.Yes, go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you've been able to fulfill many of your promises. Immigration reform isn't one of them. Just this last weekend, the  DREAM Act failed cloture by five votes. And five Democrats didn't support it; three Republicans did. How are you going to be able to keep your promise when the Republicans control the House when you haven't been able to do so with Democrats controlling both the Senate and the House, and when Republicans say they want to focus on border security before they do anything on immigration? [SEP] Well, let me say, there are a number of things that I wanted to get accomplished that we did not get accomplished. For example, collective bargaining for firefighters and public safety workers--that was something that I thought was important. We didn't get it done. I'm disappointed in that. I think we're still going to have to figure out how we work on energy, and that's an area that I want to immediately engage with Republicans to figure out.But I will tell you, maybe my biggest disappointment was this DREAM Act vote. You know, I get letters from kids all across the country--came here when they were 5, came here when they were 8; their parents were undocumented. The kids didn't know--kids are going to school like any other American kid, they're growing up, they're playing football, they're going to class, they're dreaming about college. And suddenly they come to 18, 19 years old, and they realize, even though I feel American, I am an American, the law doesn't recognize me as an American. I'm willing to serve my country, I'm willing to fight for this country, I want to go to college and better myself, and I'm at risk of deportation.And it is heartbreaking. That can't be who we are, to have kids--our kids, classmates of our children--who are suddenly under this shadow of fear through no fault of their own. They didn't break a law; they were kids.So my hope and expectation is that, first of all, everybody understands I am determined and this administration is determined to get immigration reform done. It is the right thing to do. I think it involves securing our borders, and my administration has done more on border security than any administration in recent years. We have more of everything: ICE, Border Patrol, surveillance, you name it.So we take border security seriously. And we take going after employers who are exploiting and using undocumented workers, we take that seriously. But we need to reform this immigration system so we are a nation of laws and we are a nation of immigrants. And at minimum, we should be able to get the DREAM Act done.And so I'm going to go back at it, and I'm going to engage in Republicans who I think some of them, in their heart of hearts, know it's the right thing to do, but they think the politics is tough for them.Well, that may mean that we've got to change the politics. And I've got to spend some time talking to the American people and others have to spend time talking to the American people, because I think that if the American people knew any of these kids--they probably do, they just may not know their status--they'd say, of course we want you. That's who we are. That's the better angels of our nature.And so one thing I hope people have seen during this lame duck: I am persistent. I am persistent. If I believe in something strongly, I stay on it. And I believe strongly in this.And I am happy to engage with the Republicans about--if they've got ideas about more on border security, I'm happy to have that conversation. And I think that it is absolutely appropriate for the American people to expect that we don't have porous borders and anybody can come in here any time. That is entirely legitimate.But I also think about those kids. And I want to do right by them, and I think the country is going to want to do right by them as well.Mike Emanuel [FOX News].
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, in light of Admiral McRaven's concerns about the absence of a defined protocol for captured terrorists, how do you balance the need for actionable intelligence with the legal and ethical considerations surrounding the treatment of detainees, particularly in high-stakes operations? [SEP] We're committed to upholding the rule of law, absolutely. But we also have a responsibility to protect the American people. We have a process, a comprehensive process, for deciding how to handle these cases. We'll consider all the factors – the threat level, the intelligence value, the legal constraints. Our troops have clear instructions: apprehend the individual, gather the intelligence, and do it in a way that minimizes risk to American lives.
label: Implicit

sentence: Given the international sanctions against North Korea, how can this gas pipeline project proceed without effectively compensating them, President Lee? [SEP] Well, thank you for the question. I'm not sure if this is the right place to discuss this, but I'll address it. We've been exploring importing Russian gas into South Korea for a while. We're currently in discussions with North Korea about the possibility of this affordable gas traveling through their territory for use in South Korea. This benefits Russia by allowing them to sell their gas, North Korea by providing them with a resource, and South Korea as well. However, it's important to note that we haven't had detailed discussions with North Korea and Russia yet. While economically beneficial, this also involves security considerations. This project is not imminent, and we are mindful of the North Korean nuclear issue. Thank you.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. So how do you define, differentiate, and deal with—deal with the law of yours for Indians in India and Indians' law for H–1B visa in America? So how do you differentiate this? [SEP] Yes, we're talking about the H–1Bs, and we are—look, the relationship we have—this is not from me, this is from almost everybody that saw it: They say in the history of India, which has a long history and a brilliant history in so many different ways, there's never been a reception given to somebody like was given—and I would like to say for the United States of America. But nobody else that came here got the kind of reception we got.We have been—we gave—it was 125,000, I think, seats they had yesterday. They were full. You had thousands and thousands of people outside. Prime Minister Modi was telling me thousands of people outside.That's not uncommon for me, to be honest with you. But when I look at 125,000 seats—and that was an incredible scene yesterday. In addition, all of those people lined up from the airport to the event, it was an incredible thing. Nobody has ever seen anything like it.The Ambassador just told me that he's been in India for a long time. He's never seen—in fact, both Ambassadors, our Ambassador and the Ambassador from India, said, in 40 years, he's never seen anything like it, what took place yesterday and, you know, earlier than that. But yesterday—they've never seen anything like it.So it was a great compliment. It was a great compliment to our country. I'm the leader of the country, but it was a great compliment to our country. But Prime Minister Modi said today they've never, ever had any event like that. In fact, they said usually when somebody comes in, they have to look for people to fill up the areas. They said we had—there was something very special.Look, it's a massive country in terms of its population. And people just wanted to see. They wanted to pay their respect to the United States, and so I appreciate it. I was a recipient, in a sense, but I was just—I was just really representing the country.Yes, Peter [Peter Baker, New York Times]. Go ahead.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, circling back to your earlier remarks on racial equality, how do you see criminal justice reform fitting into your broader agenda, especially considering your upcoming trip to Kenya? And while we're at it, any thoughts on Bill Cosby's Medal of Freedom? [SEP] Wow, April, you've certainly packed a lot into that question! Let's just say...
label: Declining to answer

sentence: But didn't you just say this morning you were against it? [SEP] I'm against anything where the people aren't being taken care of properly. They deserve money; it's not their fault they got shut down by China. Whether it's the Post Office or the $3½ billion for universal mail-in ballots, they won't make a deal. These are just two parts of a bigger deal. What they really want is bailout money for the Democrat-run States and cities in trouble, like New York, California, and Illinois. They want to bail them out, and we don't want to do that, especially not for $1 trillion.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. She said that your refusal to get testing up and running; your—I'm paraphrasing—your flip-flopping on social distancing and masks; and your delusional belief that you know better than the experts—all of that, in her words, are reason that one American dies of COVID-19 every minute. What do you think of that? [SEP] I think that's probably one of the reasons she was a terrible candidate and was forced to leave the race because she got her facts wrong. You know she's very bad on facts. She is very weak on facts.And just so you understand: We've done more testing than any country in the world by far. That includes India which has 1.5 billion people. That includes China. That includes every country in the world. We've done more testing. We have better testing than any country in the world. They call; they want to know: Where do we get it? How do we get it? We have better testing than any country in the world.When you do as much testing as us however as you understand you develop more cases. If you tested instead of 65 million people which is what we've done—when you test that many people—you're going to find cases that normally you wouldn't see.If you go to Mexico and you go to other countries you'll see they do almost no testing. They test if somebody is not feeling well. They test if somebody is symptomatic. They test very little. They test very little.We've done more testing than anybody in the world. We've done the best job of any country in the world and that includes from making ventilators that nobody else could have done. We are the ventilator king of the world. We're supplying the whole world now in a few short months with ventilators that are very hard to produce very expensive very complex very delicate very very important. We've done a great job.And then on top of that when you look at the numbers—how we were impacted less than these other countries. And now you look at the explosion of countries that you would have said did such a good job and some of them had advantages over us for obvious reasons having to do with the pandemic. But when you look at the job that we've done compared to others we've done a great job.And she—I read today that she's very short on facts. She—I think she's going to be a big failure. And I think—I look forward to the debate between her and Mike Pence because I think he'll do even better against her than he did about—against Senator Kaine which was a total wipeout. So we'll see how it all works out.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, as you prepare to leave office, what do you consider to be your biggest regret? [SEP] Well, there are always things you wish you could have done differently. But I try not to dwell on the past. I prefer to focus on the future. I'm confident that America will continue to be a beacon of hope and freedom for the world.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, what specific measures are you taking to ensure your legislative goals are achieved in the coming year? [SEP] We're exploring all avenues, engaging with stakeholders, and leaving no stone unturned. The legislative process is, as you know, complex and multifaceted. We are optimistic, yet realistic, about the challenges that lie ahead.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, can you definitively rule out a government shutdown before the new Congress convenes? [SEP] Look, I can't predict the future. We're negotiating in good faith, but there are always uncertainties. So, no promises.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: How widespread do you believe disloyalty is within the government, and what specific criteria will be used to identify and remove these individuals? [SEP] We want people that love our country, that's all. We want people that are loyal to the United States. We don't want people that are trying to undermine our agenda. It's very simple.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, do you have any details about the shooting? Were they targeting anyone in and around the White House? [SEP] No, we—there are no details. We just found out just now. It was outside of the White House, this area right over here. And they'll have details for you in a little while.Somebody is taken to the hospital. It seems that the shooting was done by law enforcement at that person, at the suspect. It was the suspect who was shot.
label: Explicit

sentence: President, with respect to North Korea, beyond expressions of hope, can you detail specific, measurable outcomes achieved through your diplomatic efforts? Furthermore, has your perspective on the value of direct negotiations shifted in light of recent events? [SEP] I'm not going to lay out the playbook for everyone to see. What's important is that it's in 's interest, and the world's interest, to resolve this peacefully. We're demonstrating strength, unmatched strength. We have significant resources deployed, which we hope to never use. I think they're starting to understand the situation, and hopefully, we can get them to negotiate a mutually beneficial agreement. I see some progress, but we'll see.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: If this deal is truly detrimental and costing the country millions, why not simply terminate it? [SEP] Next question, please. I believe I've addressed this adequately.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: In what specific area do you believe cooperation is impossible during the subpoena process? [SEP] Which instance of cooperation are you referencing?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue your administration's Syria policy lacks a clear objective. Could you outline your long-term goals for the region, and how you plan to achieve them, specifically regarding Assad's future? [SEP] Look, the situation in Syria is complex, very complex. Our primary concern remains the cessation of violence and the prevention of further bloodshed. Assad's role is, shall we say, a key consideration in achieving a stable and lasting peace. While his legitimacy is certainly questionable, we must also consider the geopolitical realities and the interests of all parties involved – Russia, Iran, and the various factions within Syria itself. A political transition is essential, one that safeguards the rights of all groups, including minorities. Secretary Kerry has been instrumental in navigating these delicate negotiations. The Russians, too, are beginning to realize the limitations of military intervention alone. Ultimately, a solution requires a comprehensive approach that addresses the underlying causes of the conflict and ensures a future where all Syrians can live in peace. It's a tough situation, a very tough situation.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I have a domestic question for you. And then, Mr. Macron, I have a President—a question for you about Ukraine.But first, President Biden, do the freight rail workers deserve more than 1 day of paid sick leave, like millions of Americans have? And if so, why didn't you negotiate for that when you were helping to negotiate that contract that you now want Congress to impose? [SEP] I love you guys. I negotiated a contract no one else could negotiate. The only thing that was left out was whether or not it was a paid leave.You know I've been trying to get paid leave not just for rail workers, for everybody. But that other team—they're called the Republicans—they voted against it. They said we couldn't do it. We're one of the few nations in the world that don't have paid leave for our workers.And so what we're doing is—we can't afford to have—and by the way, in the meantime, they got a 43—45-percent increase in salary, et cetera. There's a lot of good things that happened in that.And if in fact this shuts down over the question of 1 to 5 paid—or 7 or 9 or whatever the number is that've been negotiating—of paid leave days, it's going to immediately cost 750,000 jobs and cause a recession.And so what I made really clear is that—what was negotiated was so much better than anything they ever had that it's worth—and they all signed on to it, by the way. There are only four unions that—out of the 13 or 14—that didn't agree. So the majority at the time it was—that I presented it, they asked me to do it. I presented it; they all signed on.But here's the story: It doesn't mean because we are going to pass this, God willing, on—by Friday, by the time the—by the weekend that we're—that I'm going to back off of paid leave.I made it really clear: I'm going to continue to fight for paid leave for not only rail workers, but for all American workers. I suppose—I imagine it may surprise some of our European friends that there's no paid leave in the United States of America. We're one of the few major countries in the world that don't have it. It's about time.And so that's the context in which this all took place. And you know, and labor signed on to it as well, as you recall, initially. There were 4 unions out of the, I think, 13 or 14 that didn't like it.And—but I think we're going to get it done, but not within this agreement—not within this agreement. We're going to avoid the rail strike, keep the rails running, keep things moving, and I'm going to go back, and we're going to get paid leave not just for rail workers, but for all workers.
label: Explicit

sentence: Given the UK's rising coronavirus cases, why are they exempt from the travel ban, especially when numerous Schengen countries have lower infection rates? Will you reconsider their inclusion on the ban list? [SEP] That decision came from the experts, and we're constantly monitoring the data. The UK numbers are concerning, so we might have to adjust our policy. We're also thinking about removing some countries from the list, too. It's all very fluid.
label: Claims ignorance
