[SEP] We are committed to working with the Chilean government on any requests for information regarding the past. It's crucial to understand our history, including the complex and sometimes difficult relationship between the U.S. and Latin America. However, we must also avoid being defined by our history. Chile has made remarkable progress in recent years, with the full support of the United States. I cannot comment on all past policies, but I can affirm our commitment to democracy, poverty reduction, and inclusive development. We strongly support the open markets that have flourished in Chile and the efforts of President Pinera and his predecessor. While it's important to learn from our past, we must also focus on the challenges of today and tomorrow.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with the clock ticking on your time in office, what are your remaining priorities? And are you worried that the immigration bill might get bogged down in election-year politics? [SEP] Well, we've still got a lot to do. We need to pass this energy legislation, renew No Child Left Behind, and get these trade bills moving. Panama, Peru, Colombia – those are important. And we want to build on the progress we've made with the Korean free trade agreement. We're hoping to bring back a successful Doha negotiation for a vote, which means we need to extend TPA. And we need to keep the budget balanced. The deficit's been coming down faster than expected, thanks to higher tax revenues and our fiscal policies. But we need Congress to be responsible and not overspend or raise taxes. That would hurt the economy. And of course, we have to keep fighting the war on terror. I'd like to find common ground with Democrats and Republicans on Iraq, but some just want to pull out. I disagree with that. Most Americans do. Immigration is a tough one. It's very emotional. I've always supported comprehensive reform. I campaigned on it. I understand the concerns about illegal immigration, which is why we've been working to secure the border. We're doubling the Border Patrol, building fences, and using new technology. I even sent the National Guard down there for a while. This bill addresses those concerns. It sets benchmarks for border security before any other reforms take place. But you can't have real border security without a temporary worker program. People will come here to work, and they'll find a way. That creates an underground industry of smugglers and document forgers. It's inhumane. We need to give people a legal way to come here and work temporarily. And we need a tamper-proof ID card to verify employment. The hardest part is what to do with the people who are already here. Some people want to deport them all, but that's not realistic. And we can't just give them automatic citizenship. So we've developed a plan where they have to meet certain requirements to get a Z visa, like background checks and fines. They go to the back of the line for citizenship. If you support the bill, I appreciate it. If you don't, you can always find something to criticize. It's easy to pick it apart. But I believe it's the right thing to do. I want to get it done because it will solve the problem. I want to take it out of politics. Immigration debates can bring out the worst in people. We're a nation of immigrants. I was moved by the story of the Coast Guard ensign whose grandfather came from Mexico. He's serving America with pride. That's what immigration can mean for America. Welcoming people who want to work and pursue the American Dream renews our spirit. We have an opportunity to pass a good law now. It will be difficult, and politics will play a role. But I hope members of Congress will rise above it. I will.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. How are you going to bridge that gap? Will the U.S. commit to send additional doses overseas? And given the gap, is it actually realistic to end the pandemic by 2022? [SEP] It is—it may take slight—slightly longer than—worldwide. But the United States is going to continue—I think there's a possibility, over 2022 going into 2023, that we would be able to be in a position to provide another billion—us. But that's not done yet.I only—I've been very careful, as I've dealt with this pandemic, to tell you what I know and say what I thought could be done, and when I've announced that I've gone and done it. What I don't want to do is be getting too far ahead in suggesting that we can do things and I can do things—the United States can do things that I don't have done yet.So I—there was a clear consensus among all our colleagues at the G-7 that this wasn't the end; we were going to stay at it until we're able to provide for—able to provide for—the needs of the whole world, in terms—because, look, it's not just the right thing to do. And from a—how can I say it?—from a moral standpoint. But it is also the correct thing to do, in terms of our own health, our own security. You can't build a wall high enough to keep out new strains. You can't do that.And so I think this is going to be a constant project for a long time. And there may be other pandemics. We—again, setting up a system whereby we can detect—before it gets out of control—one, a pandemic, that may be on the horizon—a virus—is important.So we are not going to—as long as there's nations in need that—being able to be vaccinated, we in fact—not only that: We've been engaged in helping—which I've made clear, and most of our—my colleagues understood it. I mean, they understood it—knew it from trying it themselves. This is a gigantic logistical effort. It's one thing to send nation X, X number—Y number of vaccines. It's another thing to have the people that can actually get it in somebody's arm. And so we are also providing the ability for other countries to manufacture their vaccines. We've all agreed on that.India has the capacity to do that. They don't have the material capacity thus far to do the manufacturing. But there's a lot going on to provide—not only to, quote, give vaccines, but to provide the ability of the countries in question to produce their own vaccines. Last question. Last question. The President. I'm not going to answer it. No, I'm joking. Last question.Peter Alexander, NBC News.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You said more than once that you did not believe that Donald Trump would ever be elected President, and that you thought he was unfit for the office. Now that you've spent time with him, sitting down and talking to him for an hour and a half in the Oval Office, do you now think that President-elect Trump is qualified to be President?And if I can do a compound question, the other one is, you mentioned staffing and tone. What do you say to those Americans who may not doubt that there will be a peaceful transition, but that are concerned about some of the policies and sentiments, either expressed by President-elect Trump himself or his supporters that may seem hostile to minorities and others? Specifically, I'm talking about the announcement that Steve Bannon, who is a proponent of the so-called alt-right movement, what many call the White nationalist movement, is going to have a prominent role in the White House under a President Trump as his chief strategist and senior adviser. What message does that send to the country, to the world? [SEP] Okay. Athena, without copping out, I think it's fair to say that it would not be appropriate for me to comment on every appointment that the President-elect starts making if I want to be consistent with the notion that we're going to try to facilitate a smooth transition.Look, the people have spoken. Donald Trump will be the next President, the 45th President of the United States. And it will be up to him to set up a team that he thinks will serve him well and reflect his policies. And those who didn't vote for him have to recognize that that's how democracy works. That's how this system operates.When I won, there were a number of people who didn't like me and didn't like what I stood for. And I think that whenever you've got an incoming President of the other side, particularly in a bitter election like this, it takes a while for people to reconcile themselves with that new reality. Hopefully, it's a reminder that elections matter and voting counts. And so I don't know how many times we have to relearn this lesson, because we ended up having 43 percent of the country not voting who were eligible to vote. But it makes a difference.So given that President-elect Trump is now trying to balance what he said in the campaign and the commitments he made to his supporters with working with those who disagreed with him and Members of Congress and reaching out to constituencies that didn't vote for him, I think it's important for us to let him make his decisions. And I think the American people will judge over the course of the next couple of years whether they like what they see and whether these are the kinds of policies and this is the direction that they want to see the country go in.And my role is to make sure that when I hand off this White House that it is in the best possible shape and that I've been as helpful as I can to him in going forward and building on the progress that we've made.And my advice, as I said, to the President-elect when we had our discussions was that campaigning is different from governing. I think he recognizes that. I think he's sincere in wanting to be a successful President and moving this country forward. And I don't think any President ever comes in saying to himself, I want to figure out how to make people angry or alienate half the country. I think he's going to try as best he can to make sure that he delivers, not only for the people who voted for him, but for the people at large. And the good thing is, is that there are going to be elections coming up, so there's a built-in incentive for him to try to do that.But it's only been 6 days. And I think it will be important for him to have the room to staff up, to figure out what his priorities are, to be able to distinguish between what he was campaigning on and what is practical, what he can actually achieve. There are certain things that make for good sound bites, but don't always translate into good policy. And that's something that he and his team, I think, will wrestle with, in the same way that every President wrestles with.I did say to him, as I've said publicly, that because of the nature of the campaigns and the bitterness and ferocity of the campaigns, that it's really important to try to send some signals of unity and to reach out to minority groups or women or others that were concerned about the tenor of the campaign. And I think that's something that he will want to do. But this is all happening real fast. He's got commitments to supporters that helped to get him here, and he's going to have to balance those. And over the coming weeks and months and years, my hope is, is that those impulses ultimately win out. But it's a little too early to start making judgments on that.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. With a Republican Congress, you failed to achieve three major goals of your second term: Social Security reform, a Tax Code overhaul, and a comprehensive immigration bill. Why shouldn't Americans give Democrats a chance to work with you on those issues, especially when divided government seemed to work in the late 1990s, on the budget? [SEP] That's a tricky little question there. [] First, I haven't given up on any of those issues. I've got 2 years left to achieve them. And I firmly believe it is more likely to achieve those three objectives with a Republican-controlled Congress and a Republican-controlled Senate. And I believe I'll be working with a Republican-controlled Congress and a Republican-controlled Senate.I understand here in Washington, people have already determined the outcome of the election, like it's over even before the people actually start heading—voting. But that's not what I see when I'm on the campaign trail. You know, we've got some people dancing in the end zone here in Washington, DC. They've got them measuring their drapes; they're going over to the Capitol and saying, My new office looks beautiful. I think I'm going to have this size drape there, or this color. But the American people are going to decide, and they're going to decide this race based upon who best to protect the American people and who best to keep the taxes low.Secondly, I'll tell you what I see—you didn't ask, but I'm going to tell you anyway. I see there's a lot of enthusiasm amongst the grassroots activists. Our people are going out there to man the phones and to put up the yard signs. You know, they're showing up when it comes time to—these absentee votes. We're organized. We've got a fantastic grassroots organization to turn out the vote. This campaign has obviously got national implications to it, no question about it: the Iraq war, the security of the country, economic vitality and growth. But each of these elections turn out to be local in their scope and in their character.And we've got good candidates running hard, and we're going to win. Now, I know that defies conventional wisdom here. I'm not suggesting anybody in this august crowd has determined the outcome of the election already, but they're running profiles on who this person is going to be running this office, or this one that's going to be—magazines have got all kinds of new stars emerging when they haven't won the votes yet.And anyway, thanks for asking about the campaign. I'm enjoying it out there. I like campaigning. It's what guys like me do in order to get here. We campaign. We shake the hands, you know, and give the speeches. And Laura is campaigning too. From my perspective, our people are ready to go out there and vote for—vote our candidates back into power.Let me see here, Michael Allen [Time].
label: Deflection

sentence: With so much stuff in the Defense and VA budgets that's hard to cut, where are you actually going to find the savings, Mr. President? [SEP] Wait, 'so many' what are you referring to?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, the G-7 oil price cap is meant to lower gas prices, but is it really going to work for the average American? And how much longer will they have to pay extra because of the war in Ukraine? [SEP] So, the key question is, will this cap actually bring down the price of gasoline for everyday Americans?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Okay. And then, a follow-up: You mentioned the word inflation there. You recently said you have no short-term answer to bring down gas prices. But, as you know, it's not just gas prices now. Rents are up. The cost of everyday items are up. Inflation in the U.S. is at a 13-year high.So when specifically should Americans expect those prices to come down? [SEP] Well, look, first of all, the significant reason why prices are up is because of COVID affecting the supply chain. I mean, I know you—I'm not trying to be instructive; I know you know this. Number one.Number two, if you take a look at, you know, gas prices and you take a look at oil prices, that is a consequence of, thus far, the refusal of Russia or the OPEC nations to pump more oil. And we'll see what happens on that score sooner than later.Number three, I think if you take a look at what we're talking about—you look to this coming Thanksgiving—you know, we're in a situation where we find that we are in a very different circumstance.Last Thanksgiving, you know, I—as I said, this year, we're working on the supply chain issue. But last Thanksgiving, I sat down with my wife, my daughter, and my son-in-law. This Thanksgiving, we're all in a very different circumstance. Things are a hell of a lot better, and the wages have gone up higher—faster than inflation. And we have generated real economic growth.It doesn't mean these dislocations aren't real. They do affect people's lives. For example, one of the reasons why I decided to talk about the need to deal with the operation and the gouging that occurs in some of the pricing of beef and chicken and other things is that that's why I think we're-—that's why I indicated to you we're going to look at whether or not there's a violation of antitrust laws and what they're doing.So there's a lot to look at. But the bottom line is that I think that—and anyone who would prefer, as bad as things are in terms of prices helping—hurting families now, trade this Thanksgiving for last Thanksgiving.
label: Explicit

sentence: Concerning the Beirut explosion, even if there's just a hint it was a bomb, are you taking any steps to protect U.S. interests in the area? What's the plan? [SEP] We're tight with the government there, and we've got all our people on it, including the military. We'll get to the bottom of it; we probably already know what happened. Thanks, everyone.
label: Deflection

sentence: If Republicans attempt to block your executive action by withholding funding, how will you guarantee its effectiveness? And could you provide an estimate of the number of people potentially affected by this action, perhaps in the range of 2 million or more? [SEP] I suspect that when I unveil the executive action, it will be comprehensive and include a lot of specifics. And I'm certain there will be plenty of follow-up questions.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, with all due respect, the media believes it is taking too long for you to reach a deal with the other side. This is your third year in office and your third budget. You have stated that you would rather be a one-term President if it meant you could do the tough things that must be done. I am not suggesting you invite Republicans to the negotiation table today, but why not? Since you are not, what more can you do to foster the spirit of cooperation that you mentioned is necessary for bipartisanship? Finally, do you believe the markets will wait two years? [SEP] Jackie, I should have written all of this down. My brain is running out of space.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, families deserve answers. When, precisely, did you learn the truth about the friendly fire incident, and why has it taken so long for the Pentagon to provide a definitive explanation? [SEP] Well, let me say this: the moment I had reason to believe the original information was incorrect, I immediately called for a full and comprehensive investigation. Now, these things take time. It's a complicated situation, and we need to make sure we have all the facts before we jump to any conclusions. I can't pinpoint the exact moment, but I can assure you that we are committed to getting to the truth and providing the families with the answers they deserve.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your administration's focus on austerity measures in Europe is counterproductive and exacerbating the crisis. What alternative strategies are you advocating to promote growth and stability in the Eurozone? [SEP] We believe that a balanced approach is needed to address the economic challenges in Europe. We support fiscal responsibility and structural reforms. We also believe that it is important to invest in growth and innovation. We are working with our European partners to find solutions that will lead to a stronger and more prosperous Europe.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the urgency of the economic situation, why is your administration taking a measured approach instead of implementing immediate and decisive measures to reassure the markets and protect American families? [SEP] We are constantly analyzing options available to us. My view of the economy is that the fundamentals are strong, that we've had strong growth for a reason: that we're competitive; we got flexible workplace; that we kept taxes low; exports are up.Like many Americans, I'm concerned, and I'm concerned about the fact that Americans see their costs going up. I know Americans are concerned about whether or not their neighbor may stay in their house. And so we're dealing with these issues.On the housing front, I made it clear we're not going to bail out lenders, and we're not going to help speculators. But we will help creditworthy people stay in their homes. And that's what Secretary Paulson has done, along with Secretary Jackson, in putting together what's called the HOPE NOW coalition, which has got lenders and financiers and consumer advocates all working together to develop standards to make it more likely a creditworthy person can refinance their home.See, the difficulty we face in the housing market is that the lender, the person who actually made the note, oftentimes doesn't end up owning the note. That note could be—in the recent past has been bundled and sold as an asset. And so there's no telling who owns the mortgage of the person who wants to renegotiate. And so we're helping deal with the new realities in a way that we believe is going to be effective.Secondly, the Congress can really help by passing a FHA modernization bill. The House passed a bill. The Senate passed a bill. They need to get together when they get back, quickly, and get it to my desk so that it makes it easier for the Federal Government, in this case, to help people refinance their homes.In terms of further stimulation, we'll consider all options. And so we're watching carefully.
label: Implicit

sentence: The National Intelligence Estimate suggests we're in a civil war in Iraq. You speak of victory and preventing a catastrophe if we fail, yet you claim it's not an open-ended commitment. How do you reconcile these seemingly contradictory statements? [SEP] Victory in Iraq won't resemble victory in World War II. It will be a society with relative peace, not necessarily zero violence. The key is helping the Iraqi government establish a security force capable of stopping ethnic cleansing and dealing with criminality. There's also the issue of al-Qaeda and disaffected Sunnis seeking to regain power. It's a complex situation, regardless of what you call it. My decision to intervene was to prevent further deterioration and support a constitutional government that shares resources equally, promotes federalism, and partners in the war on terror. Success means a bulwark for moderation, not a safe haven for extremism.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you. Mr. President, the Asad regime is engaged in a brutal crackdown on its people. France has recognized the opposition coalition. What would it take for the United States to do the same? And is there any point at which the United States would consider arming the rebels? [SEP] I was one of the first leaders, I think, around the world to say Asad had to go, in response to the incredible brutality that his government displayed in the face of what were initially peaceful protests.Obviously, the situation in has deteriorated since then. We have been extensively engaged with the international community as well as regional powers to help the opposition. We have committed to hundreds of millions of dollars of humanitarian aid to help folks both inside of and outside of . We are constantly consulting with the opposition on how they can get organized so that they're not splintered and divided in the face of the onslaught from the Asad regime.We are in very close contact with countries like Turkey and Jordan that immediately border and have an impact and obviously Israel, which is having already grave concerns, as we do, about, for example, movements of chemical weapons that might occur in such a chaotic atmosphere and that could have an impact not just within , but on the region as a whole.I'm encouraged to see that the n opposition created an umbrella group that may have more cohesion than they have had in the past. We're going to be talking to them. My envoys are going to be traveling to various meetings that are going to be taking place with the international community and the opposition.We consider them a legitimate representative of the aspirations of the n people. We're not yet prepared to recognize them as some sort of government-in-exile, but we do think that it is a broad-based representative group. One of the questions that we're going to continue to press is making sure that that opposition is committed to a democratic , an inclusive , a moderate .We have seen extremist elements insinuate themselves into the opposition, and one of the things that we have to be on guard about—particularly when we start talking about arming opposition figures—is that we're not indirectly putting arms in the hands of folks who would do Americans harm or do Israelis harm or otherwise engage in actions that are detrimental to our national security.So we're constantly probing and working on that issue. The more engaged we are, the more we'll be in a position to make sure that we are encouraging the most moderate, thoughtful elements of the opposition that are committed to inclusion, observance of human rights, and working cooperatively with us over the long term. All right?Thank you very much.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the West Bank annexation suspension, what is your best estimate for how long that will last? [SEP] What's your guess? Seriously, tell me. We're all-in on this peace thing. The Emirates deal is huge. We're hammering out the details – embassies, flights, the whole nine yards – and then rolling it out across the region. How long will it take? Your guess is as good as mine. But we've put peace first, even though the sovereignty thing isn't off the table. It's just on the back burner while we give peace a chance to work.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, concerning Putin, do you think he is changing his disruptive behavior, especially towards NATO and the US? Also, about the infrastructure list you gave him, were the penalties for interference clearly stated, and what was his reaction? [SEP] I'll tackle the second part first. I let him know we have serious cyber capabilities. He knows we do, though he doesn't know exactly what they are. If they cross the line, we will respond in the cyber realm. He gets it.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Canada, you mentioned several topics. Could you please clarify which aspect of the Canada-U.S. relationship you'd like me to address first? [SEP] Hold on, that was a whole laundry list of questions! [] Were you trying to cover everything at once? []
label: Clarification

sentence: Vice President Biden referenced a 30% chance of failure in a recent discussion. Could you shed light on the topic of that conversation and whether you agree with that assessment? [SEP] Well, I must admit, I don't have a clear recollection of the particular conversation Joe is referring to. Nevertheless, I think what he was attempting to express – and I wouldn't necessarily attach a specific percentage to it – is that given the magnitude of the challenges we're facing, any single action we take will only be a component of the solution, not the entire solution. As I mentioned in my opening remarks, not everything we do will unfold precisely as we intended. We're confronting unprecedented circumstances, and while there's a general understanding among economists about the direction we need to take, we still have to contend with the financial system, ensuring banks are lending again, addressing the housing crisis, and establishing a regulatory structure to prevent future crises. These are all major, complex undertakings. So, I suspect that's the general idea Joe was conveying.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, a year after you called for bipartisan cooperation, many feel there's been little progress. How would you grade your own performance in reaching across the aisle, and what specific obstacles have hindered your ability to find common ground with Democrats? [SEP] Iraq is one area where we've found some common ground. While some in Congress question our initial involvement, the recent testimony from David Petraeus and Ryan Crocker seems to have shifted the debate. I hope we can continue to find common ground by ensuring our troops are adequately funded. We also found common ground on FISA. I believe the existing law is effective for national security, which is what the American people want. It allows our intelligence professionals to understand Al Qaida's intentions. The law should be enhanced to provide liability protection to phone companies that assisted us. So, there's common ground there. I hope we can find more as Congress moves forward with legislation. The reason I spoke out today is because there's much to be done. I'm not a legislator, but as head of the executive branch, I urge Congress to show progress and achieve results. It's difficult to find common ground when important bills aren't even being considered. Not a single appropriations bill has reached my desk. How can we find common ground without an appropriations process? We found common ground on trade bills, which are crucial for our economy. Exports helped us overcome the weakness in the housing market last quarter. It makes sense to continue opening up markets to goods and services. Yet, no trade bills have been moving. Veterans Affairs is another area where we can find common ground. I asked Bob Dole and Donna Shalala to lead a commission to ensure our veterans receive the benefits they deserve. I was concerned about bureaucratic delays and a system that didn't recognize the unique challenges of the current war. I'm concerned about PTSD and want people to focus on it. We sent up a bill, and I hope they move on it quickly. There's a place where we can find common ground.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the U.S.-Japan alliance and your upcoming trip to China, how can the U.S. promote freedom in the Indo-Pacific without clashing with China? Also, Mr. Prime Minister, about Japan's defense role, did you discuss Japan potentially intercepting North Korean missiles with the President, and what's your vision for Japan's defense? [SEP] Well, let me just say, the Prime Minister here is going to have the best defense system in the world. He's buying a lot of equipment from the United States. The best equipment. And he'll be able to handle anything that comes his way. As for China, look, President Xi and I, we have a great relationship. We're friends. But China's been taking advantage of the United States for years. Unfair trade practices, the whole deal. We're talking hundreds of billions of dollars. It's got to stop. So, we're going to make sure that trade is fair, it's reciprocal. That's the key word: reciprocal. If they charge us a hundred percent, we charge them a hundred percent. Simple as that. And we're already working on it. It takes time, you know, there are laws, regulations, all that stuff. But we're getting it done. And you're going to see a big difference. A very big difference. Now, about Japan's defense, they're buying a lot of equipment from us. The best equipment. And they're going to be able to defend themselves. They're going to be very safe. Thank you.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, in regards to the Senate proceedings, would you like to see a speedy end or a detailed investigation of the facts? What's your opinion on the argument between White House Counsel Pat Cipollone and Jerrold Nadler last night? And are you completely against John Bolton testifying? [SEP] You're asking a barrage of questions.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, isn't it naive to trust Kim Jong Un, given his track record of broken promises and provocative behavior? [SEP] We are not naive. We are realistic. We understand the risks involved in engaging with North Korea, but we believe that the potential rewards are worth the effort. We are approaching this with our eyes wide open and with a clear understanding of the challenges ahead.
label: General

sentence: President Trump's letter reportedly contained strong language urging you not to be a 'tough guy' or a 'fool.' How did you interpret this unconventional diplomatic approach, and did it influence your decision-making process in any way? [SEP] We value our relationship with the United States and appreciate President Trump's concerns. We believe that we share common goals in the fight against terrorism and the promotion of regional stability. We are committed to working with the United States to address these challenges. We have communicated our concerns and objectives clearly to President Trump and his administration.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, from China, regarding North Korea: Is it still your belief that a relationship similar to that of the U.S. and Vietnam is attainable? [SEP] Say that one more time, please. I want to be sure I understand.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you. Mr. President, oil prices are up. The economy is in a serious downturn. What can world leaders do? And would you approve of intervention to strengthen the U.S. dollar, which many people say is contributing to the rise in oil prices?And, Mr. Prime Minister, do you believe that the U.S. is holding up moving forward on climate change? [SEP] First of all, our economy is not growing as robustly as we'd like. We had positive growth in the first quarter; we'll see what happens here in the second quarter. But nevertheless, it's—we're not as strong as we have been during a lot of my Presidency. And so, as you well know, Toby [Tabassum Zakaria, Reuters], we passed a stimulus bill that is now in the process of passing money back to consumers, which had a positive effect and, hopefully, will continue to have a positive effect.We're working with the Congress to get a housing bill out. We're—we passed uninsurance benefits—unemployment benefits—excuse me. And yet we got a problem when it comes to reliance upon foreign sources of oil. For 7 years, I've been trying to get the Congress to explore for oil domestically. Now is the time, when they come back from their Fourth of July vacations, to open up ANWR and open up the Outer Continental Shelf so that we can say to the world that we will do our part in increasing supply, so that we can transition from this period of reliance upon hydrocarbons to a new period of advanced technologies.In terms of the dollar, the United States strongly believes in a strong dollar policy and believes that our—the strength of our economy will be reflected in the dollar.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Park, concerning North Korea's nuclear ambitions, what is the most important factor in persuading them to disarm, and what was discussed with President Obama on this matter? Also, what role do you see China and Russia playing in this effort? President Obama, what are your thoughts on Kim Jong Un, and what message would you send to him today? [SEP] Our shared goal is clear: North Korea must abandon its nuclear weapons and become a responsible member of the international community. This is essential for peace on the Korean Peninsula and the world, and it also benefits North Korea's own development. To encourage this change, we must work together. China's influence is significant, so their participation is crucial. China and Russia, along with the international community, share the goal of a denuclearized Korean Peninsula and are cooperating to guide North Korea. China has actively participated in adopting and implementing U.N. Security Council resolutions regarding North Korea's missile fire and nuclear testing. Russia is also firmly committed to denuclearization and has actively supported U.N. Security Council resolutions. They've also worked hard to include a stern message to North Korea in the G-8 Foreign Ministers meeting's joint statement. These efforts are vital to sending a unified message that their nuclear weapons are unacceptable and urging North Korea to make the right decision. I don't know Kim Jong Un personally, so I can't comment on his personal characteristics. However, his actions have been provocative and seem to lead to a dead end. We will maintain a strong deterrent capability and won't reward provocative behavior. But we remain open to North Korea taking a peaceful path of denuclearization, abiding by international commitments, rejoining the international community, and achieving security and prosperity for its people. If North Korea's current path hasn't led to a strong, prosperous nation, now is the time for Kim Jong Un to re-evaluate and change course. If he chooses a different path, the international community would welcome it. China, Russia, Japan, and other key players in the six-party talks have made this clear. But there must be changes in behavior. Actions speak louder than words, and so far, we haven't seen actions indicating a willingness to move in a different direction.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. ——who get infected. But when you're talking about the scope of this virus, when you look at the percentage of the population that's died, there's only three countries that have more deaths than the U.S. So how do you explain that: that—why the percentage of the population who has died is so much higher in the U.S.? The President. Well, I think, actually, the numbers are lower than others. I'll get back to you on that. But we, proportionately, are lower than almost all countries. We're at the bottom of the list.And we're—relative to cases, also, we're at the bottom of the list, which is a good thing, being at the bottom of the list. But I can get back to you. We have about four or five different lists on that. And we're, generally speaking, at the very bottom of the list. So I'll get back to you. Q. Because when I—when I look at the Johns Hopkins, you know, Coronavirus Resource Center on their website, it says the most affected countries, when you look at deaths per 100,000 people of the population—so how many people in the population have died—you have the U.K., Peru, Chile, and then the U.S.You know, Canada has 8,000, 9,000 deaths. Obviously, they're smaller than us, but that's only 6 percent of the population—you know, that's 6 percent of our total cases. So why are the deaths so much higher in the U.S.? [SEP] Well, a lot of our numbers were based on the—New York had a very tough time, as you know. New York, New Jersey—that area. And when you take them out—just as an example, take a look at Florida, relative to New York.That's not to say anything wrong with New York. It was just a very tough place. People are close together. It's crowded. It's not easy.But when you take that out, our numbers are among the lowest. And even with it in—I will get back to you, but we have among the lowest numbers. They've done a fantastic job on it.Yes, please. Go ahead.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Just to reiterate, you're saying you have absolutely no details about the attacker's identity or the weapon they used? [SEP] That's my understanding. I haven't been briefed on those specifics.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, your stance on the Pope's potential recognition of a Palestinian state and its implications for a two-state solution would be greatly appreciated. [SEP] Well, let me tell you, folks, the Senate, they're doing a tremendous job with trade. We're talking about deals that are smart, progressive, and really boost growth, not just in Asia-Pacific, but maybe even in Europe. And I'm getting the tools to enforce these deals, which is something that hasn't always happened, believe me. So, a big thank you to the Senators who voted to get this thing moving. For those who didn't, I'm not giving up, not even a little bit. I'll keep showing them why this is the right move, not just for the big guys, but for the small and medium businesses too. And most importantly, it's for the American worker, the forgotten man and woman. I wouldn't back any deal that doesn't create jobs and give Americans a real shot at success, higher incomes, and higher wages. That's my number one priority, always has been. Now, about Elizabeth, it's nothing personal, folks. The press, they love to make a big deal out of it when allies disagree on policy. But I've got friends, great friends, in the Senate and House, even early supporters, who don't see eye-to-eye with me on this. And I get it, I really do. They've seen plants close, jobs go overseas, just like me. They worry about enforcing labor and environmental agreements. They want fair trade, not just free trade. They're concerned about inequality, automation, and globalization, which have helped those at the very, very top while middle-class families, great families, struggle. These are people who share my values, tremendous values. They even put out a progressive statement of principles that was basically my agenda, except for trade. It's a policy difference, a disagreement on what's best for our people, the American people. I believe we're better off writing strong rules, the best rules, with teeth on things like child labor, deforestation, and intellectual property. We need to write those rules for the biggest, fastest-growing market in the world. If we don't, China will, and our businesses and workers will suffer, believe me. As for outsourcing fears, companies looking for cheap labor can already do it, they're already doing it. This deal gives us a chance to bring manufacturing back to the U.S., back where it belongs. Nike's bringing back jobs because of new technologies, great technologies. But we need to be able to sell over there to make the most of it, to really win. That's why I'm arguing with my progressive friends. We need to focus on things we agree on: minimum wage, job training, infrastructure, collective bargaining, overtime pay, paid sick leave, and honest budgets. These are the things that will address their concerns. Blocking this trade deal won't, especially since they admit the current rules are bad for U.S. workers. How does sticking with the status quo help? It doesn't make any sense, folks, none at all. I support enforcement and the signed provisions. I have concerns about the currency language, but I need to talk to Senator Schumer and Sherrod Brown about how to fix it without hurting our monetary policy. Now, remind me, what was the other question? I've got so many things on my mind.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, should President Zelenskyy concede any Ukrainian territory to secure a cease-fire with Russia, or is that completely out of the question? Also, should Russia be removed from the G-20? [SEP] On the G-20 question, yes, I think so. But it depends on the G-20 members. I raised that today. If Indonesia and the others don't agree, then we should ask to have both Ukraine and Russia be able to attend as observers. Now, what was that first question again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. You've talked a lot today about how these professionals are excellent, have been critical and necessary. Does this experience at all give you pause about those consistent cuts? [SEP] No, because we can get money, and we can increase staff. We know all the people. We know all the good people. It's a question I asked the doctors before. Some of the people we cut, they haven't been used for many, many years. And if we have a need, we can get them very quickly.And rather than spending the money—and I'm a business person—I don't like having thousands of people around when you don't need them. When we need them, we can get them back very quickly. For instance, we're bringing some people in tomorrow that are already in this, you know, great Government that we have, and very specifically for this.We can build up very, very quickly. And we've already done that. I mean, we really have built up. We have a great staff. And using Mike, I'm doing that because he's in the administration and he's very good at doing what he does, and doing as it relates to this.Yes. Go ahead, please. Go ahead, please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering the staggering number of casualties and the enormous financial burden of the Iraq War, why shouldn't Americans conclude that your persistence with the initial strategy demonstrates a lack of realism or an unwillingness to acknowledge mistakes? [SEP] Look, it's easy to play Monday morning quarterback. The situation on the ground in Iraq was constantly evolving. As Mike Hayden, then head of the NSA, told the Iraq Study Group, the initial strategy wasn't working, and we needed a change of direction. But he also cautioned against simply abandoning the Iraqis, as their government wasn't ready to take full responsibility. We've seen remarkable progress in Anbar Province, where local citizens have turned against Al Qaeda. This bottom-up reconciliation is just as important as any top-down political agreement. So, while the costs have been high, we're seeing positive developments that justify our continued efforts.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, to be clear, is the use of chemical weapons a red line that would necessitate military intervention by NATO? [SEP] We're not going to telegraph our response.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, in your discussions today, did you explore the possibility of Canada increasing its stimulus efforts? And for both of you, what is your outlook for the Canada-U.S. relationship in four years? What will the automotive sector look like? Will the border be more or less porous? And will a carbon market exist? [SEP] That's quite a few questions all at once. [] Did you collaborate with Jonathan on that? Is that--[].
label: Clarification

sentence: Following the phone call, you stated that you informed him of his error. What was his response, and did he admit to it? [SEP] Well, I wouldn't exactly say I 'told' him anything. I simply inquired, 'What transpired?' And I gathered the impression that he was unaware of having made the statement in question. I, myself, did not hear him utter those words.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, critics say your approach to Iran is inconsistent and lacks a clear strategy. How do you respond? [SEP] My strategy is very clear: maximum pressure. We will not allow Iran to develop nuclear weapons. We will not allow them to destabilize the region. We will use all the tools at our disposal to achieve these goals. And we are seeing results. Iran is weaker than ever before. Their economy is in shambles. They are facing internal unrest. We are winning.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Obama, with the Trans-Pacific Partnership facing hurdles in Congress, are you considering a revised strategy to secure its approval, and should currency manipulation be addressed in the agreement? Also, your comments on the killing of Taliban leader Mullah Mansur and Pakistan's concerns are requested. [SEP] We are working hard to get TPP passed and are confident we will. As for the Taliban leader, this action does not represent a shift in our approach.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. But what about the criticism that this isn't targeted enough? [SEP] All right, last question. Suzanne [Suzanne Malveaux, Cable News Network].
label: Dodging

sentence: President, with the DC mayor mandating masks, what's the administration's stance on requiring them at the White House and other federal locations? [SEP] We're discussing it internally. We'll let you know what we decide. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: What kind of weapon was involved? [SEP] Regrettably, I cannot provide details on that matter.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: So, Mr. President, when can the American people expect this to happen? [SEP] I honestly have no idea. To be frank, I don't know.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, reflecting on the Afghanistan intervention, do you believe the results justify the significant investment of lives and resources, considering the ongoing challenges in the region? And to President Karzai, given the persistent issues of corruption and governance, how do you respond to critics who question the effectiveness of international aid, and are you fully committed to a peaceful transfer of power following the upcoming elections? [SEP] The reason we went into Afghanistan was simple: to dismantle Al Qaeda after they attacked us on 9/11. That was our primary goal, and we've largely achieved it. We've decimated their leadership, disrupted their operations, and made it much harder for them to launch attacks against us. Our men and women in uniform deserve immense credit for that. Now, did we solve all of Afghanistan's problems? No. Nation-building is a long and complex process. But we created the conditions for a more stable and secure Afghanistan, one that is less likely to be a haven for terrorists. We established a relationship with a responsible Afghan government that is willing to cooperate with us to make sure that it is not a launching pad for future attacks against the United States? We have achieved that goal. We are in the process of achieving that goal. And for that, I think we have to thank our extraordinary military, intelligence, and diplomatic teams, as well as the cooperation of the Afghan Government and the Afghan people. On the issue of corruption, it's a serious problem, and we're working with the Afghan government to address it. It's not just a matter of money; it's a matter of governance and accountability. We need to ensure that international aid is used effectively and that the Afghan people benefit from it. And on the elections, I am committed to a peaceful and democratic transition of power. The Afghan people deserve to choose their own leaders. And certainly, I would be a retired President and very happily a retired President. Last question from one of yours.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you. And, Mr. President, when you took office, you canceled the Keystone XL pipeline. This week, your Government delayed the environmental assessment to reroute Enbridge Line 5, and at the same time, you're approving oil drilling in Alaska.So what's your response to people who say it's hypocritical to stymie Canadian energy projects while allowing your own? [SEP] First of all, I don't think it is, but I'll be very brief.The difficult decision was on what we do with the Willow Project in Alaska, and my strong inclination was to disapprove of it across the board. But the advice I got from counsel was that if that were the case, we may very well lose in court—lose that case in court to the oil company—and then not be able to do what I really want to do beyond that, and that is, conserve significant amounts of Alaskan sea and land forever.I was able to see to it that we are literally able to conserve millions of acres—not a few—millions of acres of sea and land forever so it cannot be used in the future.I am banking on—we'll find out—that the oil company is going to say not—that's not going to be challenged, and they're going to go with three sites. And the energy that is going to be produced they're estimating would account to 1 percent—1 percent—of the total production of oil in the world.And so I thought it was a good—a—the better gamble and a hell of a tradeoff to have the Arctic Ocean and the Bering Sea and so many other places off limits forever now. I think we put more land in conservation than any administration since Teddy Roosevelt. I'm not positive of that, but I think that's true.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Navalny situation, what concrete steps will your administration take against Russia, and what message will you deliver to them? What role should the international community play? [SEP] Well, it's certainly a concerning situation, and we're looking into it very carefully. I've always been firm with Russia, you know that. But let's not forget the bigger picture. We're making tremendous strides in the Middle East, brokering peace deals that others couldn't even dream of. And I was the one who warned everyone about Nord Stream 2, Germany's dependence on Russian energy. We're also engaged in vital nuclear arms negotiations with Russia, which, frankly, is more important than this climate change nonsense. As for Navalny, we need to see the facts first, but we're watching it closely. It's a terrible thing if true.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, considering the current political climate, marked by partisan divisions and ongoing investigations, what specific strategies will you employ to foster bipartisan cooperation and achieve legislative progress? [SEP] I'm a unifier. I bring people together. The election is over, it's time to heal. We're going to reach across the aisle and get things done. If they want to work with us, we're ready. If not, we'll do it ourselves.
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, some critics suggest your approach to foreign policy is erratic and inconsistent. You seem to praise authoritarian leaders while simultaneously criticizing democratic allies. Can you clarify your strategy for maintaining strong international relationships? [SEP] The point is, we're not going to be the world's punching bag anymore. We've been losing hundreds of billions of dollars every year. These countries, they're laughing all the way to the bank. I'm not going to let that happen. I'm here to protect American workers and American businesses. If that means being tough on our allies, so be it. They need to understand that the gravy train is over. We want fair deals, and we deserve them.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, while you were in office, your administration oversaw a significant increase in the national debt. How do you justify this increase, and what measures did you take to ensure fiscal responsibility? [SEP] Well, look, we had to rebuild our military. It was depleted, a disaster. And we cut taxes, which stimulated the economy. We created the greatest economy in the history of the world, before the China virus came along. So, you know, you have to spend money to make money.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. And what, in your view, happened? Do you think he backed off because of that—of your statement? [SEP] No, no, I'm just saying. I just—I just found it interesting that, Biden is being apoc—Biden is being extremist. And it turns out, you all are writing about it now. Kind of fascinating.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. What's your stance on supporting American oil producers? [SEP] I'm sorry, could you run that by me one more time?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the potential use of chemical weapons, has your administration received actionable intelligence suggesting President Putin is preparing to deploy or utilize such weapons? Furthermore, what would be the U.S. or NATO's military response to such an action? [SEP] With respect to your first inquiry, I'm unable to divulge specific intelligence matters at this juncture. However, let me be unequivocally clear: any use of chemical weapons would be met with a response. The precise nature of that response will be calibrated to the specific circumstances of their deployment.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering your budget office's prior estimate of 7.7% unemployment by the close of 2012, do you foresee this new initiative leading to a reduction in that figure? Moreover, do you believe it will be more effective than the Recovery Act in terms of fostering economic expansion and generating employment opportunities? [SEP] This package is not of the same magnitude as the Recovery Act, but the circumstances are different. The Recovery Act was enacted during a period of potential economic collapse, with projections of unemployment reaching as high as 15 or 20 percent. That crisis has been averted due to our efforts to stabilize the financial system and the actions of the Federal Reserve. We are no longer facing the threat of a double-dip recession. However, while the economy is growing, company profits are increasing, and the private sector is experiencing some job growth, the pace is insufficient to significantly reduce the unemployment rate, given the 8 million jobs lost prior to and during my administration. This package provides a supplementary stimulus that is more substantial than most economic forecasters anticipated. Indeed, some are already suggesting that we may witness accelerated growth and increased job creation as a result. The payroll tax holiday will have a positive impact, and unemployment insurance is particularly effective in ensuring the continuation and potential acceleration of the recovery. Overall, economists concur that this will contribute to economic growth and job creation in the coming months. This was the primary consideration in my decision-making process. It is crucial to remember, particularly for my fellow Democrats who are deeply committed to middle-class, working-class, and low-income families facing the greatest challenges in this economy, that the most effective jobs program is a growing economy. The most effective anti-poverty program is ensuring that individuals have employment and the economy is expanding. While other measures can be taken, if the economy is not growing and the private sector is not hiring at a faster rate, we will continue to face difficulties, regardless of the number of programs implemented. Therefore, in evaluating our options, I concluded that prolonging the uncertainty for an additional 3, 4, or 5 months would not only directly affect individuals whose paychecks are reduced and those who rely on unemployment insurance to cover their expenses, but would also have a detrimental impact on the overall macroeconomic health of the economy.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Aside from the stimulus checks, what specific measures will alleviate the economic distress of struggling citizens? [SEP] Look, the key is certainty. Permanent tax cuts are a must. People are already facing uncertainty with rising gas prices, potentially hitting four dollars. Making the tax cuts permanent removes one major unknown. Furthermore, our energy policy needs a serious overhaul. While renewables are important, we must increase domestic oil and gas production. It's been too long since we built a new refinery. I even proposed using old military bases, but Congress rejected it. Basic economics dictate that reduced supply and steady demand lead to higher prices. Taxing oil companies is counterproductive; we should incentivize domestic investment. This stimulus package, coupled with tax cuts and a revised energy strategy, offers a path forward.
label: General

sentence: What about John Brennan? The Africa Summit? The Ebola crisis? Mr. President, I thought we were going to discuss your birthday plans. [SEP] Seriously, what happened to the birthday wishes?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Just to follow up, what do you plan to do about that interference, sir? [SEP] Well, we're going to look at it very closely. You're telling me that this came out a little while ago, and I've heard that it came out. It came out just a little while ago, and we're going to look at that very closely.But you started off with Russia.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You talk about the U.S. Government and the Iraqi Government working closely together on benchmarks. I'm wondering, sir, why was Prime Minister Maliki not at the news conference yesterday with General Casey and Ambassador Khalilzad? Would that not have sent a strong message about there being a very close level of cooperation between the two Governments? [SEP] Elaine, I have no idea why he wasn't there.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Could you elaborate on the preconditions for meeting with the North Korean leader, and do you believe he is capable of fulfilling them? [SEP] I never prejudge what someone will or won't do based on their words. We'll see. If he makes a firm commitment to discuss his nuclear arsenal, then I'd meet with him. The commitment must involve discussions about denuclearization and de-escalation. My Secretary of State and others would negotiate an outline for how we would proceed. I won't repeat past mistakes by granting him international legitimacy without concrete progress. I need specifics. I wouldn't rule out meeting with North Korea entirely, but my team would first meet with their counterparts to establish clear objectives.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Would you rule it out forever that you would never consider it? [SEP] What I'm saying is, is that there's a difference between Mr. Ledgett saying something and the President of the United States saying something.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with the TPP facing headwinds in Congress and other nations awaiting U.S. action, will you adjust your strategy for securing its approval? Should the agreement be revised to address currency manipulation? Also, your comments on the killing of Mullah Mansur and Pakistan's concerns? Does this signal a new offensive in Afghanistan, and are you concerned about a more hardline successor? [SEP] Look, every trade deal is a tough sell, especially in an election year. Everyone wants a better deal. But I'm confident we'll get it done because it's the right thing for America and the world. This is the fastest-growing region, a huge market for us. They sell to us with low tariffs, but ours are higher there. This deal eliminates 18,000 taxes on U.S. goods. It also addresses labor and environmental concerns, things people have worried about in the past. I haven't seen a credible argument that TPP will hurt us. We'll be better off. As for currency manipulation, we have provisions to monitor it, but binding countries on monetary policy would mean binding our Fed, which we won't do. On Mansur, he targeted U.S. personnel. This isn't a shift in approach. We're not re-entering combat. But as Commander-in-Chief, I have a responsibility to protect our people. That's the message we're sending.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering your strong stance on human rights, will you call upon Israel to declare its nuclear program and become a signatory to the Non-Proliferation Treaty? If not, how do you reconcile this with your advocacy for the treaty's universal adoption? [SEP] Well, Scott, you started by talking about U.S. behavior, and now we're talking about Israel. Let's focus on the United States. I do think that as part of the NPT, our obligation as the largest nuclear power is to take steps to reduce our nuclear stockpile. That's what the START Treaty was about. As for Israel, I'm not going to comment on their program. I'm going to point out that we have consistently urged all countries to become members of the NPT. So there's no contradiction there. We think it is important that we have an international approach that is universal and that rests on three pillars: that those of us who have nuclear weapons are making serious efforts to reduce those stockpiles; that we are all working against the proliferation of nuclear weapons, and those countries that don't currently have nuclear weapons make the decision not to pursue nuclear weapons; and that all countries have access to peaceful nuclear energy. So whether we're talking about Israel or any other country, we think that becoming part of the NPT is important. And that's not a new position. That's been a consistent position of the United States Government even prior to my administration.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you very much, Mr. President. Senator Max Baucus was widely seen as the best hope for a large-scale deal to overhaul the Tax Code. What does your decision to nominate him as Ambassador to China say about your hopes for major tax bill in your second term? [SEP] It says that Max Baucus is going to be an outstanding Ambassador to China, and I'd like a swift confirmation. And my expectation and hope is, is that if both the Senate Democrats—or if Democrats and Republicans in the House and the Senate are serious about tax reform, then it's not going to depend on one guy, it's going to depend on all of us working together. And my office is ready, willing, and eager to engage both parties and having a conversation about how we can simplify the Tax Code, make it fairer, make it work to create more jobs and do right by middle class Americans.Jackie Calmes [New York Times].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, the FDA is reportedly considering stricter guidelines for the emergency authorization of a COVID vaccine. Are you okay with that? [SEP] Well, I'll tell you what, we're looking at that, and that has to be approved by the White House. We may or may not approve it. That sounds like a political move, because when you have Pfizer, Johnson and Johnson, Moderna, these great companies coming up with these—the vaccines, and they've done testing and everything else, I'm saying, Why would they have to be, you know, adding great length to the process?We want to have people not get sick. The vaccine is very important. It's the final step. I believe it's going to be the final step. And no, we're looking at that, but I think it's—that was a political move more than anything else.
label: General

sentence: Sir, concerning Canada, did your discussions involve their stimulus measures? Furthermore, what's your vision for the Canada-U.S. relationship in the coming years, including the auto industry, border policies, and carbon trading? [SEP] Wait, wait, wait. You're throwing a lot at me at once. Are you sure you're talking to the right person?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given the potential economic consequences of a default, are you willing to consider any compromises on spending cuts or revenue increases to reach a deal with Congress on the debt ceiling? [SEP] We're always willing to listen to reasonable proposals, but we won't agree to anything that would harm the economy or undermine our priorities. We need to invest in our future, not cut our way to prosperity. We're confident that we can find a solution that is both fiscally responsible and good for the American people.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, your administration has mentioned ongoing efforts to address the offer concerning the situation with Russia. Could you elaborate on the alternative approaches being considered and Russia's response to these proposals? [SEP] While I appreciate the question, divulging specific details about these alternative approaches would be imprudent at this juncture. Premature disclosure could jeopardize the delicate negotiations and potentially undermine our efforts to secure the safe return of our citizens. Rest assured, we are exploring every viable avenue to achieve this objective.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, are you having second thoughts about those sanctions? [SEP] Look, I love our country, but you have to give credit to President Erdogan. He got Pastor Brunson back. Nobody else could manage that. President Obama couldn't do it. He was going to be in jail for 35 years! Pastor Brunson was an innocent man. I called President Erdogan, and before you knew it, Pastor Brunson was standing right here in the Oval Office with me. So, from my perspective, he's a tough guy, very tough. But I get along with him. I think he was treated unfairly regarding that weapons system. He was told he couldn't have it, and then after he bought another system, we said, 'Okay, we'll sell it to you.' But it was too late. He'd already bought the plane. So, it's a complicated situation. We're working on it. We'll see what we can do.
label: Implicit

sentence: Considering the potential for a legislative stalemate on immigration reform, Mr. President, are you prepared to prioritize other policy initiatives that may have a greater chance of bipartisan support, or do you remain committed to pursuing executive action despite the likely political fallout? [SEP] We're committed to addressing all of the challenges facing our country, and we're not going to let political obstacles stand in our way. We're going to continue to work hard to find solutions that benefit all Americans, and we're confident that we can make progress on a wide range of issues.
label: General

sentence: What guidance do you have for Democrats navigating the new administration, and what are your thoughts on Nancy Pelosi's future? [SEP] Let's address Nancy first. She's a remarkable leader. Much of our success is owed to her. I typically avoid party endorsements, and as I'm leaving office, I should probably stay out of it. However, I can't praise her enough. She possesses strong convictions and exceptional political skills. She tackles difficult issues, even when unpopular with her base, because it's the right thing to do. To the Democrats, I advise giving the new administration a fair hearing. Don't emulate Mitch McConnell's approach of blanket obstruction. That's not why people elect us. Stand firm on your principles, but if the new administration is pursuing policies beneficial to the country, collaborate. Always prioritize what's best for the American people. That's been my guiding principle. You'll inevitably make mistakes, but you'll remain true to your oath. Remember, the U.S. plays a vital role globally. We must champion democracy, the rule of law, a free press, and collaborate with other nations to improve the world.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, with no concrete evidence of an impending threat, are you comfortable with your Homeland Security Secretary's 'gut feeling' about a potential summer attack? What does your own intuition tell you? [SEP] Well, my gut, aligned with my advisors, tells me that when we identify a legitimate threat, we'll inform the public to ensure homeland security. Al-Qaeda remains a significant threat, demanding robust intelligence and response capabilities. We must not embolden them through failures in theaters of war. We must relentlessly pursue them and bring them to justice before they strike us again. This is an enduring challenge, an ideological conflict with competing visions for the world. What sets this apart is the asymmetrical use of power – IEDs and suicide bombers as tools to achieve strategic goals. Their aim is to impose their vision, expel the U.S. from key regions, and establish safe havens where women are oppressed, mirroring the Taliban's Afghanistan. It is our duty to defend ourselves by remaining on the offensive and promoting an alternative ideology. Throughout our history, we've assisted others in realizing the blessings of liberty, even former adversaries, understanding freedom's power to foster peace. As we navigate this ideological battle in the 21st century, we must remember that liberty can transform societies. The debate centers on whether nations like Iraq can self-govern and whether their people value liberty. I firmly believe freedom is a universal value, not exclusive to Americans. The 2005 elections demonstrated this, defying threats and violence. Iraq is just one front in the broader war against jihadists and extremists. This struggle will persist, much like past ideological conflicts. I believe democracy will continue to spread throughout the Middle East if the U.S. remains engaged. That's why I'm committed to diplomatic involvement in the region. Condi Rice and Bob Gates will visit in early August to reaffirm our strategic partnerships and encourage the pursuit of freer societies, supporting the Iraqi government's survival. Achieving this is vital, and we must succeed to fulfill our duty. This is demanding work. The question is whether we persevere or retreat, allowing polls to dictate the country's fate. Retreat would necessitate future intervention with greater force to protect ourselves, as events overseas directly impact our security.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Park, concerning the denuclearization of North Korea, you highlighted the significance of international cooperation. Could you detail your discussions with President Obama on this topic, and what are your views on the contributions of Russia and China? President Obama, what are your thoughts on Kim Jong Un, and what message would you impart to him today? [SEP] Regarding North Korea, our collective aim, alongside the international community, is denuclearization and their integration as a responsible actor on the world stage. This fosters peace on the Korean Peninsula and globally, while also benefiting North Korea's own advancement. To facilitate this, we must collaborate effectively. China's influence is substantial, rendering their participation indispensable. We addressed this matter. China and Russia, in concert with the international community, share the objective of a denuclearized Korean Peninsula and are cooperating to guide North Korea. China has actively engaged in adopting and implementing U.N. Security Council resolutions pertaining to North Korea's missile launches and nuclear tests. Russia is also committed to denuclearization and has actively supported U.N. resolutions. They also contributed to incorporating a strong message to North Korea in the G-8 Foreign Ministers' meeting statement. These concerted efforts are vital in conveying a unified message that their nuclear weapons are unacceptable and urging them to make the correct decision. I lack personal acquaintance with Kim Jong Un and cannot offer commentary on his character. However, his actions have been provocative and ultimately self-defeating. We will maintain a robust deterrent and refrain from rewarding provocative conduct. Nevertheless, we remain open to North Korea pursuing denuclearization, adhering to international commitments, reintegrating into the international community, and achieving security and prosperity for its populace. If North Korea's current trajectory has failed to yield a strong, prosperous nation, Kim Jong Un should consider a change of course. Should he do so, we and the global community would welcome it. China, Russia, Japan, and other participants in the six-party talks have articulated this clearly. However, a shift in behavior is imperative. As the adage goes, 'Actions speak louder than words.' Thus far, North Korea has not demonstrated a willingness to alter its course.
label: Implicit

sentence: Regarding the ongoing investigation, can you share any details about its location or express your confidence in its outcome? [SEP] Look, I'm deliberately keeping my distance from that. As the nation's chief law enforcement officer, I could insert myself, but I believe it's best to let the Attorney General handle it. He's got Durham, a highly respected individual, leading the charge. We'll see what they uncover. I'm not going to speculate at this point.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering your statements about the necessity of addressing both Afghanistan and Pakistan, why has Pakistan's contribution to resolving the conflict been largely overlooked at this summit? Did your conversations with President Zardari result in any advancement regarding the reopening of supply routes? And if the broader issues with Pakistan are not resolved, will NATO's achievements in Afghanistan be at risk? [SEP] Well, my discussion with President Zardari was brief, but I reiterated our public and private stance: Pakistan is part of the solution in Afghanistan. A democratic, prosperous, and stable Pakistan is in our national interest. We share a common enemy in extremists in both countries, and we must address the tensions arising from our decade-long military presence. President Zardari believes these issues can be resolved. We didn't expect the supply line issue to be resolved here, but we're making progress. Everyone in the alliance and Afghanistan understands that security, stability, and prosperity require resolving these issues and joining the international community to prevent extremism. There are real challenges and tensions between ISAF, the US, and Pakistan, but they are being addressed through military and diplomatic channels. Ultimately, a successful, stable Pakistan is in our interest, and it's in Pakistan's interest to work with us to prevent extremism. We're committed to this, and every NATO/ISAF member is too.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, what distinctions do you see between the current situation in Iraq and a full-blown civil war? And are you concerned that labeling it as a civil war would undermine the argument that we're fighting the central front of the war on terror there? [SEP] The reality is that Zarqawi's strategy was to instigate sectarian violence. The Samarra bombing last winter was a clear attempt to fuel that violence, and unfortunately, it succeeded. The recent bombings are a continuation of that effort. So, we've been dealing with this phase for some time now. Our primary goal is to collaborate with the Iraqis to create an environment where the majority of the population can see a peaceful path forward. The recent bombings are part of a pattern that has persisted for about nine months. I plan to discuss this issue with Prime Minister Maliki when I meet him in Jordan on Thursday. I will ask him directly: What do we need to do to achieve success? What is your strategy for addressing the sectarian violence? I will assure him of our continued commitment to pursuing Al Qaeda and preventing them from establishing a safe haven in Iraq. I will also inquire about what is required and what his strategy is for Iraq to become a self-governing and self-sustaining nation. This will be an important meeting, and I am looking forward to it.
label: Dodging

sentence: Given the recent declaration from North Korea regarding their nuclear programs, which notably omits any mention of existing nuclear weapons, does the White House consider this declaration satisfactory? Furthermore, following the decision to remove North Korea from the list of state sponsors of terrorism, what leverage remains for the United States to ensure progress on the abduction issue, a matter of grave concern to Japan? [SEP] Let's be clear: North Korea remains under the heaviest sanctions of any nation globally, and that will not change. The only path to lifting those sanctions is through verifiable adherence to their commitments. The idea that delisting somehow nullifies these sanctions is simply inaccurate. We are operating on an action-for-action basis. The destruction of the cooling tower was a verifiable step forward, a positive sign. However, we have other serious concerns, including the abduction issue. Progress on the nuclear front cannot come at the expense of addressing these other critical issues. We need good-faith negotiations to achieve progress on all fronts, for the benefit of Japan and for North Korea itself.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, with June marking the deadliest month for American soldiers in Afghanistan since the war's onset, is Afghanistan now the main battleground in the war on terror, eclipsing Iraq? Are Al Qaeda and the Taliban gaining ground? And is there a possibility of deploying more U.S. troops sooner than the previously stated 2009 timeframe? [SEP] Look, any time we lose a soldier, anywhere, it's heartbreaking, and our thoughts are with their families. We're incredibly thankful for the Americans who step up and risk their lives. Now, June was tough in Afghanistan, but it was also tough for the Taliban. One reason we've seen more deaths is because our troops are taking the fight to a tough enemy. They don't want us there because they don't want America denying them a safe place to hide. We're pushing an idea that's the opposite of theirs, so of course there's going to be resistance.
